HEADLINE: Democrats Meet To Plot Strategy For '92 Election

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL ,Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIDDLEBURG, Va., June 14

 BODY:
Several of the Democratic Party's most likely Presidential hopefuls retreated to an estate in the exclusive hunt country here today to begin plotting how they might wrest the White House from the Republicans in 1992.
Although the overnight meeting included 21 of the party's most reliable contributors, and although some promises were made, Democratic party officials said afterward that it was less a fund-raising event than a strategy meeting intended to give Democrats an "early start." 
 "It is clear to us that President Bush is very vulnerable in 1992, because this Administration has absolutely no domestic agenda," said the Democratic National Committee's chairman, Ronald H. Brown.
 
One Declared, Several Maybes
 The meeting, held at the home of Pamela Harriman, a Democratic fund-raiser and activist, about an hour west of Washington, drew the party's one declared candidate, Paul E. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts Senator, and a number of possible candidates for 1992 or 1996: Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas; Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey; Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas; Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the Speaker of the House; Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader; Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa; Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska; George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, and Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, all of whom are considered possible candidates, were invited to today's meeting but said they could not attend.
Mr. Brown and others emerged from the meeting to say that they had arrived at a "preliminary strategy" and that they had agreed that Democrats should put aside intraparty rivalries and focus on organizing for the general election rather than for the primaries. They declined to give details of their new post-primary strategy.
The party's last Presidential nominee, Michael S. Dukakis, the former Massachusetts Governor, suffered in 1988, several of those present said, because there was no organized effort in place to carry his candidacy out of the Atlanta convention.
"There was not in place a coordinated campaign strategy post-convention," said Steve Grossman, who was co-chairman of Mr. Dukakis's finance committee and is the co-chairman of the new fund-raising effort, called the Democrats' Victory Campaign '92. "You can't decide on a national strategy when the Republicans were planning Willie Horton, the Pledge of Allegiance and Boston Harbor 12 to 18 months before."
Party leaders have said they hope to at least match their 1988 fund raising but they would not disclose any goal that has been set. The Democrats raised about $50 million for the 1988 general election campaign, in addition to the $46.1 million provided by the Federal Government.
 
Looking at Opinion Polls
 The Democrats have also taken heart from recent public and private polls that show a significant disparity between the numbers of Americans who say they approve of President Bush's overall performance, especially on foreign policy, and those who say they are content with the nation's domestic health.
In a New York Times/CBS News Poll conducted last week, 75 percent of those surveyed said they approved of the way Mr. Bush was handling his job. But 57 percent said they thought the economy was fairly bad or very bad.
Mr. Clinton said party leaders hoped to seize on these perceived weaknesses in Mr. Bush's armor of popularity to regain the White House. He said they must capitalize on working people's concerns about health care, the economy and education.
"They're worried that their schools aren't very good and when they get out of them they won't be able to afford to send them to college," Mr. Clinton said.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 19, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption on Saturday about a meeting of Democratic leaders to plan 1992 campaign strategy misidentified the man who was third from the left and omitted the identity of the woman. He was Robert Farmer, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee; she was Pamela Harriman, at whose home the meeting was held.

HEADLINE: Pressed Lawmakers Report Sharp Declines in Speaking Fees

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Under attack for their ties to special interests, members of the House and Senate reported significant declines in the speaking fees they accepted last year from corporations and other groups affected by legislation.
The annual disclosure reports made public today showed that in 1990, the last year that House members legally permitted themselves to take speaking fees, they collected a total of $5.6 million, a computer-aided analysis by The New York Times shows. That is a decline of close to $1 million, or nearly 13 percent, from the previous year. 
 Sixty-four senators accepted $2 million last year in payments for speaking engagements. That, too, was a dip from 1989, when senators took in more than $2.7 million, a drop of about 25 percent.
 
Increasing Sensitivity
 After years of escalating payments of speaking fees, the decline last year occurred in part because more members have become increasingly sensitive about ethical questions that could be raised and have refused the payments. Some who did take the fees were more careful about the number of appearances they made and what groups they appeared before.
The decline could also be due in part to the weakened economy last year, with organizations trimming appearance fees from their budgets.
"That's a substantial decline," said David B. Magleby, a professor at Brigham Young University who specializes in campaign finance. "A lot of members had grown accustomed to the fees. For it to have declined that much means that there must have been a sense that this was less and less acceptable. Everybody's a little squeamish."
In a largely symbolic vote, members of the Senate went on record last month to join the House and ban outside fees, predominantly for speaking and to a small degree for writing.
 
Fees and Donations
 In 1990 House members could keep up to $26,850 in speaking fees -- 30 percent of their Congressional salaries for the previous year -- and had to donate any amount received above that to charity, for which they can take a tax deduction. Senators could keep 27 percent of their annual pay, or $27,300 for most members. Some lawmakers donated the fees to charity even when they did not have to.
The documents also show that the most influential members were the most successful in supplementing their incomes with outside fees.
Senator Ernest F. Hollings, a South Carolina Democrat who is chairman of the Commerce Committee, led the Senate in speaking fees, taking in $82,200. He had to give away $55,212 to charity, and he did. Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the Republican whip, ranked second, accepting $78,900 and giving $51,967 to charity.
Third was Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, who was paid $78,100 for 43 speeches and three newspaper articles and kept $30,400. George J. Mitchell, the Senate Democratic leader, accepted $40,000 for 20 speeches and gave $10,000 of it to charity. As leaders, Mr. Mitchell's and Mr. Dole's salaries are higher than those of other members and therefore their speaking fee limits were also higher.
 
Rostenkowski Far Ahead
 Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, continued his tradition of drawing by far the most in speaking fees. He accepted $309,850 from 66 groups, and then gave $283,000 to charity.
Those paying Mr. Rostenkowski included the Harry Walker Agency, $12,000; Public Securities Association, $7,500; Health Insurance Association of America, $7,500; National Soft Drink Association, $7,500, and National Association of Broadcasters, $5,500.
A distant second was Representative Patricia Schroeder, a Colorado Democrat who is a leading spokeswoman on womens' issues and who considered running for President in 1988. She earned $157,696 in fees and donated $131,280 to charity. The House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, took in $30,000, while Robert H. Michel, the House Republican leader, accepted $56,650 and donated $27,650.
When they pass speaking fees on to charity, members can generate good will in their districts through those donations.
"Most of it goes to charities in my district," Ms. Schroeder said of the fees she earned. "We have a Pat Schroeder scholarship for displaced homemakers at the University of Colorado. I give money to some of the universities and Planned Parenthood and child care and all sorts of things."
Senators this year receive an annual salary of $101,900, while representatives get $125,100.
 
Many Trips Accepted
 Beginning this year, House members got a pay rise in return for forsaking speaking fees, though they continue to accept expense-paid trips from interest groups. The 1990 disclosure reports were full of examples of members' accepting trips both to tropical vacation spots and to places where they could learn something.
Several members cited a charity golf tournament at the Greenbrier, a Virginia resort, while others reported that the German Marshall Plan Foundation had brought them to Germany for a week of "fact-finding."
The Aspen Institute, a private group that sponsored many lawmakers' trips, paid for a six-day trip for Representative Constance A. Morella, Republican of Maryland, to travel to Bermuda for a conference on Southern Africa. Shorter, less exotic trips were more common, like Dean Witter paying Representative Mike Synar, an Oklahoma Democrat, air fare from Washington to New York to give a speech.
Some members were particularly sensitive about their finances, to the point of reporting gifts under $100 that do not have to be disclosed. Representative Alex McMillan, a North Carolina Republican, attached a six-page list of gifts to his report, including four almond crescent cookies, a dozen heart-shaped sugar cookies and a banana valued at 25 cents from a group called "People Protecting Primates." Representative Jolene Unsoeld, a Washington Democrat, reported receiving a $5 surgical shirt from the Service Employees Union and $10 worth of pistachio nuts from the Paralyzed Veterans of America.
 
Special Effort by Riegle
 One senator who was especially forthcoming in his disclosure report was Donald W. Riegle Jr., a Michigan Democrat. Earlier this year, Mr. Riegle was given only a a mild sanction from the Senate Ethics Committee for his efforts to help Charles H. Keating Jr., a major contributor who operated a troubled savings and loan institution.
In his report, Mr. Riegle noted that it "provides specific detail beyond that required under Senate disclosure rules." The report also said that Mr. Riegle's "net worth figure includes items normally omitted by members." For example, the Senator listed the exact value of his home in McLean, Va. -- at $272,500 -- though he was only required to place its value in a general range.
Many more lawmakers chose not to take speaking fees last year. According to a tally by Common Cause, a group that lobbies for tightening ethics rules, 39 senators no longer accept the fees for personal use, an increase of eight over last year. The House disclosure forms made public today showed that 292 of the 435 members took speaking fees in 1990. But several more may have accepted fees; 21 members have been granted extensions on filing their disclosure reports.
Dozens of members said they received from General Motors free videotaped copies of the public television program, "The Civil War." But there were wide variations as to how much the videos were worth, with member estimates ranging from $120 to $395.

MOSBACHER ACCEPTED TRIPS
 WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher accepted plane trips to Europe and the Caribbean and a cruise on the Queen Elizabeth II from an investor, a business group and others last year, according to his financial disclosure statement released today.
Mr. Mosbacher and his wife, Georgette, sailed on the British luxury liner last October from New York to Tangiers, Morocco, and Southampton, England, the statement shows. The five-day trip, valued at $5,500, was paid for by the Young Presidents' Organization, a business group based in Irving, Tex.
Both Mosbachers spoke at seminars during the cruise, which was part of the group's university education program, said Elaine Vitt, spokeswoman for the group.
It is legal for Mr. Mosbacher and his wife to accept the trips, but some critics contend they should not.
"It is inappropriate for public officials to travel at the expense of private interests, and particularly private interests that have business before those officials," said David Eppler, a lawyer for the consumer advocacy group Public Citizen.

HEADLINE: Burned Out in Bergenfield

BYLINE: By Samuel G. Freedman; Samuel G. Freedman is the author of "Small Victories: The Real World of a Teacher, Her Students and Their High School," which was a finalist for the 1990 National Book Award for nonfiction.

 BODY:

TEENAGE WASTELAND
Suburbia's Dead End Kids.
By Donna Gaines.
262 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $23.  
 When four teen-agers committed collective suicide in the blue-collar suburb of Bergenfield, N.J., in March 1987, Donna Gaines responded with both sorrow and memory. Ms. Gaines, a sociologist and journalist who writes for The Village Voice, had worked as a "street counselor" for troubled adolescents on Long Island. And, more important, she had grown up amid drugs and anomie nearly 20 years earlier, and had seen friends wind up addicted, in detoxification centers or dead.
She brought her academic credentials and her human empathy to Bergenfield, less to unravel the reason four young people deliberately locked themselves inside a garage with their car running than to understand and illuminate the broader culture of the people she calls "burnouts." She sees in them a certain rebellious dignity, a disdain for the hypocrisy they perceive in school and family. Their allegiances belong only to one another and to the heavy metal bands, like Metallica, that articulate their despair.
It is Ms. Gaines's provocative thesis that in postindustrial America these working-class children are denied the real or metaphorical mobility that could liberate them from their limited lives. The wanderlust and social experiments of the 1960's, which the author credits with rescuing her from desperation, were no longer options once the guns-and-butter economy that undergirded them slid into recession. The boom of the 1980's saw a decline in meaningful and remunerative work for high school graduates, leaving little besides fast-food and gas station jobs. Drug abuse, alcoholism and even suicide, Ms. Gaines argues, are the symptoms of a larger cultural and economic disease.
"In the scheme of things," she writes, "average American kids who don't have rich or well-connected parents have had these choices: Play the game and try to get ahead. Do what your parents did -- work yourself to death at a menial job and find solace in beer, God, or family. Or take risks, cut deals, or break the law. The Reagan years made it hard for kids to 'put their noses to the grindstone' as their parents had. Like everyone, these people hoped for better lives. But they lived in an age of inflated expectations and diminishing returns. Big and fast money was everywhere, and ever out of reach. America now had an economy that worked sort of like a cocaine high -- propped up by hot air and big debt. The substance was absent. People's lives were like that too, and at times they were crashing hard."
There is wisdom and pathos in such words; in her way, Ms. Gaines is writing about the sons and daughters of the characters in Russell Banks and Raymond Carver's fiction. She wants to bring alive these children -- girls clinging to fantasies of happy marriage, boys dreaming of rock-and-roll stardom, all of them endlessly cruising Bergenfield's main street in search of some cathartic party.
The problem is that Ms. Gaines spends too much prose establishing her own burnout credentials and not enough letting her subjects tell their own stories. She misses no chance to show off her knowledge of rock-and-roll, taking the book's title, "Teenage Wasteland," from the chorus in the Who's anthem "Baba O'Reilly," and managing in the acknowledgments alone to drop the names of Lou Reed and Led Zeppelin. Countless times during the narrative she depicts herself trading heavy metal tapes with the Bergenfield boys and swapping makeup tips with their girlfriends. Yet when a boy awkwardly (and to my mind understandably) propositions her, she declares, "This move is really off the wall." His confusion about her motives says something larger about the confusion that hobbles this book and leaves its promise terribly unfulfilled: does Ms. Gaines want to understand Bergenfield's burnouts, or to be one of them?
Her inconsistent position extends to the prose itself. At times, Ms. Gaines writes with great common sense and a welcome contempt for child-development jargon. Her analysis of the special education system into which her subjects periodically disappear is particularly withering, while her respectful portraits of vocational education teachers and even military recruiters demonstrate an open mind at work. All too often, however, she describes Bergenfield and its teen-agers with a faux hip tone that strikes me as an unintentional kind of slumming. Consider one typical example: "A group of about seven teenagers are sitting around a truck in front of the 7-Eleven. Burnouts. I know from the pose, the clothes, the turf. Yep, in another age they'd be hitters or greasers or hippies or heads or freaks. On another coast -- they'd be stoners. Archenemies of jocks, dexters, rah-rahs, or socs for all eternity."
A powerful book dwells within this manuscript, and the tragedy is that neither Ms. Gaines nor her editor could extract it from the surrounding self-indulgence. In trying to make us care for these easily scorned youths, the author makes her presence and her actions so central to the text that at its end only she -- the outsider, the interloper -- emerges as an affecting three-dimensional character.

HEADLINE: Postings: Bigger Plans on Hold;
Range With a River View

 BODY:
Ten years ago, Arthur E. Imperatore bought a 350-acre strip of property along the New Jersey waterfront for $7.5 million from the liquidators of Penn Central holdings. At the time, he thought that his plans for Port Imperial, the new city he wants to build there, would be well beyond the blueprint stage by now, but the recession and other problems upset the timetable.
Undiscouraged, the onetime truck driver and now head of A-P-A Transport Corporation of North Bergen, has put a portion of his dormant riverfront land to use by opening the Port Imperial golf driving range and minature golf course. The property is in Weehawken, at the foot of the Palisades between Boulevard East and Pershing Road. 
 "I thought it would be a good conditional use of the property," said Mr. Imperatore, who still hopes to develop up to 1,200 units of housing and 9 million square feet of commercial space on his tract on the west bank of the Hudson. "Building the new range was a way of beautifying the property and at the same time gives golf enthusiasts a chance to polish their swings."
Open since May 25, the driving range and miniature course cover approximately 13 acres. The range has 45 tee stations -- 20 of which are enclosed for year-round use -- and the miniature course has 18 holes. The complex is open every day, with a bucket of 75 balls priced at $7, a bucket of 45 at $4, and no charge for the use of a golf club. Miniature golf is $5 for adults, $3.50 for children.
Plans call for a pro shop and snack bar to open later this summer. In addition to the golf range, Port Imperial also has a restaurant and 300-slip marina. Mr. Imperatore operates a ferry service between West 35th Street in Manhattan and Weehawken.

HEADLINE: Postings: Rehabilitation Struggle;
At Last, Open for Tenants

 BODY:
New York stories are often about small victories over long odds. Such a story had a happy ending in the Bronx last Tuesday when the Castle, a renovated 223-unit, seven-building complex of Tudor-style apartments at 1950 Andrews Avenue, opened for tenants after years of struggle over the management of the Federal housing rehabilitation grant that helped pay for the project.
The Castle was originally foreclosed by the city for nonpayment of taxes during the recession of the mid-70's. In the following years, a struggle dragged on between community groups and the Department of Housing Preservation and Development over ownership of the building. A group of housing activists claimed they held the mortgage on the property, while the city insisted that foreclosure was final, and picked Sydney Engel, of Lynbrook, L.I., for a gut rehabilitation. 
 The squabble delayed and almost derailed a $3.8 million rehabilitation grant under the Federal Housing Development Action Grant program the city had obtained. In the end the city won out, and lent Mr. Engel $12.7 million for the $20 million project, along with a $1.4 million grant.
In exchange for the subsidy, Mr. Engel agreed to reserve 20 percent of the apartments for low-income families, and the rest will be rented to families of moderate means.
Rents for the one-, two- and three-bedroom apartments range from $320 to $603 a month for low-income tenants, and from $536 to $736 for moderate-income families.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Metrotech;
How Developers and City Hall Retain Big Tenants

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
TWO months ago, executives at Forest City Ratner Companies were getting nervous. Unaccustomed to big vacancies in their developments, they had a 23-story tower nearing completion at Metrotech Center in downtown Brooklyn with some 390,000 square feet yet to be leased.
"We were looking at 50,000- to 100,000-square-foot tenants," said Paul A. Travis, chief operating officer of Forest City Ratner, in Manhattan. "We thought eventually that we'd lease that space to several financial-service companies. The question was how long 'eventually' was going to be." 
 Meanwhile, not far away, executives at Bear, Stearns & Company, the financial concern, were contemplating a move of 1,500 employees from Manhattan to Jersey City or -- more likely -- Whippany, N.J., where the company owns a 55-acre site and already has data processing and other operations.
"The lease at 2 Broadway was up in three years," said James K. Lang, managing director of Bear Stearns, whose headquarters are in 245 Park Avenue, at 46th Street. "We knew that if we had to start re-educating people, now was the time to do it. The direction we were heading in was Whippany."
Then, early in May, Bruce Ratner, the president of Forest City Ratner, sent an 18- by-18-inch model of Metrotech Center to Alan C. Greenberg, chairman and chief executive of Bear Stearns.
"That was a very smart marketing move," said Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development.
Evidently.
One month later, the parties joined with Mayor David N. Dinkins at City Hall to announce that Bear Sterns would move 1,500 employees in its securities processing department -- not to New Jersey, but to 250,000 square feet in One Metrotech Center, on Jay Street, near Willoughby Street.
"It's great for Bear Stearns," Mr. Ratner said, "it's obviously super for the city, and I'm not complaining either."
The lease runs 12 years, with a 5-year option. Neither tenant nor landlord will discuss the rent. Known until recently as the BUG Building -- after its major tenant, Brooklyn Union Gas -- One Metrotech Center is to open in September. Bear Stearns will begin its move there in June 1992.
The fact that Forest City Ratner had the space in hand was critical. So was the swiftness with which the Dinkins administration put together discretionary tax benefits and energy savings. So too was the fact that 57 percent of the Bear Stearns workforce lived in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island. And then there was Metrotech itself.
"By the time we move here next June," Mr. Lang said, "we believe the infrastructure is going to be a knockout. Whatever the preconceived notions are about downtown Brooklyn will disappear."
Metrotech is moving even more quickly than its developers had anticipated. Two Metrotech Center opened last year. The two buildings that compose the Chase Financial Services Center are well under construction. To the north, Polytechnic University, Forest City Ratner's partner in Metrotech, is completing its Center for Advanced Technology in Telecommunications and Dibner Library of Technology and Science.
All told, Metrotech now comprises 11 existing or prospective buildings on an irregular site bounded by Willoughby, Jay and Tillary Streets and Flatbush Avenue Extension. Several blocks away, at Fulton Street and Hudson Avenue, is another building that carries a Metrotech designation.
Mr. Ratner conceded that it was not unlike the tendency in Manhattan to spread a prestigious address around, such as 237 Park Avenue, which is actually on Lexington.
The size of Metrotech was a point Forest City Ratner wanted to make with the model it sent to Mr. Greenberg. "The message we were trying to get across," Mr. Travis said, "was that there is a whole complex here, not just a block of space."
Mr. Greenberg's initial reaction to the model, as Mr. Lang tells it, was, "Get this thing out of here." But the company invited Forest City Ratner to pursue its case. "When they came to our office," Mr. Lang recalled, "we said: 'Here's our spread sheet on Whippany. Meet these numbers or beat them.' "
A number of general incentives were already in place, among them:
*A 13-year exemption from real-estate taxes on the new building, after which taxes are phased in over 10 years. These savings are passed from developer to tenant.
*A 12-year elimination of the commercial rent tax, a direct benefit to the tenant.
*A 12-year corporate tax credit of $500 a year for every employee moved to Brooklyn.
But that was not yet enough.
"The only way we would go to Brooklyn -- because we figured that Brooklyn and Jersey City were roughly equal -- was if the city would do more," Mr. Lang said. James E. Cayne, president of Bear Stearns, met with the Deputy Mayor. As Mr. Lang told it, his message was: "We need relief at 245 Park or the Metrotech deal won't work. You're killing us with the real-estate taxes."
The company was startled by City Hall's quick response. "They were terrifically cooperative," Mr. Lang said. "The city bent over backward to give us some concessions."
"The challenge for us," Deputy Mayor Hernandez-Pinero said, "was to confront the attitude that said, 'Once you leave Manhattan, it doesn't matter where you go.' From our perspective, there is a world of difference between going to downtown Brooklyn and going to Whippany."
"The bulk of the benefits they're going to receive are as-of-right incentives, so we didn't do anything extraordinary," she said. "We've added a couple of discretionary items, neither of which has a direct impact on our operating budget."
One of these was an exemption on sales taxes for items with a useful life longer than a year, such as computers and communication equipment. The other was the provision of lower-cost New York Power Authority electricity to Bear Stearns headquarters.
Given the discretionary benefits, whose value Mr. Lang put at about $17 million, he said "the deal was better for the first 12 years in Brooklyn than in Whippany."
Whippany still had economic advantages in the longer run, but Bear Stearns was concerned about losing employees in a move almost 25 miles west of the city. This was particularly true since 30 percent of the workers live in Brooklyn.
"We felt a little trepidation about moving our people that far away," Mr. Lang said, although an earlier move of some 200 workers went smoothly. "We never put in the numbers on how much it would cost to replace employees, but theoretically, the farther you move out, the higher it gets."
Bear Stearns is vacating a total of 285,000 square feet in Manhattan -- 185,000 square feet in 2 Broadway, at Bowling Green; 65,000 at 866 First Avenue, between 48th and 49th Streets, and 35,000 at 245 Park Avenue.
If there is a big loser, it may be the Reichmann family of Toronto, whose Olympia & York concern owns 2 Broadway and 245 Park Avenue. "They tried very hard to effect a deal with us," Mr. Lang said. "They gave us a very favorable proposal, but over the long haul, the economics were far more favorable moving to Brooklyn." Through a spokesman, Olympia & York said it expects to re-lease the Bear Stearns space by 1994.

HEADLINE: Talking: Contractors;
Resolving Disputes Over Work

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
ONE of the greatest fears of a homeowner about to have renovations done is a dispute with the contractor before the job is complete. There is a sense of vulnerability when walls are down, plumbing lines disrupted or windows removed.
 Fortunately, a greater acknowledgement of this problem by public officials and industry professionals is leading to speedier and more effective resolution programs. In addition, the recession is persuading more contractors to accept voluntary resolution methods that might have been spurned in the boom years of the 80's. "In these difficult times they need reconciliation," said Dave Rosehill, former chairman of the mediation committee of the New York-Long Island chapter of the National Asssociation of the Remodeling Industry. "They need to keep the good name that leads to referrals." 
 A contractor who would have refused a job because a homeowner insisted on an abitration or mediation clause in the contract now might be accept that clause because he is more anxious to get work.
 As a start, the homeowner should insist, before work begins, on some form of binding method of resolving disputes. "If something happens, you will be in a much stronger position," said William Barbera, a real estate lawyer in Pelham, N.Y.
 The clause could require the parties to submit their differences to the American Arbitration Association. This can usually result in a hearing within three weeks and a decision no longer than 30 days afterwards, said Robert Meade, vice president of program development for the association, which is based in New York City.
 Or the two sides could agree to resolve their differences through a more informal type of mediation. If so, the details should be spelled out before the job begins, say lawyers, because it can be difficult to reach agreement once a dispute has erupted.
The parties could agree to find another contractor or building consultant acceptable to both sides to review the situation and suggest a solution. Or they could agree to abide by the determination of an objective third party with suitable expertise. For example, Tauscher Cronacher, professional engineers in Rockville Centre, L.I., will provide what they call a "defects and deficiencies" report for about $400 -- a document also useful when facing arbitration or litigation. Some home inspectors do similar consulting work.
 Assuming, however, that the contract is silent regarding disputes -- or there was no contract at all -- the homeowner is still left with some options. In most instances, lawyers advise, legal action should be a last resort becaue fees can be high and there may be long delays in getting cases tried. "You may wait three years for a trial date if the amount is over $3,000," warned Mr. Barbera.
Instead, the homeowner should turn speedily to the contractor's professional association or the agency that issues his license -- if licensing is required in the area -- or both.
The likelihood of professional affiliation is increasing as more contractors join these groups to enhance their credibility. The National Remodelers Council, which began in 1962 as a division of the National Association of Home Builders, has doubled the number of local chapters, to over 100, in the last six years. Typically, members must comply with the findings of local mediation committees as a prerequisite to continued membership. Mr. Rosehill said that his chapter receives about two complaints a month.
Action is normally begun within two weeks of the receipt of a written complaint, "sooner if it's something serious like a leak," he said. He said he first makes a friendly fact-finding telephone call to each side and visits the site, if needed.
Last summer, a homeowner complained that repeated requests to the contractor about constant condensation on newly installed replacement windows got nowhere. Mr. Rosehill soon discovered that the contractor had placed the matter in the hands of his supplier without bothering to find out why the supplier had failed to notify the window manufacturer, who should have sent a representative.
 Mr. Rosehill made sure this was done. The representative soon discovered that the windows were neither faulty nor improperly installed. Rather, the homeowner had been running an air-conditioner at a setting so high that it had created condensation. A lower setting corrected the problem.
 Notifying the contractor's licensing office is equally powerful since the contractor could lose his right to continue in business if he fails to cooperate with an inquiry. The office can also be the source of information about possible reimbursement should there be no likelihood of the contractor's ever making good.
 Kenneth Rudnick, a hair stylist with a home in Huntington Station, L.I., found this out after contacting the Suffolk County Department of Consumer Affairs when his licensed contractor vanished, leaving an exterior renovation half done.
 Since it soon became apparent that the contractor would never return, Mr. Rudnick found himself eligible for $2,000 from a "restitution fund" established three years ago from licensing proceeds for just such a case. Although it was a year before he got the money, it has given him enough cash, he said, to pay someone else to finish the job.
Sixty-four other homeowners have been paid from the same fund, said Jane Devine, the Commissioner.
The idea of such a fund is now spreading to other counties and states, among them Maryland, Virginia and Hawaii.
 If an architect has been retained the homeowner should never confront the contractor directly. Rather, the architect should be used as the mediator, said John Alvarez, vice president of the Connecticut Society of Architects.
"It takes the emotional layer out of the argument and allows the architect to speak as one professional to another," he said.
 Mr. Alvarez told of a recent incident in which an homeower was angry with a contractor because the finish on a floor that had just been hand-stenciled by an artist had started to streak. The architect first researched the problem to see who was at fault and why. He found it was, indeed, the contractor, and he was able to pursuade him to redo the floor by showing him through a technical analysis why his initial attempt had gone awry.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
A New Neighbor for the Maritime Center

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
RATTLED by the recession, two historic districts in South Norwalk are expected to draw strength from the restoration of a turn-of-the-century red-brick building next door to the debt-ridden Maritime Center on North Water Street.
But while city officials believe that converting the 22,000-square-foot structure into restaurants and shops is best for the area, several merchants and restaurateurs on the adjacent, one-block Washington Street Historic District are concerned about the competition. 
 "The project serves our goal of creating a human-scale, attractive environment," said Jack Burritt, director of the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency, which controls the area. "More shops and restaurants will bring about a critical mass that the specialized boutiques and bistros on Washington Street do not."
 With its blind, boarded-up facade at a right angle to the Maritime Center entrance, the city-owned building that formerly housed offices of the Hatch & Bailey Lumber Company has been an eyesore to the 460,000 people who in the last year patronized the center, with its shark tanks, IMAX Theater and boat-building and marine-life exhibits.
 Last month, Orb Management Ltd., a 20-year-old Manhattan company experienced in conversions, was designated by the Norwalk Common Council to redevelop the building with the help of the Manhattan architectural firm of Beyer Blinder Belle. Their proposal calls for two 5,000-square-foot indoor-outdoor restaurants, with the remaining space devoted to shops and offices.
 Orb is negotiating with the Redevelopment Agency on details of the $3 million project, which will eventually need approval by the Common Council and the city's planning and environmental agencies. An opening is anticipated in mid-1992.
 Because of its large financial commitment to the Maritime Center, which is in the Reed-Putnam Historic District, the city has taken a profound interest in the area. Since it opened in 1988, the center, converted from an old factory, has been unable to meet the payments on two bond issues of $23 million and $7 million, floated in 1986 and due in 2015 and 1996, respectively.
The city has been paying $3 million a year on the debt, to the consternation of Norwalk taxpayers, plus an additional $363,000 in 1990 toward operating expenses. Grants of $2.1 million from the state have also been applied to the debt.
 Last November, Peter Marnane became the center's new director, initiating features that included an automated dinosaur exhibit, concerts and lectures by celebrated naturalists.
Revenues have improved, and he said he is optimistic that "this will be the first year that we will be able to cover our operating costs of almost $6 million."
 With its excursion-boat dock and picturesque location at the mouth of the Norwalk River, the Maritime Center was expected to attract crowds that would spill over to the businesses around the corner on Washington Street.
"That has not happened," said William Elmore, proprietor of the Rialto restaurant. "We get very little traffic from the center. This started out trying to be a South Street Seaport, but the center wasn't received that well and until they make it less educational and more entertaining, people just walk through once and never come back."
 "There must be a better bonding between the city and the SoNo area," said Ralph Bloom, curator of the Norwalk Heritage Museum on East Avenue. "For example, there are no public rest rooms without paying $5 admission to the Maritime Center."
His museum was rejected by the city as a potential tenant for the Hatch & Bailey conversion.
 The Museum of Cartoon Art in Rye Brook, N.Y., also made an unsuccessful bid for tenancy, as did the Maritime Center itself. "The city was concerned about our poor financial record," Mr. Marnane explained. "Now Orb Management will make the money on food service and gift shops that we had hoped to make."
 Russell Cooper, head of the new SoNo Business Association and a third-generation store owner on Washington Street, believes that "negative opinions about the Hatch & Bailey proposal are coming from people whose businesses are in trouble anyway." Last year, he switched his 56-year-old tuxedo rental store to trendy children's wear.
"Business improved by 40 percent," Mr. Cooper recalled. "You have to stock what the customer wants."
WASHINGTON STREET was developed in the early 80's by the Collins Development Corporation of Stamford with Federal funds. Collins still owns most of the stores, and Arthur Collins, company president, said he is "very concerned."
"A greater variety of shops and restaurants will bring more people," he said.
 He has tried to stem a rising tide of vacancies by "forgiving" some of his tenants overdue rents, rather than reducing rents. Leases remain at around $15 a square foot, according to Dwight Collins, his son and a vice-president of the company.
 La Provence, Sweptaway, Donovan's, Pasta Nostra, and other popular restaurants are doing less business than a year ago, whether dinner prices for two are $40 or $20. Souvlaki, a Greek restaurant, will soon open in one of four vacant stores. There is a total of 30 retail spaces.
 Sassafras, a gift shop with a Victorian flavor, attracts a stream of browsers, and John Deorio, the owner, is worried about the Maritime Center's influence.
"They get a lot of schoolchildren, not the type of customer I need," he said. "They should have an aggressive schedule of entertainment to attract a 25-and-up age group with disposable income. To assume that more families flocking to the Maritime Center will make us fly is a fallacy."
 While the new project is a lightning rod for everyone's frustrations in the district, it is also the only one moving forward. Plans announced last year by Katz Realty for converting the old City Hall into a Maritime Inn on Main Street are moribund. A major mixed-use renovation to the Lock Building factory across the street from the center is "on the back burner," said Michael diScala, the developer. And the railroad station three blocks away, approved by the city for a $100 million, mixed-use redevelopment by the Starrett Company of Manhattan, is "not near the starting line," according to Richard Bassuk, company president.
 Susan Hewitt, a partner at Orb Management and project manager for the Norwalk undertaking, said: "Washington Street and the Maritime Center area need to regard themselves as part of the same economic unit. We want to collaborate with them to help bring that about."

HEADLINE: BROADWAY;
Great White Way Still Shimmers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Tony Awards held last Sunday highlighted one of New York's continuing success stories: Broadway is and has always been a beacon for actors, writers, producers, directors, musicians and dancers from all over the world. While in a given year any individual, including the Times critic Frank Rich, may judge the lights on Broadway to be "dimmer" or "brighter" ["The Great Dark Way: Slowly, the Lights Are Dimming on Broadway," June 2], it's well to remember that the marquees always shine more brilliantly here than anywhere else. 
 Broadway, Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway are not competitors, as Mr. Rich implies in skewering this year's crop of Tony nominees. Rather, they complement and reinforce one another, making the entire New York theater experience that much richer. Shows like "A Chorus Line," "Ain't Misbehavin' " and "Once on This Island," which moved from Off Broadway to Broadway, illustrate this interrelationship.
Theater is a dynamic industry that has a $1.5 billion impact on our local economy annually. More tourists come to New York to see plays and musicals than for any other single reason. And theater is part of why individuals, businesses and even industries choose to locate here permanently. The city's recognition of the history and magic of New York's theaters has led us to protect them by landmarking more than 40 playhouses and stages.
New York theater has had its ups and downs and is currently operating in the same tough financial climate that we are all experiencing. But our theater is a valuable treasure and a unique cultural and economic resource. We in the city administration believe applause and curtain calls are in order.
 
BARBARA J. FIFE
Deputy Mayor,
The City of New York

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

JURIED ART SHOW
 The Mamaroneck Artists Guild will open its 35th National Open Juried Exhibition on Friday at Westchester Community College in Valhalla. While the guild's new quarters at 2120 Boston Post Road have more exhibition space than the old gallery on Larchmont Avenue, there is still not enough room for the 248 works in the show. Paintings and sculpture in all media, fiber, jewelry and ceramics by artists from Florida to Alaska will be judged for 29 awards of $50 to $300.
 Two receptions are to be held, one from 6 to 9 P.M. Friday, the other from noon to 3 P.M. when the show closes on June 30. 
 The gallery director, Nan Walsh, said, "We are the oldest nonprofit art cooperative in the county, despite the claims of others." New members are juried into the 350-member organization each year by 17 judges. Out of 90 applicants 10 were accepted in 1990.
 Among the works on view in the Valhalla exhibition are "Cosmos," a photograph by Stan Lapa at $700; "Unfurled," a bronze by Ms. Walsh, at $5,000; "Wasn't Life Peaches and Cream?" a $3,000 collage by Marilyn Cohen; and "Dancer at Rest," a $15,000 bronze by Aaron Spiegelman. Prices start at $75. The show may be seen daily from noon to 5 P.M. Call 834-1117 for more information.
 
RECALLING TOSCANINI
 All you need to get into Tuesday's "Remembering Toscanini" program at Wave Hill in Riverdale is $1 and a few streaks of gray hair. The last of a series of events for the elderly, it will be conducted by Mortimer H. Frank, curator of the Toscanini collection at Wave Hill. "We don't proof people at the door," Mr. Frank said, "but people in their 20's probably would not feel comfortable."
 The program will survey the 17 years, from 1937 to 1954, when Toscanini conducted the NBC Symphony Orchestra. "His performance style, extraordinary talent, and his compulsiveness to push performers to limits that other conductors never dreamed of makes most of them pale in comparison," Mr. Frank said.
 He will show one complete video of a televised concert featuring Wagner's original overture to "Tannhauser" and play a recording of a rehearsal in which Toscanini shows his temper. For the final four years of the conductor's tenure at NBC the concerts were televised and recorded on kinescopes, an early and crude method of preserving picture and sound.
 "But," Mr. Frank said, "the technology was later developed to enhance the picture and transfer it to videotape, and by stripping away the sound track and replacing it with the superb sound transcriptions that were engineered at the time of the concerts, we now have excellent synchronized videos."
 The video and recording will be accompanied by Mr. Frank's commentary on various aspects of the conductor's life and work. The program begins at 1 P.M. For directions to Wave Hill or for more information call (212) 549-3200.
 
GAMES FOR FATHERS
 Father's Day at the Hammond Museum in North Salem will be celebrated today in the Great Hall with continuous games of cribbage, dominoes, chess and other board games. Visitors can come and go as they like, participating or kibitzing from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M.
 The Japanese Stroll Garden will be open for viewing and the Silk Tree Cafe will serve brunch from 11:30 A.M. to 2 P.M. for $17.50 a person. Admission to the museum is $2; children $1. For lunch reservations, call 669-8345; for directions or other information call 669-5033.
 
RIDING REFRESHER
 Adults who would like to polish their horseback riding skills can do so at the Pleasantville campus of Pace University. Two-hour sessions held Monday through Thursday evenings include handling the tack, grooming the horse and ring work with English saddles. The program ends Aug. 15.
 Riders must be able to walk, trot and canter and must sign up for a minimum of four sessions. Schedules will be tailored to meet individual needs on a weekly or daily basis and prices vary from $100 to $625, according to the number of sessions and complexity of workouts.
 Call 773-3788 for more information.
 
JAPANESE TRADE
 Don E. Newquist, commissioner of the United States International Trade Commission in Washington, will talk about "The Japanese Distribution System and Prospects for Improving U.S. Access" at a luncheon meeting of the World Trade Club of Westchester on Wednesday.
 The commission is an independent, bipartisan agency established by Congress to make determinations of injury and threats of injury to American industry by imports. It also analyzes trade data for Congress and the President as a basis for United States trade policy.
 Mr. Newquist will discuss features of the Japanese system that act as barriers to imports and a threat to economic growth in the United States posed by the closed Japanese markets.
A reception will begin at 11:45 followed by lunch at 12:15 at the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza, 66 Hale Avenue in White Plains. Reservations at $40 may be made by calling 948-6444.
 
CELLO AND FOLK SONGS
 Eugene Friesen, a cellist with the Paul Winter Consort for eight years, has taken off on his own, incorporating poetry and scat-singing with his solo acoustic and electric cello. Accompanying him at the Towne Crier in Pawling on Friday at 9:30 P.M. will be Glen Velez, a percussionist and member of the Paul Winter Consort, and Phil Markowitz, a pianist. Admission will be $14.
 At 9:30 P.M. Saturday, the Towne Crier will present Tom Rush, a songwriter and folk singer who has made 15 albums and has filled Carnegie Hall, Symphony Hall in Boston and the Kennedy Center in Washington at recent concerts. Tickets are $17.50.
 The Towne Crier Cafe is at 66 Route 22. Call 855-1300 for reservations or more information.
 
GOLF TOURNAMENT
 Each year the Red Klein Golf Tournament is held in memory of Mr. Klein, a member for decades of the county's Recreation Department. Tee-off time for the more than 80 golfers who turn out for the event will be 7 A.M. Thursday at the Dunwoodie Golf Course in Yonkers.
 Two-man teams (it is an all-male tournament) must sign up in advance for the 18-hole competition. The entrance fee is $11, plus an $11 greens fee. Prizes worth $200 and $300 are contributed by the pro shop. For more information, call 428-0760 or 476-5151.

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory;
Exhibit Honors Blacks' Inventions

 BODY:
"The Real McCoy: African-American Invention and Innovation," an exhibition organized by the Anacostia Museum of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, begins a two-year tour in July, when it starts a three-month stay at the California Afro-American Museum in Los Angeles. The exhibition highlights early creative and scientific achievements by African-American inventors and enterpreneurs.
Artifacts, audiovisual presentations and copies of inventions show the major contributions to America's industrial and technological development. Among the inventions is the McCoy lubricator, which is a device to oil moving locomotives. The inventor, Elijah McCoy, the son of slaves who fled to Canada, put an end to the costly and time-consuming process of stopping a locomotive so it could be oiled. 
 Another inventor was Norbert Rillieux, whose commercial application of vacuum evaporation made the production of refined sugar economically feasible in this country. C. J. Walker, a washerwoman, became the first woman to be a self-made millionaire in America. In 1905, she successfully marketed a product for straightening the hair of black women, which eventually yielded her a business empire with a line of beauty products and cosmetology schools.
The exhibition will be in Los Angeles from July 15 to Oct. 27. Other cities the exhibition will visit include Kansas City, Mo.; Rochester; Fort Worth; Detroit; Tampa, Fla., and Chicago. The tour ends in Columbia, S.C., in July 1993.
Visitors to the exhibition can buy a catalogue of these and the other pioneering achievements of African-Americans. The book, "The Real McCoy: Invention and Innovation, 1619-1930" ($17.50, Smithsonian Institution Press, 1989), was written by the curator of the exhibit, Portia James, a historian at the Anacostia Museum.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Chapman;
Plan to Require Campus Residency Angers Students

DATELINE: ORANGE, Calif.

 BODY:
Despite opposition from its student government and a protest demonstration by students last month, Chapman College will require its noncommuting undergraduates under age 21 to live in campus housing starting in the fall.
Ann Bolger, the director of residential life and acting vice provost of student life at the private college, said the policy would affect 250 students under 21 who lived in campus residence halls in the last academic year and some 300 incoming freshmen. They will be billed about $5,000 for room and board for the year. 
 Ms. Bolger added, however, that commuters who live with their parents or guardians will be exempt from the policy, and those undergraduates currently living off campus could continue to do so. Students wanting to avoid the new rules will have to plead their case by letter.
"We haven't determined these exemptions yet, but the students will at least need to demonstrate that living on campus won't benefit them as students," Ms. Bolger said.
 
Revenue Sought to Pay For Hall
 Chapman has had this residency policy for about eight years, but to coincide with the fall opening of a new residence hall, housing 300 students, college administrators decided that this was the time to start enforcing it.
"The original reason for having this policy was because the college wanted to become a residential campus," Ms. Bolger said, adding that the present administration still has this goal in mind.
"But now the college is also looking to secure a stable revenue" to pay for the new hall, which cost $6 million, Ms. Bolger said. She added that if the college did not force students to live on campus, many rooms would be empty.
"We are trying to put a stronger emphasis on campus life, and it would be better for students," she said. "Residence students persist longer, are retained in higher numbers and have higher-quality academic experiences."
 
'The Rooms Are Small'
 But some students, who say the cost of living on campus is already too high, are not so sure.
Todd A. Adams, a sophomore who organized a demonstration against the housing policy, said in an interview: "The rooms are small, the food is gross. It's really overpriced and I can't afford to live there again." He said the turnout of 50 people for the protest was high considering it was Chapman's week for final exams.
Mr. Adams, a political science and economics major from Tulsa, Okla., lived on campus last year and is obliged to do the same next year. "I have to look on down the road, so that if they say I have to pay, I'll find another school," he said.
V. Elise Bigelow, president of Associated Students, the student government, said, "Students find that their rights are being violated, and I haven't spoken to any students who are in favor of it." Because many student have reacted negatively to the residency policy, Ms. Bigelow said, Associated Students has taken a formal stand against the policy.
Ms. Bigelow, a senior political science major from Big Timber, Mont., said she was writing a proposal suggesting alternative means of keeping residence halls full without forcing students to live in them. She said she planned to deliver the proposal at the next meeting of the Chapman trustees, set for tomorrow.
Ms. Bigelow suggested that once the new residence hall was opened, Chapman could close one of its existing halls each year for renovation so that only one hall was closed at a time and all the available rooms on campus would be occupied.
"The existing halls are in poor shape in a lot of ways," Ms. Bigelow said.
But Ms. Bolger said, "I'd say they are in average condition for 20-year old buildings."

HEADLINE: Stamps

BYLINE: By Barth Healey

 BODY:
Stamp collectors pretend to be organized: they have catalogues listing when stamps were issued, complete with technical printing details and retail prices. They have albums with little squares to mount the stamps in.
They also have shoeboxes. Filling up the shoeboxes can be a lot more fun than mere obeisance to the orderliness imposed by others. 
 Every stamp show -- known to hobbyists as a bourse, a delightfully antique word -- offers the opportunity to fill another shoebox.
There has been a strong trend in recent years toward postal history -- envelopes with stamps and routing marks and the like that tell a stamp's story, where it has been and how it has been used. Once, almost all the items on dealers' tables were stamps; now there are very few dealers who do not offer postal history items as well.
A collector can survey postal history in any organized or disorganized way that appeals.
A personal favorite, and very economical, are whimsical place names found in cancellations. Envelopes and cards in this exceedingly ad hoc category can be had for a dollar or two. There is seldom any point to the purchases; they are just fun.
A few favorites at random are these:
A postcard sent during a vacation in the West in 1940, postmarked Lazy Day, Mont.
A letter sent to The Christian Herald in New York City from Saint Mary's, Pa., in 1901, an interesting link between cancel and addressee.
A 1946 letter from Vermont with a town name that matches the stereotype of the rugged New Englander: Adamant.
A postcard responding to a survey of music education in Arkansas, on which the printed stamp bears a flag cancel from Stamps, Ark. (Stamps, by the way, was the home of the writer Maya Angelou; she returned to Stamps as part of a 1982 documentary that is occasionally rerun on public television.)
Is there any logic here? No, but so what?
 Browsers are always welcome at stamp bourses. Here are some planned for today and next weekend. The shows in San Antonio today and Aurora, Colo., next weekend will offer special stamp exhibits as well.
TODAY: Sacramento, Calif., Stamp and Postcard Show, Holiday Inn, Interstate 80 and Madison Avenue.
Milford, Conn., "Third Sunday" Stamp and Coin Show, Knights of Columbus Hall, Bridgeport Avenue.
Grand Rapids, Mich., Stamp, Coin and Baseball Card Show, Rogers Plaza, 1110 28th Street.
San Antonio, Texpex '91, Municipal Auditorium, 100 Auditorium Circle.
Toronto, Stampex '91, Sheraton Center, 123 Queen Street West.
NEXT SATURDAY and SUNDAY: Anaheim, Calif., Stamp Expo '91, Grand Hotel, 1 Hotel Way, across from the entrance to Disneyland.
Aurora, Colo., Topex '91, Denver Radisson Southeast Hotel, 3200 Parker Road.
New York, Metropolitan Stamp Show, Days Inn, 440 West 57th Street in Manhattan.
Richmond, Central Virginia Stamp Bourse, Holiday Inn/Crossroads, 2000 Staples Mill Road.
Rhinelander, Wis., Northwoods Stamp and Coin Show, Nicolet College.
 
False Franking
 Two new coil stamps in the Transportation series will offer a bonanza to modern postal history fans interested in false franking. Such franking means that the value printed on a stamp does not, in fact, indicate accurately how much postage has been paid.
In the past, false franking has occurred when the Postal Service has allowed a bulk mailer to use up outdated stamps after rates changed. The difference between the old rate and the new rate is paid at the time of mailing, but there is often no marking on the envelope to indicate this.
Bulk mailers use a variety of postal rates, depending on the tax status of the mailer and the amount of pre-sorting done before mailing. Prior to the latest rate change on Feb. 3, there were at least 12 different rates.
Two stamps issued on May 25 in Secaucus, N.J., a brown 5-cent showing a canoe and a dark green 10-cent showing a tractor trailer, will now be used to cover most bulk mail rates.
The canoe stamp has the notation "Additional Nonprofit Postage Paid," and the tractor-trailer stamp has the words "Additional Presort Postage Paid." The phrases describe officially what had been the ad hoc decisions by individual postal officials.
The general public should also be pleased: printing fewer different stamps saves the Postal Service money and helps keep rates steady.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Selling Paseo's Sizzle Between the Lines

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
THE big new thing in television advertising seems to be tongue-in-cheek subliminals. In other words, poking fun at the public's perception that advertising is getting the job done by attacking the subconscious.
There is, for instance, the double-talking big-star guy who leaves you with the uncomfortable knowledge that you have been at this viewer stuff long enough to understand even the fastest of ad-speak. 
 And then there are those (wild!) commercials for Toyota's (hot!) new Paseo. If you watched any part of the Chicago Bulls' prance through Magic's china shop, you will have seen the ads -- and you might well have seen them even if you gave Michael Jordan a pass.
The commercials for the new two-plus-two sporty coupe began with the basketball playoffs, but they are running all over the place, and they pretend to the practical while touting the tingle.
 The idea, according to a Toyota spokesman, is to go after the young-male market with a car that is sensible but exciting. The ads flash bikini images and the words "wild" and "hot" and "sexy," and all the while an announcer drones on about good basic transportation.
It might work, and Toyota is counting on 35,000 Paseo sales this year, and another 50,000 in 1992. But the proof will be in the car itself, not in what Madison Avenue says, no matter how it says it. The truth (boring and sotto voce) is that Paseo is a long way from loosely bound excitement.
The ads, in fact, may have Paseo's story exactly backward. With Toyota's latest entry, the fun actually is on the outside, and the sleek and brightly painted body wraps a core that is strictly econobox.
It is billed as a '92, so the company will have more than a year's production to brag about when it comes time to tally sales for the model year. But it also is a car that will have to fight some stiff competition in the form of the Geo Storm, Hyundai's Scoupe and Honda's CRX, all of which also have their charms.
A big part of Paseo's lure will be its palette of body colors, eight in all, and the tester was a gorgeous aqua, which Toyota calls turquoise pearl. The integrated bumpers were the same shade, and along with fared-in headlights, flush windows and close-fitting body panels, they contribute to a commendably low drag coefficient of .32.
That helps fuel efficiency, of course, and it makes the black and gray interior a quieter place. Seated behind the sport wheel with its three spokes, you survey a dash dominated by an 8,000-r.p.m. tach on the left and a 110-m.p.h. speedometer on the right.
Oddly, in a car so basic, there are surprises. Power steering is standard, as are remote latches for the trunk and fuel-filler door, and a pull-out tray offers dual cupholders. The aqua Paseo also had cruise control and air-conditioning, but you can't have power windows or central door locking or very many options at all. This is a car that is what it is.
The sideview mirrors have to be adjusted manually, as does the optional sunroof, which opens as a vent or can be removed and stowed in the trunk. Storage also must be found for the roof's opaque insert if you want the rays to penetrate the tinted glass.
Company literature makes a thing of "full-fabric" sport seats, but they too are relatively spartan and lacking in adjustment. They are also firm to the point of discomfort.
The Paseo has no airbag, which means Toyota had to find a way around the safety regulations, and the car was given passive shoulder belts, hooked to the door in the way that Volkswagen and Honda used to do it. These, though, are cumbersome, and you have to force your way under them and fight your way into the car.
There are a number of nice things to say, however. Storage is relatively good, with a big glove box and a couple of cubbyholes in the dash, which has a tray molded into its top. A console between the buckets contains the shifter and parking brake, and there is a fold-down rear seat that offers a sizable passthrough for long objects in the trunk.
Most cars as small as this also make the mere idea of rear seats a bad joke. In the Paseo, there is actual room back there, although passengers shouldn't be expected to smile if the trip is going to be more than a quick ride home.
And the word "quick" does have its place when you talk about the Paseo. Under the hood, the little 1.5-liter engine sports twin cams, four valves for each of its four cylinders, and fuel injection, and it puts out an even 100 horsepower.
That is quite sufficient in a car that barely nudges the needle of the scale above 2,000 pounds, and that comes equipped with a five-speed stick or an optional automatic that is electronically in tune with the engine. It might be said that Paseo walks away smartly.
It does that, too, with excellent economy, and mileage is rated at 28 city, and 34 highway. When you combine that with a base price (and a realistic one, since there are few options), of only $9,988, you have a car that delivers its own message. It doesn't need too many parentheses.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Toyota's Paseo, designed primarily for U.S. buyers, adds pizazz to the entry-level market. (Toyota Motor Sales, U.S.A.)

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Confusion Reigns in Tokyo

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
This has not been a good year for the Tokyo stock market. But it has probably been even worse for the forecasters, economists and analysts who attempt to predict the market's course.
Tokyo had been hit by a market crash early in 1990 and again by the Persian Gulf crisis later in the year. And it is still staggering, lagging way behind the recovery of markets in many other countries, including the United States. The Nikkei index of 225 leading shares, which closed on Friday at 25,093.89, needs to rally 23 percent to regain its level of 30,837.99 before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August and 55 percent to catch the record high of 38,915.87 that it reached on the last trading day of 1989. 
 As for the forecasters, they have been counting on a cut in interest rates to give the market a spark. This assumption is behind current forecasts that have the Nikkei 225 rising 8 percent to 20 percent, or roughly to 27,000 to 30,000, relatively soon.
Some analysts expected the interest rate cut in the first quarter of the year; some, in the second quarter. Well, it is already June, and interest rates have not been cut.
Many who have been predicting the cut will now be hoping for it in the third quarter. And some may delay the due date of the reduction in the official discount rate, which is now 6 percent, until the end of the year.
For investors, this leaves the outlook for the Japanese stock market quite murky -- and risky. One argument many analysts have been making for getting back into the market is to avoid the rush when interest rates are cut. If there is a stampede back into the market, a lot of the potential gains could be gone in a hurry. But how do you tell if and when that is going to happen?
The latest disappointment for forecasters came last week. The Bank of Japan's quarterly survey of companies, known as the Tankan, showed the economy slowing and business confidence declining. But the news was not bad enough. The report showed some capital investment strength, instead of the weakness that would presage a sharp decline in the economy.
Altogether, the report did not signal that a fast slowdown in the economy is around the corner -- the kind of economic slump that would trigger a cut in interest rates to cushion the fall.
And Yasushi Mieno, the canny head of the Bank of Japan, seemed once again to be purposefully vague about what it will take to satisfy him that inflation is low enough. Consumer inflation is at 3 percent and falling. Real estate prices, which are especially important to Mr. Mieno, are also declining. But, he indicated last week, he is now worried about the tightness in labor markets and the level of capacity utilization.
To add to the confusion, the rally in the dollar last week against the yen and other currencies makes any move to lower interest rates in Japan more difficult. Such a cut in rates would weaken the yen, swelling the huge Japanese import bill and adding inflationary pressure to the economy.
"Everyone has lost a good yardstick at this moment," said Yuichi Kohashi, executive vice president of Daiwa Securities America Inc., bemoaning the difficulty of divining what is likely to happen next. Daiwa had forecast an interest rate cut by the end of June and probably earlier.
Salomon Brothers is another of the many firms confounded by the Bank of Japan and the economic data. Salomon had predicted an interest rate cut in the first quarter, then shifted its predicted date to the third quarter, when Mr. Mieno in April signaled he was unlikely to act soon.
Last week's developments are "ammunition for the authorities to delay the official discount rate cut to late in the third quarter or even later," said Kermit L. Schoenholtz, a Salomon analyst in Tokyo.
For a stock-market rally to materialize, cuts in interest rates are almost certainly needed. The market, which analysts say is overvalued now, will not be moved much by other forces. While the Tankan data was not as downbeat as had been predicted, forecasters still expect the Japanese economy to slow sharply from the 5.6 percent growth, after adjustment for inflation, in the gross national product last year.
Some economists expect the G.N.P. figures to be released soon will show a torrid growth rate of 10 percent to 14 percent for the first three months of 1991. But then the slowdown will begin, they say, with the economy flat in the second quarter and declining in the second half of the year.
For the whole year, Salomon is below the consensus, with a prediction of around 2.5 percent. Daiwa, for now, is closer to the consensus, around 3.5 percent to 4 percent.
In addition, total corporate earnings look miserable. Salomon is expecting a small decline overall for the current fiscal year, which ends next March 31.
With Mr. Mieno playing hard to figure out and the rising dollar and weakening yen giving the Bank of Japan less maneuverability, timing the turnaround will be as frustrating as ever. Last week, lamented Mr. Kohashi, "there was no solution, just postponement."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
For This Quiz, The Answer Is More Confusion

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
Take out your pencils for a multiple-choice test. The best and brightest forecasters at Wall Street's leading blue-chip firms think that:
a. The recession is over, the recovery will be tame and inflation will be low. 
 b. The recession is over, the rebound will be robust and inflation is a danger.
c. The recession is not over, and the timing and strength of the recovery are uncertain.
d. All of the above.
The correct answer, unfortunately, is "All of the above." And that may provide some explanation for the bond market's uneasy behavior and the uncertain signals it has been sending to the stock market, which jerked and jittered through the week and finally closed at 3,000.45, up 23.72 points for the week.
Indeed, the soothsaying disagreement is such that some analysts think investors are being charged a "confusion tax" -- a penalty that simply reflects the market's inability to figure out who's right. "It would be hard to quantify how much of the long Treasury bond yield is caused by uncertainty," said Josh Stiles, a bond analyst for I.D.E.A., a British research firm. "But it is very real."
Gilbert Benz, an economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York, thinks the correct answer to the quiz is "b." But he agrees that traders may just be driven by indecision, "especially in a week like this."
That is, a week in which the Government reported Thursday that May wholesale prices were up an unexpectedly high 0.6 percent and that May retail sales were strong. That supported the "robust recovery" case. On Friday, the Government reported that May consumer prices rose a benign 0.3 percent, confounding the alarmists. The latter figure helped "confirm our low-inflation recovery forecast," reported Ed Yardeni, the chief economist for C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell, who votes for "a" in the quiz.
But Mr. Stiles points out that 65 percent of the professional traders polled by his firm on Friday think "c" is the right answer, and that the recession is not yet over. Moreover, many are fearful that the Federal Reserve will misread the economic evidence and move soon to tighten credit in response to unfounded inflation fears.
And Lawrence Kudlow, the chief economist for Bear, Stearns & Company, doesn't even agree that there is any disagreement. "Curiously, I see a very broad agreement," he said. "In the last 10 days, the consensus has shifted to expect a strong recovery. I just think they're wrong. My view is we're getting a recovery, but it will be substandard."
Mr. Benz brings the debate full circle by pointing out that professional forecasters "usually underestimate the economy's strength in the early stages of a rebound." Which is perilously close to that schoolroom baffler in which someone says, "Everything I say is a lie" and students have to wrestle with the logical consequences. One big difference: Billions in trading profits aren't riding on whether the students come up with the right answer.
