HEADLINE: Sticky Problems in Bringing Films to Soviet Screens

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
In 1989, Ismail Merchant and James Ivory, the New York film producer and director whose company's credits include "A Room with a View" and "Mr. and Mrs. Bridge," made a deal to sell their films in the Soviet Union. Merchant Ivory Productions planned to license three movies to Paritet, a Moscow-based company. The deal was in rubles, which Merchant planned to use to make a film in the Soviet Union.
But Merchant Ivory's foray into the new market ended badly. Paritet sued Merchant for $26 million for the profits it said it lost because the first film, "Deceivers," was delivered late and incomplete and subsequent films were not delivered at all.
On May 19, the American Arbitration Association fined Merchant Ivory Productions 2.3 million rubles. Though it is neither in dollars, as Paritet had sought, nor anywhere near the 15 million rubles that Paritet used to arrive at $26 million, the fine is substantial. 
 In fact, depending on the rate the parties use to convert rubles to dollars, Merchant Ivory may end up paying a fine that far exceeds the top amount -- of several hundred thousand dollars -- that any American film company has earned distributing a film in Russia.
The Arbitration Association gave no explanation for its decision. But the case sheds light on the differences in moviegoing customs in the two countries and the potential for difficulties that film companies may have in a country that is struggling to transform itself into a market economy.
Historically, few United States companies have distributed their films in the Soviet Union. Indeed, in an action last week unrelated to the Merchant Ivory case, the Motion Picture Association of America, which represents this country's major film companies, announced that it would cease licensing films there or sending films to the Moscow Film Festival. The move was in protest of the absence of any Soviet law against film piracy, a chronic problem for American studios doing business in that country.
Another problem in doing business in the Soviet Union is that the banking system is new, hard currency is scarce and the ruble is volatile, with various rates of exchange for various transactions. Despite the arbitration association's decision, Paritet and Merchant Ivory may face a battle over the valuation of the ruble settlement. Charles Sutherland, whose consulting firm, Washington Film Associates, represented Paritet, claims that, using the new commercial rate of exchange to buy rubles, the figure is equivalent to $1.3 million. Mr. Sutherland maintains that rate is appropriate because the decision said that rubles must be obtained "by any legal means available."
 In a telephone interview, Mr. Merchant said his company is exploring several options for paying the damages. But he said he hoped to buy the rubles at a rate better than the commercial exchange, and thus pay no more than about $71,000. William Horner, of Horner & Isaacs, the law firm that represented Merchant Ivory, said the company could, for instance, buy rubles on the floor of the State Bank Currency Exchange or work out an arrangement with another company that might swap rubles for rights to some of Merchant Ivory's films. Mr. Sutherland maintains that "except for an auction, there is no legal method for buying rubles." But time is pressing; the settlement must be paid by June 19.
The squabbles between Paritet and Merchant Ivory started soon after their agreement was signed. Paritet claimed that Merchant Ivory was very late in delivering the prints of "Deceivers," that it sent the wrong kind of sound track and that one print was damaged. Merchant Ivory argued that it was not notified that one type of print, the internegative, was faulty until seven weeks after the shipment. "We would have sent new reels for damaged reels," Mr. Merchant said.
The dispute over the sound track is more peculiar. The wide variety of dialects in the Soviet Union makes it impossible to produce a single dubbed film. Mr. Sutherland argued that it is routine in international film agreements to get a special magnetic sound track rather than the optical sound track that Merchant Ivory sent. Paritet would have used the magnetic sound track to make separate audiocassettes for each region.
But Merchant Ivory argued that the contract did not require any sound track at all. It sent one, it said, as a courtesy. Merchant Ivory contends that Paritet had told it that, instead of providing dubbed films to each theater, it planned to use individuals who would simultaneously translate the film orally at the movie theatre. "If there had been dubbing, we would have had to approve the translation in any case," said Mr. Horner.
Even more central to the argument, Paritet complained that "Deceivers" arrived so late that it could not release it in the winter when movie attendance is highest. As a result, it said, it lost potential profits from three to five million tickets. It forecast additional lost revenues from the two films that did not arrive based on its projections of ticket sales of 8 million to 10 million apiece.
Attendance numbers in the Soviet Union have always been difficult for American companies to verify, according to the M.P.A.A.'s president, Jack Valenti. And Mr. Merchant said that Paritet's claim was unrealistic because the films were only modest hits in the United States and were unlikely to generate as much business in the Soviet Union. "Quartet," one of the films Paritet requested, sold about 400,000 tickets at the box office here, Mr. Merchant said.
But Mr. Sutherland countered that his client based the numbers on its previous experiences in distributing American films and that his figures are checked by Goskino, the Soviet film agency.
Many American companies have been reluctant to license films to the Soviets because the arrangements pay poorly. While United States companies typically receive a flat fee plus a percentage of box-office profits in major foreign markets, they seldom earn more than a flat fee in the Soviet Union, usually in the $150,000 range for a movie that might sell as many as 35 million tickets. As a result, the Motion Picture Association of America reported 1990 revenues of only $750,000 from the Soviet Union.
The association's decision on Tuesday to stop licensing films to the Soviet Union follows previous attempts to find a more viable way of doing business in the Soviet Union. Two years ago, in an effort to improve revenues, the M.P.A.A.'s Mr. Valenti struck an agreement with Goskino. The agreement would have allowed American companies to earn both a flat fee and a percentage of profits from ticket sales. The agreement was in rubles rather than dollars, but was still an improvement over prior terms, Mr. Valenti said.
However after the agreement was signed, Mr. Valenti recalled, a group of high-level Soviets came to the United States. "They had never heard about the deal," he said. 'They said they did not know anything about it."
Since then, some efforts have been made to strike deals, not just by small companies like Merchant Ivory but by the major studios as well. One step forward was taken last year when Michael Macclesfield, vice president for international sales of United International Pictures, signed an agreement to distribute MGM's "Gone With the Wind," for a hard-currency guarantee in dollars and a percentage of profits in rubles. Mr. Macclesfield said 8.5 million tickets have been sold, but was not specific about how much money the company had actually earned from the deal.
But that arrangement remains the exception. William Mechanic, head of the Walt Disney Company's international distribution business, reflected the caution of others: "The Russians have one of the highest attendances in the world, but I don't think anyone has any idea what the business is worth," he said. "Disney has not licensed to the Russians for the past three years."
Eventually companies will take more steps forward, but the progress is bound to be very slow.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/June 9-14

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Can Apple and I.B.M. Find Common Ground?
 

For more than a month rumors were circulating in the wilds of Silicon Valley and in button-downed Armonk, N.Y., that Apple Computer Inc., and its arch rival, the International Business Machines Corporation, might talk about working together. The rumors said John Sculley, Apple's chairman, had the idea and broached it with I.B.M. Last week the rumors proved true. The companies sat toe-to-toe at I.B.M.'s headquarters in Armonk. Though details are still scant, it seems the meetings were about collaborating on work stations, powerful computers one step up from PC's. I.B.M. has a fast new chip, the RS/6000, it would like Apple to use. Apple is working on new software. Sounds like a nice fit. One possibility is that the companies might form a joint venture, with I.B.M. helping to defray Apple's development costs. If do they strike a deal, it would be a big blow to Hewlett-Packard, Sun Microsystems and the other work station makers.
 
The Banks Win One
 
Want to add a little dazzle to that drab bank lobby? Put in an insurance desk. That was not possible until last week when the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit decided state-chartered banks could sell insurance if state law permitted it. The ruling came in response to a move by Citicorp to overturn a Federal Reserve Board decision last year ordering it to stop selling and underwriting insurance through the Family Guardian Life Insurance Company, one of Citicorp's Delaware subsidiaries. The ruling -- which will bring smiles and profits (it hopes) to Citicorp and the nation's other big banks that are looking for new businesses -- is likely to make the Fed and the insurance industry wince. For the Fed, the ruling questions its regulatory authority. For the insurance industry, the ruling means a powerful new rival.
 
Adland in an Uproar
 
It was not the advertising industry's finest hour. Last week at the Clio Awards dinner in New York, the industry's equivalent of the Academy Awards, 300 irate guests seated at tables simply walked on stage, took the awards and then walked out. They were furious because the banquet organizers did not show up. "If I hadn't been up for two Clios, I might have found it amusing," said Robert Waldner of J. Walter Thompson in New York. "I took home one award, but so did one out of every two people there." In the end, to help prevent a melee, waiters and waitresses handed out awards just like hors d'oeuvres. Another dinner is scheduled for next week.
 
Pickens's Miscalculation
 
Back in the 1988, T. Boone Pickens figured natural gas prices could only go higher. So the Mesa Limited Partnership, which he heads, borrowed $700 million and bought more reserves. Trouble was, gas prices never did rise. They stuck at about $1.25 per 1,000 cubic feet and Mesa was saddled with a total of $1.2 billion in debt. Last week, Mesa borrowed $616 million in long-term debt from a number of insurance companies and large institutions to pay off some short-term obligations. To get the money, Mr. Pickens had to pledge more than half of Mesa's natural gas reserves -- 1.2 trillion cubic feet. With the new loans, Mesa will be able to stretch out payments for up to 21 years. But trouble remains. According to Mr. Pickens, gas prices have to reach $2 per 1,000 cubic feet before the company can make a profit. They won't do that before 1993, he concedes. If prices don't recover, the gas could be auctioned off to pay back Mesa's creditors.
 
Cable Keeps Climbing
 
The price of basic cable television service keeps rising. Regulations by the Federal Communications Commission were supposed to prevent that. Last week, the F.C.C. adopted rules to give local governments more power to push back prices. But the rules contain a lot of loopholes: They only allow local governments to regulate "basic," service, loosely defined as the retransmission of broadcast channels. Because of this, cable operators have already begun moving some programs from basic service onto their premium, extra-cost channels. And because of the way the rules are written, most big cities will be exempt from local control. Consumer groups are dubious over whether the rules will bring down costs.
 
Lifting Auto Sales Gloom
 
The General Motors Corporation may have slimmed down, but it still has a lot of market muscle. Its sales increased by 17.8 percent in early June, compared to the 1990 period. That was enough to offset a 1 percent loss by the Ford Motor Company and pull the entire domestic industry up by 9.4 percent. "These numbers give greater confidence that sales may have bottomed," said Harvey Heinbach, of Merrill Lynch & Company in New York.
 
 In Brief
 
Like a lot of companies these days, the Unisys Corporation has too much debt -- $3.43 billion worth. So it agreed to sell its Timeplex Inc. computer networking subsidiary for $207 million to Ascom Holding of Switzerland.

 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Inflation's Staying Power
 
Three years of sluggish monetary growth, lackluster gains in the gross national product and a recession should have had inflation licked. If only that were so. According to the Labor Department, the Producer Price Index, which measures wholesale inflation, was up 0.6 percent in May, the largest gain in seven months. Granted, most of the increases in the producer index came from higher energy prices -- they have since come down -- and a onetime increase in tobacco prices. But the underlying inflation rate has not come down. "I'm disappointed," said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities in New York. "This is exactly the situation the Federal Reserve does not want to be in -- the beginning of a rebound with no improvement in inflation." A high inflation rate inhibits improvements in the housing market and "causes interest rates to go up," he said. These numbers are giving the bond markets the jitters.
 
A Slight S.& L. Upswing
 
No one doubts that the savings and loan industry is ailing. It has been plagued by massive failures that could cost taxpayers as much as $500 billion over the next 40 years. The institutions seized by the Government lost $726 million in the first quarter. But a part of the industry -- the thrifts that survived on their own -- showed surprisingly strength. They had profits of $626.8 million in the first quarter, according to the Office of Thrift Supervision -- the first profits in four years. Analysts said the profits came from the growing spread between what institutions pay depositors and what they charge for loans. Good for the institutions, tougher on the borrowers.

Consumers Back and in Demand
 
Finally, the consumer is starting to spend. According to the Commerce Department, retail sales were up a by 1.0 percent in May, a sizable jump for the month. And demand picked up for a broad range of goods. "We are definitely in a recovery," said Rosanne M. Cahn, an economist at First Boston Corporation.
 
A Fleeting Trade Surplus
 
For the first time since 1982, the United States posted a trade surplus. But don't uncork the (domestic) champagne just yet. Though the surplus was large -- $10.2 billion in the first quarter, according to the Commerce Department -- it was largely because of a one-time transfer of $22.7 billion from countries that helped pay for the Gulf War. It was also because of a recession-related slip in demand for imports. "Without those payments, the current account defict would still be about $70 billion this year. With the Gulf contributions, it will come down to about $20 billion," said William R. Cline, senior fellow at the Institute of International Economics in Washington. But more foreign payments are coming. Kuwait and Saudi Arabia pledged to help pay for New York's ticker tape parade.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL


That Winning Yeltsin Touch
 
Last week, Boris N. Yeltsin was elected president of Russia -- and this time he had opponents. Mr. Yeltsin, who renounced Communism a year ago, ran on an economic reform ticket with a long list of objectives. "The first priority is a new tax system. The second is privatization. The third is monetary reform," said Judy Shelton, senior research associate at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University. But one objective could put Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev out of business: ending the Russian contributions which pay the Soviet central government's bills.

Bright Side to Business in Japan
 
Japan is a tough place to do business. But not as tough as some think. A survey by the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan and A. T. Kearney, a management consulting firm, concluded that American companies doing business in Japan are often more profitable than their parents. Maybe so. But exporting to Japan remains tricky. This year Japan is expected to have a record worldwide trade surplus -- more than $70 billion.
 
Unified, Germany's in Deficit
 
Chalk it up to unification. West Germany, the world's largest exporter, had gone a decade without a trade deficit. But unified Germany reported a $790 million deficit for April, mainly a result of a 17 percent eastern German import surge. Economists think it will finish the year just breaking even, which, presumably, will make the United States look good. "Anything that takes away another country's trade surplus is good for American exports," said Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics in New York.

HEADLINE: Technology;
Radisson Proposes Twin Hulls for the Queasy

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Radisson Hotels International, the Minneapolis-based hotel chain, has decided to get into the $4.6 billion cruise business, and it is doing so in dramatic style. It has commissioned a 410-foot catamaran-like ship whose novel design is expected to reduce seasickness.
Diamond Cruise Ltd., a joint venture that includes Japanese, Finnish and American investors, began building the vessel, the world's largest twin-hull ship, in January in Finland. The ship will be managed by Radisson, a unit of the Carlson Companies, one of the largest private companies in the United States. 
 If the catamaran design indeed provides stability and minimizes seasickness, Radisson could tap into a market of people who have avoided cruises for fear of having an expensive vacation ruined by queasiness.
The twin-hull catamaran design has been around for centuries and is popular for sailboats. But commercial shipbuilders have been wary of the high expense of building a second hull and the technical uncertainties associated with building such a craft on a large scale. The longest existing catamaran is less than half the length of the proposed Radisson vessel.
There are currently only 17 commercial twin-hull vessels in operation, ferrying passengers on the rough seas off Japan and Hawaii and conducting oceanic research.
The new ship, the Radisson Diamond, is designed to carry up to 354 passengers. It is scheduled to be completed in May 1992 for about $125 million, 10 to 15 percent higher than the cost of a comparable single-hull ship. The plan is to charge $600 a day per person, putting Radisson in the top end of the cruise industry.
With the hotel business overbuilt, Radisson is attracted by the double-digit growth that the cruise industry enjoyed in the 1980's, when capacity surged at the same time the economy was prospering. The supply of new ships will continue to increase dramatically in the next few years, however, and there is some question whether demand will to keep pace.
Stability on choppy seas is the chief advantage of the Swath (small water-plane area twin-hull) design. The twin hulls allow shipbuilders to construct a much wider vessel, but one that has less contact with the water than a traditional ship.
"It allows so much less contact with the sea than a mono-hull vessel," said Robin Lindsey, vice president of cruise operations for the Radisson Diamond. "The smaller the water plane areas, the less effect the movement of the sea actually has on the movement of the vessel." The total water-plane area on the Radisson Diamond is less than half that of a single-hull vessel with the same passenger capacity.
The design cuts down on rolling, pitching and heaving, the movements of a vessel that cause seasickness.
"Stability was the starting point for this vessel," Mr. Lindsey said. He cited surveys that show fear of seasickness as one of the most common reasons given for not taking a cruise. Only about 5 percent of the United States population has ever gone on such a voyage.
But some industry professionals are skeptical that Radisson will be able to make an effective sales pitch by targeting vacationers with weak stomachs.
"I am not sure how you can go out and say, 'Take a cruise on our ship, and you will not get seasick,' " said Oivind Mathisen, editor of Cruise Industry News, a newsletter for cruise-industry executives.
W. Bruce Turner, an analyst with Raymond James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla., said, "If indeed there is a noticeable and discernible difference, maybe they can market that as a slight value-added dimension."
Radisson executives acknowledge the delicacy of the weak-stomach promotion. "I didn't find a very positive way to put a twist on it," said John Norlander, president of the Radisson Hotel Corporation, a sister company of Radisson International. As a result, the company will focus on the novel design and the luxury and spaciousness of the ship's appointments.
With a breadth of 105 feet, the vessel is as wide as traditional ships that are twice its 410-foot length. In addition to providing stability, this allows for large dining rooms, staterooms and common areas. "It gives you a totally different space configuration," said Mr. Mathisen. "In a sense, it is less like a traditional ship and more like a floating resort."
Because of the extensive space the Swath design provides, the industry has been toying with the new technology for a number of years. "Shipyards over the past 10 years have frequently presented their drawings for the ship of the future, and they have often had this twin-hull design," said Mr. Mathisen. Still, he said, mainly because of the high cost of building a new ship, executives have been slow to place orders.
In the ship industry, there is a fear of being the first one to try something, in case it does not work. Shipping experts say just because something works in a model tank does not mean it will work on the open seas.
Aside from the higher costs of building the Diamond, which stem primarily from the additional steel needed to construct the second hull, there are several other drawbacks to the design.
The Diamond is slow compared with other ocean liners, cruising at just over 12 knots, compared with the usual 17 or 18 knots. The ship has an engine in each hull. But the size of each hull is a constraint on the size of the engines, and the speed generated by the two smaller engines does not match that of a conventional ship with a single large engine. The slowness in turn restricts the ship's possible destinations. For instance, it would be impractical to schedule a round-the-world cruise on the Diamond. The ship will be based in Puerto Rico to allow quick access to the Caribbean islands, where it will do most of its cruising. Most cruise ships are based in Miami.
Another problem is that each hull has a deep draft, about 25 feet, making it impossible to dock in some ports. A single-hull 400-foot ship might draw as little as 15 feet. To compensate, the Radisson ship will have several water taxis to take passengers ashore at such harbors.
Intriguing new technology or not, Radisson will face stiff competition in the cruise industry, as a host of ships on which construction began three years ago start coming to market. "It could be a very difficult time, especially for a new operator entering the market," said Mr. Turner of Raymond James & Associates.

HEADLINE: All About/Car Recycling;
An Afterlife for Automobiles

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
The entire building shakes and shudders as a 6,000-horsepower electric motor drives a rotary shredder that reduces whole automobiles to fist-sized recyclable pieces of metal scrap in about 30 seconds. The pieces fall onto a moving conveyor that passes under a magnetized drum, which lifts off the steel and iron. The drum leaves other metals, plastic and miscellaneous materials for hand sorting. The iron and steel chunks are stored in huge piles nearby until they are shipped to steel mills around the world to be made into new products.
This is recycling that works. As governments and industries struggle to establish recycling programs for newspapers, plastics and other household trash, the Prolerized Schiabo Neu Company, a privately held recycling company here, turned 300,000 old cars into high-grade iron ore last year. With scrap at about $90 a long ton, a typical car fetches about $100. For the shredder, costs vary widely depending upon location, the age of the equipment in use and the costs of disposing of what cannot be recycled. 
 According to the Institute of Scrap Recycling Industries, a trade group in Washington, shredders like this processed nine million old automobiles last year and enough appliances, industrial materials and construction debris to provide steel makers with 58 million tons of scrap -- 43 percent of all the steel produced domestically. They also contributed 61 percent of all lead produced, mostly from old batteries. There are about 220 shredders in the United States.
Structural steel, which is bigger and thicker than the steel used in automobiles, must be flame cut by hand before it can be recycled in the nation's steel minimills.

 
 
The Shredders
A Way to Separate The Useful Metals
 Auto recycling has evolved over the decades. Starting in the 1930's, cars were often burned in the open to get rid of seats and other combustible materials. Concerns about air pollution put an end to open burning by the 1960's, so the cars were simply compressed into cubes and sent to steel mills.
As long as they were going into open hearth furnaces along with iron ore and limestone in the basic steel forming process, these "dirty bales" were acceptable, said Mr. Jay A. Zimmern, general manager of Prolerized Schiabo. But the rise of the minimill industry (so called because it does not have ore processing equipment present in fully integrated mills) in the 1970's, increased the quality requirements for scrap.
"You shred to get rid of impurities," Mr. Zimmern said. The impact of the shredder even cracks the paint off the outer panels of cars. Because only ferrous metals are attracted to the magnet, the resulting material is almost entirely iron and steel.
Shredding also permits efficient packing of the electric arc furnaces that are the heart of minimills. Material in small chunks fills the furnace more completely than large bales.
Prolerized Schiabo shreds more than cars, although they are the biggest single input. It also buys and chops up steel doors, desks, hot-water heaters and shelving. It will not take appliances with motors because some contain polychlorinated biphenyls that could render the company's entire inventory as hazardous waste under Environmental Protection Agency rules.
It also takes structural steel from old buildings and other structures, and flame cuts it into lengths that will fit in an electric furnace. "The West Side Highway came through here," Mr. Zimmern said.
Metals other than iron and steel are sorted by hand from a conveyor belt in a nearby building. An experienced eye can tell die-cast zinc from aluminum or stainless steel. Everything, even the mixed materials that are left after the identifiable materials are pulled out, is eventually sold.
 
The Minimills
Turning Scrap Back Into Steel
 The steel minimill industry, an increasingly important part of the worldwide steel business, relies entirely on recycled scrap for its raw material. The highly efficient minimills produce many grades of steel at less cost than mills that start with virgin ore. In the United States, minimills account for about 20 percent of total steel output.
"We solve a problem for society," Mr. Zimmern said of the shredders and minimills. Recycling cars and appliances removes unsightly waste that otherwise would take up scarce landfill space. Mr. Zimmern estimates the amount of scrap processed here last year would have used six million cubic yards in a landfill, compared with the 175,000 cubic yards of valueless material actually dumped.
Recycling iron and steel is environmentally beneficial because it reduces the amount of iron ore that has to be gouged from the earth's crust. And since it takes 74 percent less energy to make steel from scrap than it does from virgin ore, it means less air pollution from burning fuel.
Most of the scrap processed at this waterside facility is exported to Japan and Korea. So it is possible that an old Chevrolet or Buick going into Prolerized Schiabo's shredder would come back in a few months as part of a shiny new Toyota or Hyundai. Nationwide, 19 million tons of steel scrap were exported in 1989, the latest year for which figures are available.

 
 
The Dismantlers
Stripping Cars For Spare Parts
 Automobiles are recycled in stages. The first stop is usually at a dismantler, like Riverside Auto Parts in Avanel, N.J. Each car that comes in is evaluated, and useful parts are removed.
Since dismantlers are the source for used parts for amateur and professional mechanics, they have a good feel for what is in demand. "On some cars, we remove the glass and store it," said Robert Terefenko, the manager at Riverside Auto Parts. "We know it will sell." On other models, the glass is ignored and other parts removed.
Dismantlers have a good eye for value, said Michael A. Cerreta, an executive of the Schiavone-Bonomo Corporation, a scrap-metal dealer here and one of the owners of Prolerized Schiabo. "I may pay $50 or $60 for a car strictly on a weight basis," he said. "But Riverside may pay $200 because they know the hood could be worth as much as $700 as a crash part."
The dismantler is responsible for removing things like lead-acid batteries, which could be hazardous to workers if the acid leaked, and gas tanks, which can explode.
When all the useful or potentially contaminating materials have been removed, the auto hulk is put in a press and flattened. This is largely for transportation efficiency. A truck that could haul six full-size autos can take 18 when they are compressed.
But business is off somewhat these days, thanks to the national economic recession. "Scrap over all is down about 30 percent," Mr. Zimmern said. With fewer new-car sold, fewer cars are junked. But even with a slowdown, Prolerized Schiabo buys 1,000 cars a day to meet the need for recycled steel.
 
 
 
THAT'S A 385-POUND, 3-WEEK HAMMER
 
 
The heart of a large automobile shredder is a 50-ton rotor with 20 blades or hammers made of hard manganese steel. Large grapplers lift car hulks off flat-bed truck trailers and place them on a conveyor that carries them to the entrance of the 50-foot-high machine.
The car drops in the machine and the hammers smash and tear at the metal until the pieces are small enough to fall through holes in the bottom that measure 5 inches by 10 inches. According to the Institute of Scrap Recycling Industries, small shredders start at about $1 million and a large one can cost well over $5 million. And because of the violence of the action inside the shredder, even the hardened steel hammers have a relatively short life.
Brand new, each 385-pound hammer looks like a bow tie, with holes in the middle where it can be mounted to the rotor. Each corner of the bow tie represents a working face of the hammer. As one face is worn down, it is turned to expose a new face. By the time a hammer's useful life is over, it resembles a figure eight, with all the corners worn round.
Officials of Prolerized Schiabo said the average useful life of a hammer is about three weeks. What is left is recycled to companies specializing in manganese steel.

HEADLINE: No Pain, No Gain -- or How New York Can Resolve This Crisis and Avert Another;
PRIVATIZATION

BYLINE: By Richard M. Daley ;Richard M. Daley is Mayor of Chicago.

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
In whatever shape New York City survives this financial crisis, another siege is only a matter of time if there are no fundamental changes in how the city gets and spends its money. Most such structural reforms have been considered politically unthinkable -- until now. The Op-Ed page asked several specialists for ways that fiscal necessity could be the mother of municipal invention.
 We've introduced privatization in city government, and the innovation hasn't been nearly as distasteful as many predicted. In this union town, there were plenty of skeptics. But privatization has worked -- with bumps. 
 For example, city towing crews could not keep up with the abandoned cars, trucks and even buses that littered the streets. Since 1989, abandoned vehicles have been towed by neighborhood companies that quickly respond to complaints while paying $25 a vehicle, which is sold for scrap metal. A service that cost Chicago millions has netted more than $1.2 million over the last year. City crews now spend all their time on illegal parking downtown.
City street-paving crews were inspired to improve their performance beginning in 1990 when we hired private contractors to pave the wards adjacent to where they worked. Both sets of crews competed to see who could do the job faster and better.
But we learned that not all privatization would go smoothly when we privatized drug treatment and contracted janitorial services for several facilities. Instead of spending $1.5 million to rehabilitate our aging drug treatment center, in 1990 we contracted with two private nonprofit organizations that have run innovative substance-abuse programs for years. This allowed us to reassign center staff members to city health clinics at nights and on weekends. City employees, who had become accustomed to working 8 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., Monday through Friday, were outraged that their schedules were adjusted to serve the public better. Never mind that no jobs were lost and that we now serve 200 more clients a year at three centers instead of one, while saving $737,000 annually.
Organized labor cooperates fully. In 1990, when Chicago contracted for janitorial services at some facilities, unionized companies agreed to hire, at the same wages, all the low-seniority janitors who were released after other city jobs were found for the high-seniority janitors. In the first year, the city saved $900,000 on cleaning supplies. The union saved jobs for its members. But not all the workers were happy. Besides the working hours, which inconvenience the public, they like the city's generous benefits.
City government should stick to basic services it provides very well and buy others. It matters little to the tax-paying public, which expects good service, who renders it.

HEADLINE: No Pain, No Gain -- or How New York Can Resolve This Crisis and Avert Another;
Small Change

BYLINE: By Anthony E. Shorris and Mark Elliott; Anthony E. Shorris was city Finance Commissioner. Mark Elliott was Deputy Budget Director.

 BODY:
In whatever shape New York City survives this financial crisis, another siege is only a matter of time if there are no fundamental changes in how the city gets and spends its money. Most such structural reforms have been considered politically unthinkable -- until now. The Op-Ed page asked several specialists for ways that fiscal necessity could be the mother of municipal invention.
Budgets aren't balanced with one or two good, big ideas, and even modest savings don't come easily. Still, small change can add up. For example, every Fire Department battalion chief doesn't need a driver; they cost $14 million a year. Most firemen spend less than 2 percent of their time fighting fires; imagine how many housing code inspections they could make. 
 Pretrial detainees wait, on average, 47 days in jail for their day in court. It was 41 days just 18 months ago. Returning to the old level would save $80 million annually that could be used to preserve drug programs for inmates.
Many sanitation workers spend fewer than three hours a day picking up garbage but are paid for eight. Changing that might save the recycling program, especially if one-man trucks were used.
The city fills out its paperwork correctly 90 percent of the time in the child welfare program, yet still faces the loss of up to $30 million in state sanctions for mistakes. Simplifying the standards would save enough money to preserve drug treatment programs for families.
The time isn't right for spending $40 million to implement the new charter. The purported improvements in democracy are not worth it.
Pharmacies' lobbyists have prevented the city from making bulk purchases of drugs and equipment. The savings from such purchases could save periled outpatient clinics.
How about cash incentives for city workers who collect child support payments from fathers who run out on their children? A 10 percent increase in collections would generate $7 million to use for programs for the homeless.
Are there dozens more ideas like these, perhaps better? Sure.

HEADLINE: Political Talk

BYLINE: By Josh Barbanel

 BODY:

Albany on Holiday
After failing to pass a state budget until the ninth week of the new fiscal year -- costing local governments tens of millions of dollars in interest payments -- the New York State Senate acted swiftly last week to award its 1,600 staff members an extra paid holiday, at a cost of $175,000 to taxpayers, according to the State Comptroller's Office. 
 As a reward for arduous work during the protracted budget wrangling -- which produced a budget that cut spending but was still not balanced, said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo -- the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, ordered Senate offices closed last Monday and gave the staff a paid day off. The day was declared an official Senate holiday to commemorate the Persian Gulf war.
In another example of the confusion that beclouded the State Capitol during most of the budget fight, the Senate was under the mistaken impression that the Assembly had gone along with the gesture. But Assembly staff members who took the day off used up a vacation day or compensatory time.
Although the Comptroller put the cost of an extra holiday at $175,000, John McCardle, a spokesman for Mr. Marino, said the holiday might have saved money by closing offices, thus cutting down on the use of lights, telephones and equipment.
 
 Cutting vs. Saving

As a candidate for mayor of New York, David N. Dinkins portrayed himself as a responsible liberal, committed to the proposition that spending more for services for the poor would not only help people, but would save money too.
In a sort of trickle-up economic theory, he argued that expanding health programs, drug treatment and other preventive services could cut the city's budget by keeping more poor people out of hospitals, jails and foster care.
"It costs approximately $2,000 to keep a family together," he said during the campaign. "If it busts up and the kids are placed in foster care, it costs $10,000 to $12,000 per child. Aside from the human considerations, which are obvious, it costs less."
Now, after months of fiscal worries and budget-cutting, a coalition of the city's largest private social-service agencies is making exactly the same point as they lobby against cuts ordered by Mr. Dinkins in some of the same programs he championed during the campaign.
In a report released at a City Hall news conference last week, the coalition, the Human Services Council of New York, argued that, for example, a proposed $4.7 million cut in a program to help drug-addicted mothers could soon cost the city $8.9 million a year by forcing more children into foster care.
During the campaign, Mr. Dinkins also argued that by spending more, the city would bring in millions of dollars in matching state and Federal funds. The social-service agencies say that by cutting the drug program, Mr. Dinkins will be giving up $14.3 million in state and Federal aid.
"I think that both candidate Dinkins and Mayor Dinkins would acknowledge that now all of the figures show these cuts will have a dramatic impact on the city," said Megan McLaughlin, executive director of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies and co-chairwoman of the coalition. "By cutting back services, it costs you more in the long run."
The Mayor's acting press secretary, Leland T. Jones, said that when the budget ax fell, Mr. Dinkins was forced to maintain spending on programs mandated by law, at the expense of others.
"We are very sympathetic to the Mayor's original intention when he took office," Mr. Jones said. "We are concerned that the gap between what he wanted to do and will be able to do is alarmingly wide."
 
 In the Pre-Turnpike Era

In its never-ending search for an identity beyond that of a rest stop between New York City and Philadelphia, the State of New Jersey has found a new symbol -- the 70-million-year-old Hadrosaurus foulkii, which is now the official state dinosaur.
At a bill-signing ceremony at the State House in Trenton on Thursday, Gov. Jim Florio said the Hadrosaurus and New Jersey were, "historically speaking, perfect together."
The bill-signing culminated a three- year lobbying campaign by students at the Strawbridge Elementary School in Westmont, near where a nearly complete skeleton of the dinosaur was unearthed in 1858. The species is named after its discoverer, William Parke Foulke, a scientist from the Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences.
While legislators dallied over the measure, the students were promoted from the third to sixth grade.
Alas, the designation of Hadrosaurus may do little to raise the esteem of New Jersey in the eyes of its neighbors. The dinosaur is now in residence in Pennsylvania, at the Academy of Natural Sciences.
 
 Are We There Yet?
 A few hundred bookworms were gathered in the park across the street from City Hall on Thursday, protesting budget cuts that could force the closing of libraries, when Mayor Dinkins decided to join them.
But instead of walking the 100 yards or so from City Hall to the site of the protest at the far end of the well-tended park, Mr. Dinkins climbed into the back seat of his shiny black Cadillac and was chauffeured to the demonstration.
If Governor Cuomo on occasion walks from his World Trade Center office to meetings in lower Manhattan, why did Mr. Dinkins drive across the street -- especially at a time of deep budget-cutting?
Mr. Jones, the Mayor's acting press secretary, attributed the decision to time constraints and security, not mayoral flat-footedness. He said that with the rally about to end, the Mayor's bodyguards decided it would take too much time for Mr. Dinkins to make his way through the crowd to get to the podium.
"Even if the crowd was friendly, they thought this would be the best way," Mr. Jones said. After speaking, Mr. Dinkins waded into the crowd.
 
 On the Front Lines

Everybody loved the parade. The bands blared, the soldiers marched, the confetti flickered in the sunlight, and the politicians made a frontal assault on the reviewing stand.
New York City's ticker-tape parade for the Persian Gulf veterans brought out the politician in all the local politicians -- whatever their position on the war -- as they vied for a spot in the front ranks of the reviewing stand, in view of television cameras.
Mayor Dinkins, who said he opposed the war but supported the troops, stood front and center throughout. Representative Steven J. Solarz of Brooklyn, one of the chief Congressional hawks, was assigned a seat in the fourth row of the viewing stand near City Hall. But as the bands marched on, he appeared standing in the front row at Mr. Dinkins's right hand.
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, who had preferred economic sanctions to military action against Iraq, somehow made her way to the front of the platform to be photographed with Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of the operation. Her official seat was in the fifth row.

HEADLINE: Former Satellites of Moscow Fault Western Aid for Soviets

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 15

 BODY:
Eastern European officials have angrily criticized Western economic aid to the Soviet Union, saying it has hurt their beleaguered economies by causing Moscow to reduce purchases from the former Soviet bloc.
In speeches in the last week, Hungarian, Polish and Czechoslovak officials have called on the West to structure any future aid to Moscow so it boosts, rather than undercuts, their nations' exports to the Soviet Union. 
 Eastern European officials complain, for instance, about Western farm credits to the Soviet Union, which often require Moscow to buy agricultural goods from the donor countries. Credits like these make it hard for Hungary and Poland to sell their farm goods to the Soviet Union, and increases economic pressure on countries that are already reeling from the disintegration of the Comecon trading bloc.
"What they give with one hand they destroy with the other in Central Europe," Bela Kadar, the Hungarian Minister of International Economic Relations, said this week at a conference in Geneva.
 
$1.5 Billion Farm Aid by U.S.
 Although Eastern European officials interviewed did not criticize the United States in particular, they faulted aid programs like the $1.5 billion farm aid credit to Moscow that the Bush Administration announced on Tuesday. Moscow is to use that money to buy American farm goods.
Eastern European officials say their countries are far too small and their budgets too stretched for them to put together huge credit packages like those made by the United States, Germany, Italy and other countries.
"This type of aid is diverting trade away from Eastern Europe, and not just in agriculture" said Laszlo Lang, director of the Central European Research Center, based in Budapest.
In recent days, Eastern European officials have stepped up their campaign about aid to Moscow because they are eager for the West to rethink its aid policies before the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, meets with the leaders of Group of Seven industrial countries in London in July.
Western officials say they do not plan to grant extensive aid to Mr. Gorbachev in London because Moscow has not yet shown a firm commitment to a market economy, but Eastern European officials say it is only a matter of time before the West steps up aid.
 
Triangular Aid Is Urged
 At a conference this week in Bardejov, Czechoslovakia, Prime Minster Jan Krzysztof Bielecki of Poland and Foreign Minister Jiri Dientsbier of Czechoslovakia urged the West to pursue a policy of triangular aid, in which a Western donor nation might, for instance, use its aid to buy Eastern European goods that would then be sold or given to the Soviet Union.
Mr. Bielecki said, "If the western credits for the Soviet Union were earmarked for the purchase of needed goods from Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland, this would provide us with the means for restructuring our state enterprises, which in former times sent 80 percent of their production to our eastern neighbor."
Some Eastern European officials say that as a condition for granting aid to Moscow, the Group of Seven should require the Soviet Union to pay what it owes on goods recently purchased from the former Soviet bloc. They would also like the West to require Moscow to honor supply contracts it has with Eastern Europe, especially regarding oil.
"What we're saying is aid to the Soviet Union could also help Central Europe," said Michael Cermak, a spokesman for Czechoslovakia's Foreign Minister. "It's in the West's interest to have stable democracies here instead of countries with serious economc and social problems."

HEADLINE: Orwell Journal;
On Some Plots, Sheep May Not Safely Graze

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ORWELL, Vt., June 14

 BODY:
The problem was how to mow the steep, rocky hillsides of two cemeteries in this farming town next to Lake Champlain. Noel Smith, the town manager, was certain he had a solution that was perfect for the 1990's: environmentally safe and at the same time economical. The answer, he thought, was sheep.
That was why he was pleasantly surprised last winter, when Jean Beck, a local sheep farmer, was the low bidder on the job of mowing two of Orwell's four cemeteries. 
 Ms. Beck said she and her flock of 20 Dorset sheep could do for about $250 what would cost up to $3,000 with mechanized mowers. Most of her cost would be in transporting the sheep and setting up the electric fence to contain them.
"I thought it would be an excellent way to keep the cemeteries open at a cheap price," Ms. Beck said.
But having provided for care of the dead, Orwell's three selectmen soon discovered that they had not reckoned with the wrath of the living. "These people have some strong concerns, some very real concerns, that we considered but didn't anticipate would be so strong," Mr. Smith said.
Tyson Allen registered one of those concerns. At a meeting of the Board of Selectmen on Tuesday, he said he has 11 relatives buried in the two graveyards and is certain they would not like to be tended by sheep.
"My Aunt Mabel is in there," Mr. Allen said. "If she had wanted to be buried in a sheep pasture, I'm sure she would have conveyed that to us."
Cecelia Barnes felt the same way, and she is a sheep owner. "It's the most horrible thing I ever heard of," she said. "It's disrespectful."
The first public rumblings of anger were heard in May. As May turned to June and the grass began to grow in earnest, so did the tensions in town.
Outsiders jumped into the debate. An editorial writer for The Rutland Herald wrote: "Since sheep were Vermont's chief agricultural product a century and a half ago, it is quite likely that some of those buried in Orwell's cemeteries back then would feel comfortable at the presence of such familiar animals."
The editorial went on: "The earliest depictions of Jesus show him as beardless youth with a sheep slung over his shoulders. There is no record that anybody has protested this portrayal as a desecration."
Finally, the selectmen added the sheep question to the agenda of Tuesday's regular meeting to bring the matter into the open. Lynn Allen, wife of Tyson Allen, set the tone for the confrontation when she presented the board with a petition "strongly opposed to the use of sheep as lawnmowers." It was signed by 136 of Orwell's 1,000 residents.
When Ms. Beck tried to explain that her sheep would be pastured at any one cemetery only for a couple of weeks at a time, Mrs. Allen sharply reminded her what sheep do after they eat.
After a heated half-hour debate, two selectmen split on the issue. Ron Huntley, the board chairman, cast the deciding vote -- against the sheep -- but only after having his say.
"Personally, I am 100 percent in favor of having those sheep in those cemeteries," said Mr. Huntley before bringing his gavel down on the unruly meeting. "They have never looked better. The problem is that people are threatening to turn the sheep loose or to shoot them."
Then he turned to a group of residents who had volunteered to mow and trim the cemeteries for the rest of the season at no cost to the town.
"I'm going to vote to remove the sheep," he warned them, "on condition that the people who have volunteered to maintain the cemetery do what they say they're going to do. If I see that those cemeteries aren't being kept up, those sheep will be right back where they were."
With that, most of the crowd moved into the misty night on the lawn of Town Hall, where they continued the debate in small groups.
Ms. Beck said she was upset that some local people had threatened to harm her sheep. When she discovered Monday night that the baling twine she used to tie the gate had been cut, that was the last straw.
"This is a whole new type of democracy we have in Orwell," she said angrily. "The minority rules here."
But Doris Wickman, a sheep supporter and member of the Orwell Historical Society, was relieved. " "We in Orwell don't like all this media publicity," she said. "We don't like the way this thing has split the town. I'm glad they did what they did."

HEADLINE: Gorbachev Steps Up His Campaign to Recover Credibility on Economy

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 15

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today accelerated efforts to convince the Western world that this time, he really means it when he says the Soviet Union wants to move swiftly to a market economy, though on his own terms.
In an interview broadcast on Soviet television tonight, after leading a meeting of Soviet officials and scientists on privatization, he said he had accepted an invitation to address the leaders of seven industrialized democracies in London next month after their summit meeting July 15-17. 
 "Some say Gorbachev is going to London as a blackmailer, others say he's going as a supplicant," he said, playing down to his Soviet audience the idea that the Soviet Union would get large-scale Western aid only by giving in to Western demands. "All this is not serious, it's superficial and irresponsible. Nobody's going to to put anyone on his knees, nobody's going to dictate to anyone."
Jacques Attali, President of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, said after meeting with Mr. Gorbachev this morning that he thought the Soviet leader was "fully committed to a market economy." But Mr. Gorbachev, who faces strong resistance from Communist e hard-liners at home, is clearly eager to be seen here as speeding reforms for his own reasons, and not as a capitulation to the West.
 
$702 Million for Soviet Projects
 By the same token, some Western leaders are bending over backward to avoid putting Mr. Gorbachev into an uncomfortable position.
Mr. Attali said today that he would like to have the authority to invest more than the $702 million his bank now can apply to projects in the Soviet Union. He said Mr. Gorbachev had also accepted an invitation to talk with officials of the bank during his visit to London next month.
"They're going in the right direction, but there is a need to clarify a certain number of things: the relationship between the center and the republics, the stabilization of the money supply, taxes, and precise laws on privatization, separating the state from capital," Mr. Attali said at a news conference. "It can't be done overnight."
 
Pressure on Gorbachev
 Some of the answers might come if Mr. Gorbachev and Boris N. Yeltsin, the newly elected President of the Russian Republic, can agree on elements of a new seven-year plan to integrate the Soviet Union into the world economic system that was worked out by Soviet and American economists in Cambridge, Mass., earlier this week.
The main Soviet architect of the plan, Grigory A. Yavlinsky, an economist with ties to Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin, will show it to Mr. Gorbachev at the beginning of the week, according to his associates here. The American version of the still largely secret plan will be presented to President Bush at about the same time, Mr. Yavlinsky told the Soviet newspaper Izvestia on Friday.
The election of Mr. Yeltsin, who supports radical economic change in the country's largest republic, will increase pressure on Mr. Gorbachev and his Government to agree to the new plan, Mr. Yeltsin's supporters say, but there are still questions here about how the authorities intend to proceed.
Mr. Attali seemed to hint after seeing Mr. Gorbachev in the Kremlin today that a currency revision that would replace or sharply devalue the ruble could be in the offing.
The ruble is now nearly worthless as a means of acquiring goods and services Russians want to buy. They pay 30 to 35 rubles apiece for United States dollars instead. Mr. Attali, reporting that he and Mr. Gorbachev had discussed the importance of achieving "internal convertibility" of the ruble as a first step in getting Soviet inflation under control, was asked what that term meant. Other Soviet officials have used it frequently as well.
"I can't comment," the French banker said. "It is a very sensitive matter."
But Valentin S. Pavlov, the Soviet Prime Minister, said in an interview with the Government newspaper Izvestia today that the withdrawal from circulation of 50- and 100-ruble notes last winter had not achieved its purpose of drastically reducing the stock of illicitly obtained money in circulation. The run on already scarce consumer goods has continued even after prices on bread and most other household products were raised last spring, leaving store shelves largely empty, he said.
"Instead of tens of billions of rubles," he said, "we got ten."
People and companies that could prove they had acquired the large notes by legal means were able to exchange them for smaller ones. The overall money supply, which has been growing as fast as the Government can print bills, remains too high, having grown 20 percent a year for the last two years.
"Exchanging the notes was not currency reform," Mr. Pavlov said.
What the Soviet Union needs before a market economy can even begin to get going here, even some Soviet Communist Party members agree, are three things: clarity in national and republic laws about the nature of private ownership of business or property, goods that people want to buy, and money that has the confidence of buyers and sellers. None of those conditions exists now, and from all accounts it will take years to put them all in place.
"If you could freely buy and sell and acquire property or land or businesses in rubles, then you could say they were 'internally convertible,' " said Alexander Papachristou of the American law firm White & Case, whose office has the somewhat unenviable job of advising would-be foreign investors in businesses here.
As it is, many Russians here in the capital prefer to use dollars or German marks, and Mr. Papachristou, who has studied the regulations that Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Pavlov and the Soviet state bank have promulgated, supposedly to undergird the move to a market economy, finds much to be puzzled about.
"By Aug. 1," he said, "regulations promulgated by the state bank will make it necessary for every joint venture here to get a license to sell goods retail for foreign currency. These regulations affect all business activity in the country today, and are starkly at odds with the assertion made by Gorbachev and others that the country is moving toward a market economy and opening to foreign investors.
The regulations also heavily tax foreign-currency earnings of companies here and, in theory, bar foreign-owned joint ventures from paying their employees except with rubles they do not want, he said.
And the latest published version of a draft law on privatization and what the law calls "destatization" of state-run enterprises makes clear that the state will retain a considerable say in their affairs even after they are sold to private investors or stockholders, according to Mr. Papachristou.
 
People Tired of Promises
 "I haven't yet seen a plan that convinces me that they mean to go to privatization as we understand it," a Western diplomat said. "But my guess is that the political factors are now going to force Gorbachev to move in a more radical direction again. He must have gotten the point that the West is not going to move unless he does."
Mr. Pavlov told Izvestia, "People are tired not only of all kinds of shortages, but of promises to replace them with prosperity," acknowledging that Mr. Gorbachev had been talking about economic changes since 1986 with little to show for it. After rejecting one plan to move to a market economy in 400 days, last year he turned down another one to do it in 500 days.
The state budget deficit soared to more than 100 billion rubles, panicking consumers who snatched bread, clothing and meat off the shelves. In the first quarter of this year, the national income fell by 12 percent.
The Soviet leader and Mr. Yavlinsky have been playing down the amount of Western economic aid and grants that the Soviet Union would need to throw off the legacy of three quarters of a century of Communism and rejoin the developed world, probably because, if it ever happens, it would take hundreds of billions of dollars.
Izvestia asked Mr. Yavlinsky if his plan contained a specific figure.
"It does," he replied. "And what is it?" Izvestia said. "I won't say," Mr. Yavlinsky answered.

HEADLINE: Security Seen as a Dividend of Soviet Aid

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
As a debate simmers in Washington over what sort of economic aid the United States should extend to the Soviet Union if it adopts democratic, free-market reforms, the question inevitably arises: what is in it for the United States?
The answer from many of those who favor aid, including economists, members of Congress and Administration officials, is that the payoff for the United States -- if there is one -- will be primarily in political-security terms and not economic ones. 
 "For the United States, the case for Soviet aid is really a political call, not an economic one," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International and former Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.
 
Buying a Tranquilizer
 "If you really want to get some economic bang for the 30 billion in bucks people are talking about, there would be a lot better way to spend it," Mr. Hormats said. "If the aid works, what you are buying is an economic tranquilizer designed to stabilize a potentially chaotic situation in the Soviet Union, in order to permit a transition to a free market and more democratic confederation of some sort."
To be sure, whether the Administration chooses to develop a Soviet economic rescue package will depend primarily on the seriousness of the Soviet Union's own rescue plans, or as President Bush said Friday: "The reforms have got to be detailed a bit more before blank checks are written, and even then it would be difficult. We're not rolling in cash."
But Mr. Hormats said the size of any aid program would also depend on "how desperate" the Administration believed the political situation in the Soviet Union to be, whether it was in the national security interests of the United States to try to stabilize it and whether that would be possible with any amount of money. Hopes for immediate benefits to the American economy will be secondary.
Indeed, Administration officials acknowledge that the key factor prompting President Bush this week to grant Mr. Gorbachev's request for $1.5 billion in additional credits to buy American food was a fear that food shortages in the Soviet Union, coupled with political turmoil, might lead the country to implode before any reform program could be instituted.
 
Possible Global Consequences
 Since the Soviet Union occupies one-sixth of the world's landmass, has 12,000 nuclear missiles, countless conventional weapons and some 50 nuclear reactors, a few billion dollars in credits is deemed a small price to pay for helping to prevent political and economic turmoil there, the consequences of which could be global, officials say.
"Spending American tax dollars to aid the Soviet economic transformation is the easiest proposition in the world to mock," said Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard University economist who has been working with Soviet economists on a five-year, $100 billion reform plan. "But those who want to stand by and see the Soviet Union collapse have an incredible lack of historical memory."
Americans are taking for granted the cooperation exhibited by the Soviet Union in recent years on a broad front including Eastern Europe and the Persian Gulf war, Mr. Sachs said.
"Do we really want to wait for a right-wing backlash in the Soviet Union, produced by a sense of failure, paranoia and anger about losing the cold war?" he added. "We will very much regret that. That is exactly the sort of sentiment that produced a man like Hitler after the First World War."
Not everyone, though, accepts this aid-to-prevent-nuclear-chaos argument.
"I think that it's somewhere between a new form of nuclear blackmail and gross exaggeration," Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, said in an interview on the Public Broadcasting System foreign affairs television series "American Interests." "The fact is that the Soviet military is in control of the nuclear weapons, they're primarily controlled by Russians in Russia and I don't think that it's a serious, very serious problem."
 
Some See Political Benefits
 Nevertheless, the potential benefits in American national security terms go beyond preventing nuclear chaos. Virtually all of the leading economists and lawmakers now advocating some American aid package do so on the condition that it not be paid out unless the Soviets take concrete steps to transform their economy from central control to a free market and their polity from a Communist system to a democratic one.
If such a transformation can be promoted, said Stanley Fischer, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist working with the Soviet Union, "you will end up with both a democratic and capitalist Soviet Union, and the fact is you find very few wars between democracies."
When Representative David R. Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on international operations, is asked by constituents why their tax dollars should go to help transform the Soviet economy, this political point is where he takes off from.
"We now have the opportunity to participate in the most fundamental change in a major society in the 20th century and to help shape that society in a way that will give us an opportunity to minimize our defense expenditures," Mr. Obey said. "We now spend $120 billion a year on military expenditures, which principally involve the defense of Western Europe from the Soviet Union.
"If we can promote democratic changes in the Soviet Union that will allow us to reduce that by only 10 percent a year, you could still save a lot more than the few billion that anyone up here is talking about for programs to promote Soviet reform. It makes sense financially, it makes sense economically and it makes sense in security terms. The most expensive thing would be to do nothing."
 
Effect on Eastern Europe
 Mr. Sachs argued that to think that an internal explosion in the Soviet Union would not have a spillover effect in Eastern Europe or the Muslim nations to the south would be "extremely naive." The Soviet Army remains in Germany and Poland, and its withdrawal from Eastern Europe could easily be derailed by internal turmoil.
Eastern European economies have already been badly hurt by the fact that the Soviet authorities have halted virtually all of the barter arrangements they had and are now insisting on being paid hard currency for Soviet oil exports. Because the Eastern Europeans are short of hard currency, they are having to look to the West for help in buying oil and have lost about 50 percent of their exports by no longer having access to many Soviet markets.
"So here we are pumping money into Eastern Europe to support reforms there, and it is being offset by the economic downturn in the Soviet Union," Mr. Sachs said. "And ask yourself: How many Western businessmen are going to want to invest in Eastern Europe if the Soviet Union is exploding next door? Imagine the refugee problems for Eastern Europe that would cause. You can't bottle up turmoil."
Finally, an orderly transition to democracy in the Soviet Government would, almost by definition, have to be accompanied by granting republics the right of self-determination, and that means the Baltic republics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia would be much more likely to find a nonviolent path to independence, which has been a basic objective of American foreign policy.
On the purely economic side, the Soviet Union with its 290 million people and vast natural resources represents an enormously attractive potential market if its resources could be fully tapped through a free-market system. But there would be little direct benefit to the American economy, except for certain sectors like consumer product and food producers, oil and gas equipment manufacturers and machine tool makers. The most immediate beneficiaries would be the Europeans in general and the East Europeans in particular, given their historical trade links with the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: Census Study Finds Drop in Homeownership

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
Many Americans, particularly minority members, young people and single people, are finding the prospect of owning their own homes more and more elusive as homeownership rates decline in the country, a Census Bureau study says.
The report found that 57 percent of all owners and renters could not afford to buy a median-priced house with a conventional, 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage. Thirty-six percent of current homeowners and 91 percent of renters did not qualify for such a property. 
 Even a modestly priced house is too expensive for 48 percent of the nation's households, according to the report, made public on Thursday. It said 15 percent could not afford to buy a home at even the lowest prices.
 
Findings Still Apply
 Findings of the study, which analyzed the income, debt levels and savings of 12,000 households surveyed in the spring of 1988, are still valid three years later, said Howard A. Savage, a Census Bureau statistician who wrote the report with Peter J. Fronczek,
Home prices in many markets have risen less rapidly or even declined and mortgage rates have fallen from between 10 percent and 10.5 percent in 1988 to 9.5 percent this spring. But with the onset of the recession, fewer lenders are offering mortgages with low down payments.
"This seems to be telling us that the step from renting to homeownership is a big step for a large number of households and perhaps a bigger step than was generally realized," said Mark Obrinsky, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association.
The study found sharp differences in the ability to buy a home by region, age, marital status and race or ethnic background.
For example, 77 percent of black families and 74 percent of Hispanic families could not buy a median-priced home, as against 43 percent of white buyers and 46 percent of non-Hispanic buyers.
Thirty-nine percent of married couples could not afford a median-priced house, as against 75 percent of all single people and 87 percent of single women with children.
Twenty-seven percent of families headed by people between 55 and 64 years old could not buy a home as against 94 percent of families headed by a person younger than 25.
By region, the proportion of households that could not afford a median-priced house were: the West, 63 percent; Northeast, 59 percent; South, 56 percent, and Midwest, 51 percent. The median prices were Northeast, $100,000; West, $95,000, and Midwest and South, $60,000.
A median-priced house is one that is more expensive than half the homes in a market and less expensive than half. A modestly priced house was defined as one that costs less than 75 percent of the homes in the market.
 
Lower Rates Had Little Effect
 Mr. Savage said the study's most surprising finding was that lower interest rates, which mean lower monthly mortgage payments, did almost nothing to improve renters' prospects of buying homes.
"It helps some, but it's not statistically significant," Mr. Savage said. "They just flat don't have the money. You can lower monthly payments, but if they don't have enough for a down payment then it's an irrelevant question."
The problem of declining homeownership rates is not new. After rising steadily, to 66 percent in 1980 from 55 percent in 1950, the rate edged down to 64 percent in 1990.

HEADLINE: Commencements;
First Lady Urges Tolerance at Northeastern Graduation

 BODY:
Barbara Bush stressed the importance of tolerance in a speech to the graduating class of Northeastern University yesterday.
"Real tolerance is an ideal our country has strived for from its beginning," Mrs. Bush said to the 2,155 graduates of the Boston institution's nine undergraduate colleges. "America was founded as a haven for tolerance of people of all kinds. Certainly we've made progress, but we still have a long, long way to go." 
 Mrs. Bush was awarded an honorary doctor of public service degree at the school's 90th commencement.
Others recognized for achievement were Brig. Gen. Richard Neal, the Marine spokesman in the Persian Gulf war; Representative Nicholas Mavroules, Democrat of Massachusetts; Bernard Solomon, former executive vice president of the Bank of New England Corporation, and Norman Rosenblatt, dean of Northeastern University's College of Criminal Justice.
Also given honorary degrees were Harvey Krentzman, president of Advanced Management Associates; Bill White, president of the National League of Professional Baseball Clubs, and Robert Bateman, a Canadian artist.
 
Chicago University
 The art of the argument and what can be learned from debating was the last lesson for graduates at the University of Chicago's 99th commencement yesterday.
The convocation speaker, Wayne C. Booth, the school's George Pullman distinguished service professor emeritus, addressed 1,674 undergraduates and graduates in three ceremonies yesterday and Friday.
"One sign that any graduate has moved beyond training toward genuine education is exhibited in a kind of conversation, the kind in which both parties act not just as teachers but as learners," he said.
Honorary degrees were given to Robert C. Merton, a Harvard University economist; Jacques H. Dreze, the founder of the Center for Operations Research and Econometrics in Belgium; Gordon H. Bower, a psychologist at Stanford; Thomas R. Cech, a chemist at the University of Colorado; James A. Miller, an oncologist in Wisconsin, and Oliver Smithies, a pathologist in North Carolina.
 
 Bennington College
 Harvey Gantt, the Democratic candidate who ran unsuccessfully against Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, last fall, gave the commencement address on Friday at Bennington College in Bennington, Vt. It was the 56th annual commencement for the liberal arts college, and 130 bachelor's degrees were awarded. Mr. Gantt, an architect and businessman, is a former Mayor of Charlotte, N.C.

HEADLINE: William Lewis Dies; Economics Laureate And Adviser Was 76

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
William Arthur Lewis, a Princeton University professor emeritus who was an adviser to several nations and won the Nobel Prize in economics in 1979, died yesterday at his home in Barbados. He was 76 years old.
Mr. Lewis was widely considered an authority on economic growth and political and social change in emerging nations. He shared the Nobel Prize with Theodore W. Schultz, a University of Chicago professor, for research into economic development "with particular consideration of the problems of developing countries." 
 In 1954, Mr. Lewis published what many economists considered one of the first academic works in this area, "The Theory of Economic Growth." He also wrote 11 other books and more than 80 monographs and articles.
Mr. Lewis was born on St. Lucia in 1915 and was educated at the University of London, where he earned his bachelor's degree in 1937 and a doctorate in 1940. He taught there until 1948 when he left for the University of Manchester. He was named vice-chancellor of the University of the West Indies in Kingston, Jamaica, in 1959.
He joined Princeton's faculty in 1963 and was named the James Madison Profesor of Political Economy. He taught undergraduate and graduate courses in economic development and modern economic history.
Mr. Lewis is survived by his wife, Gladys Jacobs Lewis of Barbados and Princeton, N.J.; two daughters, Elizabeth Lewis of Cranbury, N.J., and Barbara Lewis of Brooklyn, and four brothers, Stanley Lewis of Ghana, Earl Lewis of Trinidad, Allen Lewis, a former Governor-General of St. Lucia, and Victor Lewis of St. Lucia.
A state funeral is planned for June 22 on St. Lucia.
