HEADLINE: The Nation;
Minority Leaders See A Clash of Hues In a Rainbow Coalition

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS they have throughout the civil rights struggle, black and Hispanic leaders like to project an aura of solidarity -- at least in public. Yet, bubbling just beneath the surface are political and social tensions that threaten to undermine gains made by both.
Spokesmen for Hispanic groups say that blacks, with their political strength and with a sense that the term "civil rights" is synonymous with "black," have received a disproportionate share of jobs, power and media attention, often at the expense of Latins. 
 Among many blacks, the sentiment seems to be that Hispanic claims are Johnny-come-lately, largely coming on the heels of progress charted and achieved by blacks. The views of these blacks may be best summed up in the words of Clarence Mitchell, who was a lobbyist for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. He once told Hispanic leaders, "Blacks were dying for the right to vote when you people couldn't decide whether you were Caucasians."
The strain between the two largest minority groups is tinged with mutual distrust and tempered by mutual need. Both sides know that the political power of the rainbow coalition envisioned in recent Presidential election years cannot be fully harnessed without cooperation. Blacks realize that their numbers will soon be overshadowed by Hispanic population gains. Hispanic leaders are all too aware that the cultural diversity and large immigrant population within their own ranks has prevented the kind of unity that black politics has mustered and that they need.
The riot in the Mount Pleasant neighborhood of the nation's capital last month was only the latest manifestation of the racial tension. The disturbance, touched off when a black policewoman wounded a knife-wielding Salvadoran immigrant, was accompanied by charges from Hispanic leaders that the city's largely black political power structure ignores Hispanic needs.
Washington is not alone. Across the country, the two groups are vying for political power and competing for ever-shrinking funds for education, employment, health care and housing programs.
 
The Different Agendas
 For example, though Hispanic residents make up about 20 percent of Chicago's population, only 2.2 percent of the apartments managed by the Chicago Housing Authority have Hispanic tenants. By comparison, blacks lease 86.8 percent of the apartments, though they make up about 40 percent of the city's population.
 On the Federal level, blacks, who make up 12.1 percent of the population nationwide, hold 17.8 percent of the jobs in the civilian work force. But Hispanic Americans, who are roughly 9 percent of the population, hold only 5.1 percent. Hispanic leaders say this results in skewed enforcement of civil rights laws. They note that only 5 percent of the discrimination charges filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in 1989 involved Hispanic complainants.
The two groups have also clashed over the redrawing of district lines for Federal and local offices in New York, Chicago, Houston and Los Angeles. Last year, a dispute over immigration law almost resulted in the walkout of Hispanic groups from the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, the main lobbying arm of the civil rights movement. Only last-minute pleading by Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the N.A.A.C.P., prevented the action. But Mr. Hooks plays down the notion that there is a problem. "People keep stirring up stuff that wasn't happening," he said.
Raul Yzaguirre, president of the National Council of La Raza, the largest Hispanic civil rights organization, and many others disagree. "It's not a question of potential problems," he said. "They're happening all over the country."
Indeed, last July a group of black and Hispanic scholars and political leaders met at Harvard University to privately air differences. "Hispanics believe that blacks embrace the rhetoric, but not the values promoted by the civil rights movement," Charles Kamasaki, vice president of the National Council of La Raza told the gathering.
To several blacks at the session such statements were an eerie echo of complaints they made years ago about white liberals. "I felt very sympathetic with the frustrations and aspirations that were voiced," said Christopher Edley Jr., a Harvard Law School professor who is black. "But it is also clear that many blacks will feel uncomfortable that a group which had been junior partners becomes co-equals, if not more."
Nevertheless, the subject is being addressed in more and more forums. At a meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors in San Diego this weekend, Mayor W. Wilson Goode of Philadelphia said that he and other big city mayors should help other minority groups gain political influence.
"It's very difficult to open the doors overnight," he said. But he added: "All of us need to do some soul-searching about how we use our offices for inclusion."
To some conservatives the stresses between the two groups are a logical result of civil rights laws that they say seek to enshrine a concept of proportional representation in employment and political power. "I think that the civil rights laws really now play into the hands of raw racial politics," said Clint Bolick, director of the Landmark Legal Center for Civil Rights, a conservative public policy organization.
Others assert that the laws have simply provided the opportunity to compete for power.
"The Irish and Italians battled it out in Boston and New York over who would dominate the police force and ward politics," said Professor Edley. "It had nothing to do with affirmative action. It's just a historical phenomenon of urban life that groups compete. I think it's a sign of political progress."

HEADLINE: The World;
Yeltsin's Gain in Clout Is Dramatic, But Gorbachev Still Has the Real Power

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
FOR all the excitement and familiar trap pings of the race the whirlwind campaign tours, multiple candidates, rich promises and even dirty tricks -- the presidential election in the Russian Federation last week was still not a presidential election in the Western sense.
 For one thing, it was not exactly clear what powers Boris N. Yeltsin had gained and what he could do with them. For another, it was still an election only in one constituent republic, even if this one happened to comprise three-fourths of the Soviet Union and half its people. 
 None of this took away from the importance of the election as a dramatic step in the fascinating process through which democracy is struggling to be born in the Soviet land. By giving 60 percent of their vote to Mr. Yeltsin despite a determined challenge from the Communists, Russian voters handed the champion of decentralization and democratization a potent mandate in his struggle against stubborn rear-guard actions from the "center." Perhaps more significant, they moved one step closer toward overcoming Russia's ancient tradition of government as a dispensation from on high.
But to appreciate what the election was, it is important first to understand what it was not.
The Russian presidency was conceived more as a political maneuver than as a democratic institution. Mr. Yeltsin proposed the office for much the same reason that Mikhail S. Gorbachev created an all-union presidency last fall, to give the chief executive some independence from a quarrelsome and ponderous parliament. The main difference was that Mr. Gorbachev had himself elected by the Supreme Soviet, while Mr. Yeltsin, confident of his popularity, went to the voters.
But in the improvisational and evolutionary game of Soviet politics, it is still not clear what powers and levers of national sovereignty Mr. Yeltsin won. Already as president of the Russian parliament he could issue decrees and had announced a program of radical economic change. Often, though, these steps were undone by the Kremlin.
So even with added clout from his new mandate and title, Mr. Yeltsin's authority is likely to remain ill-defined and incomplete until Russia and other constituent republics reach a satisfactory union agreement with Mr. Gorbachev and the center, clearly delineating constitutional responsibilities and powers.
Meanwhile, it is still Mr. Gorbachev who holds the ultimate reins over the military, the K.G.B. and most national assets. Significant as it was as a first for Russia, the election was not yet the national election that reformers, with Mr. Yeltsin at their head, have increasingly demanded of Mr. Gorbachev.
 Mr. Yeltsin's victory may have prompted President Bush to invite him to the White House, but it is still Mr. Gorbachev and the center who will have the last word on the "Grand Bargain" to exchange Western dollars for Soviet reforms, as proposed last week by an unofficial team of Soviet and American economic experts.
All this, however, is not to say that the Russian election was no more than an elaborate referendum. The very fact that the Communists fought Mr. Yeltsin so fiercely gave the voting national significance and imbued his victory with tangible political authority.
 Mr. Yeltsin had clearly demonstrated his popularity, had insulated himself from the wiles of the hostile Communist bloc in the Russian parliament, and had collected a new mandate for the contest with Mr. Gorbachev over the shape and identity of the evolving Soviet state.
 
A Truce
 That long struggle arrived at a truce in late April when both realized that Mr. Yeltsin's popularity neutralized Mr. Gorbachev's powers and vice versa. The feud showed that no economic reform, no matter how bold or well conceived, could take hold without political stability.
The truce, reached between Mr. Gorbachev and leaders of nine republics, opened the way to negotiating a new union treaty. Mr. Gorbachev seems to accept that in these talks the republics will be recognized as sovereign and will themselves determine what responsibilities to cede to the central government.
All through Soviet history, power has flowed only in one direction, from the Kremlin down through the ministries and party organizations, the K.G.B., the 15 constituent republics and on to the lowly citizen in whose name it was all done. Rights or privileges were bestowed from above -- and withdrawn at will.
Mr. Gorbachev's initial concept of perestroika was largely an enlightened variation on the theme: a new, more liberal dispensation from the center. But whenever his creation has tried to assert a life of its own, Mr. Gorbachev has acted in the paternalistic tradition he was reared in, trying to rein in his willful child.
 More than any other leader, Mr. Yeltsin has come to represent that enfant terrible. Armed with a keen political instinct and a populist touch, he has learned to harness the popular forces unleashed by perestroika to defy and challenge Mr. Gorbachev at every turn, steadily chipping at the center's powers.
The process has been frustrating and dangerous at times, and may yet have its twists and turns. But its effect has been the gradual reinvention of democracy in a land with pitifully little experience of it. Perhaps there is a lesson of history that many forgot in the early euphoria of perestroika -- that democratic institutions and traditions do not spring up full grown, but must grow organically from perceived needs and political struggle. Such was the Russian presidency. Conceived as a political maneuver, its consequences not really known, it still served as a significant step in the evolution of a new social contract.
It is unlikely that Mr. Gorbachev was too happy with the outcome, given his antipathy to Mr. Yeltsin. But as an astute politician, he may recognize that he too may have won. It was his truce with Mr. Yeltsin, more than anything else, that set off the events leading to his invitation to London, where the major industrial powers will meet next month.
In the longer term, the election appears likely to accelerate the drive toward a new union treaty and the first free election of a truly national leader in the Soviet Union. Should Mr. Gorbachev win that, he could end up with far more real authority than he now has, trying to hold together the rump of a discredited and rotten dictatorship.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Boris Yeltsin, who easily won the Russian republic's presidential election with 60 percent of the vote, greeting supporters last week before voting in Moscow. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: The Region;
Bridgeport Declares It Can't Go It Alone

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, CONN.

 BODY:
BY resorting to bankruptcy court June 6, this city, located in one of the wealthiest counties in the nation, issued a declaration of dependence: Bridgeport's problems were no longer its alone, but also those of its suburban neighbors and the state.
Last week the city's aldermen furthered that declaration by raising property taxes much less than needed to balance its $319.4 million budget. If Bridgeport succeeds in filing for bankruptcy it intends to operate at a deficit, in defiance of the state financial review board that has supervised the city for the last three years. 
 The court will decide next month whether this community of 141,800, Connecticut's largest city, can claim protection under Chapter 9 of the Federal bankruptcy laws. In papers filed Wednesday, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said the city lost its right to seek protection when it accepted the review board's authority in 1988 in return for help in selling bonds to cover a $60 million deficit.
One goal of Bridgeport's bankruptcy is to escape the review board's authority and its requirement of a balanced budget, which would mean either raising the property-tax rate, already the highest in the state, by 18 percent; or ending garbage collection and laying off police officers. The budget already eliminates street cleaning and other programs.
Another immediate goal is to use bankruptcy to renegotiate union contracts Bridgeport considers "onerous and economically burdensome," according to the bankruptcy papers. But many state and local officials say such a course was unnecessary. Some unions had already offered concessions, but Mayor Mary C. Moran could not, or did not want to, follow through.
"She's seen fit to have unions seen as those who are really bankrupting the city," said Cesar A. Batalla, a review board member and president of the city's Puerto Rican Coalition, a civil-rights group. "But they never ran the city."
Everyone agrees on the more distant goal of stabilizing the tax rate to stem the flight of businesses and the middle class, and being able to compete with suburban communities for new jobs. In particular Bridgeport sees its Long Island Sound waterfront as a site for more marinas, shops and middle-class housing, instead of the sewage plants, public housing projects and closed factories that dominate it now.
"We're hoping, as things develop, that the burden of taxes will shift from the residential to business, commercial and industrial," said Luca Cardozo, an administrative aide to the Mayor.
Such stabilization, however, would require Bridgeport and other cities to succeed where they failed in this spring's legislative session in Hartford: they must change how Connecticut, with its system of strong home rule, views cities and suburbs essentially as equals.
The cities want the state to stop mandating programs it fails to finance. They also want it to provide more tax relief and school aid and to move toward regional solutions to affordable housing and other problems that concentrate the poor in cities.
Those problems often result in a stark contrast between Bridgeport and its suburbs. Much of it is economic: in 1987, the last year for which census data are available, per capita income was $10,534 in Bridgeport, $20,954 in Fairfield and $18,712 in Trumbull. Connecticut's average was $16,094.
 
A Second Parachute, of a Sort
 The disparity in wealth carries over to property. Bridgeport's tax rolls, which haven't grown in two years, total $2.302 billion, less than the $2.34 billion in neighboring Fairfield, a suburb with only 53,400 residents. One result is Bridgeport's tax rate is twice as high.
Because Connecticut has no regional government, the area's homeless shelters, drug-treatment centers, public housing, hospitals and other services are almost all in Bridgeport, using the city's streets and sewers, fire and police, yet paying no taxes. The city has 22,800 residents on welfare, or 15 percent of the population.
On Thursday the financial review board ordered Bridgeport to balance its budget and threatened more legal action if it did not.
 Officials in New Haven, which is considered to be right behind Bridgeport in fiscal crisis, vow not to follow suit. New Haven has a stronger economic base, said its chief administrative officer, Douglas Rae, who is on leave from Yale, where he is a political science professor. New Haven often complains of Yale's nonprofit status, but Yale provides a solid employment base, he said. Its corporations pay a larger share of the taxes than in Bridgeport, where homeowners pay 70 percent.
New Haven is like a parachutist who has just pulled the string on his first parachute, Mr. Rae said. Bridgeport "pulled its first parachute and it didn't work," he said. "Now it's pulled its second."

HEADLINE: The World;
Displaced in the Gulf War: 5 Million Refugees

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER

 BODY:
IT took Iraqi soldiers less than four hours to cross the 80 miles of desert between Iraq and Kuwait City last Aug. 2. But that audacious move set off what is now regarded as one of history's largest, fastest and most widespread migrations. While the statistics are still being compiled, American officials and representatives of international relief organizations estimate that at least 5 million people from more than 30 countries have been temporarily or permanently displaced by the crisis in the Persian Gulf.
"A world on the move" was how one State Department refugee official characterized the migration. Another official, Princeton N. Lyman, Director of the State Department's Bureau for Refugee Programs, called the displacement, particularly the phase caused by Iraq's civil warfare this spring, "a human tragedy of tremendous proportions." And Court Robinson, a senior research analyst at the U.S. Committee for Refugees, a private, nonprofit group in Washington, said, "This was surely one of the largest migrations ever; I can't recall an instance in which so many people moved in so short a time." 
Until the last disastrous phase of the migration, there were no epidemics and few displacement-related deaths. "The people who fled Iraq and Kuwait for Jordan soon after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait were horribly confused and disoriented by their sudden plunge from middle-class status to instant poverty," said Philippe L. Boulle, director of the New York office of the United Nations Disaster Relief Organization. "But unlike migrants in Africa, they were physically strong enough to withstand a few days of poor conditions. As a result, virtually no one died."
The people who fled in March during the Iraqi civil war were less fortunate. The State Department says that at least 6,700 Iraqis, most of them Kurds, died in Turkish refugee camps near the border. In addition, the image remains of hundreds of thousands of Iraqis, again mostly Kurds, who did not reach those camps and were stranded on wintry mountain roads stretching 165 miles into harsh, remote terrain -- a "logistics nightmare," said Mr. Lyman. No one will ever know just how many of these terrified, desperate people, mired in a mixture of mud and excrement, died of hunger or exposure. Doctors Without Borders, the French group of volunteer doctors, estimated that at the peak of the crisis, 1,000 Kurds a day were dying.
The relatively low death rate throughout most of the crisis is attributed to a fast and well coordinated international relief effort. James N. Purcell Jr., director general of the Geneva-based International Organization for Migration, said his group airlifted more than 200,000 people to about a dozen countries with no loss of life. Countries throughout the world have contributed about $1.35 billion in emergency aid.
 
Economic Misery
 Though the death rate was low, the first-wave migrants have faced not only debts, but the loss of back wages, unemployment compensation and abandoned savings, says a report issued last month by the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, a privately funded human rights group. "They were often abused and discriminated against in the gulf," said Arthur C. Helton, of the Lawyers Committee. "But despite this, they've lost jobs they will never find at home" Their own countries, most of them poor, have also paid heavily in the loss of foreign exchange and remittances, slowing of economic growth, and the addition of burdens to school and social-service systems that have often strained them beyond capacity.
Officials in Bangladesh, for example, estimate that a million dependents relied on the incomes of about 110,000 Bangladeshis who worked in Kuwait and Iraq, and that these people and their country, one of the world's poorest, have lost at least $45 million in revenues; in addition, the Government spent $36 million to bring stranded workers home. Before the invasion of Kuwait, Pakistanis throughout the Middle East had been sending home between $1 billion and $2 billion a year, and about 15 percent of this had been coming from 160,000 workers in Kuwait and Iraq.
Officials break the migration into three phases that correspond roughly to before, during, and after the gulf war. During the first wave, from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 until the American-led coalition attacked Iraq in January, more than 1.5 million people fled Iraq, Kuwait and other gulf countries. They included some 700,000 Egyptians, 380,000 Kuwaitis, 250,000 Palestinians or Jordanians and more than 350,000 Asians, most of them from India, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh and the Philippines. More than 700,000 of them left through Jordan, which initially was overwhelmed but within weeks organized an effective relief campaign.
In addition, about one million Yemenis fled back to Yemen from Saudi Arabia, which strongly encouraged their departure after the Yemeni Government criticized the Saudis for inviting American forces to defend them.
Having been unprepared for the first onslaught of dispossessed, relief organizations were determined to be ready for a second. In early January, they appealed for money to feed, house and transport up to 400,000 additional refugees in the event of war. Millions of dollars were raised to build mobile camps in Syria, Turkey, Iran and Jordan.
 
Surprises
 But from January to mid-March, only 65,000 people fled, about 35,000 of them Iraqis who went to Iran and 28,000 of them Asians or people from other Middle Eastern countries.
What few anticipated -- and hence, no one adequately prepared for -- was the third, most devastating wave of flight, triggered in late March by Iraq's civil war. "More than two million people got up and left their homes in less than six days," Mr. Robinson said.
In late March and early April, the United Nations estimated, 1.5 million Kurds abruptly left for Turkey and Iran. Most have returned, but not necessarily to their homes. The State Department estimates that of the 1.2 million Iraqis known to have fled to Iran -- all but 100,000 of them Kurds -- 500,000 are still in Iran and need help. In addition, Iran says 700,000 to 800,000 Shiite Muslims from Iraq have entered Iran or have sought refuge in marshes near the border, but this has not been independently confirmed.
While most of those displaced in the first wave reached their home countries within a month, people are still dribbling out of the region. Some 2,500 of the more than 16,000 Vietnamese who were working in Iraq showed up last week in a recently erected tent city in Syria. And Jordanian officials recently reported that thousands of cold and hungry people who had been stranded for days at a desert border camp between Iraq and Jordan had been ordered to return to Baghdad -- to obtain exit visas.

HEADLINE: The Region;
Cuomo Lobs 384 Balls Back to the Legislature

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
GOV. MARIO M. CUOMO'S veto of 384 items from the state budget last week led many politicians in Albany to one of two conclusions. Assemblyman William B. Hoyt, a Buffalo Democrat, said the Governor was trying to reassert himself as "the dominant muscular figure in Albany." Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat, saw the move less as a demonstration of power politics than as the latest volley in a grand "philosophical battle" over the role of state government.
Both interpretations ring true. 
 In striking $937 million in spending from the budget passed by the Legislature on June 4, Mr. Cuomo used an unusually bold maneuver to take control of the budget process he had abandoned a month earlier.
So rarely has Mr. Cuomo used the full force of his office and personality to box in the Legislature that lawmakers were actually stunned when the vetoes were announced on Monday, even though the press had been forecasting the Governor's decision for days.
Deep disagreement over how to spread the pain inflicted by a $6.5 billion budget gap caused the record 65-day delay in passing the $51.9 billion budget. Legislators, who are held accountable by voters for the level of state aid granted to local governments and organizations, agreed that the brunt of the cuts should fall on the state bureaucracy. Mr. Cuomo, who must answer to disgruntled state workers and users of state services, wanted local governments to shoulder an equal burden.
Outraged by the Legislature's cuts of more than $250 million from state agencies, Mr. Cuomo indiscriminately vetoed spending from the programs that legislators hold dearest, including $412 million in state aid to school districts and $145 million in revenue sharing for local governments.
Mr. Cuomo regularly takes credit for increasing the share of state spending that goes to local governments, to 65 percent in 1990 from 60 percent when he took office in 1983. But he made it clear with his vetoes that he could tolerate only so much damage to the state agencies, including the state police, Office of Mental Health and the Department of Transportation.
The legislative response to the vetoes, meanwhile, showed that the Republican-led Senate and the Democratic-led Assembly have forged an alliance to preserve state aid to municipalities.
 Assembly Speaker Mel Miller charged that Mr. Cuomo, who frequently blames the Federal Government for shifting the burden of taxation to the states, was guilty of shifting the same burden to local governments.
"We tried to avoid copying the Federal trend of shifting responsibilities to local governments without providing the resources to support those responsibilities," said Mr. Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat. "Unfortunately, the Governor has chosen a different course for state government to follow."
The Governor replied that the Legislature's argument about the proper role of government did not disguise the real intent of lawmakers -- to win the largest possible share of state aid for their constituents. Legislators from both parties, he said, had refused to reform their habits to reflect the economic reality of the times. The Senate Republicans, with their power base on Long Island, insisted on maintaining high levels of school aid. The Assembly Democrats, with their base in New York City, resisted cuts in Medicaid and welfare programs that would disproportionately harm the city, where most recipients live.
The Governor ridiculed the Legislature's priorities, particularly its decision to spend $60 million on pork-barrel "members items" -- including the promotion of the seafood industry and the building of sound barriers near busy highways -- at the same time it was cutting more than $250 million from vital state agencies.
 There was a broad speculation in Albany about why the Governor chose to veto virtually everything he could. Some were convinced that Mr. Cuomo sincerely believed that the Legislature had passed a budget that was $899 million out of balance. Others said, and the Governor essentially conceded as much, that Mr. Cuomo was using the vetoes to reopen negotiations with the Legislature to win back hundreds of millions of dollars that had been cut from his agencies.
Those who analyze every gubernatorial act for evidence of Presidential intent saw the vetoes as an attempt by Mr. Cuomo to shed an image of gubernatorial weakness and profligacy.
"I heard the people talking about treachery and disloyalty and complicated political motivations, running for President, moving to the right, all the schemes," Mr. Cuomo said. "I heard it all, and it's not pleasant to hear."
Whatever his motives, the Governor's strategy seemed to be working. He convinced the legislative leaders to delay considering an override of his vetoes until after the state completes a $3.9 billion borrowing on June 21.
And on Wednesday, the chance for an override in any event diminished greatly when the Assembly minority leader, Clarence D. Rappleyea Jr., announced that the Assembly Republicans would not provide needed votes.
The Legislature doesn't need to override the Governor to answer the challenge of his vetoes; it can simply pass new spending bills at any time. But the maneuvering did suggest that Mr. Cuomo would at least succeed in drawing the Legislature back to the negotiating table, where political victory will be measured by whose philosophy of government prevails and by who shows the most muscle.

HEADLINE: Revolving Accounts;
Are Banks Going Down the Same Path As S.& L.'s?

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AT a time when "savings and loan" has become synonymous with "bottomless pit," warnings last week that the nation's banking system faced worsening problems had an eerie familiarity.
Here was L. William Seidman, who heads both the savings and loan system's bailout and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, once again raising his estimate of the number of banks that are likely to fail and place additional strains on the Government-backed insurance fund that protects deposits. The "pessimistic scenario" that he called unlikely in January is now playing itself out, he said. As many as 440 banks may fail this year and in 1992, costing the insurance fund $23 billion and leaving it with a deficit of nearly $6 billion next year. 
 Parallels to the savings and loan crisis are already being drawn. Steadily worsening reports drip out on the condition of a Government-backed deposit insurance fund. Regulators concede they have not always moved promptly enough to shut down institutions, such as the Bank of New England, and contain their cost. And critics say that the Band-aid solutions being applied, in the form of Treasury borrowing, will do no more than postpone the inevitable bill to taxpayers until after Election Day 1992.
"We're in the grand denial phase, just like 1987 and 1988, when Congress and the Administration did nothing about savings and loans," said Walker Todd, a lawyer who is on leave from the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland to write a book about the Federal Reserve Board.
Between honest differences of opinion and the imperatives of politics, it is difficult to find a consensus on exactly how much trouble the banking system is in and what is likely to happen. Charles A. Bowsher, the Comptroller General, said last week that the industry would probably not be able to pay the Government back if the insurance fund had to borrow the $70 billion from the Treasury that the Bush Administration has said might be needed.
 
Most Make Money
 To be sure, most American banks are posting profits, but a major problem remains: too many of the biggest banks have made too many of the worst loans, resulting in huge losses and longterm weakness.
On Capitol Hill, where the House banking committee is to begin drafting legislation Wednesday to lend billions of dollars of taxpayer money to the battered deposit insurance fund, lawmakers are running scared.
No incumbent sees anything to gain politically by voting to put more public funds at risk, although everyone recognizes something has to be done to avoid further damage to the nation's financial system. Many members blame themselves as much as the regulators and the Reagan Administration for the savings and loan debacle -- Congress, after all, approved the industry's deregulation -- and they see the possibility of a repeat performance.
"It's hard to have any confidence in Congress," said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa. "Everyone is bracing themselves for more bad news. The membership in general looks at this with a jaundiced eye."
President Bush, who met separately last week with House and Senate leaders to jawbone on behalf of his legislation, is trying to use the plight of the insurance fund as the engine to pull a trainload of structural changes to the banking system.
 
Obfuscation?
 Mr. Bush's sweeping plan would free the industry of decades-old restrictions that prevent banks from expanding into new businesses and across state lines.
Some say that the Bush proposals obscure the real problem and would merely hide the industry's difficulties -- and the taxpayers' exposure -- until after the 1992 elections. They also maintain that allowing banks to go into new and riskier businesses would simply add to the industry's woes.
"The Administration is so caught up in its grandiose plans for bank restructuring that it is willing to gamble with the deposit insurance fund," said Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who heads the House banking committee. "At the moment, the Administration seems quite willing to rearrange the chairs on the deck of the Titanic while money and confidence flow out of the deposit insurance system."
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has said that if Congress rejects the Administration's proposal, a taxpayer bailout will be necessary. But those opposed to the legislation say Mr. Brady is merely attempting to pressure Congress and to be in a position to blame Capitol Hill if the lawmakers reject the measure and a disaster follows.
Few are predicting that the banking industry's problems will cost the taxpayers as much as the $130 billion that the Administration says it needs to rescue savings and loans (the General Accounting Office estimates that over 40 years the total bailout cost could be as high as $500 billion). There is general agreement that a banking bailout could cost between $25 billion and $50 billion.
But the news last week from Mr. Seidman, the chairman of the F.D.I.C., was in some ways the worst since the agency was created during the Great Depression. While most of the nation's 12,900 banks are in good shape, the 1,028 teetering ones include some of the largest American banks ever to be in such shaky condition. Federal regulators refuse to identify troubled banks for fear of creating a panic, but financial analysts do so routinely, and those that are publicly traded are readily identifiable by their relatively low share prices.
Most are in the Northeast and Texas, but there are signs that California may be the next region to face a banking crisis.
The latest figures indicate that more than 6 percent of all construction and development loans in the West are delinquent, an early warning signal, according to Mr. Seidman, that the region could be in for harder times. In the Middle West, currently the healthiest region for banks, construction loan delinquencies are running at about half the California rate. The figures also show that among the nation's largest institutions, a whopping 16 percent of all construction and development loans have gone sour.
"You don't need thousands of banks to fail to face a crisis," said James R. Barth, a professor at Auburn University and formerly an economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. "You could have relatively few big ones and the costs would be enormous. That's the difference from the s.& l.'s. Nobody can look at the bank insurance fund and say, 'By God, there are ample reserves to handle these large troubled banks.' This should be maddening to taxpayers."
What's more, regulators have begun to believe that even though the economy is pulling out of the recession, it is not carrying the sick banks with it. Their crisis rests with the commercial real estate markets, which experts say could take years to turn around, and may hardly be affected by a recovery that many economists predict will be sluggish.
 "Most banks are doing better," Mr. Seidman said last week. "But the troubled banks are not doing better. And clearly, the big problems are at the bigger banks."
By the F.D.I.C.'s reckoning, if Congress does nothing, the bank insurance fund, which only four years ago was $18.3 billion, will be in the red by almost $6 billion next year. What makes the report so unsettling is that the F.D.I.C.'s forecasts have been less reliable than the typical weather man, generally erring on the side of optimism.
Each new estimate over the last year has predicted a darker gathering storm, and the regulators themselves say the numbers are only their best guess, even though they are based on the most reliable information available from the banks themselves. Mr. Seidman once predicted a profit for the F.D.I.C. in 1991, meaning it would take in more in premiums than it paid out in claims. Now he says it could be a year of record losses.
"Their forecasts have been ostrich-like," said Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution.
Nor would it be particularly reassuring if the industry is able to repay the loans that will be taken from Treasury. The increase in bank premiums to pay off the borrowing will inevitably be passed on to the public in the form of higher fees and lower returns. The losses will also be felt by bank shareholders.
"You can't get the money to cover the losses out of thin air," said John G. Medlin Jr., chairman of the First Wachovia Corporation of Winston-Salem, N.C. "It will have to come from customers and from shareholders."
Ultimately, Mr. Medlin said, the industry's plight will not be resolved by Washington, but by the banks themselves.
"The basic problems of banks are risk management, not what the regulators or the members of Congress are doing," he said. "It's what the managers of the banks are doing, and they have to be more careful about who they are lending money to."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 6; Column 1; Week In Review Desk

HEADLINE: The Region;
New York City's School Spending: New Math

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
THE New York City school system is often pictured as something of a high roller among the nation's school districts, but a series of recent reports suggests that it spends about as much on each student as other American cities, and is falling behind its own state's average. One major reason is that while New York State's contribution to the city schools has risen, the amount contributed by the city has dropped sharply -- from 24 percent of its tax-levy budget in 1982 to 16.87 percent in 1991.
These disparities were one reason board officials were pleased last week that Mayor David N. Dinkins named H. Carl McCall, a Citibank vice president who served six years as a state senator, to the seven-member board. Mr. Dinkins wants Mr. McCall to become the board's president, an uncertain prospect given the ambitions of the Bronx representative, Ninfa Segarra. 
 But whether Mr. McCall succeeds or not, his contacts and his experience as a consensus builder were widely regarded as long-needed weapons to protect the board's budget against the long knives of fiscally embattled state and city governments. City and state officials are weighing program cuts that would cost the school budget $505 million.
There is, to be sure, an unmeasurable amount of waste in an enterprise of 956,000 pupils, 122,000 workers, 32 school boards and an almost $7 billion budget. Periodic revelations have told of administrators using stationery money to buy themselves office furniture and of computers standing idle in closets.
There are no scholarly measures of how much gets frittered away. Moreover, the schools are troubled by a high, though improving dropout rate. A report last week said that when students are tracked until the age of 21, 29.4 percent drop out, and most students read and calculate below appropriate levels.
But a report by Robert Berne, associate dean of the Wagner School of Public Service at New York University, and Leanna Stiefel, an economics professor there, shows that even with its excesses, New York City spends only 91 percent as much per pupil as the state average, despite its greater burden of poor, handicapped and non-English-speaking students. Fifteen years ago, before the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's, it equaled the state average.
"A student who entered kindergarten in New York City in 1977 received less than three-quarters of the spending of a student in the rest of New York State over the course of the next 13 years," the report asserts.
New York City also did not look as reckless as its legend in a study last month of 10 cities by the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand. The study, conducted for a group of business executives advising the Mayor, found that Yonkers spends $8,598 for each of its pupils; Rochester $7,719; Syracuse, $6,754, and New York only $6,146. New York's per-student spending does exceed Philadelphia's at $5,704 and Los Angeles's at $4,675. But, Mr. Berne notes, this state is a more expensive place to do business.
The board spends so little in part because it receives comparatively meager financing from its parent city. Buffalo spends 46.85 percent of its tax-levy budget on schools and Baltimore 24.4 percent while New York City spends only 16.87 percent.
"It is difficult to make an argument that expenditures per pupil are high," Mr. Berne said. "Teacher salaries are below the state average, class size is above the state average and the city spends less on administration than other districts in the state.
 
Catholic Schools
 Even the perennial contrast between New York's schools and those run by the Roman Catholic Church may not be as glaring as commonly characterized.
The argument is often made that schools in the Archdiocese of New York, which includes not only Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island but also seven northern counties, spend a fourth as much per pupil -- $1,735 compared to $7,107 -- as public schools do. Yet, they have smaller classes and higher graduation rates.
School officials and scholars like Mr. Berne say that Catholic schools seem frugal partly because a hefty share of their costs is borne by the public system.
After a recent article in Time magazine replayed the differences, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez wrote a letter arguing that the board's per-pupil costs were artificially inflated by the money it spends on Catholic schools. That includes funds for 30,000 daily lunches at 130 Catholic schools, for bus transportation for remedial reading and mathematics programs, all by acting as a conduit for Federal and state "pass through" funds.
 Nora Murphy, a spokesman for the archdiocesan schools, acknowledged that remedial, food and busing costs are not included in her schools' per-pupil average. But she argues that even if the archdiocese did count these costs there would still be a sharp discrepancy.
Scholars like Mr. Berne say that the contrast would still be tempered somewhat by understanding that roughly 20 percent of Catholic school teachers are nuns, priests and brothers paid stipends of about $15,000 and that lay teachers earn salaries ranging from $19,300 to $25,500. Public-school teachers, by comparison, start at $26,700 and earn as much as $52,750.
Public schools can't choose whom they educate. They must take all handicapped and troubled students, the most expensive because they require more teachers and counselors. New York spends $1.5 billion -- almost one quarter of its budget -- on 119,000 children classified as handicapped, though a majority may be lagging readers and behavior problems.

HEADLINE: Beauty;
Expensive Habits

BYLINE: BY PENELOPE GREEN

 BODY:
EVEN IF WE'RE IN THE THROES OF A RECESSION, THERE are still folks who may find it difficult to recede from habits ingrained during the last decade.
Not to worry, though. Those totems of conspicuous consumption -- cashmere, caviar, pearls, gold -- are now available in bottled form. For those who can no longer afford a $1,000 cashmere sweater set, there's always cashmere mascara, $13.50 from Christian Dior. If the gold market's got you down, Divinaura, a "beauty enhancer" from Guerlain, comes flecked with bits of gold at a mildly affordable $56 an ounce. Real gold, six milligrams of 24-karat gold in each bottle, enough to make a prospector sweat.
Here's how a few luxe-laced products match up with the pricey commodities from which they take their inspiration:
Guerlain Divinaura (remember, there are six milligrams of gold in there, a mini-lode that works nicely to make a knee or shoulder gleam): $56 for one ounce. One troy ounce of gold, roughly 31 grams, traded for $363 the other day. At $363 for 31 grams, six milligrams would set you back about 7 cents.
La Prairie Skin Caviar (O.K., it's not real caviar, just salmon-roe-sized beads of allantoin and other moisturizing elements. But still, "when the beads were submitted by our development team," says Aileen Rowland, chief operating officer of the company, "what did they look like? Caviar!"): $90 for two ounces. Beluga caviar at the Petrossian Boutique in Manhattan: $69.50 for one-sixteenth of an ounce.
Mascara Parfait from Christian Dior: Thickening Lash Care with Cashmere (real cashmere, and "it's great because no goats are killed," says Nancy Tessmer, advertising and public relations assistant at the company): $13.50. Short-sleeved cashmere T-shirt at Cashmere Cashmere in Manhattan: $275.
Hydra Perles Hydro-Protective Day Cream from Yves Saint Laurent (these aren't bona fide pearls, but "perfluorine pearls, silicone pearls and aqueous pearls"): $40 for one ounce. Thirty-inch single strands of cultured pearls at Mikimoto in Manhattan start at $1,500.
While I doubt that the cosmetics companies were thinking in these terms, the deployment of luxury goods as ingredients is a great gimmick -- one that conjures up all the ghosts of the 80's, but without any scary consequences. Still, if you're the sort that prefers to tough out tough times, perhaps the new men's cologne Recession (for "the man who used to have everything") is more the ticket. "The economy stinks," reads the legend on the package. "You shouldn't have to."

HEADLINE: A Persistent American Yearning

BYLINE: By James Reston; James Reston is the former executive editor and Washington columnist for The New York Times. This article is adapted from his memoir, "Deadline: Our Times and The New York Times," to be published in October by Random House.

 BODY:
THE LAST DECADE OF A CENTURY IS A TEMPTING TIME FOR PRESIDENTS, journalists, end-of-the-world preachers and other dreamers. Presidents in particular begin meditating on their place in history, and wondering how to make it look a little better than it was. George Washington made his famous farewell address in the last decade of the 18th century, and foresaw safety and prosperity for the new Republic in isolation from the quarrels of the world. In the last decade of the 19th century, President McKinley was not thinking of isolation (or of his sudden death soon to come), but was planning a new American empire and leading the country into the Spanish-American War. And at the beginning of the last decade of the 20th, George Herbert Walker Bush, the 41st President, was proclaiming the dawn of a "new world order," and starting it with a war against Iraq in the Middle East. 
 After studying the fortunetellers of the past, I admired their bravery more than their judgment. In the 1890's, the best of them were writing confidently about a future world of "inevitable progress." They were convinced that there was something in the nature of the universe, or maybe in the economics of supply and demand, or in the spread of knowledge and education that would surely lead to the Golden Age. By the time I arrived in Washington two world wars later, however, the pessimists had taken over, with books deploring "The Decline of the West" (Spengler), "The End of Our Time" (Berdyaev) and "The Fate of Homo Sapiens" (H. G. Wells).
All of their guesses were interesting, but most of them were wrong, for the world changed faster than they could change their minds. Some chalky genius, monkeying around in a laboratory or a garage, was always discovering how people could fly like birds, or send messages, pictures and even the music of Beethoven through space, or extract more food from the bounteous earth, or wipe out disease or go to the moon. These thinkers and tinkerers invented not only a better mousetrap but also a better mouse, named Mickey, who went into the movies and made children happy. They also developed new ways to kill more people, with atom bombs, but the human race just went on producing more children by the same delightful old-fashioned process anyway.
I admired the optimistic spirit behind President Bush's new world order, but I couldn't find much new in it other than his war in the Middle East. He vowed it would assure "for ourselves and for future generations" an Age of Peace, "where the rule of law, not the law of the jungle, governs the conduct of nations." I was all for George, but I thought this sounded very much like the pronouncements of other Presidents, particularly those of Woodrow Wilson, who thought not only that America could "change the world" but also that it had a moral duty to do so.
There was, I thought, something both wonderful and goofy about all this persistent American determination to reform the world. It reminded me of the little signs that used to hang in some of the service stores in Dayton, Ohio, when I was a boy. I forget the exact words, but they promised to do anything "possible" by tomorrow but conceded that the "impossible" might take a few days longer. This was the spirit that had conquered the American continent, survived the great economic depression of the 30's, helped restore Western Europe and Japan after World War II and survived the cold war with the Soviet Union for almost half a century.
But before you could say Saddam Hussein or even Yasir Arafat, President Bush had sent half a million Americans to the Middle East battlefield when Congress wasn't looking, and chased the Iraqis out of Kuwait in four days. It was a perfect American war: quick, flashy and all on television. More Americans were murdered at home during those four days than were killed in the war. President Bush called it, without undue modesty, the greatest military victory in the history of the Republic, and scarcely mentioned the 150,000 Iraqis who were slaughtered in the process.
Accordingly, I began to wonder about these wars to end war, and think that maybe old John Adams had a better idea. Adams said at the end of the 18th century that America should always try to help other nations in trouble, but he added that we should "go not abroad seeking monsters to destroy." In my years in the capital, however, we were finding monsters all over the world, not only big-league monsters in the Soviet Union and China but bush-league monsters in Korea, Vietnam, Cuba, Nicaragua, El Salvador, Panama, Iraq and various other places that didn't want our advice about freedom and democracy, or even know what the words meant.
No doubt the Iraq war served several useful purposes. It put future aggressors on notice that they could not assume American neutrality. It made clear that the United States regarded the oilfields of the Middle East as "vital" to its security and would not permit them to come under the control of any hostile power. It put an end to the self-doubts that had plagued the nation after its defeat in Vietnam, but this "Vietnam syndrome" was followed by a kind of "Iraq swagger" of boasting that Uncle Sam was No. 1 and would now at last redeem the optimistic visions of Woodrow Wilson and the other prophets of eternal peace.
My optimism didn't go quite that far. I thought the long nightmare of an atomic war was over for the foreseeable future, but I had more modest dreams. I didn't believe in new world orders that relied on fighting wars rather than deterring them, or in United Nations resolutions that "authorized" the United States to do most of the fighting. I believed in collective, not selective, security, and I thought we needed to ask ourselves some questions.
What areas were really "vital" to the security of the United States? Would our schools and slums be high on this list? When and how were we going to make the United States independent of Middle East oil and how? How could we have a new world order without cooperation between the United States and the Soviet Union? When were these giants and the other industrial nations going to control or stop the shipment of advanced military weapons and materials for the production of nuclear, chemical and bacteriological explosives to the shaky gangster nations of the world? In short, where was the end-of-the-century threat to United States security anyway -- abroad or at home?
So every once in a while I mounted my old pulpit at The Times and suggested that the time had come, not for another new world order proclaimed, financed and policed by the United States and started with a war, but for a new American order beginning with a reappraisal of our commitments and resources and a reform of our priorities and decision-making procedures. I wasn't throwing off the disorder of the old world -- it made so much news! -- I just felt it could be improved with a little less fighting and a little more patience, common sense and diplomacy. I may have been wrong about this, but I didn't think it would hurt to review our commitments, keep them in line with our bank balances, pay our debts and prepare our children for the new problems of the coming century.
I thought I knew George Bush fairly well, but I didn't recognize his warrior pose. For years I had been longing for some Gentleman President to come along and set an example of calm thinking and honest talking, and I felt that George Bush was precisely that sort of man. The one I knew had promised "a kinder America" in "a gentler world," and I admired his record. His whole career seemed a preparation for the Presidency. He had more personal experience in Congress, business, military intelligence, war and diplomacy than any other President of my time. He was not an ideologue, having come out of the old Teddy Roosevelt-Col. Henry L. Stimson progressive nonpartisan tradition. I followed his career in the House of Representatives and at the United Nations. My wife, Sally, and I flew around with him during the 1980 Presidential campaign, when he was mocking Ronald Reagan's "voodoo" economics, and I felt sure he would bring a more pragmatic spirit to the White House.
In many ways, he did. On most things, he consulted the leaders of Congress. He abandoned his silly campaign promise of "no new taxes" (when he finally switched, he called the new taxes "revenue enhancement"). He tolerated dissent, and he held almost as many news conferences in his first year in the White House as Ronald Reagan did in the previous eight years. But something happened to him on his way to the White House. He campaigned like Richard Nixon and talked like Lyndon Johnson, saying publicly that Saddam Hussein was "worse than Hitler," and vowing publicly to "kick him in the ass." And when it was said that maybe he was a bit of a "wimp," he disproved it by wandering into two wars in his first two years in office.
He defied the principles of the United Nations when he went to war in Panama to get rid of a dictator named Noriega (again, the personal military approach to foreign policy), then relied on the United Nations principles when he went to war against Iraq, and defended the wars as moral contributions to good over evil.
More important, he talked about "the next American century," and said it was the purpose of the United States to insure the stability and security of the Middle East. "Among the nations of the world, only the United States of America has both the moral standing and the means to back it up," he said. "We are the only nation on this earth that could assemble the forces of peace."
The Republicans used to call this sort of thing "globaloney." Whatever it was, I thought it aroused excessive expectations that would be followed, as usual, by excessive disappointments. After all, most of the events that determined the history of this century -- the collapse of the old empires, the rise of Communism and Nazism, the Great Depression and the cold war -- were not foreseen. Nevertheless, President Bush presumed to talk confidently about his new world order for the next "American century."
There was no doubt that Saddam's brutal aggression deserved to be punished, but there were many places in the world where war might be morally justified but politically unwise. My fear was that this interventionist policy would eventually produce a negative reaction in the United States, weaken the Western alliance, revive the spirit of American isolationism and provoke racial tension among blacks, who made up a disproportionate percentage of the American ground forces.
His 100-hour ground war against Iraq, however, was highly popular. It was short and dramatic. The armed services demonstrated more military foresight and skill in waging the war than the civilian diplomats had shown in preventing it. And the American press decided that nothing short of an economic depression could keep President Bush from being re-elected in 1992.
I AVOIDED THIS GUESSING game, considering all my embarrassing predictions of the past. I thought George Bush was driving into a future he could not foresee, with one eye on the rear-view mirror and the other on the next election. He was, I believe, thinking like an old soldier about the foreign wars of the past, and not thinking much about the health of the nation, or even about the advice of his own doctors to give his fluttery heart a rest.
Before the Iraq war started, I wrote that saying "my President, right or wrong" was like saying "my driver, drunk or sober," but once the bombs started falling on Baghdad and Tel Aviv, the debate ended and the popularity of the President increased, as it did at the beginning of the Korean and Vietnam Wars. Accordingly, I worked on my own idea, not of a new world order, but of a new American order, which, in my imagination, would be planned in the last years of the 90's and put into operation with a fixed deadline of Jan. 1, 2000.
I found that, to my delight and to the despair of my younger friends, the older I got and the less information and energy I had, the more dogmatic I became. My wife greeted this with a melancholy sigh, but I went ahead anyway. The new American order of my imagination didn't contain anything that was not both reasonable and achievable. For example, it would have in place by the first day of the new century an energy program that didn't depend on the oil of the Middle East. I thought this was essential, even if we had to rely on the sun, the wind, atomic energy, taxes and horses. I didn't think this was ideal, but it seemed to me more realistic than counting on peace and sanity in the Middle East.
In my new American order, the world wouldn't be peopled by phantoms, and the objective would be to settle political disputes by negotiation, even with scoundrels, and not by proclaiming another "American century" with Uncle Sam as schoolmaster and chief of the world police. "Let George do it," I told myself, wasn't a policy but a line out of an old musical comedy, which I didn't think would be very popular when the bills came in.
By Deadline Jan. 1, 2000, under my dreamy scheme, both political parties would be in agreement (1) that the main threat to the nation's security came from within and not from abroad; (2) that a strong and modified defense force was essential, and (3) that even America's resources were limited, and should not be squandered on reluctant peoples who would rather fight than eat. I thought that clarity as well as charity begins at home, and therefore that we should cut our military guarantees to the essential minimum and reduce all moral posturing by Congressmen and columnists as much as possible under the First Amendment. (This would, of course, be denounced as the new isolationism, but I thought it was better to be denounced for avoiding unnecessary wars than for fighting them.)
Under my fantasy of a new American order, the two political parties would have an official smoke-filled room, preferably the old Supreme Court chamber in the Capitol, where candidates for the parties' nominations for the Presidency and Vice Presidency would be chosen by party leaders who knew something about character and ability to govern the country. The political parties would, before the election of 2004, I insisted, have abolished the present disgraceful system of campaign financing and arranged for at least six free television debates between the candidates (minus all reporters). They would not eliminate the state primary elections, but would retain the power to veto any turkey or quail proposed in these popularity contests.
On one wall of this smoke-filled room, there would be a portrait of Warren Gamaliel Harding to remind the pros not to make the same mistake again, and on another wall there would be a portrait of Teddy Roosevelt, preferably not on horseback, together with his favorite warning:
"The things that will destroy America are prosperity at any price, peace at any price, safety first instead of duty first, the love of soft living and the get-rich-quick theory of life. This country will not be a permanently good place for us to live unless it's a good place for all of us to live."
I had some other dandy, if not original, ideas: I thought it would help if Presidents and other leaders told the truth, and mentioned the word "sacrifice" once in a while. I didn't think we should amend the Constitution to conform to every popular whim of the day, or try to police the bedrooms of the American people. I thought it was unwise to corner dictators and other wild beasts, and since Presidents were not immortal, I favored Vice Presidents that were as reliable as a spare tire. I was for a longer school year because I was more interested in smart kids than "smart bombs," and I was for voluntary national service by young people to help in the overburdened, overexpensive hospitals, and for a national anthem that anybody could sing, drunk or sober.
Nobody listened to these fantasies, of course, but that's one of the nice things about being over 80: you don't care whether they listen, and even when they do, you can't quite hear what they say.

HEADLINE: More Young Single Men Hang Onto Apron Strings

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS

 BODY:
The rent is low and the utilities are free. There is hot food on the table and clean socks in the drawer. Mom nags a little and dad scowls a lot, but mostly they don't get in the way. And there's money left at the end of the month for the car payment.
Young, single men say these are the reasons they are living with their parents in record numbers, burrowing into the familial nest far more often than women of the same age and circumstance. 
 Facing tough economic times and marrying later, young people of both sexes have been living at home in growing numbers in recent years. But it is men, disproportionately, who are nesting with the folks, while women are more likely to live independently, alone or with roommates of either sex.
 
Nearly 1 of 3 at Home
 A recent Census Bureau survey of marital status and living arrangements shows men and women reacting very differently to the soft job market and soft marriage market. Among 25-to-34-year-olds, 32 percent of single men and 20 percent of single women were living with their parents last year.
There are few hard explanations for the wide disparity between men and women. Demographers speculate that men find living at home more attractive than women do because they are less skilled at setting up their own households, enjoy the pampering of their mothers and suffer virtually no loss of independence. Divorce rates are rising among parents, and mothers who would otherwise be living alone may value the protection and companionship of an adult son.
Until 1990, the Census Bureau did not specify marital status when tabulating those who lived at home in its annual survey of living arrangements. But demographers say they have every reason to believe the 1990 figures for single people are the highest ever.
And census figures for the total pool of young adults, married and single, show a dramatic shift in male behavior over the past two decades. In 1970, 9.5 percent of married and single men aged 25 to 34 lived with parents. By 1990 that was up to 15 percent. Among women, the two-decade rise was far more gradual, from 6.6 percent in 1970 to 8.1 percent last year.
 
Peter Pan, No Wendy
 The variation between men and women "suggests that the nest is a lot better feathered for the boys than the girls," said Frances Goldschieder, a professor of sociology at Brown University. Men are granted more freedom by their parents, Ms. Goldschieder and demographers say, and often get "a totally free ride" from their mothers on household chores.
The variation also suggests that "men need to be taken care of by women" and turn to their mothers in the absence of a wife, said Richard Hokenson, an economic demographer at the securities company Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "It's a variation on the Peter Pan syndrome," Mr. Hokenson said. "You know, the Island of Lost Boys, the song 'I Won't Grow Up.' "
Among those at home with their parents are young men earning a good living, like Ed Mastoloni, a $35,000-a-year financial analyst for a New York City insurance company. Some are unemployed and others are barely getting by.
But rich or poor, they seem to enjoy the same comforts.
"I come and go as I please, and dinner's always ready when I get home," said Mr. Mastoloni, 25 years old, who lives in his family's sprawling home in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Mastoloni says that he would be earning enough to move out if he had not recently bought an expensive jeep and a jet ski.
 
Pampering Doesn't Stop
 Jeff Seaman, a 27-year-old deputy sheriff in Cincinnati who makes $19,000 a year, also reaps the rewards of tender loving care and low overhead. "Everything's always done -- the laundry, the food -- and I don't have to worry about the cable getting shut off or the telephone," he said. "Where I used to live, there might be beer cans and pizza boxes stacked up for weeks. And I drive a Corvette, not a rusted-out Ford Escort."
The Seaman household also includes Jeff's 30-year-old brother, Doug, a health care aide who has custody of his two sons. Donna Seaman, a nurse, looks after them all, as well as her husband, Willis, who is a welder, and she muses about the ways women spoil men.
"I think us women have got to do something about these boys," Mrs. Seaman said. "It's all our own fault. All we do is wait on them."
The pampering takes many forms. Betty Sansing of San Rafael, Calif., gets up early to pack a lunch for her 32-year-old son, John, a sheet metal worker. Louise Specht of Aliquippa, Pa., does laundry for her 31-year-old son, Brian, an unemployed plumber, because she doesn't want him "puttering around with my washer." Judy Mastoloni, Ed's mother, irons her son's shirts for $1 each and takes his shoes to the shoemaker for nothing.
 
When Her Career Is Kids
 Most of the sons rave about how nice it is to live in a clean house. "Men are, you could say, lazy," Mr. Mastoloni said. "They know there's stuff to clean up, but they watch football instead. And how often does a guy get down on his hands and knees to scrub the bathtub?"
Mrs. Sansing, Mrs. Specht and Mrs. Mastoloni do not work outside the home, and demographic experts suggest that nonworking women are most likely to enjoy having their grown sons at home.
"If their career was kids, it's a justification of their choice of role," said Celinda Lake, vice president of Greenberg/Lake, a Washington polling organization.
Many fathers seem to object to the imposition on their wives more than their wives themselves do. One of them, a San Francisco garbageman, has two sons at home, aged 25 and 28. One was recently laid off as a house painter, and the other has a drug problem. Both take advantage of their mother, the man said.
"All they have to say is 'Mom, I need a six-pack, $20 and the keys to the car,' and she's off and running," he said.
 
In Return, Muscle, Maybe Rent
 When a son lives with a divorced mother, the divison of labor seems more equitable. Eva Farris, an employment counselor in Houston, shares her home with her 25-year-old son, Mike, an auto mechanic. He pays her $200 a month -- apparently the standard amount when rent is paid -- and also does her yard work and car repair.
"Plus I run off her boyfriends on occasion," Mr. Farris said.
Some demographers speculate that the increase in sons at home is related to the rising incidence of divorce. With no father in residence, these experts say, the tension between the parent and child of the same sex is missing and the mother enjoys the benefits of a man around the house. "Then it's a two-way relationship," said Martha Farnsworth Riche, the director of policy studies at the Population Reference Bureau in Washington.
Many young men said that low household costs enabled them to buy the "toys" that meant so much to them. The garbageman, who spoke on condition that he not be named, complained that his son recently bought "a Chevy muscle car instead of a four-cylinder Honda" and "now he's choking on the payments."
Mr. Hokenson, the economic demographer, spoke disapprovingly of "kids who would rather finance a better life style than pay housing expenses." But Ms. Lake notes that this generation of young adults is the first in history who will not do as well as their parents, which she describes as "a fundamental violation of the American dream."
One widely cited reason boys stay home more often than girls is that their parents grant them the freedom to stay out late and conduct sexual relationships. "With my girls, I didn't really sleep soundly till I knew they were in," said Mrs. Sansing. "With boys, it's different."
The rules vary from house to house. In the Blaustein home in Skokie, Ill., where 25-year-old twin sons are living after graduate school while they look for work, there are no clear rules but lots of leeway. "My parents go to bed without asking, 'Where is this girl staying?' so they're tacitly allowing it," said Jeremy Blaustein, who has a master's degree in Asian studies. "It would probably be different if I were a girl."
But dating poses a different sort of problem for these young men, several of whom said they were embarrassed to tell women that they lived with their parents. "It's not something I'm proud of," said Mr. Mastoloni. "When a girl asks, I shy away from it or lie."
 
Occasionally, Fathers Erupt
 Some of the fathers deal with their live-in sons with sullen silence and an occasional explosion. Herman Specht, the supervisor of a zinc smelter, is one of these, angry at his unemployed son, who came home when his marriage broke up.
"He can't keep a job and he can't keep a wife," Mr. Specht grumbled. "The only thing he can keep is his mother and father."
At that, Mrs. Specht said: "It doesn't bother me like it bothers him. I'm already cooking supper, so it's no big deal. My husband thinks back to what he was doing at that age. He doesn't understand that the economy today isn't what it was then."
The San Francisco garbageman said it infuriates him to come home "dead tired" from a midnight shift and find his sons lying around the house. If they can't find the $18 an hour construction jobs they want, he said, they should "wash dishes and deliver newspapers."
Several parents said they had strategies for ousting their sons if they didn't move in due time. Ms. Farris said she would gradually prepare Mike for the fact that it was time to leave the nest, then help him find an apartment, give him the money for first month's rent and security, and accompany him to sign the lease.
"If they can't do it themselves, you do it for them," she said.
The San Francisco garbageman has another idea. He intends to put up with his sons for until next year, when he turns 55 and is entitled to a one-time waiver of the capital gains tax if he sells his house.
"Kids today, they want to retire with you," he said. "But I've had it. We're going to move to a place that's too small for them."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 23, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page chart last Sunday with an article about adults who live with their parents misstated a figure for 25-to-34-year-old women. According to a 1990 Census Bureau survey of living arrangements, 8.1 percent of all women in that age group live with parents, not 9.5 percent.
