HEADLINE: Southwest Air's New Push West

BYLINE: By PETER C. T. ELSWORTH

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
The airline industry is only slowly emerging from one of its worst recessions ever, but Southwest Airlines has come through the storm almost intact and with its ambitions undiminished. One of the only leading airlines to report an operating profit last year, the Dallas-based carrier is expediting its push into California and using its tested recipe for growth: short flights, low fares, frequent service, moderate debt and the inspired lunacy of its chief executive, Herbert D. Kelleher.
Southwest has little choice but to look west because there is little room to expand in Texas, where it serves 10 airports, and in adjoining states. "They need a market to grow," said Jessica C. Tully, an analyst with Eppler, Guerin & Turner in Dallas. "Their main thing was Phoenix a few years ago. Now it's California." 
 In addition, the carrier is facing the possibility of future competition from a high-speed train on its bread-and-butter run between Dallas and Houston. Texas officials agreed to a plan earlier this month, but it is by no means certain that the project, which could cost as much as $7 billion, will ever be built.
"It's the only airline that appears to be making any money at the moment," said Paul Turk, an analyst at Avmark, an air-travel consulting company in Washington. Compared with other carriers, "it's a completely different beast, flying small planes over secondary routes."
Tomorrow, the carrier will raise the number of cities it serves in California to seven when it inaugurates flights from Sacramento, and it has already increased its service in California by about 30 percent this year. It has been flying into California since 1982 but is only now concentrating on the lucrative north-south market.
Analysts argue the carrier is already the leading intrastate carrier in certain key California markets despite the heavy competition from United Airlines, which dominates the key Los Angeles-San Francisco run.
"California is a natural extension, a perfect market for them and their No. 1 growth opportunity," said Glenn D. Engel, who follows the airline industry for Goldman Sachs.
"We are making money in California," said Mr. Kelleher as he strode around his office during a recent interview, gesturing with an ever-present cigarette. He noted the load factor, or percentage of seats filled, for the carrier's California operations was 61.6 percent in May, comfortably above the break-even level of 55 or 56 percent.
Still, Southwest is in for a prolonged struggle for passengers in California, analysts say. "The competition is very high, not so much because of money but because it's an important market to the big players, who regard it as a loss leader needed to feed frequent-flyer clients," Mr. Engel said. "It's important to be in a highly visible market."
Ms. Tully said, "There is too much capacity in California," adding, "Southwest will be victorious and make money but to really make money -- big profits -- someone else will have to cut back."
Mr. Kelleher said that although Southwest has no intention of stepping on United's toes by competing in the Los Angeles-San Francisco run, opting to concentrate on the alternative Burbank-Oakland route, he fully intends to make it the dominant short-haul carrier in the state.
"We are very well equipped to fight the war," Mr. Kelleher said, citing the company's strong balance sheet. According to Edward J. Starkman, airline analyst with PaineWebber, Southwest's debt-to-total-capital ratio was 32 percent at the end of the first quarter, compared with 45 percent for American and 36 percent for Delta, although United's was a lean 30 percent at the end of 1990.
USAIR Group, based in Arlington, Va., which acquired the West Coast carrier PSAir in 1987, has already cut back its service in California as part of a restructuring, the company says. "USAir has been pulling down a lot of former PSAir routes," said Mr. Kelleher. "For whatever reasons, they are doing it, and it's falling into our laps. On May 2 they ceased service to six cities, and we've had to move as fast as we can."
Mr. Starkman attributes USAir's move to Southwest's competitive edge. "That's 80 percent of the reasoning," he said. "Southwest's low fares are not promotional. These are the fares that will be there." USAir concedes that it is difficult to compete with Southwest's low ticket prices.
Southwest ranks 10th among United States carriers with about 3 percent of the domestic air travel market, according to Avmark. Now flying to 32 cities in 14 states, the carrier has built its fortunes on frequent, short-haul flights -- an ideal system for intrastate travel. "It's remarkable that with all the glitter of deregulation, Southwest has the most disciplined growth of all the entrants -- 10 to 20 percent a year," Mr. Engel said.
Within Texas, where it advertises itself as "the company plane," Southwest has regular service to 10 cities, including 83 daily flights between Dallas and Houston. It also flies to all the surrounding states, under a Federal law that limits nonstop flights from its home base, the Dallas municipal airport, Love Field, to the four states bordering Texas. The law, known as the Wright Amendment, was enacted in 1979 to allow Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport to become the region's long-haul airport. To fly beyond neighboring states from Love Field, Southwest must touch down somewhere en route.
Although Southwest fought the Wright Amendment, Mr. Kelleher concedes that it has made Love Field undesirable to other airlines and that he now has a monopoly there.
There have been moves to repeal the law, especially by Kansas politicians who claim that air service to Texas is more expensive than it need be, but Mr. Starkman believes such a move is unlikely and would have a minimal effect on Southwest.
"Southwest runs differently from everyone else," Mr. Engel said. All other leading carriers fly long-range passengers into hubs, load them onto one plane and fly them on. "The hub-and-spoke system is an efficient way to fill a plane but not an efficient way to use a plane," he said. "Southwest flies point to point, back and forth. It's a more efficient use of the plane, but it's harder to fill the plane."
But filling the plane is not as vital for Southwest because it cuts costs by flying short routes, which allows it to do without full meal service; by keeping the average turnaround time to an astonishing 15 minutes for most flights, thus keeping its planes in the air, earning money; and by using only Boeing 737's, which keeps maintenance and training costs to a minimum for the fleet of 114 planes.
In addition, the airline is known for its high productivity, which analysts attribute to a dedicated work force of about 9,000, inspired by Mr. Kelleher's antics and workaholic habits. More than half of the company's employees belong to national unions. "Southwest does not need as much revenues to make money because their costs are 50 percent less," Mr. Engel said. Southwest managed to keep its losses to a minimum in the recent downturn. While the industry lost about $4 billion last year when it was hit by a combination of the recession, skyrocketing fuel prices and a dropoff of demand as Americans opted to stay home during the crisis in the Middle East, Southwest reported a profit of $47.1 million.
In the first quarter of 1991, however, the company reported a loss of $8.2 million after a loss of $4.6 million in the fourth quarter last year. They were the first consecutive quarterly losses in the company's history.
"Compared to the others, I'm not too disappointed," Mr. Kelleher said. "$12.8 million is a small percentage of an industry loss of $3.3 billion" in the two most-recent quarters, he said, adding that he expects the company to be profitable in the second quarter, "but not as much as last year."
 
 
 
NOT JUST ANOTHER ELVIS IMPERSONATOR
 From the moment some 20 years ago when the idea for Southwest Airlines was first sketched on a restaurant napkin -- a triangle with three dots representing Dallas, Houston and San Antonio -- the personality of Herbert Kelleher has dominated the company.
For a chief executive of a billion dollar corporation, Mr. Kelleher is one of a kind. His antics have included dressing up as Elvis Presley and the Easter Bunny, delivering rap songs and serving as a flight attendant, ticket collector and baggage handler.
To publicize the carrier's new service in and out of Sacramento, for example, he sang a rap song accompanied by two people dressed as tomatoes and two as Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.
All this has earned the company not only a great deal of publicity but also staff loyalty so intense that Wall Street analysts cite high productivity as a key element in the company's success. The carrier hires only one person out of 10 who apply, and those who join the company are made to feel like part of a family. The halls of the company's new headquarters next to Love Field in Dallas are lined with thousands of photographs celebrating one Southwest party after another. Herb, as he is universally known, is usually at the center of the picture.
"There's no question that the glory of Southwest Airlines is its productivity," said Edward J. Starkman, airline analyst with PaineWebber. "The work force is dedicated to the company. They're Moonies basically. That's the way they operate."
Mr. Kelleher, who was raised in the Northeast, had no background experience to start an airline other than his training as a lawyer and his marriage into a San Antonio family.
The downside to the intensity of the 60-year-old Mr. Kelleher's involvement is the question of how the company would fare without him. It is not reassuring that he smokes five packs of cigarettes a day. "It's a concern, certainly, because there is no clear successor in line, but I don't want to overplay it," said Mr. Starkman. "This is a very strong company."

HEADLINE: Graduates Find Road to Jobs Longer and More Difficult

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
LAST week, a month after graduating from Dowling College in Oakdale, James Kowalski of West Sayville began working, at a salary of almost $30,000 a year, as an associate programmer analyst for Spectrum Healthcare Solutions in Hauppauge.
Mr. Kowalski has a bachelor's degree, with a major in computer-information systems. As a participant in the Dowling cooperative-education program since his junior year, he was an intern at Spectrum, receiving $10 an hour for his part-time work. 
"I knew I wanted to stay on full time after I graduated," Mr. Kowalski said. "I took over as many tasks as I could to show the director that I was interested and motivated. If I hadn't had my foot in the door, I probably wouldn't have found a job and might not have been able to stay on Long Island."
Many of Mr. Kowalski's friends with business degrees have gone for job interviews that have not panned out, he said. As a result, they are now living at home with their parents, working part time, waiting and hoping.
Conversely, whereas a majority of college graduates a generation ago found entry-level jobs and took their own apartments, this year's graduates on the Island are more likely to be living at home with their families, expecting to wait as long as a year before finding jobs.
Because of the depressed job market, even then there may not be openings in certain fields.
Giancarlo Marchesi, who graduated this year from the Hofstra Business School, is, like Mr. Kowalski, another fortunate job candidate. At the end of the month, he will commute from his parents' home in Westbury to Citicorp in Melville, where he was hired as a management associate at a starting salary of $30,000.
Knowing how competitive the market is, Mr. Marchesi prepared carefully for each interview, he said, including extensive research about each company.
"I went through about seven interviews," he said. "It was pretty depressing and didn't look very promising. Of my friends who graduated with me, I'm one of the few who was lucky and got a job."
The mood among recent graduates is split, Mr. Marchesi said.
"Since the recession started last year, we were ready for this and knew how tough it would be," he said. "Half of my friends have become more aggressive in their job search, and the other half are resigned but optimistic. Within a year, they think they'll find jobs."
The job outlook for graduates is mixed. The consensus among university officials is that there are fewer companies recruiting on campuses and fewer jobs available. But, they say, there are still openings.
Traditionally, three months after receiving their degrees, 95 percent of C. W. Post graduates have found full-time positions, said the director of the Career Placement Center at the college, Mince Kohler. That may be a bit longer this year, she said, and candidates are more likely to take the first offer.
The average time for finding a job, most university officials say, is seven to eight months at salaries of about $25,000.
"This is a fragmented and selective labor market that is more difficult to navigate than in previous years," the regional Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, said. "It tests the capacity of adapting to a rapidly moving situation, and depends on what skills a candidate brings to the labor market and how flexible he is in adapting those skills to the market.
"Applicants may have to adjust their horizons. They may not get the exact job, in the exact field, at the pay or location that they had their hearts set on. We're talking about flexibility, but even in this difficult market, there still is hiring taking place."
Colleges do not conduct most follow-up surveys until at least six months after commencements. But a spokeswoman for the Long Island Association, Valerie Scibilia, said there was a general feeling that although there were some openings on the Island, an overwhelming number of people was applying for them.
The demand seems greater for higher-level positions, she said, adding that entry jobs may be slightly more available.
A majority of graduates are staying on the Island, said the director of career services at Adelphi University, Ann Robinson. Most graduates are living at home with their families, she added, working part time while continuing job searches.
 
Teaching Market Gloomy
 In teaching, which is suffering one of its worst markets on the Island in many years, candidates are more willing to relocate, Ms. Robinson said. The tightest markets are in the Northeast and Far West, she said.
Graduates willing to look for jobs throughout the country increase their chances 1,000-fold, said the career counselor at the State University at Stony Brook, Peter Burke.
"But kids from Long Island generally want to stay here," he said. "They even look at New York City as a foreign land. But after confronting reality, many slowly start to open up their horizons."
Among the fields cited as having few opportunities are banking, education and engineering.
Many of the fields have cycles, Mr. Burke said, adding:
"But there are no dead-end fields. A job search largely depends upon a candidate's motivation and perseverance. If someone wants something enough, he'll get it."
At Hofstra, there was a 10 percent increase this year of students using placement services, said the vice president of student services, Peter Fishbein.
 
Co-op Education Programs on Rise
 At some colleges, cooperative-education programs have grown. The programs combine academics and work.
The colleges having co-op programs include Dowling, Polytechnic University, the Long Island University campuses at C. W. Post and Southampton and Suffolk Community.
This year, 350 Post interns had pre-employment positions, the director of cooperative education, Marcy Smelkinson, said. She added that, after graduation, 45 to 80 percent stayed with the companies.
The interns' average salary is $7.10 an hour. Ms. Smelkinson said co-op students tended to find jobs faster and to earn more than graduates without experience.
 
Dowling Interns Average $7.50
 The average salary for a Dowling intern is $7.50 an hour, the program coordinator, Michael J. Mooney, said. For those staying with the companies, salaries after graduation are usually $2,000 to $3,000 higher than for applicants with no experience.
Of the 53 Dowling graduates in the co-op program, 30 have been accepted for permanent employment at the workplaces, Mr. Mooney said. More than 70 companies had agreements with 111 students.
Graduates in the health fields face especially good prospects, Mr. Ehrenhalt said. That industry, he added, is one of few expanding in the New York metropolitan region.
 
Opportunities in Nursing
 In nursing, starting salaries have risen, from about $25,000 to $35,000, Ms. Robinson said, adding that there were also openings in health-related careers like physical and rehabilitative therapy.
Computer work, particularly setting up systems with software, is a strong field, Ms. Kohler said. Another possible field is marine science, including biology, chemistry and environmental sciences, said the director of career development at L.I.U.-Southampaton, John McCrudden. "Environmental issues are a hotbed today," he said. "And there are considerable opportunities on all levels in environmental consulting firms, research facilities and state and local agencies."
Last year, 76 percent of the graduates from L.I.U.-Southampton found employment in six months, Mr. McCrudden said. But business graduates, he said, are finding it harder to obtain jobs.
At Five Towns College in Seaford, 60 percent of the graduates specialized in music, a profession that has shown slight growth, said the vice president of the college, Martin Cohen. "Entertainment is one area in which, even in a recession, people are still spending money," he said.
Students have found work repairing instruments, recording and other areas, Mr. Cohen said. The performing-arts market is holding nationally, he added, but is down regionally.
The mood is generally optimistic among the graduates, and it is an exciting time for them, said Mr. Fishbein.
"They read the papers and know that the economy is tough," he said. "But it just makes them a bit more determined and aggressive. Instead of interviewing with two or three companies, they may see four or five. And even the interviewing experience is an important one."
College graduates do not face the bleak prospects that high school drop-outs do, Mr. Ehrenhalt said. "These youngsters will get placed," he said. "If they approach the job market creatively and with flexibility, they'll do all right."

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Mountain View, Calif.;
A Civic Center For a Revival

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN

 BODY:
A $44.5 MILLION civic center resembling an Italian piazza and part of an effort to bring business and office tenants to this city 30 miles south of San Francisco has opened.
The complex, which was completed in April, includes a 77,000-square-foot City Hall and a 46,000-square-foot community theater that arc around a 30,000-square-foot courtyard opening onto Castro Street, the main commercial strip. 
 At the center of the courtyard, a pair of slender octagonal buildings, one of them a seven-story entrance to City Hall, are intended to serve as an "urban gateway" connecting Castro Street and Pioneer Park to the west. An underground parking garage for 240 cars lies beneath the civic center.
The three-story bulk of the City Hall and theater complex, accented by the two taller structures, stands beside a 10-story concrete office building from the 1960's. The architect, William Turnbull of San Francisco, said that to overcome the incongruity in scale, he attempted to break the dominance of the high-rise by "putting public space at its feet."
The new civic center replaces a demolished city hall on the same site. The older building was undergoing earthquake reinforcement several years ago when workers discovered that it was structurally unsound. The design for the new complex was selected in 1986 after a competition.
Early versions of the plan presented the same buildings in simpler in form, but city officials asked for more ornate detailing and brighter colors. The final plan features salmon-colored walls and a gray-green tile roof. Mr. Turnbull, expressing some reservations about the outcome, said, "It's a little too post-mod for us."
The civic center is part of a far-reaching plan by local officials to revitalize the downtown. In recent years, this city of 67,000 people has been a bedroom community for the larger cities of Silicon Valley.
Now, it is actively promoting development, including downtown office and residential construction. Currently, $140 million worth of construction is either planned or under way, said Ken Alsman, the city's economic development director.
Redevelopment, however, has not come cheaply. The civic center ran about $15.5 million over its budget. The city also spent $12 million to redesign the traffic patterns on Castro Street.
City officials acknowledge that the redevelopment has strained the city's budget, but Mr. Alsman said the civic center was worth it. "My sense is, in the long run, this kind of presence in the community will be to its long-term financial benefit," he said.

HEADLINE: No Pain, No Gain -- or How New York Can Resolve This Crisis and Avert Another;
ALBANY-CITY SWAP

BYLINE: By Charles Brecher and Raymond D. Horton; Charles Brecher, who teaches at New York University, and Raymond D. Horton, who teaches at Columbia, are, respectively, research director and president of the Citizens Budget Commission.

 BODY:
In whatever shape New York City survives this financial crisis, another siege is only a matter of time if there are no fundamental changes in how the city gets and spends its money. Most such structural reforms have been considered politically unthinkable -- until now. The Op-Ed page asked several specialists for ways that fiscal necessity could be the mother of municipal invention.
The "two New Yorks" are headed for bankruptcy. Continuing their current policies would, in the next four years, produce cumulative deficits of $13 billion for the state and $16 billion for the city. 
 A partial "solution" only aggravates the problem. To reduce their deficits, state and city officials pursue beggar-thy-neighbor policies. To balance his budget, Gov. Mario Cuomo cut about $400 million in aid for New York City. Mayor David Dinkins, facing a $3.5 billion deficit, is seeking more state aid.
A better approach would reflect the common interests of the two New Yorks. One such change would rearrange the relationship between the state's taxing authority and major mandated costs shouldered by localities.
New York localities carry an unusually heavy load of public service financing, primarily because Albany requires them to contribute substantially to welfare and Medicaid programs. Of the 50 state governments, New York's requires the largest local contribution.
In 1990, the statewide cost of welfare and Medicaid exceeded $14.7 billion; about $5.2 billion was paid for by state taxes, about $3.3 billion by local taxes and the rest by the Federal Government.
State assumption of local welfare and Medicaid costs would pave the way for tax reforms beneficial to the state as well as to its localities. It would require the city to give up approximately $2.2 billion in local taxes committed to meeting welfare and Medicaid mandates. It would also permit the city to drop the two taxes identified as most harmful to the local economy -- the unincorporated-business tax and the commercial rent tax -- and still have substantial sums left for further tax cuts and closing short-run budget gaps.
This swap would be good for the state as well as the city. Nearly half of the state's revenues are derived from the New York City economy. By placing heavier tax burdens on localities like New York City, which has a large number of poor residents, state policy creates incentives for businesses to relocate to places that have fewer poor residents.
This swap would require new statewide taxes to pay for the state's added welfare and Medicaid responsibilities. The most sensible new source of state revenue would be higher personal income tax rates. The personal income tax is broad-based, progressive, federally deductible, and would yield large sums with small rate increases. The result would be a more efficient and equitable system of financing government across the state.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
An Upscale Gallic Grab for the American Wallet

BYLINE: By Nancy Marx Better

 BODY:
"It is a joy when you are able to tell the difference between a Chateau d'Yquem and an ordinary burgundy." So said Jean-Louis Dumas-Hermes, fifth-generation head of the Paris-based fashion house that bears his name. Mr. Dumas-Hermes was breakfasting at the Mayfair Regent in New York with two colleagues from the Comite Colbert, an association of France's leading luxury goods manufacturers, plus a few upscale providers of services.
Nattily attired in French-cuffed shirts and Hermes ties, the gentlemen were discussing American sartorial style. It is a subject with which Mr. Dumas-Hermes first became familiar some years ago, during a brief stint as an assistant buyer at Bloomingdale's. 
 "Today, we find that executives don't want to show off so much," Mr. Dumas-Hermes said. "They want to have a certain elegance. But they don't want to wear things that people can recognize from 20 yards away."
These are trying times for haberdashers like Hermes, makers of $95 ties, $2,000 attache cases and other business accessories with definite, but discreet, long-distance recognition factors. In a leaner America, visible status symbols are on the wane.
As one New Yorker, Alan Millstein, explained, "This fancy European merchandise appealed to parvenus." Now, added Mr. Millstein, a retail consultant, "the money is gone, and so are the customers. People are going back to basics."
Managers from the Comite Colbert's 70 member companies -- Chateau d'Yquem, the premiere sauternes producer, belongs, of course; ordinary red wine, whatever the provenance, does not make the cut -- convened in early June for their annual international summit. There was a black-tie gala at the Central Park Boathouse for advertising, marketing and publishing executives and a Champagne street festival celebrating "l'art de vivre," the art of living. The goal: to woo Americans, who represent 14 percent of the Comite Colbert's worldwide sales.
"It's important for successful people to appreciate fine quality," said Mr. Dumas-Hermes, speaking with the authority of one whose great-great-grandfather began the family business as a saddle maker in 1837. "It's what sets executives apart, the ability to discern." He added, "Of course, price is a concern. You can't sell a tie for $1,000."
While Mr. Dumas-Hermes admits the recession and the weak dollar have dampened American demand for top-of-the-line imported goods, he won't reveal specific statistics. (Neither will most of the other Comite Colbert companies; privately held, they need not and do not release financial information.) "Sure, it's a bit difficult to operate in this economy," he said. "It's a challenge, because we're under pressure to make things that are cheaper, to develop a mass-market attitude."
But the group intends to retain the standards set by Jean-Jacques Guerlain, the parfumeur, when he founded the Comite in 1954, borrowing the name of Jean Baptiste Colbert, a statesman and supporter of artisans in the court of Louis XIV. No member's products may be entirely machine-made or distributed in abundance. "We're not switching our strategy because Wall Street is up or down," Mr. Dumas-Hermes said.
The Comite has noted a shift in American tastes. "In the 1980's, Americans were impressed by the logo on a product," said Alain Boucheron, head of Boucheron jewelers, who will succeed Mr. Dumas-Hermes as chairman of the group next month. "Now they're impressed by craftsmanship."
Indeed, said Mr. Millstein, Americans have eschewed items with initials for some time. "They don't want to be seen carrying a briefcase with a logo stamped all over it. They want to whisper, not shout." (Yes, Louis Vuitton, Yves Saint Laurent and Chanel are Comite members, but all have aggressively protected the exclusivity of their images, rather than flaunting them like Gucci. The famed Hermes logo is artfully woven into the design, not imposed upon it.)
Mr. Boucheron believes executives are becoming more sophisticated. "It used to be that you had to buy something from a certain company, even if you didn't really like it, because it made you feel important," he said. "Today, you buy something because it gives you pleasure."
Still, Mr. Dumas-Hermes is waiting for Americans to develop a "signature," or personal style, like their European brethren."To be frank," he said, "I find there is an awful lot of uniformity in executive dress here. There are only a few things that make a difference, like the tie, the shirt, the shoes. These things should be in harmony with your character, to express who you are."
In an educational effort, the Comite Colbert recently launched an internship program for American students of management and design. This summer, a student from the Harvard Business School will work for Hermes, analyzing the company's international structure. A student from the Fashion Institute of Technology will help create accessories at Nina Ricci. A student from Columbia's Graduate School of Business will develop an international pricing strategy for Puiforcat, fine silver. A student from the Parsons School of Design will apprentice as a Baccarat candlestick maker. All will receive free passage on Air France (the Concorde) and free lodging at member hotels, which include the Plaza Athenee, Ritz and Crillon.
"We don't care if the students ultimately go into these businesses or not," said Christian Blanckaert, the group's president and a former director of the French Government's tourism office. "In fact, we wish they wouldn't. What we want is that 20 years from now, a handful of top executives in America will remember the summer they spent in France, and what they learned about l'art de vivre."

HEADLINE: Ethiopians in Israel Get Equal Treatment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your June 6 report "200 Ethiopians Trapped in West Bank" implies that these immigrants from the 1984 airlift are being denied choices in housing and employment, being forced to hold menial jobs far from home. 
 Yes, Ethiopian immigrants to Israel in 1984 were sent to Kiryat Arba, as well as many other cities. Kiryat Arba is a small, residential town in the West Bank, which houses primarily Israelis, many of whom work in Israel proper. Their daily commute is a fact of life. Israel's economy allows people to pursue education and jobs as they wish.
The Ethiopians living in Kiryat Arba are in the same boat as the other Israelis. Although many of them hold menial jobs or are unemployed, others have become professionals who have had a positive impact on their communities and Israel as a whole. As they progress up the economic ladder, they can use their new resources to make life style changes as they see fit.
Is it a government's responsibility to move residents to more comfortable public housing or to encourage them to be part of the economic mainstream and enable them to move themselves?
 
DAVID B. SAMSON
Binghamton, N.Y., June 6, 1991

HEADLINE: Big Order Expected By Airbus

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 16

 BODY:
Airbus Industrie plans to announce this week that the Federal Express Corporation, the express airfreight carrier, will order up to 75 new cargo planes from Airbus in a $6 billion deal, officials from the European aircraft consortium said.
The deal, which is set to be announced at the Paris Air Show in the next few days, will be one of Airbus's biggest successes in the American market, which has long been dominated by Boeing and McDonnell Douglas. The order will also be the consortium's largest ever for cargo aircraft. 
 In winning the Federal Express order, Airbus has bested an offer from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, which, along with the Boeing Company, has frequently complained that Airbus receives government subsidies that give it an unfair competitive advantage. The American market has been the biggest challenge for Airbus, which rejects the charges of unfair subsidies.
 
'Blow for McDonnell'
 "This is a real blow for McDonnell Douglas," an industry analyst said at the Paris show.
According to Airbus officials, Federal Express is placing firm orders for 25 A-300 wide-body twin-engine aircraft and is taking out options on 50 other A-300's. The Airbus A-300 won in a competition against McDonnell Douglas MD-11 cargo planes, the Airbus officials said.
The Airbus planes, which are scheduled to be delivered over 15 years beginning in 1993, will replace for the most part Federal Express's Boeing 727's and McDonnell Douglas DC-10's.
An Airbus official said that on many routes to and from Federal Express's hub in Memphis, a single A-300 could replace two Boeing 727's now serving the route. The Airbus official said: "This makes economic sense for Federal Express. They can use one aircraft with two pilots and two engines instead of two 727's with a total of six pilots and six engines."
Airbus officials said final papers for the deal were not yet signed, but they said Federal Express officials were coming to Paris this week for a news conference about the order.
The Federal Express order is by far the largest announced at this year's Paris Air Show, the world's largest air show. This year the show has a downbeat mood. Civil aircraft orders are down because of airline financial troubles resulting from a plunge in air traffic during the Persian Gulf crisis. Military aircraft orders are also down because of the end of the cold war and cuts in military budgets.
On Thursday, Boeing announced orders, totaling $2.74 billion, for 41 aircraft from four buyers: American Airlines, Delta Air Lines Inc., Lufthansa A.G., and GPA Group P.L.C., an Irish airplane leasing company.
Airbus, which delivered 165 aircraft last year, expects revenues of $7.4 billion this year, up from $4.7 billion in 1990.
Airbus's victory in the Federal Express order is just one of several ways in which Airbus has squared off against its American archrivals at the Paris show.
Jean Pierson, Airbus's managing director, said his company was talking to several airlines to see whether they would be interested in a 650-seat aircraft. With airports more congested than ever, Mr. Pierson suggested that airlines might be looking for aircraft even larger than Boeing's 747, whose typical layout holds around 400 passengers.
Airbus officials said they hoped such a plane would be ready in about 10 years, when a large number of 747's are expected to be retired from service.
At the show, Philip M. Condit, a Boeing executive vice president, said his company was also talking to airlines about developing a plane larger than the 747. He said Boeing would consider a stretched version of the 747, a double-deck version the whole length of the plane, or a completely new design.
Mr. Pierson also said Airbus was studying development of a 130-seat aircraft to compete against Boeing's 737-300. Airbus's commercial director boasted that the aircraft, which would be a shortened version of the 150-seat A-320, would capture more than 50 percent of the market against the 737-300's. Airbus officials said that if they decided to go ahead with this new aircraft, which would be called the A-319, it would cost about $400 million to develop, or one-tenth the cost of an all-new design.
Airbus's partners are Aerospatiale of France and Deutsche Airbus of Germany, each of which holds a 37.9 percent stake, British Aerospace P.L.C., which has a 20 percent share, and CASA of Spain, with 4.2 percent.

HEADLINE: Dirt Roads: Deep Ruts, High Cost, but Status

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTH SALEM, N.Y.

 BODY:
In the beginning, there were dirt roads. In spring, tires got stuck in the mud; in summer, a film of dirt dulled shiny cars. Then there were paved roads, an indisputable sign of progress. Right?
Wrong. Across northern Westchester County and in neighboring Putnam County, dirt road devotees argue that it is worthwhile to save a disappearing network of back roads that evoke the bucolic simplicity of another century. And these advocates -- often affluent commuters to Manhattan, horse farm owners and would-be naturalists -- hold their position even as some officials of financially strapped towns point out that dirt roads cost twice as much to maintain as paved roads do. 
 In the process, the dirt road has emerged not so much a symbol of sleepy-town life but of status.
 
Preserving Heritage
 "Years ago, you could tell who the most politically powerful person in town was because his road would be paved," said Ray Keating, a member of the zoning board of appeals here. "Now it's come full circle, and the most powerful live on the dirt roads."
Whenever there is a proposal to pave a stretch of dirt road, there is a skirmish.
In Putnam County, the passions turned litigious when a group of homeowners sued the town a year and a half ago to pre-empt a developer's plans to pave 300-year-old Indian Brook Road. The homeowners won in an out-of-court settlement. Earlier, another group, Dirt Roads of Philipstown, was less successful in preventing the town from paving a few stretches of dirt.
"It's a heritage that we have to preserve for our kids, because once they're paved, they're gone," said Jay M. Vitale, a carpenter who is president of the Indian Brook Road Conservation Association. "It's like wanting to bulldoze George Washington's home."
Here in North Salem, the horse capital of Westchester, an uproar followed a proposal by Mr. Keating to create special tax districts for homeowners on dirt roads so that the extra maintenance expenses would not burden denizens of blacktop. "Anytime you make a proposal like that," he said, "they accuse you of wanting to pave over the town."
 
Dirt Is Costly
 In some towns, officials are just as protective of dirt roads as residents.
A few weeks ago, for example, the post office in New Castle threatened to stop delivering mail along one badly rutted road until it was paved. But the pro-dirt town government reminded the postal service of its legal obligation to carry the mail, regardless of road conditions, and chose to fill the potholes instead.
The controversy over the value of dirt roads is not new, but there is a growing realization of their costliness.
Perhaps no one is as aware of that as highway superintendents. The roads have to be constantly scraped and leveled during the spring thaws by workers on overtime, and then calcium chloride must be used to control dust in summer. Stephen Waterbury, highway superintendent for the Town of Lewisboro, had to spend $25,000 on materials alone during a two-week period last winter.
 
'They Fit the Mold'
 "The dirt roads are a tremendous drain on manpower and resources, especially in a year when you take a $25,000 hit and you're losing $50,000 in state aid," said Mr. Waterbury, who estimated that it costs two to three times more to maintain Lewisboro's 14.5 miles of dirt roads than a similar length of blacktop.
"We have 20th-century traffic and part of an 18th-century highway system out there," he said. "Right now they look really nice. They've hardened up, and so they fit the mold of the little Currier and Ives road, but if you were here in February, you would have heard different."
Karen Iocavelli, a former member of the North Salem planning board and an ardent conservationist said, "Town boards are going to have to take a hard look at which roads should be saved, because there is no question that the cost of maintaining them is becoming prohibitive."
Many longtime residents do not understand how a little asphalt will destroy the semirural atmosphere. Others are simply tired of the inconveniences, from broken axles to towing bills.
 
'Piling On More Dirt'
 Josephine Hodge, a homemaker whose house fronts on a dirt road in Lewisboro, is ready to start a petition drive to have her road paved.
"When the ground is thawing, the road gets so soft that it's impassable," said Mrs. Hodge, who has lived there for 32 years. "The ruts get deep, and they keep piling on more dirt. Sometimes, I feel that our tax dollars are really going nowhere."
In Lewisboro, however, the master plan adopted in 1985 states that dirt roads represent the rural character the town wants to save. "The town philosophically has gone on the record that we would like to keep those roads as long as we can," said the Town Supervisor, Jo Ann Simon. "Yet I'm also aware of the problems they cause in terms of maintenance."
Some officials said that the recession and losses in state aid were making it hard for them to pave roads this year -- even where residents occasionally agreed on paving -- because the initial outlay approached $85,000 a mile for material alone.
"You have to put out a lot of money to leave things the way they are," said Mr. Waterbury of Lewisboro, "but at the same time, you don't have the money to make the big investment that would save money in the future."
Advocates of dirt roads argue that the roads are safer than paved roads because people are forced to drive more slowly. They also slow the pace of development. But more than anything, people seem to enjoy the poetry of dirt roads and the feeling of being transported back in time.
"We don't want to keep other people out," said Suzi Biederman, who lives on Jay Cox Road and who is a member of Dirt Roads of Philipstown. "We want to maintain what is here. That's why we moved here from New York City."
Some, however, question the commitment to rural life of dirt road aficionados. In North Salem, for instance, a homeowner's request to put a small goat breeding farm on 23 acres created a recent stir from residents concerned about odors and manure run-off. The request was rejected by the zoning board of appeals.
"You get this schizophrenic view," said Mr. Keating, who cast a dissenting vote. "People will use the issue of rural character, but they don't really mean rural so much as neat white fences. Rural is semichaotic with working farms that smell. Goats are not prestigious. They may be rural, but they are not prestigious."

HEADLINE: Brazil Seeks To Resolve Debt Impasse

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRASILIA, June 16

 BODY:
On the eve of a visit to the United States, Brazil's President and his new Economy Minister said in interviews here today that they planned to speed up talks with commercial banks over Brazil's $50 billion foreign debt.
"We have a sense of urgency," Marcilio Marques Moreira, the Economy Minister, said of the debt impasse which has moved little in the first 15 months of the Government here. "I hope that by the end of the year we might have it wrapped up." 
 Several hundred yards away, at the Planalto Palace, President Fernando Collor de Mello indicated that the new urgency comes from the top.
"I would have been very happy if this negotiation over our debt had been concluded last year," said the 41-year-old President. "No one is more desirous of a quick conclusion of debt-negotiation process than I am, than the Brazilian Government is."
 
Talks With Bankers
 On Monday, the President and the Economy Minister are to arrive in Washington for a four-day visit. In an indication of the trip's new emphasis on debt, a day in Los Angeles was dropped in favor of a day in New York -- Thursday -- to talk with bankers.
As a signal to the banks, Brazil's delegation will include a new debt negotiator, Pedro Malan, Brazil's representative to the Inter-American Development Bank. It was announced here on Thursday that Jorio Dauster, debt negotiator since last year, would be reassigned to Brussels.
Mr. Dauster was the last holdover from the economic team of Zelia Cardoso de Mello, who resigned one month ago as Economy Minister. Bankers had complained that Ms. Cardoso's approach on the debt was highly confrontational and yielded few results.
Indeed, when Mr. Collor meets with President Bush on Tuesday morning at the White House, the Brazilian will be unable to report much progress on the debt issue. The Senate here delayed until Tuesday a vote on an agreement to repay $8 billion in back interest.
 
Little Progress on Debt
 Approval is expected, but leftist opposition to resuming full payments on the debt remains high. Today, a Supreme Court Justice here rejected a petition by a coalition of five left-wing parties to suspend all debt-service payments until Congress establishes the "legitimacy" of the loans.
Despite these distractions, bankers and economists interviewed here and in Rio de Janeiro believe that the Government wants to move quickly in talks that are to begin in July over rescheduling principal and interest in Brazil's medium- and long-term debt.
"He want's a deal, I know it," the Rio de Janeiro representative of an American bank said of Mr. Moreira. Before becoming Economy Minister, Mr. Moreira served as Brazil's Ambassador to the United States and, before that, as a director for Unibanco, Brazil's fifth-largest private banking group.
At the United States Embassy here, an official said, "It's a real speed-up over what we were hearing from Zelia."
"In Washington, they are going to ask for as much U.S. Government help as possible," the official continued, recalling official United States Government backing for securities in Mexico's debt restructuring.
But this week, in a written interview with Brazil's newsweekly Veja, President Bush seemed to discourage seeking American Government aid.
Asked about official debt reductions extended recently to Poland and Egypt, Mr. Bush responded that Poland was "a unique operation" and Egypt had a "crucial role in regional stability."
"With a cautious economic policy, the Brazilian economy, which is diversified and resistant, can and will overcome the debt problem," Mr. Bush wrote.
Caution seems to be a byword for Mr. Moreira, a discreet diplomat, who spent much of his first month assuring business people that he would not impose any new radical shock programs. During the first year of Mr. Collor's Government, the economy shrank by 7 percent -- largely as a result of Mr. Cardoso's shock experiments.
As if to present a calming image, Mr. Moreira has been photographed walking on Sundays on Ipanema beach in Rio and dining during the week in Brasilia with captains of industry.
"Nobody is thinking about a new economic package right now, and we know there's a team open to discussions," Jose Mindlin, the president of a major metal-working company, recently told Gazeta Mercantil, Brazil's leading business newspaper. "This does away with part of the anxiety in the business community."
 
Modest Inflation Rate
 Next month, Mr. Moreira plans to ease Brazil fully out of price controls imposed last January by Ms. Cardoso. Helping him is a modest 7 percent monthly inflation rate for May and a predicted 9 percent rate for June.
In recent weeks, two free-market changes have been been introduced: the start of a privatization program with the listing of terms of sale for a state steel company, and the opening of Brazil's stock market to direct investment by overseas institutional investors.
In Mr. Moreira's first month as minister the index of Sao Paulo's stock exchange, a volatile bourse, doubled to 11,000. At the same time, the value of Brazil's foreign debt on the secondary market has reached a 15-month high -- 31 cents on the dollar.
 
Unfrozen Bank Accounts
 In late May, an attempted national strike fizzled. And with production improving in Sao Paulo's factories, most economists contend the nation is beginning to pull out of one of the deepest recessions in memory.
But looming in September is another legacy of Ms. Cardoso -- the scheduled unfreezing of bank accounts.
Francisco Gros, new president of the Central Bank here, estimates that half of the currency frozen in March 1990 has already leaked back into the economy. But, many economists predict a surge of inflation in September, when the first parcel of frozen money is released to its owners.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
Companies
Federal Express will order up to 75 cargo planes from Airbus in a $6 billion deal, Airbus officials said. The deal, which is set to be announced in the next few days, will be one of Airbus's biggest successes in the American market, which has long been dominated by Boeing and McDonnell Douglas. [Page D1.] 
 
Honda took improper advantage of the United States-Canada free-trade agreement, the United States Custom Service has concluded. Honda is said to have avoided paying millions of dollars in duties on cars imported into the U.S. from its Ontario plant. [D1.]
Digital Equipment will lay off more employees in its fiscal year beginning July 1, the company acknowledged. The company's chief operating officer recently told a group of financial analysts that the number of layoffs might be similar to the reduction in the 1991 fiscal year, which was 8,000. [D2.]
The restructuring of Donald J. Trump's holdings is near completion and the developer has settled most of the major legal and financial issues facing him, Mr. Trump and some of his big bank lenders say on the eve of an important regulatory hearing. [D2.]
 
The Economy
Part-time work is increasingly becoming the only work available, more and more Americans are finding. Particularly in retail businesses, companies are seeking to save money and gain flexibility by building their work forces around part-timers. [A1.]
Wall Street is providing investors with a wealth of information on Government securities prices, data that most investment firms have for decades viewed as proprietary. The move pits virtually all of Wall Street against Cantor Fitzgerald and Telerate. [D1.]
 
The Media Business
Changes in staff and style leave no doubt at Random House that Harold Evans, whom S. I. Newhouse brought in as publisher eight months ago, is fulfilling his mandate to revamp the company. Mr. Evans has also committed Random House to broadening its publishing in business, science, art and current events. [D1.]
Not all book publishers dig into their slush pile, that mound of unsolicited proposals, sample chapters and full-length manuscripts. But those who do have discovered Tom Clancy, Martha Grimes, Kathleen E. Woodiwiss and many other authors. [D8.]
U.S. media companies' effort in Eastern Europe is minimal so far, but plenty of claims wait to be staked there. Members of a group of U.S. magazine editors and publishers who recently returned from a 12-day trip to Vienna, Budapest, Prague, Berlin, Warsaw and Krakow, said they were impressed by the vitality and inventiveness of journalists struggling to effect a transition from state control to independence. [D9.]
Television and journalism are increasingly heading "toward the lowest common denominator, suppressing variety in taste and opinion," according to one of the most respected names in media and advertising. Randall Rothenberg: Adscene. [D9.]
The appeal of an advertising trend may be waning, to wit, that of paying agencies based on criteria like how well sales pitches sell products. So suggests the latest version of an annual survey of client-agency relationships. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]

Time Warner's investment bankers have so far been wrong in telling the company that its stock would trade at $100 to $105 a share after it announced its complex rights offering. The shares plummeted on the initial news of the deal and continue to languish in the mid-90's. They dropped Friday in the face of a rising market. [D4.]
The bond market decided on Friday that the recession's end was not yet in sight. What prompted this assessment was the growing belief that the flow of Government economic data for May that was released late last week was not adjusted for the weather factor. Credit Markets. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Trump's Debt Revision Nearly Done

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
On the eve of an important regulatory hearing, the restructuring of Donald J. Trump's holdings is near completion and the developer has settled most of the major legal and financial issues facing his deeply indebted empire, Mr. Trump and some of his big bank lenders say.
The New Jersey Casino Control Commission meets this morning to review Mr. Trump's financial stability and whether he has been able to reorganize his bank debts. In April, the commission told the developer that he had to complete new loan agreements with his banks and bondholders by today's hearing or the gambling licenses for his three Atlantic City casinos might not be renewed. 
 Over the weekend, executives of the Trump Organization, the developer's main corporate vehicle, negotiated with the leading bondholders of the Trump Castle casino over a $41 million payment due today on $351.8 million of bonds. The Castle was the last of Mr. Trump's casinos to reach a major agreement with creditors.
People close to the talks said that the Castle bondholders agreed to a roughly outlined deal that would reduce the interest rate on the bonds to about 9.5 percent, from the original 13.75 percent, and would eliminate this year's interest payments. In exchange, the bondholders will get 50 percent ownership in the casino from Mr. Trump. Mr. Trump will retain the option to raise his stake to 75 percent depending on whether the casino's performance improves in the future.
Earlier, Mr. Trump had reached a settlement with some of the major holders of Resorts International bonds who were suing him for fraudulent conveyance in connection with his acquisition of the then unfinished Taj Mahal casino in 1988. The bondholders claimed that when Mr. Trump sold Resorts International to Merv Griffin in 1988, he fraudulently took millions of dollars out of the company.
Under the terms of the settlement, which the bondholders are expected to approve, Mr. Trump and one of his insurance companies will pay Resorts bondholders several million dollars to drop all claims of fraud.
Most of the big banks that lent Mr. Trump nearly $2 billion have signed a letter expressing confidence in his debt reorganization. The letter, along with the specific terms of the various loan agreements and payment reschedulings, will be presented at today's casino commission hearing.
In the letter, according to people involved in the bank negotiations, Mr. Trump's bankers express confidence that the restructuring of Mr. Trump's holdings will be completed in the near future and that this will lend some stability to his web of heavily indebted assets.
 
$70 Million in Cash
 In a letter sent to the casino commission last week, Stephen F. Bollenbach, chief financial officer of the Trump Organization, said the Trump casinos and "other properties" had in excess of $70 million in cash.
Last Friday, Mr. Trump made a $16.5 million interest payment on bonds issued by his Trump Plaza casino in Atlantic City. That payment was made one day before its due date.
As part of the restructuring plans with banks announced earlier, Mr. Trump will be released from his personal guarantee of hundreds of millions of dollars in loans. In exchange, he will give up ownership of the Trump Shuttle airline, all but a tiny percentage of his 50 percent interest in New York's Grand Hyatt Hotel, and his yacht, the Trump Princess.
The developer has also agreed to cede 20 percent of his Taj Mahal casino to bondholders in a restructuring that will put the Taj through what is known as a prepackaged bankruptcy. In such a deal, most creditors approve of a debt settlement before bankruptcy is filed. The actual bankruptcy filing then becomes a legal way of breaking original contracts and officially establishing new credit agreements.

HEADLINE: PART-TIME HIRINGS BRING DEEP CHANGE IN U.S. WORKPLACES

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN

 BODY:
In a slow but unmistakable erosion of the five-day, 40-hour week, more and more Americans are finding that the only work they can get is part time.
Throughout the economy, and particularly in retail businesses, companies are seeking to save money and gain flexibility by building their work forces around part-time workers, whose schedules can be lengthened, shortened or turned upside down each week to meet an employer's immediate needs. 
 And though many people choose part-time work, the sharpest increase in the labor force is among involuntary part-timers: those who want but cannot find jobs with regular hours and rewards.
While the nonagricultural work force grew 54 percent from 1970 to 1990, the number of involuntary part-timers jumped 121 percent, to 4.9 million, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which gets its figures through household surveys. The ranks of voluntary part-timers grew 69 percent.
 
Where Industry Flourished
 The proliferation of involuntary part-time work is most pronounced in recessions like the current one and in old, once heavily industrial regions like the Pittsburgh area.
Part-time status leaves people like Dorothy Watkins in poverty. Ms. Watkins, a 31-year-old, twice-divorced mother of two boys, lives with them in a trailer without a telephone in Wellsburg, W.Va. She cannot find a job there, she said, so she drives the 35 miles to a Giant Eagle supermarket in Pittsburgh. She usually works five days a week, from 4 to 10 P.M. -- all that management permits her, she said.
Ms. Watkins, who has been getting $4.25, the national minimum wage, is soon to get a 40-cent hourly raise, as a result of a new contract following a strike against Giant Eagle by the United Food and Commercial Workers union. But the $624 increase in her $6,630 annual income from the store and to the $100 a month in child support she receives from a former husband will not go very far.
 
Can Open Opportunities
 From her pay, she subtracts $80 a month for her lot in a trailer park and $65 a month for the loan on her car, plus medical expenses for herself, electricity for the trailer and gasoline and automobile insurance. That leaves her eligible for $150 a month in food stamps and Medicaid for the children, aid that she would gladly trade for the chance to work more. "I don't like going to the welfare," she said.
Not all part-time work is undesirable. For people with highly prized, highly paid skills, like accountants or computer programmers, part-time work is an appealing alternative. The growth of part-time jobs has also opened opportunities for people who want more money but have competing demands for their time, like children. And while few part-time workers get full benefits, many are covered by spouses' benefits.
Still, part-timers suffer many disadvantages. Often they do not know how many hours, or which shift, they will work in a given week until the previous Thursday or Friday. If they are laid off, they rarely get severance pay.
Federal law requires that employers make Social Security contributions for part-timers and that they grant the same retirement benefits they give full-timers to those who work 1,000 hours a year, or 20 hours a week. But it says nothing about full-time workers' biggest benefit: health insurance.
Soaring health-care costs are giving employers more incentive than ever to use part-timers. In a study of part-time work in March, the General Accounting Office, an investigative and auditing arm of Congress, reported that retail stores provided health insurance for 47 percent of their full-time workers but just 10 percent of part-timers.
 
The 1970's Set a Trend
 Without health insurance, workers must be ready to pay for their own health care unless they are poor enough to qualify for Medicaid, the Federal and state health program.
The accounting office study said 33 states denied unemployment benefits to part-time workers unless their earnings exceeded $2,000 a year. Of families headed by part-time workers, the study said, 21 percent have incomes below the poverty line, as against 5 percent of families headed by full-time workers.
Most of the increase in involuntary part-timers happened in the 1970's. After shooting up in the 1981-82 recession, the growth slowed in the rest of the 1980's, when people could easily find regular jobs. But in the first five months of this year, the bureau reported June 7, the involuntary part-time work force has averaged 5.7 million people, one million above the level of a year ago. The Government says there were about 105 million civilian nonagricultural workers over the age of 16 as of May.
Much of the growth in involuntary part-time workers took place in retail businesses.
 
How Statistics Can Mislead
 The Government statistics understate the place of part-time work in the economy, said Chris Tilly, an economist at the University of Lowell in Massachusetts. In a study of part-time work conducted for the Labor Department, he noted that the Government counts part-time workers, not part-time jobs. Some workers, for example, hold two or three involuntary part-time jobs. They are counted as full-timers, but in their pay, benefits and working conditions they are part-timers.
Giant Eagle, the only supermarket chain in Pittsburgh, is a believer in the part-time work force. Of its more than 6,000 employees, more than four-fifths fall into the category. It pays them a lower hourly rate than it pays full-time employees who do the same jobs, and it grants them fewer benefits.
For Giant Eagle and many other employers, part-time workers help achieve efficiency, hold down costs and serve customers better. If most customers show up between 4 and 10 P.M., why not have extra cashiers working those hours and only those hours?
"People now want you to be open 24 hours a day, seven days a week," said Joseph R. Faccenda, senior vice president at Giant Eagle. "You need a work force of full-timers to give you stability, but you need part-timers to give you flexibility."
 
Counted as 'Full Time'
 As far as the Government is concerned, Mary Rockymore is a full-time worker. The single mother of children ages 16, 11 and 8, she has been earning $5.25 an hour for 17 to 21 hours' work a week as a bakery clerk at Giant Eagle. She also earns $7 an hour working 27 to 30 hours as a gynecologist's secretary. Ms. Rockymore earns too much to qualify for public assistance, but her Giant Eagle health insurance covers only her. She gets none from the gynecologist, so she has to be resourceful in getting help for an asthmatic daughter.
"When she gets sick, I go to the hospital and explain that I have no health insurance, and they give her medicine samples," she said. Now and then, people in her neighborhood sell their food stamps to her, which is illegal. "If they have $50 worth, they might sell them for $25 or $30," she said.
Some retailers, including Giant Eagle, defy the dictionary by employing people who are part-timers in name only. Scores of Giant Eagle employees work well beyond the 35 hours a week that the Bureau of Labor Statistics considers the minimum for full-time work, but the company declares them part-timers, pays them a lower hourly rate than full-timers and provides them the same meager benefits that a 20-hour-a-week worker receives.
No law requires an employer to extend full-time benefits and pay rates to all who work more than 35 hours a week. But as part of the strike settlement, Giant Eagle made one concession: Part-timers who work an average of 40 hours a week for a year will be given health benefits not only for themselves, which has been the practice for such workers, but also for their families.
Robert Derberry, 59, works 53 hours a week cleaning the bakery at a Giant Eagle. Three years ago, as a machinist at a printing company, he earned $11.75 an hour, more than twice his pay now.
"They had real good benefits -- hospitalization, eye care, dental care, good retirement," he said. "Germany bought them out, and they took all the stuff to Germany."
Mr. Derberry works seven days a week: from 2 to 10 P.M. Monday through Saturday and from 2 to 7 P.M. on Sundays -- 53 hours. Like other part-timers who have been with the company more than a year, he has been getting health insurance for himself. But unlike full-timers, he does not receive insurance for his wife. He will qualify for benefits for her after he works 40 hours a week for a full year from the date of the new union contract.
How does Giant Eagle decide which 50-hour-a-week employees are full-timers and which are part-timers? Partly on the basis of seniority and ability.
In addition, Mr. Faccenda said, the company often offers full-time jobs on night shifts or at stores in undesirable locations if few part-timers can be found to take those jobs. But Mr. Derberry said he had never received such an offer.
 
Stability and Flexibility
 Around Pittsburgh, Giant Eagle has been an important factor in the growth of part-time work, much of it tied to the region's shift from manufacturing to service jobs in recent decades. Jobs in fast-growing stores, fast-food outlets, hospitals, health-care businesses and many other services, all big users of part-timers, displaced five-day, 40- hour manufacturing jobs.
Giant Eagle has proved a master of the odd-hour economy. Facing declining sales from competition at the start of the 1980's, it won sharp wage cuts from its unionized workers, then undertook a price-cutting campaign that drove out other chains, including A&P and Kroger.
Responding to appeals from the union that he do more for part-timers, Mr. Faccenda asked: "How long do you want to stay in business? You become uncompetitive. Your business goes down. People lose their jobs."
People like Ms. Watkins, the part-timer from West Virginia, should look elsewhere for work, he said. "Logically, if somebody has a family to raise, this job wasn't meant for them."
But for some people in Pittsburgh, like Emily and Tom Hickey, who were married in April, it is hard to find anything better. Mr. Hickey, 36, is an auto mechanic. His pay varies from $100 to $400 a week because he is paid by the job, not by the time he spends at it. He gets no benefits.
After five years in the meat department at a Giant Eagle, Ms. Hickey, 34, has health benefits only for herself. She works 40 to 48 hours a week for $5.90 an hour, a little over half what some full-timers get.
"The part-timers thought they should have given us more," Ms. Hickey said. "I did service meats. I did gourmet. I am now in seafood. I do all the work of a full-timer. I deserve to be a full-timer."

HEADLINE: U.S. Ban of Infected Travelers Attacked at World AIDS Conference

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FLORENCE, June 16

 BODY:
The United States Government came under sharp attack at the opening of the seventh international meeting on AIDS here today for its policy on restricting entry of travelers infected with the disease.
The critics, including scientists and health officials from around the world, also attacked the Bush Administration's last-minute decision to send only a couple hundred Federal scientists -- half the size of the original delegation -- to Italy for the six-day meeting. 
 In addresses to the 8,000 participants, European health officials vehemently criticized the Bush Administration policy of excluding from the United States foreigners infected with the AIDS virus. Organizers of the next international meeting, to be held next year in Boston, have said it may have to be canceled if the travel restrictions remain.
In a letter given to each participant, Harvard University, sponsor of the Boston meeting, said, "If this cancellation occurs, the resulting year's delay in progressagainst AIDS will be the responsibility of the government of the U.S."
Vasso Papandreou, the Commissioner for Health and Social Affairs of the European Communities in Brussels, said her organization had made a point of congratulating Italy for providing unhindered entry for people infected with the virus. including participants at the meeting. Mrs. Papandreou said she would write the Health and Human Services Secretary, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, to express her organization's concern about the travel restriction.
In criticizing the reduction of the United States delegation to Florence, speakers cited the pressing need to answer scientific puzzles like how the AIDS virus spreads in the body to paralyze the immune system. The human immunodeficiency virus, which causes AIDS, is known to be transmitted through sexual intercourse and blood, but scientists do not know what cells the virus first infects.
The Federal Government, which sent more than 700 scientists to last year's meeting in San Francisco, first held this year's delegation to 400 because of the cost of foreign travel. Last week, the Administration and Congress imposed new budget restrictions, causing the Public Health Service to halve its delegation.
Dr. William Roper, the head of the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, the Federal agency responsible for tracking the AIDS epidemic, was among those who canceled at the last minute.
 
Scurrying for Refunds
 Today, Federal officials were seen scurrying to negotiate for refunds of hotel-room deposits and the meeting's registration fee, which was as high as $700 a person. Organizers of the meeting said the fees were not refundable, and it was not immediately clear whether any money was saved.
Repeated attempts to reach the United States Public Health Service for comment were unsuccessful.
Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the head of National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease and the ranking Federal scientist here, said he was "disturbed we couldn't send many of our scientists here." Some, he said, paid their own way.
Dr. Giovanni Battista Rossi, the chairman of the AIDS meeting here, said the exchange of ideas among scientists was an important part of meetings like this and that participants would sorely miss the opportunity for discussion with the American scientists who could not attend.
An increasing number of scientists are questioning the value of large meetings like this one, which will cost $8.5 million. The AIDS meetings have been innovative in including patients with the disease to help learn about the social, political, economic and ethical aspects of AIDS. But in recent years, fewer major advances and research findings have been presented at such large meetings, with more scientists choosing to release their findings in professional journals.
Speakers at the opening session pleaded for a greater public response to the worldwide AIDS epidemic, particularly in developing countries.
Dr. Vulimiri Ramalingaswami of the All India Institute of Medical Sciences in New Delhi said Asia was "sitting on top of a volcano" with respect to AIDS.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
The End of Union

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
On June 22, 1941 50 years ago this Saturday -- Hitler's "Operation Barbarossa" began: three million German troops invaded the Soviet Union. The "Great Patriotic War," as Communists like to call it, gave a temporary sense of nationhood to a far-flung collection of separate peoples who never were a nation.
Now, a half-century later, that imperial unity is dissolved, defeated not by any invader but by the failure of its overextended tyranny. The Soviet "union" is no more a union today than the British Empire is an empire. 
 June 1991 is the month that historians may choose as the end of the unnatural union. Mikhail Gorbachev, last of the unionists, began this epochal month with a Nobel speech throwing his empire on the mercy of the world, whining that it was "entitled to expect large-scale support" and threatening that "a new peaceful period in history will vanish" if his demands for money to maintain the old order are not met.
Following that death rattle of an expiring system, the Russian people, for the first time in their long history, went to the polls to choose a leader. The election of the anti-Communist Boris Yeltsin proclaims the Russian acceptance of the dissolution of the bonds of empire, and the devolution of power to the various republics.
The Soviet "union" is now a fiction, its facade maintained by old party apparatchiks and K.G.B. and Red Army bosses who know that with the end of the myth of homo sovieticus, "the new Soviet man," their power to do more than negotiate arms reductions will end.
The reality is Russia. The reality is eight other peoples who may be amenable to a loose association of sovereign states. The reality is three other republics and three Baltic nations that rightly consider themselves free and independent.
Is this breakup of the last imperial power good for the cause of freedom and conducive to peace? Not if you listen to our State Department status-quo enthusiasts, our Charles River Chicken Littles, our foreign policy establishment drawn up in vast, cumbrous array.
Their mantra is disintegration, as if the U.S.S.R. were still integrated or ought to be; they caution against dismemberment, as if Georgia and the Ukraine were arms of the Russian body; they warn of chaos, as if only the continuance of Moscow's old internal empire could avert anarchy.
If you buy their conclusion that the political realignment now on the march is headed not toward freedom but toward chaos, then you will find their policy makes sense: we should prop up the union, dole out money to encourage experiments with a market system and democracy, and thereby make certain that the nuclear missiles remain in responsible hands.
But what if that chaos assumption is wrong? What if the hard times and angry desire for great change now in crescendo are ameliorated by Western aid, and the Kremlin centralists are permitted to regain their authority? Once past the crisis, they can be depended upon to revert to type, and we will once again confront an expansionist superpower.
Chaos-mongers forget that the driving force for productive change is pervasive disgust with the way things are in a Communist union. The only way to improvement must be a leap into capitalism -- no more baby steps, no more hot air about phony reform and no more vain hope that Western governments will come to the rescue.
The notion that other governments can solve their problem gives the Kremlin unionists' game away. They will never understand that relief cannot come from infusions of other governments' capital. The only investment massive enough to help must come from private enterprise willing to take risk to make a profit.
That investment will come only when Russia and the other freed countries embrace private property, let the currency become convertible and make profit possible in an atmosphere of freedom.
The Russian people, by their vote last week, have shown they will follow a politician in this direction. In his meeting this week with President Yeltsin, President Bush should urge him on; he should not undercut this Russian's unprecedented mandate with warnings against disunion.
Breaking up is hard to do, but it is necessary and right; we should not make it harder by holding out false hopes of a union bailout.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Wrong Track for Tribes

BYLINE: By RICHARD E. MOONEY

 BODY:
Connecticut is getting a casino, like it or not. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan has approved the operation of a gambling hall on the Mashantucket Pequot Indian reservation near New London. Two governors tried to stop it, but the Pequots won in court.
Casino gambling now has another foothold, setting a precedent for still more. It may seem ugly to object just when Indians are getting a crack at this lucrative business. But the overriding issue is the spread of casino gambling; that the issue is raised by Indians is unfortunate happenstance. 
 Casino promoters didn't really need the Pequots' help. States are turning to gambling for "painless" revenue. Iowa now has riverboat gambling on the Mississippi. Four old Colorado mining towns are opening modern mock-ups of Wild West gambling dens. This may be painless for politicians who shy from raising taxes, but it is hardly a wholesome social standard.
While Native Americans have as much right as anyone to take the casino plunge, it's a sad fact that they are driven by economic distress. Some tribes have a sound base in manufacturing, but it's easier to open gaming halls than factories. Gambling also offers quick profit for little investment; the Pequots got financing from Malaysia after U.S. lenders turned them down.
Florida Seminoles started gambling as a business in the 1970's with high-stakes bingo. The state tried to crack down but lost in court, and the games quickly spread to other tribes. In 1987, the Supreme Court upheld the lower courts' essential point: If state law prohibits an activity, reservations must respect the prohibition. But they are not subject to regulation of activities the state permits.
Connecticut bans casinos but lets charities and other worthy causes sponsor casino-style Las Vegas Nights to raise money. Balking at the Pequots' casino plan, Connecticut argued that one-night games and a full-time gambling hall are distinguishable; the courts said they're not.
Still, casinos aren't bingo. They attract different crowds. Governors and state law enforcement authorities who resist casinos on reservations are rightly concerned with the unsavory elements that swarm to casinos; the Pequots share this concern and are cooperating with the state in planning for the casino's regulation. But authorities also fear that the establishment of an Indian casino creates pressure for casinos statewide.
Roughly 125 tribes operate some 150 gaming establishments now. Estimates of their annual gross run as high as $700 million. About half of these enterprises are for bingo; one high-tech Mega Bingo game links reservations in seven states by satellite and offers $500,000 jackpots. A third are card rooms, and most of the rest are things like off-track betting and video games.
Some tribes, particularly some large ones, don't want reservation gambling any more than Connecticut governors do. They don't like intrusive outsiders. A number have succeeded in mainstream businesses, largely through their own efforts. Blessed with natural resources, more than 30 tribes are in oil and gas. Others are in timber and mining.
The Mississippi Choctaws make parts for Ford. Several tribes have Pentagon contracts. And the Wisconsin Winnebagos are starting a pharmaceutical company to make generic and non-prescription drugs. The Winnebagos are using profits from bingo, a widely accepted game with none of the social risk that comes with casinos. The spread of casinos is unwelcome.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
