HEADLINE: A Screwy Subsidy for Drivers

 BODY:
Your employer can give you $15 worth of tax-free tokens, passes or fare cards each month for riding to work on public transportation. If it's more, you're taxed on the full amount, not just the part over $15. There is no such lid, however, when companies provide free parking for people who commute by car. That's a tax-exempt freebie, worth hundreds of dollars.
Sound screwy? It is. Heedless of fuel efficiency and the environment, the tax code favors driving to work. President Bush's energy message declared that something -- he didn't say what -- should be done about it. Administration officials lean toward a one-third increase in the modest mass-transit subsidy, plus an adjustment for inflation. 
 Meanwhile, the Internal Revenue Service is proceeding with the inflation adjustment, raising the $15 ceiling to $21. That would last only nine days in New York City, and less in some places.
The tax technocrats don't address the disparity between subsidies, nor would they change the rule on taxing the entire amount when it exceeds the tax-free limit. Only Congress can fix those things.
The theory behind the $15 exemption is that it's de minimis -- too small to fuss with. A dozen bills in Congress offer a more sensible ceiling; most say $60 or more. But the best idea comes from two Republicans, Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Representative Jan Meyers of Kansas. They would equalize the transit and parking subsidies by canceling the exemption for parking unless employees were also offered an equivalent amount for travel by mass transit and car or van pools.
Tax purists oppose all such subsidies, but that's unrealistic. Employers aren't about to impose parking fees on their lots, and Congress won't make them do so. True, a fixed subsidy benefits employees unequally, depending on their tax bracket. But that's already the case with parking privileges, and it's a subject too prickly for Congress.
The current bias in favor of cars is both bad policy and unfair. It's time to strike a balance.

HEADLINE: K. H. Klipstein, 91, Cyanamid President And Philanthropist

BYLINE: By PETER B. FLINT

 BODY:
Kenneth H. Klipstein, a former president of the American Cyanamid Company and a longtime New Jersey civic leader, died on Friday at the Meadow Lakes Retirement Home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 91 years old.
He died of emphysema and respiratory failure, his son, David, said. 
 Mr. Klipstein, a native of East Orange, N.J., earned a bachelor's degree in economics and a master's degree in chemistry at Princeton University. He started his career at his father's company, E. C. Klipstein and Sons, of Carteret, early manufacturers of dyes and other chemical products, from 1924 until 1933, when it merged with American Cyanamid.
At American Cyanamid, his posts included general manager of research, executive vice president and then president from 1961 to 1965, when he retired. He was the founding chairman of the Chemical Industry Council of New Jersey and the recipient of many professional awards.
 
Founder of Conservation Group
 In 1954, he founded the Ernest Christian Klipstein Foundation of New Vernon, N.J., in honor of his father. The philanthropy provides annual grants in higher education, cultural programs and conservation. He was its president at his death.
Mr. Klipstein was a founding member and longtime trustee of the New Jersey Conservation Foundation and also a trustee of the Morristown Memorial Hospital and the Newark Museum. He was a former board member of the National Industrial Conference Board, the Newark College of Engineering Research Foundation and the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce.
He had previously been a director of eight utilities, banks and other corporations, and the president of both the Blooming Grove Hunting and Fishing Club in Hawley, Pa., where he maintained a home, and of the Mountain Lake Club in Lake Wales, Fla.
His first wife of 53 years, the former Doris Gubelman, died in 1980. His second wife, the former Anne D'olier Pitney, died in 1984.
Besides his son, who lives in San Diego, Mr. Klipstein is survived by five grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Sir W. Arthur Lewis, 76, Is Dead; Winner of Nobel Economics Prize

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
Sir W. Arthur Lewis, a Princeton University professor emeritus who was an adviser to several nations and won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1979, died on Saturday at his home in Barbados. He was 76 years old.
Sir Arthur was considered a leading authority on economic growth and political and social change in emerging nations. He shared the economics prize with Theodore W. Schultz, a University of Chicago professor, for research into economic development "with particular consideration of the problems of developing countries." 
 In 1954, he published what many economists considered one of the first academic works in this area, "The Theory of Economic Growth." He also wrote 11 other books and more than 80 monographs and articles.
William Arthur Lewis was born on St. Lucia in 1915 and was educated at the University of London, where he earned his bachelor's degree in 1937 and a doctorate in 1940. He taught there until 1948, when he left for the University of Manchester. He was named vice chancellor of the University of the West Indies in Kingston, Jamaica, in 1959.
He joined Princeton's faculty in 1963 and was named the James Madison Profesor of Political Economy. He taught undergraduate and graduate courses in economic development and modern economic history.
Students praised Sir Arthur's courses for focusing on ideas rather than numbers. He retired in 1983.
He had been named an honorary member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1962.
Sir Arthur is survived by his wife, Gladys Jacobs Lewis of Barbados and Princeton, N.J.; two daughters, Elizabeth Lewis of Cranbury, N.J., and Barbara Lewis of Brooklyn; and four brothers, Stanley Lewis of Ghana, Earl Lewis of Trinidad, Allen Lewis, a former Governor General of St. Lucia, and Victor Lewis of St. Lucia.
A state funeral is planned for Saturday on St. Lucia.

HEADLINE: William Ogdon, 89, On Editorial Board of New York Times

 BODY:
William D. Ogdon, a member of the editorial board of The New York Times from 1946 to 1966, died on Saturday at his home in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 89 years old.
He died of a heart attack, his son, Thomas, said. 
Mr. Ogdon specialized in writing editorials on the political, economic and governmental issues of New York City and New York State. In his 35 years at the newspaper, he had also been a copy editor and later contributed articles to The Times Magazine and The Times Book Review.
On the eve of his retirement in 1955, the Citizens Budget Commission gave him a special award for "high public service." It cited "his well-informed editorial comments on all phases of municipal affairs over a period of many years and especially for his penetrating analyses of municipal finance" in 1965 that disclosed the significance of the city's efforts to gain new taxing authority from the State Legislature.
William Duley Ogdon was born in Hoopeston, Ill., and grew up in Toledo, Ohio. He earned a bachelor's degree at Transylvania College and did graduate studies at Yale. He was a reporter with The Toledo Times and a rewrite man and copy editor with The St. Louis Globe-Democrat.
He joined The New York Times in 1931, working successively as a copy editor, an editor in the Washington bureau and on the editorial page. In World War II he served in Navy intelligence and on the carrier Yorktown in the Pacific, rising to commander.
Surviving, besides his son, who lives in Manhattan, is his wife of 59 years, Juanita; a daughter, Judith Gardner of Lexington, Ky., five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 18, 1991, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about William D. Ogdon, a former editorial writer for The New York Times, misstated his retirement year. It was 1966, not 1955.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Honda Skirted Customs Fees

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
After a yearlong audit, the United States Customs Service has concluded that Honda took improper advantage of the United States-Canada free-trade agreement to avoid paying millions of dollars in duties on cars imported into the United States from its Alliston, Ontario, plant.
 Under the agreement, which was intended to encourage the use of auto parts and labor from the United States and Canada, cars assembled in one of the two countries and shipped across the border are exempt from tariffs if at least half their content comes from either country. 
Although the American Honda Motor Company said it met that test, Customs Service auditors said the actual "North American content" of Honda Civics imported from the Ontario plant was 25 percent to 30 percent less than the amounts claimed by the company, a subsidiary of the Tokyo-based Honda Motor Company. The auditors made their conclusions in a confidential report, a copy of which was obtained by a reporter.
 Details of the Honda audit were obtained from Bush Administration officials and Congressional aides eager to see the free-trade pact with Canada vigorously enforced.
 The preliminary conclusions come as the United States and Canada are negotiating a similar pact with Mexico.
 Honda, which had not seen the report, disputed its conclusions when told of them. The company said it believed that its cars produced in Canada for sale in the United States were entitled to duty-free treatment.
 In a confidential memorandum to the Treasury Department reporting preliminary results of the audit, Customs Commissioner Carol B. Hallett said, "We have determined that Honda has failed to meet the requirements for free-tariff treatment" under the trade agreement.
 Accordingly, she said, the Customs Service intends to "begin action immediately to collect $20 million in duties for vehicles imported in 1989 and 1990."
 Before imposing additional duties, the Customs Service usually gives an importer 20 days to challenge the proposed action. Once the agency decides how much is due, the company normally must pay that amount before it can file a formal protest with the Customs Service.
 
'Rules of Origin' Dispute
 The auditors did not accuse Honda of fraud, but said the company had manipulated the free-trade agreement's "rules of origin," ignored "commercial realities" and misrepresented the company's costs in an effort to avoid tariffs.
 Valuation of merchandise for customs purposes is often a complex matter in today's global economy, in which parts and labor come from many countries. As a result, manufacturers may disagree with the Customs Service about how much of a product originates overseas and how much should be counted as American.
 Donald Harrison, a lawyer for Honda, said the company had cooperated with the audit and had given the Government several memorandums explaining its position.
 "This is not just a question of dollars and cents," said Mr. Harrison, a lawyer in the Washington office of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher. "It's a matter of pride for Honda, which has invested billions of dollars in its North American operations."
 Honda is the leading Japanese auto maker in the United States. Its sales here have more than doubled during the last decade, and its Accord model is the best-selling car in the country.
 
Could Be Embarrassing to Bush
 The Customs Service report is likely to be used by members of Congress who object to the proposed agreement with Mexico and have vowed to fight it on Capitol Hill. If it is perceived as revealing a circumvention of the Canada pact, the audit could be embarrassing to the White House, which is pushing hard for the Mexico pact.
 The United States' normal tariff on imported autos is 2.5 percent of a car's value. So if an auto maker qualifies for duty-free treatment, it can save $200 on an $8,000 car.
 To establish the level of North American content in the Honda Civics that it studied, Customs Service auditors traced the source of parts used to build the vehicles in Marysville, Ohio, and in Ontario. The cars made in Ohio are not subject to tariffs, but the auditors' findings tend to confirm the assertions of independent researchers that the American subsidiaries of Japanese auto makers import many parts for cars they build in the United States.
 Customs officials and other experts on the auto industry, like Sean P. McAlinden, an economist at the University of Michigan, said Hondas produced in Canada or the United States generally have a higher proportion of North American parts and labor than vehicles sold in this country by other Japanese auto makers like Toyota. So if the Hondas do not meet the test for duty-free treatment, they said, it is highly unlikely that other imports will.
 
Pricing 'Defies Explanation'
 In addition to questioning Honda's country-of-origin percentages, the Customs Service audit also said the company's pricing policy sometimes "defies explanation." The auditors said Honda offered cars for sale to consumers in the United States at less than the cost of manufacture, as computed by the Customs Service.
 The practice of selling below cost, known as dumping, is used by companies that are willing to sustain losses to increase their share of the market. It can harm domestic industries by undercutting their prices.
 Among the auditors' findings, as described in confidential Customs Service documents, were the following:
 *The manufacturing costs of Honda Civics, as computed by Customs auditors, often exceeded the values reported to the Customs Service when the vehicles entered the United States from Canada. Some vehicles deemed by Customs to cost $8,146 were listed, at entry, as having a value of $6,868 and were offered for sale to consumers with a sticker price of $6,635, or roughly $1,500 less than the cost of manufacture.
 *Honda is willing and able to "exercise control" over prices charged by Japanese or Japanese-controlled suppliers to which it is linked in a "web of cross-ownership." Some affiliated auto-parts suppliers "sell to Honda at a price below their cost of manufacture and continually operate at a loss."
 *"Rather than basing prices on market-force factors such as actual North American costs, profit or customer-supplier negotiations, Honda prices within North America are developed and fixed in accordance with the dictates of Honda Japan."
 In an interview, Michael H. Lane, the Deputy Commissioner of Customs, said the agency had not singled out Japanese companies for investigation. "The Customs Service is doing what it's supposed to do, is carrying out its statutory responsibilities," he said.
 For Honda Civics assembled in Canada, the company certified that $3,350 worth of materials came from North America, but the Customs Service said $1,085 of this amount represented "foreign costs." The agency concluded that at least 62 percent of the materials used to produce the autos -- $3,760 of a total $6,025 -- originated outside North America.
 Even when parts were not imported, they often came from companies affiliated with Honda, the audit report said. "Of approximately $775 of materials or parts for the engine assembled in Ohio," the report said, "only three parts ($9.06) and $42.69 of raw materials are sourced from U.S.-based companies that do not have an equity relationship with Honda."
 The engines are important because they account for a substantial portion of the materials Honda listed as originating in North America.
 Honda's lawyer, Mr. Harrison, said that in calculating the North American content of its cars, Honda was entitled to count not only the direct costs of production but also related costs for the purchasing department, information services and other activities essential to production.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
East Europe's Press Still Beckoning

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
More than a year after the start of a fierce bidding war among foreign publishers for newspapers and magazines in Eastern Europe, the involvement of American media companies there remains minimal.
 Except for Time Warner Inc., which has a partial interest in developing and operating cable systems in Hungary representing 250,000 subscribers and is looking into developing a pay-television movie service there, none of the big American newspaper or magazine publishers are competing for ownership of Eastern Europe's emerging free press. 
On the other hand, Robert Maxwell of Britain; Rupert Murdoch; Robert Hersant, who owns Le Figaro in France, and the Springer and Bertelsmann groups of Germany are staking claims.
 
Media Up for Grabs
 And there are plenty of claims waiting to be staked.
 "Whoever is willing to take something over gets to take it over," said Ruth Whitney, editor in chief of Glamour magazine. "Ownership occurs not by negotiation but by anyone who steps in and fills the void."
 But the difficulty, said Pat Miller, an editor at large for the American Society of Magazine Editors, is "nobody knows who owns what."
 Ms. Whitney and Ms. Miller were members of a group of United States magazine editors and publishers who recently returned from a 12-day trip to Vienna, Budapest, Prague, Berlin, Warsaw and Krakow, Poland, that was sponsored by the society and the Magazine Publishers of America. They said they were impressed by the vitality and inventiveness of journalists struggling to effect a transition from state control to independence.
 
Americans Are Better Trusted
 John Mack Carter, the editor in chief of Good Housekeeping and director of development at Hearst magazines, said the running thread in the talks with East European journalists was their wariness of foreign investment and desire to limit foreign ownership. But while many of them were uneasy about European entrepreneurs, they were more trusting of Americans, Mr. Carter found.
 "They are like heat-seeking missiles, coming after greenbacks and looking to the U.S.A.," he said.
 One American testing the waters in Eastern Europe is Edward T. Giller, a former broadcaster based in Altoona, Pa. He and two partners set up Pentor Communications International, an American company that has commitments in excess of $2 million in joint media ventures in Poland.
 
A Polish Women's Magazine
 A year ago, Mr. Giller and his partners became majority shareholders in a venture with members of the staff of Uroda, a women's magazine formerly published by Interpress, a state-owned media conglomerate. A monthly with a circulation of 200,000, it has articles on how to earn money and how women should not be afraid to be as smart as men, profiles of successful women and features on hair, clothes and decorating the office.
 Pentor is also involved in a venture with executives of The Warsaw Voice, a two-year-old weekly and the only English-language newspaper in Poland. Simultaneous delivery in the United States will begin in July when the 24-page tabloid, costing $3 an issue, will seek readers among executives interested in doing business in Poland.
 Other Pentor ventures in Poland include a desperately needed market research firm, the only publication offering television and radio listings and a television production company.
 Market research is virtually nonexistent in Poland. As a result, publishers rarely know who their readers are. As in many East European countries, magazine distribution is controlled by the state-owned postal service. Readers sign up and prepay for magazines at the post office, which, in turn, informs publishers how many copies it will distribute. There is none of the information on age, gender, income or interests of readers that is the mainstay of American advertising.
 Pentor is also working on a distribution system that would make it more profitable for kiosks to sell the company's newspapers and magazines. Pointing to a spirit worthy of United States marketing executives, Mr. Giller said his Polish partners had come up with the idea of buying a new car and giving it to the kiosk owner who sells the most copies of the television-listings magazine in June.
 "The Maxwells and Murdochs have not been well received," Mr. Giller said, "and the Germans are trying to get in. But we have made the Poles realize that our interests and theirs coincide, and they have been very responsive to us. But it's very much like the old West. There is no corporate structure; we make the rules as we go."
 
Cable Venture With Government
 Another American company involved in Poland is Chase Enterprises, a division of Chase Communications, based in Hartford. In a joint venture with the Polish Government, Chase has begun building a cable television service in Gdansk and plans eventually to operate in nine cities. Roger Freedman, president and chief executive of Chase International, said the company had invested "many millions of dollars" in the enterprise.
 Although the spirit of change continues to blow strongly, most publications in Eastern Europe are still state-owned. Some are now quasi-public, owned in part by government and in part by former employees. For instance, Heit Vilaggazdasag/HVG, a weekly economic and political magazine in Budapest that is loosely modeled after The Economist, is now one-quarter staff-owned. The remaining shares are owned by banks and the state commerce department. On the other hand, Mlady Svet, a weekly news magazine in Prague, has been taken over and is being run by 28 members of its staff.
 Other journalists now find themselves out of work. Some editors and reporters worked on newsletters and other house organs for state-owned companies that have closed. Fund for a Free Press
 As part of United States initiatives to help build democracy in Eastern Europe, $5 million has been set aside for the International Media Fund to help countries set up independent broadcasting and a free press.
 The fund is helping to set up American journalism centers in Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia, which will be financed in part by The New York Times Company Foundation Inc., Rutgers University and the University of Maryland.
 Marvin Stone, the fund's president, who is a former editor in chief of U.S. News & World Report and former deputy director of the United States Information Agency, said legislation was being introduced to further the freedom of broadcasting in several of these countries, although many countries prefer a European model like Britain's, under which some channels are run by the state and others by private enterprise.
 
Press Production Obstacles
 The main obstacles for the press, he said, were getting newsprint, which must be imported; finding printing plants and solving distribution problems.
 "National news agencies are still under the control of parliaments, and their directors are appointed by prime ministers," Mr. Stone said.
 In a typical example, Mr. Stone said that in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, the weekly news magazine, which is modeled after Time, had no idea how many magazines were sold every week by the postal service and that it suspected it was "being ripped off."
 "They are not told for 45 days how many were sold," he said, "and then it takes two months before they get the money. That's what an arrogant monopoly means."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 18, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in the Media Business pages yesterday about foreign financing of Eastern European publications misstated the involvement of The New York Times Company Foundation. The foundation does not help finance the International Media Fund, which is affiliated with the United States Government. It does support the Independent Journalists Initiative, a privately financed group of volunteers from newspaper, television and radio organizations that conducts journalism workshops in Eastern Europe.

HEADLINE: William S. Fishman, 75, Is Dead; Philanthropist and Ex-Executive

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MERION, Pa., June 17

 BODY:
William S. Fishman, a philanthropist who was co-founder and former chief executive of ARA Services, a service management company, died Saturday. He was 75 years old and lived in Merion.
The cause of death was not immediately available, said a funeral home spokesman. 
 Mr. Fishman co-founded ARA, which helped pioneer the automatic vending business, with Davre Davidson in 1959. He was chairman from 1977 to 1984, doubling the company's business to $3 billion a year as it expanded into food services and school buses. He was president of the company, now based in Philadelphia, from 1964 to 1976 and chief executive from 1975 to 1983.
After he moved to Philadelphia in 1961, Mr. Fishman became involved with the city's cultural, civic and educational programs.
In 1988 Mr. Fishman, who was Jewish, was asked by John Cardinal Krol to become the first chairman of Business Leadership Organized for Catholic Schools, an organization that finances many educational programs. In his tenure the group raised more than $45 million for Roman Catholic schools.
Mr. Fishman also helped establish the Museum of American Jewish History on Independence Mall.
Along with Mr. Davidson, he was honored by ARA in 1982 when the company established the Fishman-Davidson Center for the Study of the Service Sector at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School.
Mr. Fishman was a fellow of Brandeis University and established a chair of economics there.
He twice served as president of the National Automatic Merchandising Association and as president of the Jewish Publication Society of America.
He was a director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, the Franklin Institute and the Academy of Music.
He leaves his wife, Selma Demchick Ellis Fishman; three sons, Alan, Fred and David; a stepson, Joshua Ellis; a stepdaughter, Jill Feninger; two sisters, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS SCENE;
Stagnant Pay: A Delayed Impact

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
THE incomes of most American households have failed to gain ground on inflation since 1973. That much-repeated economic statistic is now common wisdom. What's just now coming to light is the impact that so many years of stagnant incomes is finally having on the American psyche.
Broadly speaking, the old psychology of affluence -- the confidence that homeownership and high levels of consumer spending are birthrights -- is breaking down, demographers and pollsters say. Materialism endures; young Americans still value the good life. But they pick their purchases to simulate affluence, not achieve it. Thus, purchasing a BMW or an Armani suit might be out of reach, but not other stylish clothing or compact disk players or elegant food, and that is where the money goes. 
 "Consumers are learning to make lesser purchases and they are accepting the view that they cannot have it all," said Watts Wacker, executive vice president of Yankelovich Clancy Shulman, a market research company.
The fallout from stagnant incomes came up repeatedly last week at an annual conference in New York sponsored by American Demographics, an organization that explores attitudes and behavior to help companies market products. The impact is particularly noticeable in the under-30 generation, where stress and compromising personal goals are now commonplace, Mr. Wacker and others said.
The Roper Organization, for example, finds that the under-30 population increasingly wants to own homes and have children. But without the wherewithal, marriage and homeownership are postponed. Similarly, college students are more willing than the baby boomers were in the late 1970's to become involved in social causes. But despite their activism, young people more than ever seek jobs that pay well. The baby boomers at the same age had preferred work that interested them. "This is not greed, but simply a desire to deal with a cruel world and to seek a sense of self-sufficiency and security that earlier generations took for granted," said Bickley Townsend, a Roper vice president.
The stagnant income problem also shows up as pent-up demand that remains pent up. In the past, as the American economy came out of recessions and jobs multiplied, restoring incomes, people no longer postponed the purchase of cars and homes, and sales rose sharply. But in the recovery now apparently getting under way, car and home sales are muted, in part because even jobholders often find these major purchases unaffordable.
The Census Bureau reports that 71 percent of all families in which the chief breadwinner is 25 to 34 years old cannot afford median-priced homes in the areas where they live. The percentage rises to 94.1 for families where the chief earner is under 25. As for cars, the average new-car price is equal to 47 percent of the median annual income of American families, up from 35 percent in 1979.
The data on stagnant incomes, a trend not fully recognized by economists until the late 1980's, are now profuse. The Labor Department says the median family income of $30,000 to $35,000 in 1973 is still in that range, after adjustment for inflation. Only the wealthiest 20 percent of American families, those with incomes above $80,000, gained ground on inflation over the last 18 years.
Why wasn't the impact felt sooner? The booming 1980's helped mask the problem of stagnant incomes, in part because so many new jobs were created, although many were low-paying, and so many women went to work, postponing childbirth, says Frank Levy, a University of Maryland economist. Now the birth rate is rising sharply, as women in their late 20's and 30's finally have children. Incomes have to feed more mouths, and the economy is not generating as many new jobs.
That situation probably contributes to a startling statistic in a Yankelovich survey. Suddenly, there is a huge jump in the percentage of women who say they would quit their jobs or reduce their workload if they did not need the money. Some 80 percent of those surveyed gave this answer last year, compared with 39 percent in 1989, Mr. Wacker said.
Income also plays a major role in how much faith people have in government, says Brad Edmondson, editor in chief of American Demographics magazine. "People at the top of the income scale, households with $50,000 a year or more, still believe in solving problems through government," he said, "while people below that level turn more and more to group solutions."
Thus they form child care groups or neighborhood security patrols, volunteering their labor in lieu of payments. For the less affluent, "there is more bonding and celebration of community life," Mr. Edmondson said. "The question is whether these communities will be encompassing, or will tend to segregate groups from each other."

HEADLINE: Gulf Victory: An Energy Defeat?

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
While the allied victory in the Persian Gulf eliminated for now the threat to Western access to Mideast oil, there is widespread agreement in the oil industry that the United States' long-term energy security may have been set back.
The quick war brought oil prices back down near prewar levels, and those lower prices provide little incentive for energy conservation or new drilling in the United States. 
 "We're going to be more import-dependent than under a Saddam Hussein regime" in Kuwait, said Vahan Zanoyan, an analyst with the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington consulting firm. If Saddam Hussein controlled Kuwait and bullied Saudi Arabia, Middle East experts say, production would be cut and the market price of oil would rise, which would eventually reduce imports by this country.
The Bush Administration has a different view of the war's effect. John J. Easton Jr., Assistant Secretary of Energy for international affairs and energy emergencies, said in an interview in Washington that the war had produced "a heightened awareness of the role energy plays" and had helped unite various Government agencies, including his department and the Departments of Transportation and the Interior, in the formulation of the National Energy Strategy.
That strategy includes drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and counting on provisions of the Clean Air Act to cut gasoline consumption, and would, under the most optimistic interpretation, stabilize the proportion of oil that is imported.
But energy experts say that because the war ended quickly, at relatively low cost to the United States, it did not produce a consensus on steps to reduce oil imports. In the absence of strong Government policy, what defines the pattern of energy production and use is price.
Oil prices are now close to prewar levels. From under $17 for a barrel of crude oil before Iraq began its saber-rattling last July, prices rose to more than $40 in October. Now oil is selling in New York for under $20 a barrel, in contracts for delivery next month. At the gasoline pump, prices have followed a similar trajectory. In the next few months, gasoline and oil prices are unlikely to move sharply in either direction.
One unintended consequence of the war was to centralize further the supply of oil. One-third of the oil produced by the 13 nations of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries now comes from a single source -- Saudi Arabia. Before Iraq invaded Kuwait last August, Saudi Arabia produced less than a quarter of OPEC's oil.
The war, in fact, propelled Saudi Arabia into becoming the world's second-largest oil producer, jumping ahead of the United States. With the likelihood of continued turmoil in the Soviet Union, Saudi Arabia may become the largest oil producer before too many years.
"What we had before was a special relationship with Saudi Arabia," said Daniel C. Yergin, the oil historian. "Now we have a more special relationship."
Saudi exports to the United States last year were about 1.2 million barrels a day, up from 1.1 million in 1989, according to Energy Listener Services, a company in New York that provides news and analysis to the oil industry. OPEC provided 60.9 percent of American imports in 1990, up from 57.8 percent in 1989, despite the unavailability of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude oil in the second half of last year, it said.
 
'There's Nothing Secure'
 Ken Miller, an oil analyst at Purvin & Gertz, a Houston consulting firm, said, "We're obviously a little better off than we were with a guy armed to the teeth, like Saddam was." He added: "There's nothing secure over there. Any of those leaders can act up at any time."
Some experts say there are worse things than relying on the Saudis, who have argued for years on behalf of moderate prices, because the Saudi rulers appear persuaded that if prices get too high, customers turn to alternative fuels or invest in technology that will cut demand. In addition, the war created, for the first time, a substantial Saudi-American military alliance.
"It's hard to imagine right now the Saudis doing anything that would hurt the United States," said Howard S. Geller, the executive director of the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy. But he said Saudi Arabia had internal strains and added, "I don't think anyone would want to bet that in five years or ten years we'll have the same situation."
 
Friend Lost in '79
 The oil shock of 1979, in which prices tripled, was set off by the collapse of the Shah of Iran, at the time the United States' closest and most powerful friend in the region, Mr. Geller pointed out.
But Mr. Zanoyan said that even if the war exposed strains within Saudi Arabia, the result could well be growing influence for young, Western-educated technocrats, a change that would not hurt oil production.
Since the Arab oil embargo of 1973, America's energy posture has grown more secure in some ways, more troublesome in others. The country is more secure because energy is now a smaller ingredient in the production of goods and services. The Department of Energy calculates that in 1990 producing $1 worth of goods and services required 39 percent less oil and gas than was needed in 1973. On the other hand, imports of crude oil and oil products are up by more than 16 percent. The reason is that domestic production has declined while total consumption in 1990 was roughly the same as in 1973.
 
Move Toward Efficiency Eases
 The trend toward greater energy efficiency in the United States seems to be ending, with most of the improvement having taken place before oil prices crashed in 1986. Last year, some analysts say, energy efficiency actually declined. Even though new equipment is generally more efficient than old equipment, new cars are growing less efficient. And there has been a revival of some industries, like steel, that are energy-intensive.
"We chose to attack an unfriendly oil-exporting country, instead of attacking energy waste," said Mr. Geller of the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy.
What would have been the impact on oil supplies if Saddam Hussein had held onto Kuwait?He might have used his control of its oil and the threat of his military might to push up world prices, and experts say the short-term impact on importing countries might have been severe.
But the longer-term effect would have been less so, they say, because imports would have gradually declined under the weight of higher prices, as was the case after the price shock of 1978-80.
"Over the longer term, it wouldn't have made a heck of a lot of difference," Dr. Gerry Angevine, the president of the Canadian Energy Research Institute, in Calgary, Alberta, said in a telephone interview.
The importance of Saudi Arabia's stability rises with American reliance on imports. The Department of Energy said net imports as a percentage of petroleum products sold in this country rose from 34.8 percent in 1973, the time of the Arab oil embargo, to 43.1 percent in 1979, the time of the second oil shock. With high prices, demand was depressed and domestic production stimulated, so by 1985 imports were down to 27.3 percent. But by last year, imports were back up to 41.9 percent.
 
Prices and Consumption
 Charles J. DiBona, president of the American Petroleum Institute, the industry's main trade association, predicted, "Unless we have a very sharp increase in prices, consumption will rise and U.S. production will continue a downward trend."
Crude oil production was more than 9 million barrels a day in 1973, but for the first quarter of this year it was less than 7.5 million. Demand in the first quarter was about 16.7 million but would rise sharply with an economic recovery, experts say.
The difference is made up by imports, which have have grown quickly. But since the world's spare capacity is in the Persian Gulf, reliance on the Middle East has grown even faster. Imports from Arab members of OPEC accounted for 13.2 percent of American supplies last year, compared with 5.3 percent in 1973.
Yet amid the euphoria of victory over Iraq, those numbers have generated little concern. In 1973, Congress was galvanized by the Arab oil embargo and approved construction of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline, through which about one-fourth of American production now flows, Mr. DiBona said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Narrow Trading in Dollar As Reports Are Awaited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed mixed in narrow trading yesterday as currency specialists awaited the trade and economic reports scheduled for later this week. Gold was higher.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold gained $1.10 an ounce, closing at $368.20. A late bid at the Republic National Bank in New York placed gold at $367.60 an ounce, up 85 cents from late on Friday. 
 With no significant economic developments, currency trading responded to technical factors, analysts said. A similar trend surpressed activity in the stock and bond markets.
 
'Just Waiting'
 "Everybody's just waiting," said Andrew Busch, a trader for Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. "There will be somewhat of a wait-and-see until we get the trade number and the tan book," he added, referring to the Commerce Department's report on merchandise trade activity in April and the Federal Reserve's survey of economic activity, known as the "beige book." Both reports are scheduled for later this week.
Michael Schaufler, a senior trader for the Bank of Boston, said some traders and investors were nervous about the possibility that the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, might intervene to support the mark.
The dollar benefited from trades between German marks and British pounds, which sent the German currency lower. Political uncertainty in Britain undermined the pound, dealers said.
In London, the pound fell to $1.6258, from $1.6395 late on Friday. In New York, it cost $1.6265 to buy a pound, less expensive than the $1.6325 late on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday rates, included: 1.7955 German marks, up from 1.7940; 1.5435 Swiss francs, up from 1.5395; 6.0975 French francs, up from 6.0970; 1,337.00 Italian lire, down from 1,337.25, and 1.14175 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1432.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 140.93 yen, down 0.14 yen from Friday's close. Later in London it was quoted at 140.95 yen. In New York, the dollar held at 140.70 yen, the same rate as late on Friday.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $367.75 an ounce, from $367.90 late on Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $366.75, from $366.50 late on Friday.
Financial institutions in Hong Kong were closed yesterday and today for holidays.
Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid of $4.43 an ounce, from $4.41 on Friday. On the New York Comex, silver gained 1.8 cents, to $4.436.

HEADLINE: Kuwait Picks Airbus to Rebuild Fleet

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 17

 BODY:
Kuwait's national airline announced today that it had decided to rebuild its fleet by awarding orders to Airbus Industrie for 15 aircraft and by taking options on nine more Airbus planes, a deal that analysts said was worth almost $2 billion.
At a news conference at the Paris Air Show, Ahmed al-Mishari, chairman of the Kuwaiti Airways Corporation, also announced that his company would soon order three Boeing 747-400 aircraft. 
 In a separate announcement at the air show, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation disclosed plans to build a new 105-seat passenger aircraft that would be assembled in China.
 
G.E. Engine Award
 The Kuwaiti deal with Airbus would also award jet engine contracts to the General Electric Company and to CFM International, a joint venture between General Electric and Snecma, a French engine maker.
Mr. Mishari said, "We lost about two-thirds of our fleet during the Iraqi invasion, and lost most of our maintenance facilities, engine workshops -- the whole thing." Kuwaiti Airways officials said that during the war Iraqi forces stole 15 aircraft -- 8 Airbuses, 3 Boeing aircraft and 4 smaller executive jets.
Many Europeans feared after the Persian Gulf war that Kuwait would give Americans preference in rebuilding the country. The Europeans pointed out that they, too, had sent troops to fight for Kuwait, and since then, Kuwait has awarded many contracts to European concerns. Airbus shareholders are the British, French, German and Spanish aircraft makers.
The order announced today involved three Airbus A320 short-to-medium-range aircraft, which have 150 seats; five wide-body, medium-range A300-600R's with 260 seats; three 210-seat, medium-to-long-range A310-300's, and four long-range A340-200's, which have 260 seats.
Airbus has scheduled a news conference for Tuesday at which it is expected to announce that the Federal Express Corporation is awarding it 25 firm orders and 50 options for converted A300 cargo planes.
In the McDonnell Douglas development, the St. Louis-based company said it had signed memorandums of understanding for the new passenger aircraft, to be called the MD-95, with the China National Aero-Technology Import-Export Corporation and with the Pratt & Whitney division of the United Technologies Corporation. The new plane will replace McDonnell's DC-9's.
McDonnell Douglas has produced its MD-82 aircraft in China since the mid-1980's. Company officials said they had begun designing the MD-95, which would be company's smallest twinjet and they hoped it would start commercial service in 1994.
McDonnell Douglas officials said they had also signed a memorandum of understanding with Northwest Airlines for the airline to evaluate the new aircraft. Northwest has 142 DC-9's, giving it the world's largest fleet of such aircraft.
 
Common Features With DC-9
 The MD-95, which will complete with the Boeing Company's 737-300 aircraft, will have many common features with the DC-9. Company officials say they hope this will help airlines economize in maintenance, pilot training and replacement parts.
John Wolf, a McDonnell Douglas executive vice president, said his company hoped to reach final agreement with the Chinese late this year. McDonnell Douglas is moving an increasing amount of production to China with the goal of becoming one of the world's lowest-cost aircraft manufacturers.
Alto today, ITT Defense, a subsidiary of the ITT Corporation, announced that it was forming a 50-50 joint venture with Thomson-CSF, the French electronics group, to make radar systems for American airports.
The joint venture hopes to capture contracts that the Federal Aviation Administration plans to award to upgrade or replace up to 100 radar systems. In addition, the Department of Defense plans to award contracts to modernize or replace 60 systems. Each system will cost about $2.7 million, an ITT official said.

HEADLINE: Victorious Yeltsin Due in U.S. Today

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Boris N. Yeltsin begins a three-day visit to Washington on Tuesday that confronts President Bush with basic questions about American attitudes toward the rapidly changing Soviet Union, which has been the focus of United States foreign policy for 45 years.
The root question is this: Can Washington find some way to support Mr. Yeltsin and rapid change without undermining President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and stability? Andrei Kozyrev, one of Mr. Yeltsin's close associates, suggested at a news conference last week that Mr. Yeltsin would tell Mr. Bush that Russia was ready to pursue both goals at once, "to achieve stability through broadening radical economic reforms." 
 Victor in the first popular election in Russia's 1,000-year-history, Mr. Yeltsin arrives here as the President of a Russian Republic that stretches across 11 time zones from the Baltic to the Pacific. It has a larger population than any other part of the Soviet Union and commands nine-tenths of its oil and more than three-quarters of its natural gas reserves.
Mr. Yeltsin is a non-Communist decentralizer, who wants to shift power and the taxing authority away from Moscow; Mr. Gorbachev is a Communist centralizer who wants to preserve Moscow's dominance. It is a debate not unlike that which split the United States in the last century.
 
Yeltsin in U.S. in 1989
 Mr. Yeltsin's previous visit to the United States, in September 1989, was marked by thinly disguised official indifference. He stopped at the White House, where he met with Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, but not the President.
Until now Washington, and especially Mr. Bush, have felt that they must cling to Mr. Gorbachev, partly because they admire what he has done so far, partly because they saw nothing but a slide into the abyss without him. Now Mr. Yeltsin poses a genuine alternative -- one endorsed by the masses, as Mr. Gorbachev has not been, and one more committed, in word if not yet entirely convincingly in deed, to American ideas of democracy.
Officially, this week's visit is sponsored by Congressional leaders, and Mr. Yeltsin is to spend Wednesday largely on Capitol Hill.
But on Thursday he will be given the full treatment by the Administration, meeting with Mr. Bush in the Oval Office, with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher and with Vice President Dan Quayle.
Only Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is missing from the list, and he is out of town, talking about the future of Europe in Berlin.
 
Reconciliation With Gorbachev?
 The White House seems to have concluded that Mr. Gorbachev's recent rapprochement with Mr. Yeltsin is real, not merely tactical. Mr. Bush will be looking for confirmation of that in the talks. Some in the Administration are skeptical, and a senior White House official said last week, "It will be tricky for the President, trying to give Yeltsin his blessing without undercutting Gorbachev's turn back toward reform."
"What we hope we can do," another Presidential aide said, "is give Yeltsin every indication of American approval, and at the same time encourage Gorbachev to tell the Soviet right-wingers, 'I've got to move on this reform agenda, or you'll get Yeltsin, which you'll like even less.' "
Another Government Soviet specialist, who like the others asked that he not be identified, said the United States could not "afford to put all its eggs in Gorbachev's basket, because Yeltsin might be the boss one day."
Mr. Bush talked briefly today on the subject of Soviet relations, telling reporters as he flew from Los Angeles to Grand Junction, Colo., that work on a strategic arms treaty was "96 percent complete." Agreement on such a treaty, the Administration has maintained, is a prerequisite for a summit meeting originally scheduled for late this month.
The President said he had received a "very important" letter from Mr. Gorbachev over the weekend on strategic arms-control issues. Although he described the remaining issues as "highly technical," he said, "The tone was good and the determination to reach an agreement was positive."
"I would say it's a narrowing of differences," Mr. Bush added. "But I do think that some of the differences that remain are fairly difficult."
 
Issue of Summit Meeting
 White House and State Department officials have said in recent days that a meeting between the two Presidents is unlikely late this month or even next month, after Mr. Bush's trip to London for the annual conference of the seven major industrialized nations and subsequent visits to Greece and Turkey. But the President insisted that he was still holding both periods open for a trip to Moscow should a breakthrough suddenly develop in the arms talks.
"I don't want to get hopes up," Mr. Bush said of the possibility of an early meeting, "but I really want to have it."
The President said nothing about the Yeltsin visit, which will include a full complement of appearances on American television and conversations with American journalists. While Mr. Yeltsin is far less well known to the general public than Mr. Gorbachev, and thus unlikely to stir the popular frenzy that has marked the Soviet leader's trips here, he is a magnetic figure with a populist flair who is sure to attract wide publicity in the United States.
In addition to his appointments with leaders in the Administration and in Congress, Mr. Yeltsin is to meet labor leaders, give a reception at the Soviet Embassy and visit the Lincoln Memorial. Late Thursday afternoon he will fly to New York.

HEADLINE: White House Hopes to Lift Sanctions

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
After the South African Parliament's repeal of the last legal pillar of apartheid, senior Bush Administration officials said today that they would move ahead with plans to lift a five-year-old set of economic sanctions against South Africa by the end of the summer.
Mr. Bush's efforts to lift the sanctions are almost certain to set off an effort in Congress to retain them by several lawmakers, who say that South Africa has not yet earned their repeal. 
 President Bush, the officials said, is confident that swift movement by President F. W. de Klerk to dismantle the legal apparatus of apartheid, the system of institutionalized racial separation, has largely defused American sentiment to continue to exert pressure on the South African Government. The law by which all South Africans are classified by race at birth, repealed by vote of the South African Parliament today, was the last of several eliminated in the last year that formed the legal basis of apartheid.
A senior Administration official said that the vote fulfilled four of the five conditions in the 1986 anti-apartheid law that would allow the President to lift sanctions. When the remaining condition, the release of all political prisoners is satisfied, possibly in a month's time, the official said, the United States will be morally obligated to lift the sanctions.
 
A Contract With Pretoria?
 "There is a strong feeling here that the law represents a contract," the official went on, "and when they fulfill the contract, we have to act accordingly."
But the Congressional Black Caucus and anti-apartheid lobbies are demanding that the sanctions be continued until a new constitution giving South African blacks the right to vote is in place, although that is not a condition of the 1986 act. Under the law, which was enacted over President Ronald Reagan's veto, Congess has 30 days to challenge a lifting of the sanctions, which have prohibited new investments and most trade with South Africa.
"We feel it's very important not to lift sanctions now until we're certain the situation in South Africa is irreversible," said Representative Edolphus Towns, Democrat of Brooklyn, who is the current chairman of the 28-member black caucus. Mr. Towns said that continued sanctions are needed to keep pressure on Pretoria.
 
Opposition in Congress
 Others legislators, such as Representative Howard Wolpe, Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the House subcommittee on Africa, have disputed the Administration's contention that four out of the five conditions in the 1986 law have been fulfilled.
Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, who was influential in enacting the original sanctions law, said such an approach would be unfair. He also likened the law to a contract and said that retaining sanctions until a new condition like full voting rights is met would be "like moving the goalposts."
Mr. Lugar said he was confident that President Bush would have enough votes to veto any initiative to restore sanctions because most Americans and both houses of Congress admire Mr. de Klerk's efforts and no longer believe sanctions are necessary.
President Bush is certain to use the visit to the White House later this week by Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, to bolster his argument against maintaining the sanctions. Chief Buthelezi, the South African leader of the Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom Party, has been feuding with the African National Congress headed by Nelson Mandela over the issue of sanctions, among other things.
 
City and State Measures
 Even if Federal Government sanctions are lifted, scores of state, city and county governments have imposed their own economic penalties, and these restrictions are not dependent on whatever is done in Washington. At least 90 cities, including New York, and eight states, have some form of legislation authorizing their officials to impose sanctions on companies that do business in South Africa.
In some ways, the local laws have been at least as effective as Federal law in discouraging companies from maintaining business ties with South Africa.
This spring, J. P. Morgan & Company, the investment banker, said it would no longer handle special securities representing stock in South African companies. Although the practice was not forbidden by the law, the company said the practice was "increasingly viewed in a negative light."
The 1986 act allowed companies that already had investments in South Africa to remain there and, according to the Washington-based Investor Responsibility Research Center, there are 104 American companies still doing business in South Africa. Allison Cooper of the center, said that since the act was passed in 1986, more than 200 companies have ended their ties to South Africa.
 
South African Envoy's Comments
 Harry Schwarz, the South African Ambassador to the United States, said today that he believed there was no longer a public demand in America to maintain sanctions against his Government.
Mr. Schwarz, a former South African opposition legislator who fought apartheid in Parliament, derided those Americans who he said "want to keep sanctions alive at any price."
He said the process of change is irreversible no matter what happens with sanctions but that their repeal is needed to help South Africa recover its economic vitality.
The condition under the 1986 law that is the focus of the most dispute is the release of all political prisoners. The South African Government, which has released about 1,000 political prisoners, maintains that it has fulfilled its obligation, but the African National Congress, its principal adversary, says there are still hundreds in jail who should be freed.
The two sides are negotiating over individual cases, and the State Department has ordered William Lacy Swing, the United States Ambassador to Pretoria, to report on the situation in a few weeks.
A senior State Department official said that many countries in Africa are privately eager for sanctions to be ended so they may trade openly with South Africa, the economic giant of the continent.
To that end, President de Klerk has traveled to 10 African countries and solicited their support. In Kenya earlier this month, he expressed hope that South Africa might be admitted to the Organization of African Unity. The continent-wide group recently said it would soon reconsider its stand on sanctions against South Africa.

HEADLINE: A Livable City? Newark. Yes, Newark.

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
This sounds like monologue material for Johnny or Dave or Arsenio: Newark, once a symbol of old-fashioned industrial might and later of urban unrest and disintegration, won an award yesterday in a competition to choose America's most livable cities.
Newark. Livable. Really. 
 The Unites States Conference of Mayors announced this at its annual meeting in San Diego, commending Newark for a "true renaissance." It noted that Newark was getting its first new theater in 50 years and had its first new shopping center in 20, along with hundreds of town houses for low- and moderate-income residents. This not the only prize to come Newark's way lately. Just last week, Newark was designated an All-America City by the National Civic League, and Newark has won a shelf of trophies for a recycling program that uses tires in making pavement for roads. The method Newark uses has attracted worldwide attention. A delegation from the Soviet Union spent a week in Newark studying it.
 
Still Serious Problems
 All this for a city that used to be laughed off in the same breath as Detroit, which like Newark was scarred by riots in the 1960's, or Cleveland, where the Mayor once set his hair on fire at a ribbon-cutting ceremony.
"There's an old saying -- when you face a mass of problems, if they don't kill you, you'll be better off," Mayor Sharpe James of Newark said last week. "We faced the riots, where most people's image even today is one of Newark burning and National Guard troops marching up and down the street."
Newark still has the serious problems of any big city: crime and the perception of crime, drugs and AIDS.
 Unemployment stood at 12.6 percent in February, the most recent month for which the Bureau of Labor Statistics has compiled figures. That was up from 10.2 percent in the same month of 1990, and well above the seasonally adjusted national rate. At the same time, Newark's popula tion has been shrinking. Estimated at 315,196 in 1988, the figure was down to 275,221 in the 1990 census.
In talking about Newark's recent success in getting new construction projects going, Mayor James uses the old real-estate cliche -- "location, location, location." Newark, though, is profiting from more than being in the right place at an opportune time; the Mayor might just as well say transportation, transportation, transportation.
Newark has the nation's fastest-growing airport and its largest port for container ships, along with a train station that serves as an anchor for many of the new buildings downtown. And Newark may well become one of the few cities in the nation whose airport is reachable by rail: the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is spending $350,000 to study linking a planned people-mover system at the airport to the Northeast Corridor rail lines.
 
'Beautiful Downtown Newark'
 "Newark is so much more accessible," said Pamela Goldstein, an aide to Mayor James. "I don't want to take a potshot at New York or anything, but it's much easier to get goods in and out of Newark."
Michael Zimmer, the associate dean of the Seton Hall University Law Center, remembers arriving in Newark in 1978 and deciding that "it was a pretty dispirited place."
"Then," he said, "it was pure irony when someone said 'beautiful downtown Newark.' If you fly around Newark now in a helicopter, you would see the coming together of a viable urban environment." Mr. Zimmer suggests a helicopter because he finds the traffic increasingly snarled in the downtown area where the law school's new home is scheduled to open this year.
The streets may get more clogged as new buildings open. Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey plans to move 2,400 employees from a campus-like complex in suburban Florham Park to a Newark office tower. New Jersey Transit is expected to occupy an adjacent building. And the $200 million New Jersey Performing Arts Center is planned for the block behind Seton Hall's new law school.
 
Public and Private Investment
 Some urban experts say awards like the ones Newark has been winning lately may go to cities that pay as much attention to municipal marketing as to municipal development. But most agree that Newark has made progress.
"The secret to Newark is many years of public investment are now yielding a harvest," said Mitchell Moss of the Urban Research Center and New York University. Tax abatements and other government incentives are credited with making some new projects economically attractive. And a small number of downtown corporations -- among them Prudential Insurance, Public Service Electric and Gas, First Fidelity Bank and New Jersey Bell -- have put a large amount of money into building new buildings.
"Mayor James has been doing well, but it's like trying to push a boulder up a hill," said Norman J. Glickman, director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. "He's gotten halfway up the hill, but whether he'll get to the top remains to be seen."
Other planners are more skeptical of a Newark renaissance.
"It flies in the face of secular reality," said George Sternlieb, who founded the center Mr. Glickman now runs. "The secular reality is a city that still is essentially dependent upon welfare and on the flow of funds from the county, the state and the Feds." Newark used to have 20 percent of the job base of the entire state, he said, but now has no more than 5 or 6 percent.
Mr. James said he was not sweeping the city's problems under the rug. "We're talking about a window of opportunity," he said last week after winning the All-America City prize. "We have an award that says, 'Hey, Newark, we recognize where you were, we recognize your progress.' And that's what we accept this as -- not as an ending but a beginning to do more."
One thing that some residents say Newark must do to clinch the city's transformation is to reach beyond downtown, with its new elevated walkways connecting the buildings near Pennsylvania Station.
"People who come into Newark never set foot on Newark soil," said Mary Smith, the treasurer of New Community, a nonprofit group that built the new shopping center. "We need more things in the neighborhoods to benefit the neighborhoods."
And the livability award? In San Diego yesterday, Kay Scrimger of the Conference of Mayors said that Newark was chosen from among 117 cities "not for intrinsic livability but for purposeful actions in developing programs that promote livability." In other words, she said, the award goes to a mayor who has done something to make his city livable, not necessarily to one whose city already is. She said the prize was a black crystal sculpture, "like something out of 'Star Wars.' "
Newark clearly hopes it will get publicity from its recent awards -- and it probably won't get too much of the kind it does not need. Steve O'Donnell, the head writer on "Late Night With David Letterman," said that in nearly 10 years he could not remember putting a Newark joke on the air.
"We'll make a Cleveland Indians joke sometimes," said Mr. O'Donnell, who grew up in Cleveland, "but not Newark, maybe since we're playing to a nationwide audience. Newark may be more of a tristate-area joke than a nationwide joke."

HEADLINE: 6,000 New York City Workers Get Layoff Notices

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
Gregory Vann, a Brooklyn sanitation worker with three children, had fretted for weeks over the possibility of losing his job. When he walked into a New York City sanitation garage yesterday morning, fellow workers told him he was "on the list," meaning that he was one of the thousands of city employees being laid off by the end of the month.
"I've got babies, man," Mr. Vann said to an unmarried colleague who was also told he was being laid off but said he was not overly concerned. "You never had a little kid come to you and say, 'I'm hungry.' " 
 The troubles facing Mr. Vann were played out in city agencies throughout New York yesterday as the first 6,000 city workers were informed that they would be laid off by June 29 to save money in a time of fiscal desperation.
Workers like Mr. Vann are caught in the middle as the city and the unions square off in an 11th-hour countdown to balance the budget, which now has a $3.5 billion gap for the fiscal year that starts on July 1. The city has threatened to go through with the layoffs if they do not get the concessions they seek from union leaders, who in turn assert that they must protect their members.
 By Thursday, a total of 7,969 city employees in 24 agencies and departments are to receive dismissal slips, said Denise Collins, a spokeswoman for the city's Personnel Department.
Although measures like employee attrition and early retirement could save some money and avert some layoffs, city officials said they were holding out for a package that included larger permanent savings like changes in work rules, staffing levels, vacation days or health benefits. Without the threat of layoffs, they say, the unions would have little incentive to make other concessions.
The widespread layoffs are part of Mayor David N. Dinkins's efforts to put pressure on the unions to come up with money-saving concessions to help close the budget gap.
Neither city officials nor union leaders have said precisely what the dollar value of the concessions under discussion was, or precisely what their favored means of achieving them would be. But hundreds of millions in savings are being sought.
Mr. Dinkins said at a news conference yesterday that he hoped some of the layoffs could still be averted through union concessions. "It is very possible we could reach an agreement before these people are off the payroll," he said.
Mr. Vann was one of the thousands of workers told a month ago that his job was in danger, but like many others he remained optimistic to the end. Yesterday was the beginning of the end as the bad news went out by office teletype, by letter or in a meeting with a supervisor.
 
Hardest-Hit Agencies
 Some of the agencies hit the hardest include the Sanitation Department, with 940 layoffs; the Human Resources Administration, with 2,416; the Parks Department, with 1,321, and the Health Department, with 1,380.
Yesterday's layoffs were the culmination of a process that started months ago when most city agencies received budget-cutting targets and began singling out job titles and programs for elimination. The unions were notified of the intentions and given an opportunity to review or challenge the decisions. About a month ago, union leaders told their members who had been targeted that they were "at risk." Civil Service employees also received a similar at-risk letter.
Most of the layoffs were done on the basis of seniority and the process is certain to be complicated with seniority disputes. Some workers are hoping to be rehired later or hired for another job or in another agency.
Mr. Vann, who is 36 years old and has been a sanitation worker for 11 months, found little consolation yesterday in the hope of being rehired. He said he was angry that while the city was using layoffs to save money, financial pressures would come other ways as people filed for unemployment and welfare benefits and as higher-paid workers with more seniority continued to collect paychecks. City officials estimate that the unemployment benefits alone for the laid-off workers will cost the city about $55 million a year.
"There is a guy who has been here for 35 years and he's putting his grand-kids through college," said Mr. Vann, his eyes moist behind brown aviator glasses. "College! My kid is graduating from kindergarten and I have to figure out a way to buy him some new shoes."
Mr. Vann said he only took home $330 a week, but it put food on the table in his home in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. Now, with no marketable skills and no college degree, and with an estranged wife who is unemployed, all he has left are his pride and his wits to figure out his next move.
Ronald Princeton, a muscular 37-year-old with his hair tied back in a ponytail, drives a mechanical broom truck for the Sanitation Department. He gets up early for the 7 A.M.-to-3 P.M. shift, but yesterday he looked tired before the day had ended because he was being laid off after 20 months on the job.
"It's a hardship," Mr. Princeton said. "I have four children. My wife is unemployed. I take home $370 a week. "There is nothing I can do but look for another job and collect unemployment, if possible," said Mr. Princeton, who lives in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. "It's going to be an uphill struggle -- that's all I can say. My family's going to take it hard."
Tom Cartelli, an unmarried mechanical broom operator from Staten Island, said he felt sorry for the married men. As of June 28, Mr. Cartelli will be out of a job too, but he is counting on his skills as an electrician to help him over the rough spots.
"I tell you, I'm not happy, but it's really sad for the guys with families," said Mr. Cartelli, who is 26 years old. "I've never been on unemployment in my life. I've never been in that line. I've never been in that building."
In a letter that will sooner or later find its way into the hands of all employees due to be laid off, the city says it will provide re-employment sessions to discuss unemployment insurance benefits, retraining, education and non-city employment opportunities.
Of the three men gathered in the Sanitation Department garage yesterday, only Mr. Cartelli said he could afford health insurance, at a cost of about $100 a month for single people and more than $300 for people with dependents.
"I can't even buy what I want in the grocery store," Mr. Vann said glumly.
The layoffs were cited by union leaders yesterday as they denounced the Mayor's doomsday budget that includes plans to close libraries and turn off street lights.
"The city administration is going to learn quickly that sanitation services, just like police and fire services, are essential to the health and well-being of our citizens," said Edward Ostrowski, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association. He called the layoffs "a human tragedy."
Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Muncipal Employees, whose members will account for the bulk of the layoffs, sent the Mayor a telegram urging him to bring union, business and state and city political leaders together to reach agreement on taxes and union contributions to balance the budget.
"We need leadership, your leadership," Mr. Hill told the Mayor. "Don't let midnight toll without a solution. The city can't afford it. My members can't afford it. I can't afford it and you can't afford it."

HEADLINE: U.N. Punishes Iraq Further for Kuwait Invasion

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 17

 BODY:
The Security Council tightened its sanctions against Iraq today by unanimously approving a detailed plan for denying Baghdad military supplies and declaring that it must pay for the destruction of its most dangerous weapons itself.
At the same time, the special commission set up by the Council to supervise the destruction of the weapons announced that it would send inspectors back to Iraq later this week to look for evidence that the Government of President Saddam Hussein is secretly trying to build nuclear warheads. 
 The commission's executive chairman, Rolf Ekeus of Sweden, ordered the new inspection after receiving information about Iraq's clandestine nuclear plans from an Iraqi scientist who recently defected to the United States.
Mr. Ekeus said the decision reflected new information as well as "further analysis" of material brought back from the inspection in May by experts from the commission and the Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency, which is charged with removing all nuclear material usable in weapons from Iraq.
Under the arms embargo plan approved by the Security Council today, all countries must report to the Secretary General within 45 days the steps they have taken to insure their citizens and corporations do not supply Iraq with any military materiel, including technology and machinery that could be used for military purposes.
 
Liable for 'Full Costs'
 The Council committee set up to monitor the rest of the trade sanctions against Iraq will be responsible for overseeing the arms embargo and for ruling on disputed points.
The Council also unanimously declared that Iraq remained liable for the "full costs" of destroying its chemical and biological weapons, its ballistic missiles and its nuclear material usable in weapons. The Secretary General is to propose a plan for collecting this money, estimated in the hundreds of millions of dollars, from Iraq.
Iraq's acting representative, Samir K. K. al-Nima, told the Council that his Government refused to pay for destroying its weapons of mass destruction, but was willing to do the task itself under United Nations supervision.
Today's decisions mean that the institutional structure devised by the Security Council for punishing Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait is almost complete.
Later this week the Council is expected to define the duties of the special council it is creating in Geneva to assess compensation claims against Iraq and pay them from the country's future oil revenue once the Security Council allows Baghdad to resume selling oil on the world market.

Kuwait's 13th Death Sentence
 KUWAIT CITY, June 17 (AP) -- A 55-year-old Jordanian woman, Hamda Assad Younis, was sentenced to death today for collaboration with Iraq because during the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait she failed to close the girls' high school she ran and also edited material for an Iraqi-run newspaper. She is the 13th person sentenced to death by the special martial-law court trying those accused of collaboration.
