HEADLINE: Members of U.S. Panel at Odds Over Health Insurance for Children

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Dissent has boiled up inside a Federal commission investigating the condition of children in America, with Bush Administration officials and other Republicans assailing Democratic proposals to extend health insurance coverage to more than eight million uninsured children.
The Republican attack, which came in a dissenting chapter of a report to be issued next week, suggested that it would be almost impossible for Congress and the Administration to reach agreement soon on any comprehensive revision of the nation's health care system. 
 In the report, a copy of which was obtained today, a majority on the panel, the National Commission on Children, called for a sweeping new program of "universal health insurance for children and pregnant women." Under the proposal, employers would have to provide health insurance for employees and their children or pay a new tax to finance such coverage under a public program.
 
Dissent on Potential Cost
 In the dissenting chapter, 9 of the 34 members denounced the commission proposal, saying it would lead to "skyrocketing health costs and health care of poorer quality."
Moreover, the dissenters said in the report that the proposed new requirements meant that "low-wage workers -- the same ones most likely to lack health insurance -- would lose jobs or see their wages reduced." The Republicans estimate that 500,000 to 1.4 million workers could lose their jobs because employers might dismiss employees rather than finance added benefits. They said, "These families might consider a job to be more valuable than a Federal Government health plan."
In interviews today, Democrats on the commission, headed by Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, rejected that argument as unconvincing.
And although commissioners had fundamental differences on health care, they agreed on many other issues, including education and strategies to combat poverty.
The commission proposal on health care is like one introduced June 5 by Senate Democrats including Mr. Rockefeller and George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader. The legislation goes beyond the commission proposal by guaranteeing health insurance protection for all adults as well as children.
The dissenters on the commission include Wade F. Horn, the Federal Commissioner for Children, Youth and Families; Gerald P. Regier, acting director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance at the Justice Department; Allan C. Carlson, president of the Rockford Institute, in Illinois; Kay C. James, a former Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, and Nancy Risque Rohrbach, a former aide to President Ronald Reagan.
The attack on the Rockefeller commission proposal echoes criticism from two other influential Republicans. On Sunday, John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, defended President Bush's record on child welfare and health care and twitted the Democrats. "The Democrats would love to see a socialized structure in health care, and no agenda on health care is going to satisfy their commitment to socializing health care until it meets" that standard, Mr. Sununu said on the ABC News program "This Week."
 
Democrats Favor a Mix
 Democratic supporters of the Mitchell bill generally shun the concept of socialized medicine and say they want to preserve a mix of private and public health insurance.
But Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, said the Mitchell-Rockefeller proposal would impose "a heavy tax on jobs" by adding to payroll costs and could lead to a Government monopoly on health care. In theory, he said, it would encourage more employers to offer health insurance to employees. But in practice, he warned, "many American companies may quickly grow frustrated and simply shed the burden by pressing the Government to take over completely."
The spirited response by Republicans suggests that Democrats are in for a fight if, as expected, they pummel Mr. Bush and other Republicans as lacking a domestic agenda in the 1992 Presidential campaign. Mr. Rockefeller and another commission member, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, are potential candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
A confidential draft of the final Rockefeller commission report said the panel's proposals, taken together, would cost "$52 billion to $56 billion in new Federal funds in the first year," including $9 billion for health care. The biggest single item is a proposed Federal income tax credit of $1,000 for each child. The tax credit proposal, endorsed by commissioners from both parties, would cost $40 billion in the fiscal year 1993, the panel said.
 
Democrats on the Critics
 Commenting on the Republicans' chapter on health care, Senator Rockefeller said it had "not received the same careful independent factual and editorial review" as the rest of the report.
In a joint statement, two Democratic commissioners, Barbara B. Blum of New York and Ruth W. Massinga of Seattle, said the chapter was "based more on ideological conviction than on economic theory and solid empirical evidence."
The chapter emphasized "individual responsibility, rather than government programs" as the best solution to the nation's health problems. The dissenters suggested that "unwed parenthood" was a primary cause of infant mortality because single pregnant women and single mothers were less likely to seek the health care that they and their babies needed.
The statement by Mrs. Blum and Ms. Massinga said, "We are astounded by the causal link alleged between marital status and health conditions."

HEADLINE: Fast Start Replaces a Limp In Some Views of Recovery

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The economic recovery that almost everyone thought would start with a crawl could begin with a dash instead, according to a growing minority of forecasters, including Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
But a fast start -- which Fed officials now describe as a reasonable, albeit an unlikely, possibility -- would not presage a sustained boom. 
 Still, some Fed officials are struck by the fact that business made sharp cuts in production as sales slid. "Clearly we've had some substantial inventory hits during the recession and in the current quarter," said Wayne Angell, a governor of the Fed. "At some point in time, when you take away a huge negative number, that tends to give you a rather significant rebound."
More than a month ago, some Wall Sreet firms began raising their forecasts of how much the gross national product would grow in the last half of this year and the first half of 1992. The G.N.P. is the total value of goods and services sold.
"When we realized how deep a hole we'd dug ourselves into," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, referring to inventory cutbacks, "we realized we'd be digging out faster."
Just as efforts by businesses to cut production when sales decline can snowball into a recession, attempts to keep shelves filled when sales start to revive can give the economy a powerful kick. As a matter of arithmetic, reducing inventories subtracts from G.N.P. growth while inventory building adds to growth. Even merely trimming at a slower rate gives the economy a lift.
"There's a legitimate concern that industry is in better shape in this recession than usual, just like services are in worse shape," said Stephen S. Strongin, associate research director at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. "With one part of the economy in better shape than usual and one part worse, it depends on which you emphasize whether you worry about too much versus too little growth."
Last week's rash of economic reports made the possibility that the economy might shift directly into high gear seem more plausible, though hardly certain. Businesses reported that inventories in April were unusually lean, amounting to 1.5 months worth of sales, compared with the typical 1.65 to 1.75 months. At the same time, retail sales jumped and car buying picked up a bit.
Lean supplies and a pickup in sales make it more likely that businesses will trim inventories less in coming months. "An inventory kick like that is enough to produce a surge of real income growth next fall and winter," said Art Rolnick, research director at the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. "That is especially true if inflation comes down, too. "
As business pumps up production, there should be gains in hours worked, payrolls and, consequently, income. If inflation edges down for a while, as it almost always does in the first months of a recovery, purchasing power would rise, too.
A spurt at the start of the recovery does not imply a lasting boom. "An inventory rebound doesn't last for more than a few quarters," Mr. Rolnick said. In other recoveries, economists at the First Boston Corporation report, the swing from inventory reduction to accumulation typically adds a percentage point to G.N.P. growth during the recovery's first year and almost nothing after that.
Most of the forces that kept growth sluggish before the recession are still around, two examples being well-stocked consumers and a shrinking military industry.
 
A Slower Pace
 "You are likely to get the normal cyclical dynamics, but on top of a very slow trend, " said Richard Rippe, chief economist at Dean Witter. What is more, any speedy start now would be modest by the standards of past recoveries. At most, this rebound might start with a couple of quarters of 4 to 5 percent growth, not the high-single-digits pace registered immediately after some previous recessions.
Fed officials hasten to add that a bouncy recovery is not being forecast by the Fed, though Mr. Greenspan said two weeks ago that "the probability of a stronger-than-expected recovery is rising slightly."
Mr. Strongin of the Chicago Fed said: "This recession has a different structure going in, and the recovery has a different structure coming out. Charting its course is especially difficult."
One of the biggest differences is that alert companies started paring inventories when recession began. In most other recessions, inventories kept piling up for at least one quarter before business brought production into line with slower sales. In the long and deep 1974-75 recession, for example, inventories rose for a year before companies cut production.
At a forecasters' conference last September, Mr. Greenspan a former business prognosticator, argued that "economic forecasting is really the art of identifying tensions and understanding how they will be resolved over the short to intermediate term."
When the economy is changing direction, the tension between sales and stocks on shelves and in storerooms -- which no one except forecasters or managers ever think much about -- can provide clues to the future.

HEADLINE: Disgruntled India;
The Voters Make Clear Their Discontent, Giving No Party a Majority in Low Turnout

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Tuesday, June 18

 BODY:
The political map of India has been redrawn in the turbulent election of 1991, geographically and demographically. Traditional voting patterns have been upset as fewer voters than ever cast ballots in what is the world's most populous democracy and also one of the poorest of nations.
"I do not think our electorate is very clear about what it wants," said Ashis Nandy, a political scientist at the Center for the Study of Developing Societies in Delhi. "But the lesson of this election is that any party that has been in power has paid for it."
 
Congress Fares Badly in North
 By early this morning, with 320 of the 511 contested Parliament seats decided, the Congress Party had won 168 and was projected to win 210 to 215, well shy of the 256 it would need to form a government without a coalition partner. The Bharatiya Janata Party, the surging Hindu nationalist party, had won 73 seats and was projected to win 120. In third place, the Janata Dal coalition, which stirred controversy in championing Government affirmative action for lower castes, had won 24 seats. The rest of the decided seats went to smaller parties. 
 Denied a clear majority, the century-old Congress Party, in the throes of choosing a new candidate for Prime Minister after the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi, has been evicted from its strongholds among the poor, the Muslims and the upper castes in the northern states, and is now all but totally reliant on the support of allies in the south.
The Janata Dal coalition, which came to power under Prime Minister V. P. Singh in 1989 on a burst of enthusiasm for clean government and a break from one-party, one-family rule under Congress, now retains a significant presence in only three states, the heavily populated and important states of Uttar Pradesh and Bihar in the north and Orissa, a smaller state in the east.
Other politicians who had backed Mr. Singh as part of his National Front coalition, only to split with him over his program to aid the most disadvantaged, are battling to carve out constituencies that will enable them to survive. Much of the intellectual middle class, which had asserted itself through the front, was stunned and disappointed when Mr. Singh's promises of modernization turned out to include an expanded affirmative action program for the poorest and weakest castes.
This energized middle class, so vocal and aggressive in the previous election, is now hard to find within the vote totals being tallied.
The question is, where did they go?
A lot of them, their hopes dashed, opted out of political activity. With 53 percent of eligible voters casting ballots, the 1991 election had the lowest turnout of any modern Indian election, although even this was similar to the turnout for recent United States presidential elections.
"People like us do not vote," said Mr. Nandy, the political scientist. "Only the lower ranks still have faith in the electoral system."
But parties representing the most underprivileged Indians did not fare too well either. The Bahujan Samaj, appealing to outcastes to use their numerical superiority and seize political power, is teetering on extinction.
The Bharatiya Janata Party, the new force representing Hindu revivalism and upper caste privilege in a country that is more than 80 percent Hindu, has become the most dynamic national political organization, and in the process is positioning itself as the next hope for that significant part of the Indian middle class that is both Hindu and higher caste.
The party has captured the country's most populous state, Uttar Pradesh, the home base of the dynasty of Jawaharlal Nehru and the source of all but one of India's Prime Ministers.
 
Behind the Party's Success
 Mr. Nandy said that the success of the Hindu party had a lot to do with its effectiveness in packaging some of its least attractive appeals to religious chauvinism in the language of nationalism and equality, though equality is oftened defined as the phasing out of minority rights.
The party, however, also lost ground in states where it had been voted to power a scant year ago, raising questions about whether its success can be sustained.
The only exception to the "toss the rascals out" rule in this election seemed to be the support shown in the state of West Bengal for the Communist Party of India-Marxist, the larger of two Communist organizations. There, Chief Minister Jyoti Basu, in power for 14 years, obtained another term with a majority in the state assembly. The party was also leading in parliamentary contests.
The restless middle class has traditionally found other ways of gaining power, Mr. Nandy said, through control of news organizations and dominance of a vast Civil Service, among other methods. Many seem to feel that the overly centralized, openly corrupt political system only gets in the way of economic development.
A young clothing designer was bluntly direct. "Politicians are all jerks," he said. "There isn't any one of them competent to run this place. They are screwing up business."
 
Big Turnout of Women
 Mr. Nandy said that the failure of the Janata Dal was its inability to make its long-term development aims clear to the expanding middle class -- up to 150 million people out of more than 817 million -- whose traditional commitment has been to its own privileges in an overpopulated society where resources and jobs are scarce. Mr. Singh's affirmative action plan, which he calls essential to the social and economic growth of the nation, frightened and outraged many of them.
But politicians say that the poor performance of the Janata Dal coalition and the generally inconclusive verdict delivered by a skeptical electorate could also be explained by other factors without long-term implications.
Madhu Dandavate, Finance Minister in the Government of Prime Minister Singh and one of a lengthening list of former officials defeated in this election, said today in a television interview that in his Maharashtra constituency the turnout of women had been higher than of men. He said he believed that the women voted "from their hearts" for the party of the slain Mr. Gandhi.
A similar trend was observed in the southern state of Kerala, where a resilient Communist-led Government was wiped out in a Congress Party surge -- helped, apparently, by a large turnout of women and tacit help from the Bharatiya Janata Party, which knew it did not have much hope of penetrating the electorate on its own in a region remote from its northern power base.
Prannoy Roy, a political scientist and polling expert, said his data suggested that Congress benefited not so much from a "sympathy wave" after Mr. Gandhi's slaying as from a "re-energizing" of Congress supporters in response to the tragedy that had befallen the party.
 
Congress Seeking Allies
 Whether this modest resurgence of support for Congress is sustained, however, depends on the party's ability to choose the right prime ministerial candidate, the most effective coalition partner and the most vigorous program for dealing with an impending economic crisis in India.
Congress Party leaders have been phoning and meeting privately with officials of left-of-center parties as well as regional parties to gather the necessary majority in Parliament. A panel of two dozen Congress leaders is expected to name the party's parliamentary leader, and hence its choice for Prime Minister, in time for presentation to the party's legislators on Thursday.
After Mr. Gandhi's killing, the party leaders, seeking a sympathy vote and without a natural heir to the leadership, immediately turned to his widow, Sonia Gandhi, to ask her to take over. Mrs. Gandhi's rejection forced the party to turn at least temporarily to an ailing 70-year-old Brahmin, P. V. Narasimha Rao. Mr. Rao had faithfully served under Mr. Gandhi, who was Prime Minister from 1984 to 1989, and under his mother, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

GRAPHIC: Photo: India's century-old Congress Party, in a state of turmoil after the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi, failed to obtain a clear majority, falling short of the votes needed to form a new government. Indians viewed vote tallies being posted yesterday in New Delhi. (Associated Press) (pg. A6)

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 6.49, to 2,993.96; Trading Lags

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Stock prices moved narrowly yesterday in listless trading. With no significant news for traders to feed on, volume on the New York Stock Stock Exchange shrank to 134.2 million shares, from 169.3 million on Friday.
Because of the low volume, small losses among some blue-chip stocks were enough to trim the Dow Jones industrial average by 6.49 points, to 2,993.96. 
 "Aside from some profit taking after Friday's sharp advance, what we have is a stalemate because not enough people in the stock market believe interest rates have peaked," said Michael Metz, chief market strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. "We think last Friday's surge in bond prices was the turning point, but it apparently hasn't sunk in yet in the stock market."
 
Program Traders Sidelined
 In Mr. Metz's view, the relatively low amount of cash held by institutional investors is holding the stock market back. But it was the lack of liquidity, not cash, that kept the program traders on the sidelines. Birinyi Associates, which monitors program trading, found only one important buy and one sell program. The net result was to pare the Dow industrial averge by less than a point.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.16, to 380.13; the Big Board composite was off 0.96, at 208.38; the Nasdaq composite slipped 0.75, to 494.32, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index eased 0.23, to 367.13. There were 657 Big Board issues closing higher and 853 lower.
The fractional declines in blue-chip stocks that weighed down the Dow included a half-point dip in General Motors, to 43 3/4, and a 7/8 decline for I.B.M., to 99 1/2. G.M. was the second- most-active issue on the Big Board on a turnover of 1.65 million shares; I.B.M. was third with 1.63 million.
The most active was Computer Associates, which rose 1/2, to 10 7/8, on 2.3 million shares, much of which stemmed from 53 large blocks that changed hands.
 
Intel Up by 1 1/4, to 49 1/2
 As is often the case when the first-tier market is dull, secondary issues in the over-the-counter market drew investor attention. Intel, which was part of a generally weak semiconductor sector last week, stood out yesterday with a gain of 1 1/4, at 49 1/2.
Sun Microsystems lost 2 5/8, at 30 1/4, after a Goldman, Sachs analyst issued negative comments about the stock. But favorable comments about Novell Inc. by analysts at Smith Barney and Oppenheimer lifted the stock only temporarily.
After rising by 1 1/4, Novell closed up 3/4, at 50 3/4. Another well-regarded issue that gave up most of its gain was Costco Wholesale. After climbing well over two points on a sharp rise in earnings, it closed up by 3/4, at 42.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ames Says Insolvency Is Almost Over

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Ames Department Stores Inc., a leading discounter that filed for voluntary bankruptcy last year, told creditors yesterday that its fortunes had brightened sufficiently so that it could emerge from insolvency by the first half of 1992.
Ames said it expected to report a profit before taxes this year, compared with a loss for 1990. 
 Stephen L. Pistner, chairman and chief executive of Ames, said the company expected earnings before interest, taxes and expenses related to the bankruptcy filing to total $21.7 million this year, compared with 1990's loss of $317.2 million.
Speaking first to a creditor group and then at a news conference, Mr. Pistner said the 448-store company planned to improve sales by enhancing merchandise and increasing advertising at 124 urban "high impact" stores, those considered to have the highest sales potential. Ames also plans to place specialized departments like craft stores in 100 stores as well as create new jewelry and home furnishings departments.
 
Five-Year Plan
 The fiscal-year projections are part of a five-year plan the company said would be a framework for a reorganization plan that would be submitted to creditors.
Ames's five-year estimates call for profits before interest and taxes to rise to $129.1 million in the 1996 fiscal year, Mr. Pistner said. Current sales of $3.1 billion are expected to rise to $3.7 billion by that time, and profit margins are expected to grow seven-tenths of a percent, to 3.5 percent.
Mr. Pistner said that since Ames filed for bankruptcy protection in April 1990, the company had developed strategies to improve profitability, achieve consistent growth in comparable-store sales, reduce annual expense ratios and generate sufficient cash flow for investment in stores, support systems and operations.
But he also said Ames's sales from March through May were down slightly from the company's expectations, though same-store sales were higher. Because many Ames stores are in economically depressed New England, he said, the company had reduced its 1991 sales plan by $48 million because it did not expect the New England economy to turn around this year. Asked how Ames might be affected by the advance of Wal-Mart Stores Inc., based in Bentonville, Ark., into the North, he said: "We compete with 48 Wal-Marts now, and we've been able to blunt their openings. But we have figured a 15 percent downward effect in our five-year plan because of those expected new Wal-Marts."

HEADLINE: Kremlin Divided Over Economic Plan

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 17

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was reported today to have welcomed an unofficial plan by Soviet and American economists to integrate the country into the world market, while his Prime Minister dismissed it as a distraction.
Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the 39-year-old economist who brought the plan back from Harvard University over the weekend, presented it to Mr. Gorbachev today and found his reaction "fairly positive," he told the Soviet press agency, Tass. 
 Mr. Yavlinsky, who resigned as an adviser to Mr. Gorbachev last year, has no official connection to him any more, but remains on good terms with Mr. Gorbachev and Boris N. Yeltsin, the president of the Russian republic.
But Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov, telling the standing Soviet legislature about the Government's plans to try to halt the economic collapse, dismissed it as "a pretty piece of paper."
"I know a few gentlemen from Harvard University," he said. "They do not know our life. We can hardly expect them to explain everything to us." Mr. Pavlov was named by Mr. Gorbachev last winter to reassure those in the Communist Party who feared the consequences of too much change too fast.
The plan focuses in the short run on making the ruble convertible, privatizing small enterprises and getting the deficit under control.
Large-scale privatization of state enterprises, the establishment of financial and securities markets, and expansion of consumer goods and service would take place in later phases.
The plan was also presented to President Bush in Washington today, in advance of a seven-nation summit meeting of industrial democracies in London next month. The seven leaders will consider whether the West can help the Soviet transformation.
Mr. Gorbachev has accepted an invitation to address them after the summit meeting ends on July 17.
Soviet advocates of a shift toward a market economy say that Mr. Gorbachev was given a big push to move faster by the election last Wednesday of Mr. Yeltsin as President of the Russian Federation with 57.38 percent of the vote, on a platform of fundamental and rapid economic change.
Mr. Pavlov's remarks today were, therefore, not expected to have much effect on Mr. Gorbachev's views.
But several conservative Soviet legislators also criticized the Yavlinsky plan.
Viktor G. Kucherenko, chairman of the Parliament's committee on budget and finance, said it represented unwanted interference in the country's internal affairs.
"Russia has always attracted foreigners, but foreigners worked for our country and not the country for foreigners, as it is turning out now," he said.
In a 70-minute speech to the legislature, Mr. Pavlov said the Government would be seeking direct private foreign investment, instead of Western credits or loans, as it moves toward a market economy, at whatever speed.

HEADLINE: Experts Debate if AIDS Epidemic Has at Last Crested in U.S.

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
IS the AIDS epidemic in the United States reaching its peak? Although only a few experts are willing to say it has, quite a number believe the question is at least worth discussing.
Ten years after the first cases were recognized, the disease is still untamed and has yet to do its worst in the rest of the world. But in the United States, it could be possible in the foreseeable future to declare the deadly tide on the ebb. 
 At the least, the estimate of the number of Americans infected with the AIDS virus keeps getting less gloomy. Two times in the past five years, the Centers for Disease Control has lowered its estimates, from 1.5 million infected Americans in 1986, to 1.3 million in 1987 to one million in 1988.
The Federal agency has stood pat on its one million figure, but its statisticians concede that the number of AIDS cases actually reported has been falling short of their predictions, meaning that they may have to adjust the numbers downward yet again. In contrast, AIDS cases are rising sharply in many developing countries, participants at an international conference in Florence, Italy, were told yesterday. [Page C3.]
In this country, it is still uncertain whether there is an independent AIDS epidemic among heterosexuals. Although the AIDS virus spreads heterosexually and the total of heterosexual AIDS cases is rising steadily, such cases still appear linked to the infected pool of intravenous drug abusers, meaning the epidemic has not yet taken on a life of its own among heterosexuals who do not use drugs. Some leading researchers say they seriously question whether such a heterosexual epidemic will ever flare in this country.
Some experts insist that the AIDS epidemic has peaked in the United States -- that this is as bad as it is going to get, at least in this country. By peaking, they mean that the number of newly diagnosed cases per year has reached its highest point, even though the cumulative total will continue to grow for some time. The epidemic would be better described in terms of the number of new infections per year, since these precede onset of the disease by up to 10 years, but for lack of information on infection patterns the number of cases is the only usable index.
Many who are uncertain whether the peak has yet arrived nonetheless agree with Sir David Cox, a statistician at Oxford University in England, who said, "It is fair to say that, on the whole, the predictions have been rather on the gloomy side, but things haven't worked out quite as badly."
Like everything else that touches on AIDS, the questions of where the epidemic is going and how fast it is moving are intensely debated.
No one discounts the cruel nature of the epidemic or the pain and devastation left by the virus as it brings a lingering death to people in the prime of life. And no one dismisses the truly horrifying surge in the number of cases over the decade. In 1981, 189 cases of AIDS were reported to the Centers for Disease Control. In 1990, 43,339 cases were reported. The question, however, is what is coming next.
AIDS is among the most difficult diseases researchers have ever tried to model. Researchers do not know how many people are infected with the virus but not yet ill, how likely infected people are to infect others or how treatments that may delay the onset of AIDS might have put a lag into the statistics. All these factors increase the uncertainty in the models.
Another complication is that the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta changed its list of conditions that mark a diagnosis of AIDS in 1988, adding dementia and a wasting syndrome to the list of conditions that already included disorders like Kaposi's sarcoma and Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia. This created a bulge in the number of AIDS cases, but the bulge had nothing to do with a true increase in the incidence of the disease.
At the centers, the agency's own epidemiologists and statisticians say they are uncertain whether the epidemic has reached a plateau.
Dr. Meade Morgan, chief of the centers' statistics branch, said he expected the epidemic would peak at different times in different groups. He said it was hard to say the worst had happened until things started getting better. "It is too early to say there has been a plateau in any population," he said. "Until the numbers actually peak and then begin to decline, there is no way of knowing."
But others say the peaks have already occurred, at least in some groups. Dr. Alexander Langmuir, a retired scientist who was chief epidemiologist at the disease control agency from 1949 to 1970, said the epidemic had passed its peak among homosexual men and was starting to peak in intravenous drug users. Dr. Langmuir said his conclusions were based on intensive study of reports from the disease agency on the numbers of AIDS cases. "My belief is that the AIDS epidemic in the U.S. has crested," he said.
Dr. Joel Hay, a health economist at Stanford University, agreed. Dr. Hay has drawn up a mathematical simulation of the epidemic, using the same method as the disease centers and the agency's own data. Dr. Hay works backward from the number of cases diagnosed in each period to the number of people who must earlier have been infected.
 
Uncertainty Over Estimates
 "Our calculations say that basically all the infections occurred prior to 1986," he said, meaning that in the early years of the epidemic, the virus spread rapidly in populations like gay men and intravenous drug users so that most people were exposed and many infected. Now, with so many people at high risk already infected and with many who are not infected taking precautions to avoid infections, fewer and fewer infections are occurring. "We think there are fewer than 30,000 new infections a year now and there could be as few as 10,000 new infections a year," he said.
Dr. Morgan said that estimates of the number of new infections were fraught with uncertainty but that, if pressed, he would say that there were 40,000 to 80,000 new infections a year in this country.
Dr. Hay calculates that 500,000 to 800,000 Americans are now infected with the AIDS virus. This is considerably lower than the 1988 estimate of the disease centers that a million Americans are infected.
Dr. Morgan, the chief of statistics at the disease centers, agreed that the figure of one million might be too high. Based on that figure, he said, he would expect more cases of AIDS than are being reported.
"The cases that we're seeing reported are falling at the lower end of what we predicted," Dr. Morgan said. In contrast, he said, just a few years ago, when the number of cases reported was increasing rapidly, the Centers for Disease Control was right on target in its estimates of how many cases would be reported each year. That leaves the statisticians with two alternatives.
Either the pool of infected people is being overestimated, Dr. Morgansaid, or new treatments like the drug AZT have had a large effect in prolonging the time between infection and the onset of AIDS, postponing the time when AIDS is diagnosed.
Dr. Morgan added that it was hard to estimate how many fewer people might be infected, if the treatment hypothesis proved incorrect. "It depends which model you're looking at," he said. But he said that it might be more like 700,000 than one million, which is a number that accords with Dr. Hay's estimate.
Dr. Morgan and his colleagues are now trying to incorporate in their models the effects of drugs that postpone the onset of AIDS and deaths from Pneumocystis pneumonia. If early treatment indeed accounts for the lower-than-expected number of AIDS cases, then there will be a surge in reported cases in the next year or so when those in whom disease was postponed become ill.
From the beginning of the AIDS epidemic, the public has been terrified that it could break out of the known risk groups and take on a life of its own. But some say it is looking increasingly less likely that that will happen.
Dr. Hay noted that he had seen no evidence that the AIDS virus had broken free from the gay and drug-using communities. Dr. Dennis Bregman, a statistician and epidemiologist at the University of Southern California, agreed.
"The disease is hard to transmit," he said. "You don't get it from casual contact." He said that most cases among heterosexuals could be attributed to other known risk factors like intravenous drug use or hemophilia. "You look at it and say, where is the heterosexual epidemic?"
Dr. Harold Jaffe, deputy director for science at the AIDS division of the disease centers, added that heterosexual transmission was more difficult than people expected. The virus spreads easily among intravenous drug users, crack addicts and their sexual partners, he said, but apparently not outside those groups. Among drug users, he stated, other factors, like genital ulcers and number of sexual partners, seem to make it more likely that the AIDS virus will take hold.
"In that sort of environment, we can have effective heterosexual transmission," he said. But it seems to be much less efficient in the rest of the heterosexual population, he added.
"Five or six years ago, people suggested that this will happen to the housewife in Cedar Rapids," he said.
But the statistics show "that is not the case," he added.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Quick Profits Unlikely For New Franchises

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
When the owners of the new Miami and Denver baseball franchises begin money talks with TV stations and regional sports cable channels in the coming weeks and months, they will not be entirely in the catbird seat.
Yes, there is plenty of euphoria in the two cities whose efforts paid off in their selection as the newest National League teams (pending the approval of major league owners). But euphoria is one of the worst moods in which to negotiate. 
 Besides, there is an advertising recession nationwide, and a particularly battered economy in Denver thanks to stumbles by the banking and real-estate industries. Those who run Denver and Miami's TV stations and regional sports channels are unlikely to spend as they would have in the profligate 80's. And remember that the new franchises will not share in the last year of baseball's $1.4 billion national TV contract when they begin play in 1993.
But there are three compelling reasons why more TV and cable money will be spent on the more densely populated Miami market (the 16th largest) than the Denver market (No. 19).
*There is heavy competition from at least two Miami independent TV stations, including, WSVN and WBFS (broadcaster of 25 Miami Heat games), compared with one extremely powerful independent, KWGN, in Denver.
*The presence of two arch-competitive Miami sports cable channels, SportsChannel Florida (owner of the rights to Heat games) and the Sunshine Network (which airs Orlando Magic games), but just one, Prime Network, in Denver.
*The Hispanic population, which is half of Miami's Dade County population, is served by the highly rated WLTV, owned by the Univision network, and WSCV, a smaller station owned by the other major Hispanic network, Telemundo.
Negotiations between the Miami franchise and sports-only channels will create tensions. Sunshine is larger than SportsChannel Florida (3 million subscribers to 1.1 million), but both are aggressive parts of huge cable outfits. Sunshine is part of the Prime Sports Network; SportsChannel Florida is owned by Cablevision Systems and NBC. Although both corporate parents have engaged in merger talks, the absence of an agreement allows both to bid.
"You have to look at the best interests of the team," said Ed Frazier, president of Prime Sports. "You want to build fan loyalty quicker, and since Miami will be the only team in Florida, it will want maximum distribution."
For Miami, the media rights could add up to $10 million.
 Denver is a different tale, where media rights may only earn the franchise $5 million. What distinguishes the mountainous Mile High City from flat, humid Miami is a location -- hundreds of miles from any other major league city -- that would give it de facto domination over virgin territory. The ownership envisions a TV sphere far beyond Denver, a network of TV affiliates expanding into Wyoming, Montana, Nebraska and New Mexico.
That's fine, but most of outer-Denver is sparsely populated, and rights fees from TV stations in distant cities won't be stunning. Said Mark Wyche, a vice president of Bortz & Co., a media consulting firm: "The largest portion of their revenues will come from the Denver area. I wouldn't be concerned with running a network through Wyoming and Montana."
Potential bidders for Denver baseball on TV and cable aren't frothing over the prospect of acquiring the rights to a sure loser of a team.
"This city has gone berserk over getting the team, but then there's reality," said John Suder, general manager of KWGN. "We've lived through six years of a recession. A deal is viable. But if they come in and try to get a lot of their $95 million expansion fee back in TV rights, it won't be easy."
 
Yanks' Ratings Drop Slightly
 Whatever new spirit may be infusing the youthful New York Yankees hasn't caught on with local TV viewers. Through 23 games on WPIX-TV, the average Nielsen rating is down a tad from last season, from 4.7 to 4.6. One rating point in the New York market represents 70,437 households. The season's shining moment was the June 11 rating of 7.6 for a road game against the Minnesota Twins, which beat a 6.2 for a Mets-Braves game. Through 28 broadcasts on WWOR-TV, the Mets average rating is up to 7.4 from last year's 6.3 at the same time, but that average has eroded steadily since May 7 when it hit 8.4.

HEADLINE: Disarming the Soviets, With Aid

 BODY:
There's a big reason for the West to think hard about giving economic assistance to the Soviet Union: Moscow's military spending. Even as the Soviets seek billions in aid, they maintain the largest army in the world, devote an extravagant share of their shrinking gross national product to defense and continue to modernize nuclear forces. That's why Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and others would condition aid on deep cuts.
But that might well do more harm than good. Most likely, it would undercut pressures inside the Soviet Union that are already forcing military cutbacks and would strengthen the hand of hard-liners who oppose East-West cooperation. 
 Moscow's defense budget is of less concern than its military power. Spending is actually slowing. But the Soviet Union has considerable military potential and a nuclear arsenal that could demolish the U.S. The task is to assure that these capabilities pose no threat. That requires the ultimate conversion -- turning the Soviet Union into a satisfied power, perhaps like France, whose nuclear arms seem utterly unthreatening.
Aid, and the economic engagement that accompanies it, could do just that. They would demonstrate good will when the Soviet people need it most. And they could spur Moscow to spend more on the better things in life and less on arms.
Even now, internal pressures are sapping Soviet military strength. Moscow still has all its tanks, but the treaty on conventional forces in Europe obliges it to spend money dismantling at least 7,500 of them. Draft calls go unanswered, not only in a few independence-minded republics but elsewhere. Last fall, 22 percent of those called up did not report for duty. A divided officer corps and troops who can't be counted on to obey orders leave the Red Army in no shape to menace its neighbors in the foreseeable future.
True, Moscow's nuclear modernization continues. But it's building fewer bombers and missiles than U.S. intelligence anticipated, and the pending strategic arms treaty will oblige it to cut what it has by a third. The reason Moscow is adding to its small strategic bomber force is that the treaty, at U.S. insistence, makes it advantageous to do so by discounting warheads on bombers.
The Soviets' new SS-25 missile could actually make the nuclear balance less precarious. With its single nuclear warhead, it poses less of a threat than multi-warhead missiles. And because its mobility makes it capable of surviving, Moscow need not launch it at the first signs of attack.
Tying economic aid to deeper cuts could easily slow the process. Moscow's military-industrial complex will see such demands as blackmail, and stiffen its resistance to economic reform. It would accuse Mikhail Gorbachev of selling out to the West and weakening the Soviet Union.
Better to leave the condition implicit and let the economic transformation of the Soviet Union force a reduction in defense spending, as it inevitably must. This is surely a calculated risk; yet Americans can count on those Soviets who appreciate two political facts of life. One is that a reforming Soviet Union can't afford to allocate as much to defense. The second is that a Soviet Union that fails to reform -- and fails also to make measurable cuts in military spending -- cannot indefinitely count on Western assistance.

HEADLINE: Newark Priest Wins a 'Genius' Award

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Msgr. William J. Linder is a parish priest with a mission to find creative ways of securing affordable housing, health care and better schools for people in one of Newark's poorest neighborhoods. His income: $10,000 a year.
Monsignor Linder was named yesterday as one of 31 winners of fellowships from Chicago's MacArthur Foundation. For this, he will receive $330,000 over the next five years. 
 "My first reaction was 'MacArthur what?' " said the 55-year-old pastor of St. Rose of Lima Church. Later, when he was told that the fellowships were given to gifted people and were sometimes called the "genius prizes," he cheerfully replied: "Now we're in trouble. I guess the cycle stops here."
Monsignor Linder, who earned a doctorate in sociology from Fordham University in 1988, said he intends to use his award money to visit poor neighborhoods in other cities in search of ideas to improve job opportunities for Newark's largely black and Hispanic residents.
 
A Model for Revitalization
 The New Community Corporation, which he founded in 1968, is regarded as a model for neighborhood revitalization. The corporation was established in Newark's Central Ward in an area that was virtually burned out in the riots of July 1967.
Among the corporation's accomplishments are 8 housing developments with 2,400 apartments, including a $4 million transitional housing project for homeless families. The project, called Harmony House, was created with government and private financing.
The corporation also established an alternative school, five day care centers, a shelter for battered women and part ownership in a Pathmark supermarket -- enterprises that helped create 1,150 jobs.
For now, finding more jobs for young people is a leading preoccupation, Monsignor Linder said, and that translates into attracting new business to the neighborhood. He said he was particularly pleased about the corporation's successful renovation of a deteriorating Gothic church that was turned into St. Joseph's Plaza, a complex that includes a medical clinic, a sandwich shop, a spa and a restaurant.
 
31 Winners This Year
 The MacArthur Fellowships were awarded this year to 9 women and 22 men, and the winners will receive from $150,000 to $375,000. Since the awards were established 10 years ago by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, more than $105 million has been invested in the program.
Winners must be recommended by a panel of 100 anonymous nominators and reviewed by a 12-member selection committee and the foundation's board members.
Besides Monsignor Linder, the others who won MacArthur Fellowships this year and the amount of money awarded are:
Jacqueline K. Barton, 39, of San Marino, Calif., professor of chemistry at the California Institute of Technology; $250,000.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Greenhouse Gamblers

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IF the experts don't really know how fast the atmosphere is warming or what the consequences of warming could be, what should Washington do to slow it down? To the Environmental Defense Fund, the answer seems obvious: Buy some insurance against catastrophe, and buy it as cheaply as possible.
The defense fund wants electric utilities to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases at least to the extent that their new plants are adding them. And it wants Uncle Sam to keep the cost down by creating a market for greenhouse gas "offsets," allowing a utility in, say, Virginia or Texas to meet its obligation by paying to plant trees in Costa Rica or to trap methane from garbage dumps in Ohio. 
 The plan is bound to receive a mixed reception in the White House. President Bush's economists championed a similar market-based plan for coping with acid rain, which is the centerpiece of last year's amendments to the Clean Air Act. But Administration skeptics, notably John Sununu, have yet to concede that anyone should be asked to spend money to solve an environmental problem that may never materialize.
Commercial power plants emitting 100,000 tons of carbon annually are by no means the only important sources of greenhouse gases. But they are prime targets for reformers because their emissions are relatively easy to monitor, and their pollution-control costs can be passed on to a broad base of customers.
The bill introduced yesterday by two Democratic Congressmen, Jim Cooper of Tennessee and Mike Synar of Oklahoma, would require utilities to save a ton of carbon (or its equivalent in other greenhouse gases) for every additional ton they pump into the air. Renovated plants would have to meet the same requirement after 1995. Plants might meet the standard by switching from coal to natural gas, which produces more watts per pound of carbon emitted, or by encouraging consumers to conserve energy. But the architects of the plan hope and expect utilities to go farther afield.
Dan Dudek, an Environmental Defense Fund economist, thinks offsets could be harvested at very low cost from dozens of sources. For example, huge amounts of methane, a far more potent greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide, are currently vented from coal mines. And most of the chlorofluorocarbon gases, the most destructive of all greenhouse chemicals, are now lost when refrigerators and air-conditioners are scrapped.
Utilities might not wish to collect waste gases from mines or abandoned appliances. But they certainly could pay others to do the collecting. And if there were an active market for offsets, they could simply buy as many tons as they needed, the way General Mills buys wheat on the commodity exchanges.
The oldest objection to markets for pollution offsets -- that sinners should not be permitted to buy indulgences -- no longer carries much weight among economically sophisticated environmentalists. But other qualms are not so easily dismissed.
One is cost. Almost everyone agrees that offsets represent the cheapest and least intrusive way to buy insurance against greenhouse warming. But there is wide disagreement over how cheap the insurance would be.
Drawing on a report published last month by the National Academy of Sciences, Mr. Dudek estimates that utilities could meet the bill's requirements through the year 2005 at a cost of $10 billion to $20 billion. Bush Administration economists fear the academy is too optimistic. They doubt, for example, that higher-mileage cars would pay for themselves in savings at the pump.
But the most fundamental objection is the most imponderable: How much should be spent on a greenhouse solution before it is certain there is a greenhouse problem? The White House is in no mood to purchase a $10 billion o $20 billion insurance policy on the strength of current science. It is holding out for a far more cautious "no regrets" policy, curbing greenhouse gases only to the extent that the limits can be justified on other grounds. The prime target: chlorofluorocarbons, which are also the chief culprits in thinning the atmosphere's protective layer of ozone.
President Bush surely has the muscle to block legislation this year. But with Europe pressing for a greenhouse fix, and big business afraid to be caught on the politically incorrect side of the debate, delay is becoming less tenable.
Sooner or later -- probably sooner -- Washington is likely to leap into the unknown. When it does, an offsets plan is going to look better to the free marketers in the White House than heavy taxes on carbon emissions or the direct regulation of polluters.

HEADLINE: Summer School Cuts Create Private Boom

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
These are boom times at the New York Military Academy.
Despite the recession and the $2,200 cost for six weeks of private summer school, the academy in Cornwall-on-Hudson expects to enroll 150 students this year, up from about 80 students in the past several years. 
 Much of the growth is a result of budget cutbacks that have forced public schools to reduce or eliminate summer school. One Long Island mother, for example, recently called the academy to enroll her son in two courses that he failed this year. He was unable to take the classes at his public school because budget cutbacks had led it to reduce its summer school offerings.
"She was frantic," recalled Peter Wicker, director of admissions for the academy, which is 62 miles north of New York City. "Public schools are helping us out tremendously."
 
A Nationwide Trend
 At private summer schools and education camps elsewhere -- from Rhode Island to Ohio to California -- enrollment is also booming, because of widespread cutbacks in public summer school programs.
The Milwaukee school system, facing a $33 million deficit in the 1991-92 school year, eliminated transportation to schools and cut back to four weeks from six weeks on academic enrichment and music classes. As a result, school officials say they expect 3,000 fewer students will be able to attend summer school this year from last year's enrollment of 25,000.
In another Wisconsin system, Stevens Point, officials eliminated summer school. Last year, 2,600 students, or about 40 percent of the 7,400 total enrollment, attended the system's free summer programs.
Rather than cutting summer programs, some school systems have started charging for them. In Chicago, enrichment and remedial courses now cost $75 a credit. Even so, "because of our smaller summer program, some are turning to other options like private schools in larger numbers this year," said Joseph Ruiz, an administrator in the office of school operations.
There are other facors behind the growth of private summer programs. Parents are increasingly concerned about the quality of public schools and want to supplement their children's public education with academic courses and learning skills in a small classroom setting that they feel the public schools cannot match.
 
Rise in Private Programs
 The parental worries, combined with the demise this year in many places of public summer school, have prompted 312 private schools and camps to offer education programs this summer, a 55 percent increase since 1986, when 201 private summer education programs were offered, according to Peterson's Guides, which publishes a national directory of private summer schools and camps for children and teen-agers.
"While it is true that public schools are cutting back summer schools, it's also true that parents' perception of the quality of education at public schools is down," said Bill Cole, a spokesman for Peterson's Guides. "Parents are turning to private schools."
Private schools and camps have seized on the interest through aggressive marketing. Small class sizes, remedial and enrichment courses, recreation, culture and weekend trips are all offered -- and cost as much as $5,000 for six weeks.
The private summer schools and camps have also made themselves increasingly attractive by reaching agreements with state education departments, which evaluate curriculums and certify private programs, allowing students to transfer their private school or camp credits to their public institution.
 
Impact on Minorities
 For many, the shift toward private summer schools and camps is distressing. The cutbacks in public summer school have eliminated or severely reduced options for the less affluent, who are often members of minority groups who live in the inner cities.
Others see the push toward private summer school alternatives as an extension of school choice, the hotly-debated approach favored by the Bush Administration to allow parents to choose their childrens' schools, either public or private. The theory is that underperforming public schools will improve because of the pressure of losing students, and therefore funding. But critics say poor and minority students would be left behind in the worst schools because affluent families would seize the opportunity under choice programs to put their children in private schools.
"What you are seeing in the summer school phenomenon is a reflection of the whole issue of school choice," said Henrietta Schwartz, dean of the school of education at San Francisco State University. She said private schools were positioning themselves to take advantage of vouchers that could become available if President Bush's proposed choice plan was enacted.
In the meantime, private summer schools and camps are prospering this year, and they owe much of their success to financially troubled public schools.
In Cincinnati, for instance, a dire fiscal climate forced the school district to cancel all summer classes this year, except those for pupils in kindergarten through third grade and for high school seniors who need credits to graduate this year. Last year, the school system's summer program, which offers both remedial and enrichment courses, served 5,200 students, or about 5 percent of the school system's total enrollment, many of them poor, inner-city youths. This summer, the system expects to enroll about half that many students.
 
Painful Cuts in Cincinnati
 "We admitted from the very beginning that these cuts were very painful," said John Burner, a spokesman for the Cincinnati school system.
But as Cincinnati canceled the bulk of its summer school offerings, Purcell Marian School found itself reaping the benefits. The private Roman Catholic school offers only a remedial program, at $95 a course, but despite its limited offerings and the expense, attendance at the there is expected to swell to 500 students this summer, from 380 last year.
"We've had so many walk-ins," said Jan Rich, principal of the summer program at the Catholic school. "I suspect we'll have to close our registration period early because we will be full."
Some parents whose public school systems have retained some semblance of summer school despite budget cuts have turned to private summer schooling anyway.
Take Boye Barrie, who recently completed fourth grade in the Deer Park, L.I., school system. Stanley Diamond, who is the child's guardian, wanted his 11-year-old charge to attend summer school but ruled out the local public school program because of its limited course offerings and the lack of organized activities.
Mr. Diamond selected the New York Military Academy, where Boye will take English and other courses while also participating in horseback riding and rafting.
"I wanted him to get a combination of academics and activities," Mr. Diamond said. "It's a much better environment."
Other parents, while supporting public schools, concede that private alternatives offer more advanced and specialized training than public schools can provide. In Fort Collins, Colo., David Neenan, disturbed by the quality of public education, two years ago sent three of his four daugters to a private summer education camp, where they polished their writing skills, and learned to think critically and how to study better.
"I wanted to make sure that all those competencies were taught," said Mr. Neenan, who has spent 12 years on the local school board. "The tide in public education has gone out and I don't know that it's coming back."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Stages an Advance On Greenspan's Comments

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced yesterday after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said the economy is likely to bottom out during the current quarter.
Gold prices closed higher, edging up in New York after posting larger gains overseas. 
 Gold was up 10 cents, to $368.30 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $367.75, up 15 cents.
Mr. Greenspan told the House Ways and Means Committee that economic figures "over the last several weeks strongly suggested that the bottom is somewhere in the second quarter," which ends June 30.
The Fed chairman added that there were no signs yet that the economy had begun to grow again.
Analysts said that traders who favor the dollar were heartened by Mr. Greenspan's statements because an end to the economic downturn might lead to higher interest rates. Higher rates tend to support the dollar by increasing foreign demand for American investments.
Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager with the Bank of New York, said the dollar was also aided by expectations of a narrow merchandise trade deficit for April. The Commerce Department is to announce its trade figures today.
"The market figures it's going to be a deficit of $4 billion to $4.5 billion," Mr. Ryan said.
He said the dollar appeared to be on an upward trend. He noted that there had been no intervention by central banks to bring the dollar down.
"It's stacking up for the dollar to go higher and higher," he said.
The British pound, which has been weak recently, continued its slide against the dollar. Sterling fell to $1.6100 in New York from late Monday's $1.6265. In earlier London trading, the pound fell to $1.6120, from $1.6258 late Monday.
The dollar rose to 141.08 Japanese yen in New York from 140.70. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 141.06 yen, up 0.13 yen, and in London, it was quoted at 140.85 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, included: 1.81635 German marks, up from 1.7955; 1.5645 Swiss francs, up from 1.5435; 6.1725 French francs, up from 6.0975; 1,351.00 Italian lire, up from 1,337.00, and 1.14225 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14175.
In London, gold rose to a late bid of $370, from $367.75 late Monday. In Zurich, it rose to a closing bid of $370.25 from $366.75. The Hong Kong market was closed yesterday.
Silver picked up 1.2 cents to close at $4.448 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York.

HEADLINE: Little Change For C.D.'s, Bank Funds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down slightly to unchanged for the week ended yesterday.
According to The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest rate publication based in North Palm Beach, Fla., the latest rate trend shows the downturn in bank yields easing as the ratio between banks that are raising yields and those that are lowering yields begins to narrow. 
 At the Treasury Department's weekly auction held on Monday, average discount rates moved up for the third consecutive week to their highest since late April.
 
Rise of a Basis Point
 The rise in rates at the auctions over the last few weeks offers some hope to depositors, since the bill auctions often indicate what many banks may eventually pay on money market accounts and certificates of deposit. The three-month bill rose a basis point, to 5.61 percent, with the six-month bill increasing by a similar amount, to 5.79 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
Acknowledging that savings rates are down to four-year lows, Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, noted that banks were scrambling to keep depositors in this low-yield environment by adding new wrinkles to existing products or promoting products that appear to earn higher yields.
The largest yield changes in New York area banks this week were reported at Astoria Federal Savings, which added 11 basis points to its money market account, to yield 5.75 percent, and the Bank of New York, which reduced its money market account by 11 basis points, to 5.44 percent. Connecticut Bank and Trust posted the largest change for a three-month certificiate of deposit, by lowering the yield 21 basis points, to 5.74 percent. For a six-month certificate, Howard Savings Bank, based in Newark, and Connecticut Bank and Trust both lowered the yield by 10 basis points, to 6.30 percent and 5.85 percent, respectively; Anchor Savings Bank, based in Hewlett, L.I., raised the yield 10 basis points, to 5.9 percent.
Among commercial banks, the average money market account remained unchanged at 5.15 percent. A three-month certificate fell 2 basis points, to 5.5 percent, while a six-month maturity held at 5.67 percent.
Depositors at savings institutions saw the average yield on a money market account remain unchanged at 5.57 percent. A three-month certificate fell 3 basis points, to 5.8 percent, while a six-month maturity remained unchanged at 6.02 percent.
By comparison, at 20 large banks outside the New York market, the average money market yield fell by a basis point, to 5.25 percent, with no change in the average yield of a six-month certificate, at 5.74 percent.

HEADLINE: Treasury Criticizes Plan to Limit Bank Insurance

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
The Administration today sharply criticized a last-minute proposal that would limit Federal deposit insurance to banks that are restricted to traditional banking activities and deny it for riskier ventures.
The proposal, drafted by Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, is being considered just as the House Banking Committee is scheduled to begin its final consideration of the Treasury Department's proposed changes in banking laws, the most sweeping overhaul of the banking system since the 1930's. 
 The Schumer proposal is intended to reduce losses on deposit insurance by placing risky banking activities outside the protection of the insurance fund.
Only a "core" bank would be eligible for deposit insurance and the bank would be restricted to the types of loans that are least likely to go into default -- for instance, consumer and small-business loans. Riskier activities, like commercial lending, would be permitted only in separately capitalized subsidiaries not protected by deposit insurance.
Jerome H. Powell, an Assistant Treasury Secretary, said before the banking committee that the measure could "create or aggravate future credit crunches and otherwise disrupt routine commercial lending activites."
Mr. Powell said the proposal represented a fundamental change that would "launch our financial system into uncharted waters." He said the measure could reduce the international competitiveness of banks and produce regional credit shortages. There are sufficient safeguards in the Treasury banking measure under consideration to limit taxpayer exposure to losses from bank failures, he said.
Mr. Powell estimated that $1.5 trillion would be driven from the banking system under the Schumer proposal, reducing the availability of credit to an array of borrowers. He also strongly objected to proposed caps on the interest rates that "core" banks would pay depositors. And he said restrictions in the Schumer proposal that would sharply curtail the amount of loans a bank could make to one borrower were far too severe.
"This is a large-scale experiment and there may be something in it," Mr. Powell said. "But we have no confidence."
The Schumer proposal, which will be introduced as an amendment to the proposal on banking change now working its way through Congress, is seen as a possible compromise for a House Banking Committee that wants to reduce restrictive banking regulations, a House Commerce Committee concerned about reducing historic divisions between banking and commerce and the Treasury Department's package of proposals to modernize banking.
L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said that while the Schumer proposal was a sensible approach, he objected to controls on interest rates that would restrict the core banks to offering depositors no more than 105 percent of the rate paid on Treasury securities. "The history of price controls is the history of failure," Mr. Seidman said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Networks Having Trouble Peddling Fall's Prime Time

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
USUALLY at this time of the year, the broadcast television networks are merrily ringing up hefty price increases on the commercials they sell for the coming fall season's prime-time programs. But now the bells sound as if they are tolling, not ringing.
As the annual advance sales process -- known to the advertising, marketing and media communities as the up-front market -- continues, earlier expectations that prices would fall are proving true. The reason that ABC, CBS, Fox and NBC are cutting prices in the up-front market is the slack demand for commercial time from marketers that are reducing or postponing ad spending in response to the recession. 
 And since advertisers are instructing their agencies to trim up-front purchases of time for the 1991-92 season, the networks find themselves in the unusual position of needing to cut rates to make sales.
The combination of reduced prices and decreased demand is making it more difficult than usual to estimate how much business the networks will book by the time the up-front market ends next month. Agency media executives who have been participating in up-front negotiations -- a ritual that many describe as a bazaar crossed with a chess match and a bullfight -- are placing their estimates within a range of $3.6 billion to $3.8 billion, compared with $4.3 billion in last year's up-front market for the 1990-91 season. If the market does conclude at the lower end of that range, it would be about equal to the up-front market for the 1989-90 season.
The up-front participants are also estimating that the networks are cutting prices by 8 percent to 12 percent from what they charged during the 1990-91 up-front market.
"It is a soft economy, so it is a soft network marketplace," said Jon Mandel, senior vice president and director of national broadcast at Grey Advertising in New York. "How long that continues is, frankly, anybody's guess, but right now there are deals to be had."
The price reductions and soft demand have put an end to the networks' annual attempts to create a "jump on the bandwagon" mentality among advertisers during the up-front market, said Gene DeWitt, president of DeWitt Media Inc., a New York media management company that buys commercials for clients including Reebok International and American Family Publishers. "No one's buying that act this year," Mr. DeWitt said.
It used to be "that he who buys early buys best," said Jerome Dominus, senior vice president and director of national television and programming for J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. in New York. "Now, there's a fire sale," said Mr. Dominus, who formerly was on the other side of the table during the up-front market as the head of network sales at CBS.
As often occurs in the up-front market, the networks are pursuing varying strategies, according to participants. They describe CBS and NBC as "trying to sell everything they can up front," as Mr. DeWitt put it, because they are less bullish on prospects for the recession to end anytime soon and would rather book the revenue now than later.

HEADLINE: About New York

BYLINE: By Douglas Martin

 BODY:
A late summer afternoon is oozing into a sultry evening, and people on 45th Avenue between 21st and 23rd Streets in Long Island City are performing their nightly ballet. Some scurry home from work, some bounce balls, some chat with neighbors, some walk dogs. All are living city lives in the truest sense.
It was Jane Jacobs, the writer who changed the way many Americans think about their cities, who most persuasively preached the importance of sidewalks. In her 1961 book, "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," she called them "active participants in the drama of civilization versus barbarism in cities." 
That isn't a novel thought to Margaret Freeborn, who has been sitting nightly on the same stoop on this lushly shaded Queens street for 46 years, always with her current dog. The current one is a poodle named Whitey. "My best pal," Mrs. Freeborn calls him.
She has long owned her home and two rooming houses on 45th Avenue and has made many pals on the street, as well as acquaintances she would never dream of allowing in her knickknack-cluttered row house. She chain-smokes unfiltered Chesterfields, jokes sardonically, guards her age like a gem and goes the extra mile for fellow humans. She has paid burial expenses for some tenants.
Since her husband, John, died in November, she is alone more. But she is seldom lonely: there is that parade forever passing her stoop.
Danny, a Cuban man carrying a quart of beer and a bag of platanos, stops to complain about the price of cigars. An unemployed man with a pregnant wife sinks to his knees to ask for money, and gets a $10 "loan" as well as a warning not to spend it on gin. A dancer in "Miss Saigon" stops to talk about the Broadway show. A man with AIDS sits silently for few minutes. A red-haired woman in a very short skirt drops a breezy hello. Everyone greets Whitey by name.
A few years of this, one gets to know things about people. The man with a cane shuffling into a house across the street abandoned a wife and five children, leaving them on welfare. That woman is a drug addict; this man won a bowling tournament back when there was a neighborhood alley; that taciturn man survived the Holocaust.
And one gets to know people, some fundamentally. Eddie, who is retarded, was disconsolate when his mother died. Then Mrs. Freeborn told him that his mother was in heaven, and for a long time he kept looking up with a big smile.
Sitting on a sidewalk gives one a sense of time's passage. When first settled in the early 17th century, this whole area of Long Island City -- Hunters Point -- was a ledge of rocks in the East River. Then came the Long Island Rail Road, and residents became accustomed to seeing Theodore Roosevelt change trains on his way to Sagamore Hill. The coming of the Queensboro Bridge in 1909 and elevated trains soon thereafter made the area a handy enclave for Broadway types.
This show-business past still sparkles in Mrs. Freeborn's memory. Next door lived Lottie Burnell, an old-time movie actress. It was at her house that Mrs. Freeborn met Tallulah Bankhead and Pat O'Brien. Rin-Tin-Tin's almost forgotten son, Rinty, was buried in her backyard.
So much has changed. Gone are two drugstores, a barber shop with an old-fashioned revolving pole, St. John's Hospital and what Mrs. Freeborn calls "little neighborhood bars for the little neighborhood guys." What has thrust up in their place is the glass tower of the new Citicorp building, which looms over the northern end of the street like a misplaced rocket ship.
In her magical backyard -- where she raises roses and has assembled scores of flamingos, squirrels and other lawn ornaments, and is now nursing an injured pigeon -- Mrs. Freeborn keeps the crucifix that once crowned St. John's Hospital.
"I found it in a garbage can," she said. "Wasn't that a disgrace?"
She remembers being a platinum blonde, meeting Jackie Gleason at the old Club 18, enjoying trips to Atlantic City before gambling ruined the place and bringing up two sons, Frankie and Willie. Both are now grandfathers.
Not an hour goes by without her hearing her husband's last words: "Happy birthday, Marge."
This wise woman of the clear blue eyes remembers all her hundreds of tenants. There was one known as Wolf Man, whom she felt sorry for and gave a free room. There was the Japanese man who took such haunting photos. There was Jimmy, who was deaf and could not speak. "I had him talking," she said.
In the late sun on a New York City stoop, thoughts can jumble a bit. But one seems inescapable. When there were more rooming houses like Mrs. Freeborn's -- and more people sat on stoops -- the world was a better place.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Margaret Freeborn in the backyard garden of her house on 45th Avenue in Long Island City, Queens. (Jim Estrin for The New York Times)
