HEADLINE: Camden Fights Sewer Tax as Bill From Unwanted Guest

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J., June 14

 BODY:
On a warm day the stench from a sewage-treatment plant hangs like a foul blanket over the modest row houses and abandoned factories here by the Delaware River.
Driven by both the smell and their own sense of powerlessness, nearly one of every three property owners in Camden is refusing to pay an annual $275 sewer assessment, prompting threats of liens and foreclosures. 
 The State Assembly has approved a bill that allows Camden to negotiate for more favored treatment on fees with the sewer authority that serves the county. The legislation raises anew the question of whether the state's affluent areas use poorer cities as a dumping ground for projects they need but do not want nearby: landfills, prisons, incinerators.
 
Fee Adjustment Demanded
 Leaders of the revolt against the sewer assessment are demanding that it be eliminated or reduced citywide, not just because of complaints about the plant's odor, but also because the city collects no property taxes from the 44 acres of waterfront property where the plant stands.
Few residents in South Camden have air-conditioning, and they say the treatment plant is a particularly noxious neighbor in the summer.
"Some days some of the children get sick and throw up, and I have to call their parents to come and get them," said Viola Vukich, who for 22 years has been the secretary at the Sacred Heart School, a few hundred yards from the treatment plant.
Some 7,500 property owners have refused to pay the sewer assessment, which comes to $68.50 every quarter. As a result, the Camden County Municipal Utilities Authority has threatened to foreclose on delinquent property owners.
 
'We Were All Getting Sick'
 "I haven't paid any of the assessments," said 71-year-old Carmella Labato, who has lived her entire life across the street from the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church and School, one of the centers of protest over the treatment plant and other community issues. "They keep sending me bills, and I don't pay them. I want to stay here, but it's hard to even pay my taxes."
"Two, three years ago the odor got so intense we were all getting sick. They say we have to pay for the smell. I won't."
Camden has been home to the sewage-treatment plant for decades. Two years ago the plant expanded and began treating not just Camden's sewage, but that of every other community in the county, 37 in all: more than 50 millions gallons of sewage a day.
On June 10 the State Assembly approved a bill that would allow Camden to negotiate an adjustment in rates with the independent sewer authority that runs the plant, the Camden County Municipal Utilities Authority. Later this month the measure is expected to go before the State Senate, where it faces a fight from suburban opponents who fear their own assessments could go up if Camden's are cut.
August Longo, the Mayor of Haddon Heights and a strong voice in the Camden County Mayor's Association, which is dominated by suburban communities, said most suburban mayors asked, "Why should we pay for all of Camden?"
Three years ago the mayor's association sued and blocked a $2 million payment to Camden by the Camden County Board of Chosen Freeholders to reduce or eliminate the sewage fees that city residents paid. The payment was to be an interim measure until a permanent adjustment in fees could be worked out. The state was to put up another $2 million, but the action of the mayor's association also made that moot.
To the Rev. Michael Doyle, pastor of Sacred Heart, it is a clash between haves and have-nots.
"Camden is the weak chicken in the coop, economically and politically, and everything that is undesirable ends up being dumped on it," he said, standing in the parking lot of the church, which sits between the sewage-treatment plant and the 340-foot tower of another county plant, a giant trash incinerator.
"We'd love to be merely between a rock and a hard place. That would be something of a blessing."
Father Doyle is part of a citywide coalition of 23 churches called Camden Churches Organized for People, which is leading the sewer protest. The church itself is exempt from the sewer assessment, but the school, largely attended by black and Hispanic children from the neighborhood, is assessed $275 for every 30 children in its enrollment of 230. It owes the sewer authority more than $10,000. Father Doyle refuses to pay.
Others, fearful of losing their homes, have yielded.
"We didn't pay it for a year, but we got nervous and started paying it," said Eleanor Bogdan, who has lived in the South Camden neighborhood for 30 years with her husband, a retired welder. "I wish I could bottle the air and take it to the legislators so they would know what we live with."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Wang Joins I.B.M. in a Marketing Alliance

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Wang Laboratories, the struggling computer maker, appeared to move toward ending its role as a hardware manufacturer yesterday when it sought shelter in an unusual marketing alliance with its archrival, I.B.M.
As part of a deal in which Wang will sell I.B.M. personal computers, work stations and minicomputers, the International Business Machines Corporation agreed to invest up to $100 million in Wang. The Lowell, Mass., company has been among I.B.M.'s biggest rivals for the largest corporate accounts. 
 The arrangement will almost certainly lead Wang, which now makes minicomputers and personal computers, to withdraw as a computer maker and try to survive as a software developer and I.B.M. computer reseller, several analysts said.
But Richard W. Miller, Wang's chairman, said the company planned to continue to support its existing proprietary line of VS minicomputers and that it had not yet decided whether to stop making its own personal computers.
"This is good news for Wang customers and Wang Laboratories," Mr. Miller said, adding that the new relationship with I.B.M. would free the company to concentrate on its strongest areas. "There are certain segments of the industry that Wang can not afford to spend money on in the future," he said.
Industry analysts said the alliance would probably lead to deep cutbacks at Wang.
"Wang will have little use for any manufacturing in the future," said Casey Stern, an analyst at Starr Securities. He said the company could save as much as $300 million to $400 million a year. That could translate into staff cuts of as many as 6,000 to 8,000 employees or up to half the work force.
Other analysts said that the strategy was tremendously risky.
"I worry that there will be a significant gap between the fall-off of Wang's minicomputer sales and the increase in their software business," said George Colony, an analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "I think they've traded off short-term revenue for a nice long-term strategy."
The alliance of Wang and I.B.M. is further evidence of a long-term consolidation that has been transforming the computer business for a decade. Many computer companies that had traditionally based their business on proprietary software and hardware product lines have been failing with the advent of powerful desktop computers and the shift toward open systems.
Mr. Stern of Starr Securities said Wang had been forced into a partnership with I.B.M. because it was unable to manage the transition from its traditional minicomputer base to a new business based on networks of personal computers and work stations. He said revenues had been shrinking by about 15 to 20 percent quarterly.
I.B.M. will provide initial financing of $25 million to Wang in the form of debt convertible into Wang class B common shares, representing about 3 to 4 percent of the company's class B shares outstanding. I.B.M. officials said they would also provide up to an additional $75 million in the next two and a half years.
Wang will market both I.B.M.'s RS/ 6000 work station line and its PS/2 personal computers under the Wang label. Wang will sell I.B.M.'s AS/400 minicomputer under the I.B.M. label.
 
'No Hidden Agenda'
 A number of analysts suggested that the alliance was a first step toward I.B.M.'s acquisition of Wang -- a possibility officials at both companies strongly denied.
"I.B.M.'s commitment is long-term, but this is not a merger, takeover or buyout," said Terry Lautenbach, an I.B.M. senior vice president. "There is no hidden agenda here."
But Mr. Stern said Wang had technologies -- like electronic imaging systems -- and market strength that I.B.M. might find beneficial. He said he would not rule out a deeper financial relationship.
"I.B.M. needed to figure out a way to buy Wang without getting bad press," Mr. Stern said.
Several of Wang's big customers were pleased with the alliance. "Wang has a large and loyal customer base," said a corporate manager at a large chemical company. "Wang salesmen have been fighting I.B.M. in their accounts. The integration of their products might be good for us."
In its efforts to increase its revenue in the face of industry consolidation, I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., has tried to increase the number of arrangements allowing other companies to resell its computer systems and parts like disk drives.

HEADLINE: Again, Grim Shelters House a Rising Number of Families

BYLINE: By THOMAS MORGAN

 BODY:
New York City's emergency shelter system for families is growing more crowded again, and advocates say conditions are harsher than ever.
Despite hopeful signs early last summer that the Dinkins administration might do what the Koch administration had never accomplished -- move all families out of welfare hotels and other emergency shelters and into permanent housing -- the trend now is in the other direction. 
 Last week, after months of steady increase, there were 4,566 families in the city's temporary shelter system, compared with 3,364 a year ago. At its peak in 1987 the system -- which is separate from the shelters intended for single adults -- was home to 5,200 families. The families are given emergency housing in welfare hotels, large barracks-style shelters and smaller shelters with private rooms.
Many of those entering the system these days must wait until the early morning hours for a ride to a shelter, only to have to return to a welfare office a few hours later to start the process over for the next night.
 
Barracks-Style Shelters
 The long waits are only part of the ordeal. Because the city is short of suitable accommodations, pregnant women and mothers with babies -- who are supposed to get private rooms -- are frequently being sent to large shelters where there have been outbreaks of contagious diseases, including measles. In the large barracks-style shelters, many spend days without sheets, towels, pillows or cribs.
On a recent night, a city office in Brooklyn where homeless families come to be placed in shelters was crowded with more than a dozen families, among them Kristy Morales and her 4-month-old daughter, Stephanie, who had come in at 5 P.M.
By midnight, Mrs. Morales was near tears, rocking her daughter, whispering over and over: "I'm sorry, I'm so sorry." She was not taken to a shelter to put her baby to sleep until 4 A.M.A small part of the increase in families seeking shelter, experts say, is due to the city's troubled economy which has left more families homeless.
But the bulk of the backup in the system is due to a decrease in the number of apartments the city is making available to homeless families -- the result of an early Dinkins administration initiative that seems to have backfired.
When Mayor David N. Dinkins took office, he stepped up efforts begun by the Koch administration to decrease the number of families in shelters by giving them permanent housing. The effort was spurred by the threat of a cutoff in Federal funds for long-term stays in decrepit welfare hotels.
The new effort meant some homeless families got their own apartments in three months. That success, officials say, prompted many families who had been living in overcrowded conditions -- often doubled-up with relatives or friends -- to flood into the system in hopes of getting apartments.
The Dinkins administration responded by taking 1,000 apartments originally intended for the homeless and setting them aside for families that were not homeless yet, but were living doubled-up with others.
 
Battle in the Courts
 The loss of those apartments has in turn caused a bottleneck in the emergency shelter system, officials admit. Advocates say it has also overwhelmed the city's administrative abilities.
Last month, lawyers for the Legal Aid Society filed a contempt motion in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, accusing Mayor Dinkins, Barbara J. Sabol, the city's Human Resources Administrator, and other welfare officials of failing to meet court orders mandating minimum housing standards for homeless families.
"One of the most disgraceful things about what is happening nightly," said Steven Banks, who heads the society's Homeless Family Rights Project, "is that the city seems to have given up all pretense of complying with basic court orders, let alone meeting the basic needs of families suffering greatly because of the city's indifference."
In court papers, the Homeless Family Rights Project said that from September 1990 to May of this year, at least 691 families with pregnant women or newborn infants were placed in barracks shelters in violation of the city's own policy. A hearing on the group's motion is scheduled for July 23.
City officials say they will argue that they have done their best and would like to do more. But they say the city's fiscal crisis and limited funds to develop housing and other programs restrict what can be done.
 
Noise and Frustration
 In the crowded placement office in Brooklyn where Mrs. Morales and Stephanie waited last week, an occasional name was called over the loudspeaker, breaking the din of wailing babies and arguments between frustrated mothers and welfare officials.
A guard sitting at one end of the waiting room shouted at children and adults milling about to move aside so he could see the television better. From his desk, the guard shouted other instructions to mothers across the room.
A caseworker who reeked of alcohol by 10 P.M. forgot whose name he had called on his list and made endless trips to ask mothers about details he had already gathered. One mother, frustrated that her children were playing on the floor amid debris from a dinner snack, grabbed a broom to sweep the floor while a janitor, whose job it was to clean the waiting room, watched her from across the room.
The two cribs for babies in a corner of the waiting room were constantly occupied, sometimes with two babies in each. Several mothers said they refused to use the cribs because others used them as changing tables. By midnight, the sheets were soiled. One mother used a piece of plastic to cover her baby sleeping in one crib.
 
'It's Tough Times'
 City welfare officials have said repeatedly that they are doing their best to cope with a bad situation. Larry Schatt, director of the city's Family Emergency Assistance Program, said that welfare hotels have been improved and that more than 1,000 temporary apartments and private rooms have been provided to homeless families since November.
He also said workers try to place families in emergency shelters as quickly as possible. "We have real good people in our system who are seeing people at their worst, working at night when everyone is tired and irritable," Mr. Schatt said. "The rewards are not huge. It's tough times."
He said yesterday that the city had adopted new procedures this week to shorten the time families spend waiting at night to get emergency shelter.
 
'Like I'm a Bad Mother'
 At the Brooklyn Emergency Assistance Unit last week, Mrs. Morales kept rocking baby Stephanie, with her Windex-blue eyes, whispering to her over and over, smoking cigarettes and watching the ordeals around her.
"Sometimes the caseworkers make me feel so bad, like I'm a bad mother, when I've never done drugs and I'm just having hard times right now," Mrs. Morales said.
She said she came to New York City from Syracuse last year to help take care of her husband's ill sister. When she arrived, she discovered she was pregnant and she stayed, renting rooms wherever she could. After giving birth to Stephanie, she began receiving welfare. Recently, after conjugal visits with her husband, who is in prison upstate for auto theft, she discovered she was pregnant again.
When her turn came up, one of the caseworkers asked Mrs. Morales through the window to sign a waiver so she could be placed in a barracks-style shelter without a crib for the baby -- which she did, apparently without understanding her rights or the city's legal obligations. The caseworker did not tell her that it was against court orders for the city to present such waivers, or that he had violated city policy on the matter. He also tried to talk her out of applying for shelter at all, and asked whether she had another place to sleep, Mrs. Morales said.
 
No Blankets
 "I'm from Syracuse -- I've never been through anything like this," she said later, when a Legal Aid monitor at the shelter told her she had a right to a crib and a private room because she was pregnant and had an infant.
By midnight Mrs. Morales learned she would be sent to the Bushwick Shelter at 1675 Broadway in Brooklyn for an overnight placement in a private room. Nearly two dozen families who had been told where they would be sent were still in the office; none of them left on the city's vans and buses before 2 A.M. Mrs. Morales arrived at the shelter at 4 A.M., and was placed in a room -- a former office -- without blankets, pillows, towels or diapers. She got a bed, a crib and four sheets.
Mrs. Morales got up at 7:30 to return to the office to talk to a caseworker about shelter for the next night. Instead, she was brought to the hospital, where she suffered a miscarriage later that day. A friend is taking care of Stephanie.

HEADLINE: Seidman Will Seek $80 Billion

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
The nation's senior banking regulator will call for $80 billion to keep the costly savings and loan bailout going into next year and will also seek an overhaul of the way the rescue is managed.
The proposals are to be delivered to a Congressional committee on Thursday by L. William Seidman, chairman of both the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures bank deposits, and the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is overseeing the savings and loan bailout. Mr. Seidman is facing mounting criticism, both for the costs of the savings rescue and for the increasing problems at the banks. 
 A draft of Mr. Seidman's testimony, which he sent today to the Treasury Department and described to officials and lawmakers on Capitol Hill, was obtained from a person outside the deposit insurance corporation.
 
Seeking the Offensive
 Mr. Seidman's testimony is a clear attempt to take the political offensive by suggesting change. The Administration took the unusual step last year of trying publicly to force Mr. Seidman, an independent regulator, from office. Since then, it has turned to him as it has tried to dissociate itself from blame in the growing savings and loan and bank crises.
Mr. Seidman's proposal could reopen the rift. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who is expected to ask Congress for at least $50 billion for the bailout next week, favors the present structure.
The core of Mr. Seidman's proposal is to limit sharply the deposit corporation's control over the Resolution Trust Corporation by creating a separate board for it, giving the deposit corporation only a third of the votes.
When Congress and the White House set up the trust corporation two years ago, day-to-day control was given to the deposit corporation board because of its experience in handling failed banks.
 
Delays and Second-Guessing
 But many critics and executives who have dealt with the trust corporation say bureaucratic delays and second-guessing by the deposit corporation have been at the root of Resolution Trust's problems.
Last week, the General Accounting Office said that while the trust corporation had made significant progress in setting up a system to dispose of the billions of dollars in land, securities and other assets that the Government has seized from collapsed savings and loan associations, the agency was in such disarray that auditors were unable to provide a measure of the ultimate costs of the bailout.
As a supervisor of failed banks, the deposit corporation is also facing its worst year since its creation during the Depression, with as many as 440 banks expected to fail in the next 18 months, up from an earlier estimate of 340.
Mr. Seidman, in giving the latest estimate last week, heightened fears that the fund that protects depositors might soon be forced to rely upon taxpayer assistance. On Wednesday, the House Banking Committee is scheduled to begin considering an Administration proposal that the deposit corporation borrow $70 billion. The Bush Administration insists the banks would repay the amount, $25 billion of which would come from the Treasury, over the next 10 years.
Criticism of the savings bailout is also strong outside of Washington. Last Thursday the top state bank regulator from Arizona added his voice to the chorus of complaints about the trust corporation.
The assessment by William H. Rivoir 3d, Arizona's superintendent of banks, is significant because his state ranks second only to Texas in the amount of real estate in Government hands from failed savings associations. Arizona now accounts for about $1.7 billion, or 9.6 percent of the total real estate held by the trust corporation.
"The situation is so bad that I do not exaggerate when I say that the R.T.C.'s operations here are illegal, immoral, wasteful and downright stupid," Mr. Rivoir said in a report to a regional advisory panel of officials and private-sector executives from six Southwestern states.
"Even worse, the problem lies at the very core of the R.T.C., and it will take a complete overhaul of the system to rectify it," he said.
 
A Litany of Problems
 Mr. Rivoir, a Republican appointed two and a half years ago by a Democratic governor, described a litany of bureaucratic problems, including instances in which asset managers had no understanding of the local markets, low quality appraisals making sales impossible and lawyers hired by the trust corporation who did not look at costs or consequences.
"This situation is serious," Mr. Rivoir said. "It is destroying our local real estate market, it is shrinking our property tax base, it is hindering the bonding ability of local jurisdictions, and more to the point, it is causing the R.T.C. to accomplish exactly the opposite of its stated goals, which are to manage the acquisition of assets from failed savings and loans and to dispose of those assets with the highest possible net recovery for the Government and the taxpayer."
Mr. Seidman declined comment today on Mr. Rivoir's assessment. On Wednesday, a Senate banking subcommittee will hear from private-sector critics and defenders of the trust corporation.
Although a single board runs both the deposit corporation and Resolution Trust, the savings and loan bailout is also supervised by an Oversight Board whose nucleus consists of Treasury Secretary Brady, the Housing and Urban Development Secretary, Jack F. Kemp, and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve.
 
New 9-Member Board
 Mr. Seidman's proposal would eliminate the deposit corporation as manager of the trust corporation by merging the Oversight Board and the board of Resolution Trust into a new nine-member board.
"The time has clearly passed when operational control over the R.T.C. by the F.D.I.C. board is necessary," Mr. Seidman said in the draft of his testimony. "The current structure is functioning, and the corporation is up and running. However, any system that embraces two boards creates possible confusion with regard to accountability and can make the day-to-day operations more time-consuming. More importantly, some of the circumstances that guided Congress in establishing the operating framework have changed."
Under his proposal, the President would appoint the trust corporation's chief executive. The current director, David Cooke, is a career deposit insurance official appointed to Resolution Trust by Mr. Seidman.
Mr. Seidman's plan also calls for a three-person executive committee to be formed with the chief executive, an official from the deposit insurance board and a representative of the Treasury. The committee would act on behalf of the board in emergenices or in other situations when authority is delegated.
 
Out of the Nest
 Elaborating on his testimony in an interview this afternoon, Mr. Seidman said the proposal was intended to "streamline the structure," adding, "The R.T.C. has grown up now, so it's time to kick it out of the nest,"
Mr. Seidman also said that Resolution Trust had spent $113 billion since it was created nearly two years ago, and that it expected to recover $58 billion by selling assets from failed savings associations.
Last year Mr. Brady estimated that the bailout might cost as much as $130 billion from the start of the rescue effort in 1989. The Administration stands by that estimate. In terms of present values, Mr. Seidman said that $130 billion in 1989 translates to roughly $160 billion today.

HEADLINE: 7 Industrial Nations Plan Meeting On Soviet Aid and Rise of Dollar

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The Finance Ministers and central bank presidents of the Group of Seven industrial democracies are hastily trying to arrange a meeting for this weekend, perhaps in New York, to discuss aid to the Soviet Union and what to do about the sharply rising American dollar.
A Treasury Department spokeswoman said yesterday afternoon that "active discussions" concerning such a meeting were under way, but that a final decision had not been made. The issue was not whether to hold the meeting -- that has already been decided, by all accounts -- but whether the session can be scheduled on short notice. 
 "They don't want to go to the economic summit without having some idea of what they are going to tell the Soviet Union about aid," said Stanley Fischer, former chief economist at the World Bank. Government officials offered a similar explanation, although none wanted to be quoted by name.
 
A Preparatory Meeting
 He referred to the meeting July 15 to 17 in London of the leaders of the Group of Seven: Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States. The Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, is to meet with these chiefs on the final day at the conclusion of their gathering.
To prepare for the summit, the Finance Ministers of these same countries would gather this weekend, probably in New York but perhaps London, along with each nation's central bank president. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, would represent the United States.
The Soviet aid issue is essentially the need to reach agreement on a set of conditions that the Soviet Union would have to fulfill to qualify for aid, whether it is the $20 billion a year that a group of Harvard and Soviet economists have proposed, among them Mr. Fischer, or a lesser amount.
"You have to agree on certain basic steps that the Soviets must take, like enacting a treaty of confederation and a satisfactory agreement on economic union," Mr. Fischer said.
 
The Rising Dollar
 The meeting would also prepare the way for summit discussions of another major issue: how to coordinate economic policies now that the United States recession is apparently coming to an end. The immediate issue is the dollar, now rising sharply against the German mark and the Japanese yen.
"Maybe they'll try for an agreement on a ceiling for the dollar's value," said David Smick, a Washington economic consultant.
A connected issue is how to adjust interest rates in each country to accommodate an American economy that might be coming out of recession. Lower interest rates in the United States would be one way to weaken the dollar, by making investments in dollar-denominated securities less attractive. But the Federal Reserve is not likely to reduce rates at a moment when the recession might be ending.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Comes to U.S. With Aura and New Power

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 18

 BODY:
Boris N. Yeltsin left for the United States today as the Soviet man of the hour, adorned with the mantle of the first popularly elected Russian President and champion of a rapid transition to private enterprise.
His trip, and especially the invitation to the White House, was a notable achievement for a politician who was dumped from the Soviet Communist Party Politburo by Mikhail S. Gorbachev three years earlier and snubbed by Washington two years ago. 
 Now, outside the party, Mr. Yeltsin stands almost as Mr. Gorbachev's political equal, a man both the Kremlin and the West have to reckon with.
"Russia is becoming very independent, in foreign policy as well," he declared as he prepared to board a flight that arrived in Washington hours later. "So the best thing is to hold a dialogue with both Gorbachev and Yeltsin, not only with one figure in mind."
 
A Lure to Foreign Capital
 Mr. Yeltsin said he was not going "with outstretched hands to ask for credits." He promised, over time, to create conditions in Russia that would have foreigners rushing over "with great willingness."
His mission in the United States was "to have a dialogue with politicians, to look, to study how to organize executive power, to create contacts with the White House," and to meet politicians and businessmen.
Although the trip follows Mr. Yeltsin's electoral triumph last week, it was planned some time ago when he accepted an invitation from Senate leaders for a four-day visit to Washington and New York. An invitation from President Bush to meet with him at the White House on Thursday, however, was the direct result of his victory.
But if Mr. Yeltsin's rise sometimes leads Western analysts to view him as a potential alternative for Mr. Gorbachev, his talk of "both Gorbachev and Yeltsin" was a reminder that he had fought the Soviet Government not to seize it, but to bring it to heel.
He has sought to wrest enough power from the Kremlin, the Communist Party and the military-industrial complex to enable the 15 Soviet republics to enact radical reforms and to shape a new union, in which they would delegate authority over defense, transportation and energy to Mr. Gorbachev's central Government.
His victory at the polls last week, Mr. Yeltsin said at the airport, marked three major achievements. One was the first free election of a President in Russian history, he said. The second was the triumph of democratic forces all across the Russian republic, by far the largest of the 15. "The third," he said, "is that executive power has been turned from bottom to top. The election strengthened this power."
While Mr. Yeltsin's powers remain somewhat vague and ill-defined, it was a measure of his success that as he flew off, negotiators from nine republics sent the draft of a new union treaty to their capitals for discussion, and a radical new plan for economic cooperation with the West was getting serious attention in the Kremlin.
Even more telling, perhaps, was that Mr. Yeltsin left with a public blessing from Mr. Gorbachev. The Soviet President declared through his spokesman that he had discussed the trip with Mr. Yeltsin and considered it "very useful" and a "positive process that significantly broadens the foreign policy activities of the Soviet Union."
Those were startling words from a man whose resignation Mr. Yeltsin had demanded, and who so disliked Mr. Yeltsin that he had sent 50,000 troops into Moscow streets only three months ago to try to block a pro-Yeltsin rally.
Now the two are acting in grudging concert -- not friends perhaps, but at least conscious of a mutual dependence.
 
Why Gorbachev Needs Yeltsin
 Mr. Gorbachev, preparing to go to London next month to seek help from skeptical Western leaders, was aware that he might not have been invited without the truce with Mr. Yeltsin.
Mr. Yeltsin, for his part, seemed to recognize that for all his popularity and political skill, he could not acquire enough of the levers of power to put his policies into practice single-handed. Sixty percent of the Russian republic's industry, for example, is associated with the military and so is controlled by the Kremlin.
The months of bitter feuding between the two men ended when Mr. Gorbachev joined Mr. Yeltsin and the leaders of eight other Soviet republics on April 23 to hammer out a truce in which Mr. Gorbachev acknowledged sovereign powers of the republics and they agreed to help restore economic order.
In an interview with Izvestia last month, Mr. Yeltsin cited that meeting as a victory for the democracy and workers' movements, which had answered Mr. Gorbachev's shift to the right with quickening protests.
By the time of the truce, Mr. Yeltsin said, "I think the President understood that he has to lean on his left shoulder, even if from the center, that this is how he can move forward."
From the very start, Mr. Yeltsin seemed to catch the popular imagination. In the style of Lyndon B. Johnson or Helmut Kohl, he is a rough-hewn, home-grown professional politician with a disarming earthiness and a keen sense of the streets.
While the dissident Andrei D. Sakharov achieved the status of a prophet, Mr. Yeltsin entered the popular imagination as someone many could identify with -- a Communist who conceded that he had been wrong, a man with human weaknesses, a worker who learned from life and experience and rarely made the same mistake twice.
He has been consistent, however, in badgering Mr. Gorbachev and the Communists to move faster.
"You have to see the main thing," he said to Izvestia. "Partial reforms, gradual implemented reforms -- this will destroy us. The people won't put up with this.
"When they say that it's logical to stretch reforms over years, this is not for us," he added. "That's for a society where a tolerable level of life has been achieved and where people can wait. We have such a critical situation, plus such a massive bureaucratic system, that you have to finish with them not gradually, but radically."
His demands came to include a rapid transition to a market economy and the sale of state enterprises, the right to own and farm private land, and the ouster of Communist organizations from all enterprises and bureaucracies. He championed republican sovereignty, the institution of democracy at all levels of society, and the restoration of national heritages.
It was Mr. Yeltsin's instinct and luck to be at the forefront of shifts in the fortunes of perestroika, the program of economic and political restructuring. He accused the conservatives of half-hearted reform just as the first euphoria over perestroika began to fade. He was ousted from the Politburo as Mr. Gorbachev began to lose some of his glitter.
He called for radical reform and decentralization when the momentum of change waned, he quit the Communist Party last summer at a time it was coming to be identified with the forces of reaction, and he became chairman of the Russian Parliament as republics rebelled against the Kremlin.
Thus, by the time Mr. Gorbachev shifted to the right last fall, Mr. Yeltsin stood as a beacon for the many forces that opposed the central Government.
The liberal intellectuals and economists who had argued for a rapid transition -- including Grigory Yavlinsky, the economist who has been developing a new model of Soviet-Western cooperation -- found a haven with Mr. Yeltsin. Russian patriots flocked to the leader who argued for a restoration of Russia's sovereignty. And anti-Communists cheered for the man who demanded an end to all Communist meddling.
Mr. Yeltsin, though, never forgot the people who worked for the vast apparatus in which he had worked for 20 years as a party official. He sought to attract workers in the military-industrial complex and liberal Communists, taking an Afghanistan hero who led a faction of reformist Communists as his running mate.

HEADLINE: Petrochemical Disasters Raise Alarm in Industry

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S. C., June 18

 BODY:
The blast that killed six workers at a chemical plant here on Monday was the latest in a streak of fires, explosions and poison-gas leaks at refineries and chemical plants around the nation.
Since October 1987, when a leak of hydrogen fluoride gas at a Marathon Oil refinery forced the evacuation of thousands in Texas City, Tex., the American petrochemical industry has endured one of the deadliest periods in its history, one that has baffled Government experts and alarmed company executives. The 12 worst explosions have killed 79 people, injured 933 and caused roughly $2 billion in damage. 
 In the most recent big blast before the one here Monday at the Albright & Wilson Americas plant, an explosion May 1 at the Angus Chemical Company in Sterlington, La., killed 8 workers, injured 128 workers and residents, wrecked businesses and ruined so many homes that 23 families are still living in motels.
The explosion at Albright & Wilson Americas, a subsidiary of Tenneco, occurred as workers were mixing chemicals to make a flame retardant used in textiles. Twenty-one employees and two firefighters were injured.
 
Are There Any Links?
 Oil and chemical industry executives acknowledge the recent increase in serious accidents, but they say they do not know if there is a common link. A petroleum trade group has begun a study to determine if there is a thread.
But independent safety experts and industry unions point to several trends that they say have made plants and refineries more dangerous: a growing dependence on the use of outside contractors, slipping safety standards, improper and inadequate training, flaws in engineering and design, old and deteriorating equipment, and a more aggressive drive for profits.
Gordon Strickland, assistant vice president of the Chemical Manufacturers Association, the industry's policy group in Washington, said that safety and training are improving. He denied that any of these factors were causing the rash of problems.
"The accidents that have occurred, it seems, all have different causes," he said. "The consequence is that one cannot nail it down to design or maintenance or whatever. And I don't believe that safety is anything but a first-line interest and concern in our industry."
 
The Death Rate Doubles
 An independent research group in Chicago, the National Safe Workplace Institute, said that the fatality rate from 1971, when the Occupational Safety and Health Administration was established, until the early 1980's was less than 10 a year. Over the past four years, the rate has been has been more than double that.
In 1987, according to the institute, the number of deaths and injuries in the petrochemical industry began to rise steadily. In 1989, an explosion at the Phillips Petroleum plastics plant in Pasadena, Tex., killed 23 workers. A year later, 17 workers were killed at an ARCO Chemical Company plant in Channelview, Tex. In the first six months of this year, 23 workers have died in five accidents.
The safety group based its estimate on news articles and interviews with business executives, labor groups, and Government officials.
On Monday, in the Charleston accident, 6 workers were killed and 23 injured when a chemical reactor apparently exploded without warning. Investigators from the company and the State Labor Department have not determined the cause of the explosion.
But some aspects of the explosion described today by the plant's general manager and several workers were reminiscent of previous accidents: It occurred soon after a week-long shutdown; many of the workers killed or injured were contract workers, not plant employees, and new controls were being installed.
At this stage in the investigation there is no way to know if any of these factors contributed to the accident. And there is not a Federal agency that compiles statistics and investigates every accident the way the National Transportation Safety Board does, for example, with air crashes.
Although amendments to the Clean Air Act signed into law in 1990 established a Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board, the White House has yet to appoint any members or provide funds.
The White House, in a statement, said it has not acted because of concerns over the structure of the board, how its activities will be coordinated with the Environmental Protection Agency and OSHA, and whether it will function as an independent group or under the jurisdiction of the President.
But Mr. Strickland of the chemical manufacturers group said there should be no delay: "Congress intended for the board to be established rapidly, and the events we see today suggest it should be expedited as quickly as possible."
OSHA now conducts investigations at accident sites, but its findings are often kept secret, pending the outcome of court cases involving penalties or, in rare cases, criminal charges.
 
'We Live in Toxic City'
 In the cities and towns that are host to the nation's 2,300 refineries and chemical processing plants, more and more workers and residents are asking whether the disasters are a coincidence, or an urgent signal.
"We live in toxic city, and it is very scary," said Bebe Lising, 39, a resident of Texas City and chairwoman of the Galveston-area chapter of the Sierra Club. "People have been kept so in the dark, and a lot of jobs are dependent on the industry. Our local health department is understaffed, and the plants monitor themselves."
Labor Department reviews show that the rate of injuries in refining and chemical plants is half the national rate for all manufacturing industries and has been declining. But the statistics do not take into account deaths and injuries suffered by employees of engineering and construction companies that work under contract.
Contract workers, whose numbers are rising in chemical and refining plants, are generally paid less and perform more dangerous duties than full-time workers. Mistakes by these workers have been linked to many of the most serious accidents, including a disaster in October 1989 at the Phillips Petroleum plant near Houston that killed 23 workers and injured 232 people.
A study commissioned by OSHA determined last year that contract workers had much higher turnover rates than regular employees, received far less training and were much less aware of safety procedures in the event of an accident. The study, by the John Grey Institute of Lamar University in Texas, found that contract laborers were "routinely instructed to run in the event of an emergency," leaving regular employees to fight fires and shut down pumps and pipelines.
OSHA, a unit of the Department of Labor, is proposing a rule to require companies to give more training to contract workers. The American Petroleum Institute, the oil industry's principal trade group, has urged the Department of Labor to change its practices and report injury and accident statistics for all employees plant by plant.
Six months ago, the Petroleum Institute also started a study to see if any of the accidents had common characteristics. The study may be completed before the end of the year.
"There is great attention given to safety," said Charles Thomas Sawyer, vice president of industry affairs at the Petroleum Institute. "Is there a common reason for all of these accidents? I don't know the answer to that right now."
Last year, Congress directed OSHA and the E.P.A. to require companies to conduct studies of the potential castastrophic hazards of their plants and to submit plans for preventing accidents.
OSHA has almost finished its regulations. The E.P.A. has until 1993 to finish its regulations, which are aimed at modernizing equipment and improving manufacturing. Next month, the E.P.A. is scheduled to meet with state officials from New Jersey and California, the first states to establish rules for preventing chemical disasters.
The operating weaknesses in the petrochemical industry, say independent experts, may be the result of the aggressive cost cutting prompted by the corporate takeovers and mergers of the 1980's. To protect themselves from takeovers, or to finance the mergers, oil and chemical companies greatly increased production even as they cut costs and staff.
 
Job Totals Are Slashed
 More than 40,000 jobs have been cut in the refinery industry since 1982, according to the Petroleum Institute, leaving about 115,000 refinery workers. About 30,000 hourly jobs were lost in the chemical industry, according to the Oil, Chemical, and Atomic Workers International Union. Phillips Petroleum employed 30,000 people before it came under attack by T. Boone Pickens in the mid-1980's. By October 1989, when its chemical complex near Houston exploded, it employed 22,000.
"No sector of the economy was affected more by the raiders than the oil and chemical industry," said Joseph A. Kinney, director of the National Safe Workplace Institute. "Workers are paying for it with their blood."
Industry executives say cutting costs has not affected safety. But OSHA is studying operations at 25 plants across the Gulf Coast, the East and the Midwest to determine whether that is so.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The American petrochemical industry is enduring one of the deadliest periods in its history. Eight workers were killed and 128 people injured on May 1 in an explosion at the Angus Chemical plant in Sterlington, La. (Margaret Croft/News-Star)
 
Table/Chronology: "Deadly Blasts, Toxic Clouds" describes the 14 most serious chemical and refining accidents in the U.S., 1987-1991
 
1. Texas City, Tex. Oct. 30, 1987
 
A worker operating a crane at Marathon Oil's Texas City refinery dropped a heater on a storage tank, causing a rupture that released 30,000 pounds of hydrogen fluoride gas. Three thousand resident were evacuated for three days, and 800 people were treated for breathing disorders and skin problems.
 
2. Pampa, Tex. Nov. 14, 1987
 
Butane and acetic acid leaked from a ruptured tank, forming a vast cloud of vapor that caught fire and exploded, destroying the Hoechst Celanese chemical plant, killing 3 workers and injuring 35 people. Economic loss, including property damage, lost production, legal expenses and fines; $241 million.
 
3. Henderson, Nev. May 4, 1988
 
Fire and explosion destroyed a Pacific Engineering and Production Company plant that manufactured ammonium perchlorate, a component of rocket fuel. Two employees, including the plant manager, were killed, 350 people were injured. 17,000 people were evacuated from their homes, and property damage was found 12 miles from the plant. Economic loss: $75 million.
 
4. Norco, La. May 5, 1988
 
An eight-inch pipe ruptured at a Shell Oil refinery, releasing a vapor cloud that ignited and exploded, killing 7 workers, injuring 42 and causing property damages that resulted in 5,200 claims. Economic loss: $327 million.
 
5. Pasadena, Tex. Oct. 23, 1989
 
A valve on a polyethylene reactor was left open at a Phillips Petroleum plastics plant, venting gases that caught fire and exploded with a force of 20,000 pounds of TNT. Twenty-three workerd died, 232 people were injured, and the plant was destroyed. Economic loss: $750 million to $1 billion.
 
6. Baton Rouge, La. Dec. 24, 1989
 
A pipeline operating at high pressure ruptured at the Exxon U.S.A. refinery, releasing a cloud of ethane and propane that exploded, killing two workers, injring seven and causing property damage up to six miles away. Economic loss: $44.7 million.
 
7. Channelview, Tex. July 5, 1990
 
An explosion in a compressor at a plant belonging to a chemical company owned by Atlantic Richfield killed 17 workers. Economic loss: $90 million.
 
8. Cincinnati: July 19, 1990
 
A fire and explosion at the BASF coatings and ink plant resulted from the cleaning of a chemical reactor vessel with volatile solvents. Two workers died, 80 people were injured, much of the plant was destroyed and 162 buildings were damaged. Economic loss: Company will not reveal.
 
9. Lake Charles, La. March 3, 1991
 
A fire and explosion killed 6 workers, injured 12, and caused extensive damage at the Citgo Petroleum refinery. Economic loss; Company will not reveal.
 
10. Corpus Christi, Tex. March 6, 1991
 
Two workers died and five were injured when hydrofluoric acid vapors escaped from a gasoline blending unit at the Kerr-McGee Corporation's Southwestern Refinery. Economic loss: Company will not reveal.
 
11. Port Lavaca, Tex. March 12, 1991
 
An explosion in the ethylene oxide unit of Union Carbide's Seadrift plant kills 1 and injures 19. Economic loss: $50 million to $75 million.
 
12. Sterlington, La. May 1, 1991
 
A fire in or near a compressor detonated nitro methane at the Angus Chemical Company plant, killing 8 workers, injruing 128 workers and resident, destroying much of the town's main business district and leaving 30 families temporarily homeless. Economic loss: more than $110 million.
 
13. Henderson, Nev. May 6, 1991
 
A pipe from a storage tank at the Pioneer Chior Alokali plant leaded thousands of gallons of liquid chlorine in the middle of the night, causing evacuations, shutting down the city, sending 55 people to hospitals for treatment of injuries, mostly breathing problems.
 
14. Charleston, S.C. June 17, 1991
 
An explosion and fire at the Albright & Wilson Americas chemical plant killed 6 workers and injured 23 others including 2 firefighters. The accident occured one day after a week-long shutdown. Economic loss: still to be determined by the company.

HEADLINE: Notaries Certify That Inflation Has Arrived

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 18

 BODY:
The 30-year wait is over. Alfred E. Piombino and the 244,383 men and women represented by the New York State Association of Notaries Public -- of which he is president -- are finally getting some justice.
Since 1961, the state's notaries public have been allowed to charge no more than 25 cents every time they certify a deed, deposition, affidavit, contract or complaint. That is the lowest fee, along with those in Iowa and Massachusetts, of any state in the nation. 
 "It's an insult," said Mr. Piombino. "It's an injustice." But now, it is about to become history.
Under a measure passed by state lawmakers (many of whom are notaries public) and signed into law recently by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo (also a notary public), notaries can soon begin charging $2.
That is not exactly a huge amount and many notaries, including Mr. Cuomo, say they intend to keep right on with their present practice of not charging anything at all. That partly explains why legislation increasing the fees never seems to have become a burning issue here.
Still, to Mr. Piombino and many other notaries who have been crusading for the bill, its passage at least indicates a renewed measure of esteem for the notary's calling.
 
'A Bit More Dignity'
 "There's a respect factor involved here," said Mr. Piombino, a notary law consultant by profession. "Suppose right now you bring me a document and I say to you, 'That will be a quarter,' it sounds kind of absurd. To say, 'Two dollars,' that has a bit more dignity to it."
The state's notary fees have always seemed immune from inflation. Prior to 1961, the last time the Legislature raised the top price of a notary's seal was in 1907, when notaries were allowed to earn 6 cents for swearing a witness and 12 cents for taking an affidavit. For certain more complex duties, the notary could make a quarter, a respectable sum in those days.
With the latest jump in notary fees, even those who plan to continue notarizing without charge, as a matter of public service, seem to appreciate the new law.
 
Matter of Convenience
 "Our personal policy is that to charge a quarter is so ridiculous that we don't charge anything," said Richard Clark, the manager of the Tebbutt Funeral Home in Albany. "So now it's two dollars, we still won't charge anything. But at least it sounds like a more reasonable fee."
For many notaries like Mr. Clark, who said he hopes that "people will remember we did something nice for them some day," the chief attraction to being a notary seems to be that the service can draw customers into their place of business. Many pharmacists, as well as a few barbers and newsstand dealers, are notaries, for instance.
And for lawyers and bankers, who routinely deal with documents like mortgages and deeds that require notarization, being able to provide the notary stamp is a matter of convenience.
Still, the potential for making money is not inconsiderable, particularly with the eight-fold increase in fees that goes into effect July 24.
There are millions and millions of documents notarized in New York and around the nation each year, but nobody is able to keep an exact count.
"Some notaries notarize several times a day," said Eugene E. Hines, the executive director of the American Society of Notaries, a Washington group that represents the country's 4 million notaries public.
 
Exam Required
 "But a lot only do it once every two or three months," he continued. "I would guess the average for all notaries is probably about once a week, but that's only a wild guess."
The requirements -- and the fees -- for becoming a notary public vary considerably from state to state. One of the things that irks Mr. Piombino and other New York notaries is that even as New York has the lowest allowable fees, it has some of the strictest standards.
It is one of only a handful of states, for instance, that require aspiring notaries to take a written examination. And it charges $30 for a two-year term of office, while most other states charge less than that for longer terms.
Other states place far less rigorous standards on their notaries. An official with the National Notary Association, the other principal group representing notaries, said last year that "in some states, if somebody puts a mirror in front of your mouth and it fogs up, you can become a notary."
In Michigan, where the main requirement is a written application and state residency, more than 100 state prisoners became notaries last year. ("Mainly for the prestige," said Mr. Hines at the American Society of Notaries. "There isn't much to notarize in prison.")
While there are virtually no full-time notaries anywhere, the job does seem to carry a higher degree of prestige in other states than in New York, Mr. Piombino said. For instance, he pointed out, three states -- Maine, Florida and South Carolina -- allow their notaries to perform marriages.
And even with the new law here authorizing the $2 fees, New York's notaries still trail well behind many of their brethren elsewhere in what they can charge for their services. California and Texas both allow notaries to collect $5 fees, and Florida recently passed a law allowing $10 charges. Some states, including Maine and Vermont, put no limit at all on what notaries can charge.

HEADLINE: BIG INSURER OFFERS POLICIES TO COVER MEDICAL SCREENING

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
In a departure from longstanding practice in the health insurance industry, which has emphasized the treatment and cure of disease without paying for much preventive care, Blue Cross and Blue Shield offered today to provide insurance for periodic tests to detect medical problems in people with no symptoms of an ailment.
The Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association issued guidelines for a lifetime schedule of medical tests to detect adult diseases, including cancer and heart disease, and said it would offer coverage for these services. The United States Public Health Service expressed support for the guidelines, giving insurers an additional incentive to adopt them. 
 Other private insurers have expressed a willingness to cover preventive services and are expected to use the guidelines.
 
An Economic Investment
 The screening tests would add to overall national spending on health care at a time when the soaring costs of medicine have prompted a flurry of proposals in Congress for fundamental change in the nation's health-care system. But the concern about cost usually focuses on exotic high-technology procedures, not on simple screening tests, and Blue Cross officials described the coverage of preventive care as an investment that would yield economic gains, including higher productivity for workers.
The new coverage is envisioned as an optional addition to existing policies. Blue Cross said it could cover the costs of insurance for preventive and screening services by charging additional premiums of about $90 a year for a family and $36 a year for an individual.
 
Growing Public Demand
 The guidelines come in response to a nationwide consensus of health policy experts that insurers should cover more preventive services. That idea is backed not only by the Public Health Service but by the 70,000-member American College of Physicians. The college developed the guidelines over several years in cooperation with the Blue Cross and Blue Shield system, which is the nation's largest private health insurer, covering 73 million Americans.
Health economists suggested that Blue Cross was also motivated by a sense of enlightened self-interest, because there appears to be a growing demand among employers and consumers for insurance to cover screening and preventive care, including health education and counseling to stop smoking.
The screening schedule specifies who should be tested when for high blood pressure, heart disease, cholesterol, diabetes, thyroid problems, osteoporosis and cancers of the breast, colon, cervix and lung.
Equally important, the guidelines say certain techniques, like exercise stress testing and tests for thyroid disease, are not recommended as routine screening procedures for people with no symptoms.
Dr. Paul F. Griner, chairman of the board of regents of the American College of Physicians, said that screening -- the search for specific health problems in a person who has no known signs or symptoms -- "has enormous medical value in finding disease early, when it can be treated most successfully and most economically."
In the last year, many private insurers have quietly cut back coverage of small groups of beneficiaries on which they say they have lost money. But Pam Kelch, a spokeswoman for Blue Cross and Blue Shield, said the medical tests included in the new benefits package would not be used to screen out people found to have costly diseases or a high risk of developing such illneses.
Bernard R. Tresnowski, president of Blue Cross and Blue Shield, said the group's 73 local plans around the country could offer coverage of the recommended screening tests for "a nominal amount," about $7.50 a month for a family whose insurance coverage now typically costs $200 to $300 a month. The Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans often charge a standard premium for family coverage, regardless of the number in the family.
Dr. David M. Eddy, professor of health policy management at Duke University, who edited the guidelines, estimated that national spending on health care would increase by $2 billion to $3 billion a year if all adults complied with the screening recommendations.
 
'Improved Productivity'
 But Dr. Griner said the extra spending would result in "improved productivity of employees, greater longevity and improved quality of life" for millions of people. Americans spend more than $660 billion a year on health care, and the amount has doubled in the last eight years.
The guidelines are not rigid standards, but doctors who ignore them could expose themselves to an increased risk of lawsuits for failure to detect cancer or other diseases.
Dr. Griner, who is also the chief executive officer of Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester, said that 80 percent of the women who should be getting routine mammography were not.
To detect breast cancer, the guidelines say that women 40 years old and over should receive an annual examination of the breasts by a doctor or a specially trained nurse. In addition, the guidelines recommend annual mammography for women 40 and older who have a personal history of breast cancer or have a sister or mother with the disease. For women with no such history or risk, the guidelines call for annual mammograms starting at age 50.
Under the model benefit package for preventive services, Blue Cross would not pay for routine physical examinations, but would cover many procedures commonly performed in such examinations.
 
Health Official Hails Plan
 The 73 independent nonprofit Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans will be strongly encouraged but not required to offer the additional coverage to groups of subscribers, who would also have the option of taking it. The plans operate 89 health maintenance organizations providing care for 4.6 million people. Routine exams and screening tests are already included in the services of such prepaid group plans. The new coverage is being offered to people who receive health care through traditional fee-for-service arrangements.
Joel E. Miller, director of professional services for the Health Insurance Association of America, which represents more than 300 commercial insurers, said some of them were beginning to offer similar benefits. But he said: "Major employers call the shots. They decide what benefits to include in their health insurance packages. There needs to be a marketing and education campaign to convince employers that these benefits should be included."
Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly, is slowly adding coverage for a few selected screening tests, like mammograms. Medicaid, the Federal-state program for poor people, already covers screening for many children and coverage of other services generally depends on state decisions.
Dr. J. Michael McGinnis, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, hailed today's announcement by Blue Cross and the College of Physicians. "Historically, lack of financing has been a barrier to the delivery of clinical preventive services," he said. "A recent survey of insurance coverage for preventive services revealed that overall only 41 percent of insured adults were covered for preventive exams, and only 69 percent of preventive diagnostic tests were covered by these insurance policies."
The guidelines address these diseases, among others:
*Cervical cancer. A Pap smear is recommended every three years, beginning at the age of 20, for women who have an average risk of cervical cancer, and every one to two years for women at high risk.
*Colon-rectal cancer. Annual screening for blood in the stool is recommended for people 50 and older. Examination of the colon with a fiberoptic tube known as a sigmoidoscope is recommended every three to five years for people 50 and older.
*Coronary artery disease. Cholesterol tests are recommended at least once in early adulthood and then at intervals of about five years.
*High blood pressure. Screening is recommended every one or two years for adults with blood pressure below 140/85. People with higher blood pressure should be checked annually.
Dr. McGinnis said that the development of a model package of benefits by Blue Cross was a significant step, but only a beginning.

HEADLINE: Construction Of Homes Up 0.1% in May

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
Construction of new homes and apartments inched up by a tenth of a percent in May, the Commerce Department said today in a report that supported forecasts by analysts of a slower-than-normal housing recovery.
"We're not expecting an increase in housing starts at the torrid pace of past recoveries," said Richard Peach, an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association. 
 David F. Seiders, chief economist with the National Association of Home Builders, concurred, saying, "We're moving along at a subpar recovery pace."
 
Comments by Greenspan
 Release of the home-building figures coincided with comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, who testified before the House Ways and Means Committee, where he said the United States economy appeared to have bottomed out but showed no signs of recovering from the recession.
The Commerce Department said housing starts totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 982,000, up from a revised 981,000 in April and 907,000 in March.
But despite the sluggish pace, the increase was the first back-to-back advance since June and July 1989 and the third gain since starts plunged to 847,000 units in January.
 
Lowest Since January 1982
 The January level was the lowest since an 843,000 rate in January 1982, in the midst of the previous recession. Analysts said it represented the bottom of the current housing downturn.
The 8.2 percent gain in April was even stronger than the 6.2 percent originally reported. But the 8.6 percent decline in March was not as steep as the 9.2 percent first reported.
But the May activity was concentrated in single-family construction. New construction of single-family homes rose 3.1 percent, to an 832,000 annual rate, after a 8.8 percent jump a month earlier, the Commerce Department said.
Multifamily starts, on the other hand, fell 13.8 percent, to a 150,000 rate. Starts of buildings with five units or more plunged 16.3 percent, to a 118,000 level, the lowest since record-keeping began in 1963.
 
Fourth Consecutive Rise
 Applications for building permits rose 7.2 percent, to a 979,000 annual rate. It was the fourth consecutive monthly increase in permits and the longest string since a similar stretch from April through July 1983 following the previous recession.
The rise in starts has also been accompanied by an increase in new-home sales since January. Inventories of unsold homes fell to a 7.4-month supply in April from a 9.3-month backlog in January.
Starts soared 17.7 percent in the Northeast after falling 7.7 percent in April. They were up 14 percent in the West, where new construction rose 33.7 percent the previous month. However, starts fell 8.8 percent in the Midwest, wiping out a 5.3 percent April gain. And they tumbled 7.6 percent in the South, where they rose 1.8 percent a month earlier.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Housing Construction" shows new private housing started and permits authorized during the month, in millions, at seasonally adjusted annual rates, from Dec. '90-May '91. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Said to Offer to Back Israel With Veto in U.N.

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has assured Israel that the United States would veto any United Nations Security Council resolution affecting the Middle Eastern peace process as long as peace talks were under way, people close to efforts to convene such talks say.
The proposal is aimed at breaking the deadlock over efforts to convene an international peace conference on the Middle East. It was made in a letter to the Israeli Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, which was given to the Israeli Foreign Minister, David Levy. 
 Mr. Levy has just completed a five-day trip to the United States during which he met with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and leaders of American Jewish organizations.
A senior Administration official said the "bottom line" was that Mr. Baker would not take Israel's objections to an international conference as a definitive "no" to American-led efforts to settle the Arab-Israeli conflict by convening such a conference.
According to published reports, Mr. Shamir has ruled out a United Nations role in the peace talks. He has also insisted on Israel's right to veto proposed members of a Jordanian-Palestinian negotiating team. The latest American proposal is intended to help overcome Israel's unwillingness to permit even a symbolic role at any peace talks by the United Nations, which Israel views as hostile to its interests.
In a meeting on Thursday with leaders of prominent American Jewish organizations, Mr. Baker gave a detailed presentation of the status of his discussions with Israel and the Arab countries. Participants said he told them the Administration was awaiting a reply from Syria to a letter from President Bush asking it for concessions. But officials said Saudi Arabia and Egypt had assured the Administration that the Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad, was willing "to be flexible" if Israel would take part in peace talks.
Dennis Ross, a senior aide to Mr. Baker, was quoted by one participant as having told the gathering that considerable progress had been made in efforts to convene a conference. Specifically, he was said to have cited an agreement by Saudi Arabia to meet directly with Israel in multilateral talks about issues affecting the region -- environment, water resources, arms control and economic development.
Henry Siegman, executive director of the American Jewish Congress, who attended the meeting, said Prince Bandar bin Sultan, Saudi Arabia's representative at the United Nations, had assured him that if a peace process got under way, Saudi Arabia would participate directly in multilateral talks about such problems of regional concern as shipping and pollution.
 
Role for P.L.O. Ruled Out
 Participants in the meeting with Mr. Baker said all parties to efforts to convene a peace conference had agreed that the Palestine Liberation Organization would not be present directly or indirectly at the talks and that the United States would not consult with it directly or indirectly. All sides were also said to have agreed that Palestinian members of a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation could not be connected to the P.L.O., that they would not raise anything other than interim arrangements for the occupied territories and that they must be willing to agree to live in peace with Israel and to renounce war and terrorism.
The American proposal calls for a three-stage conference: first, a ceremonial opening session attended directly by Israel and its Arab neighbors and indirectly by Saudi Arabia and the other Persian Gulf states through a representative of a gulf defense and assistance group; a second phase, following almost immediately, of bilateral talks between Israel and its neighbors to discuss borders and peace, and a third stage, consisting of a multilateral conference on regional problems attended directly by Arab countries, including Saudi Arabia and Israel.

HEADLINE: Filipinos, Assessing Cost, Begin Volcano Cleanup

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, June 18

 BODY:
Cities and villages across thousands of square miles of the Philippines began today to dig out from a thick blanket of volcanic ash released in a week of eruptions by Mount Pinatubo.
The nearly 300,000 residents of Olongapo, a city adjoining the United States Navy base at Subic Bay, continued to be plagued by food and water shortages resulting from the eruptions, and there were reports of looting. 
 In Manila, 50 miles southeast of the volcano, swirling clouds of the talc-like ash filled the air. Volcanic ash was reported to have fallen as far away as Singapore, 1,500 miles to the southwest.
The death toll from the eruption rose today to at least 140, as more bodies were discovered. But the volcano remained relatively quiet, with a few minor earth tremors and a small eruption that dumped more ash on Clark Air Base, 10 miles east of the crater.
Street vendors made quick money today by offering cloth surgical masks -- about 10 pesos, or 35 cents, each -- to Manila residents who preferred not to breathe the fine powder that was coating their cars and houses.
Farmers arriving at Manila evacuation centers from Zambales province, west of Mount Pinatubo, said their crops were buried under as much as three feet of ash and volcanic rock.
"There is nothing left," said Leonardo Mercado, 47 years old, who has a small farm near the city of Castillejos. "It is all ash and sand now. The roof of my house collapsed from all the ash."
 
Long Trek to Safety
 Mr. Mercado said that he and his family walked nearly 15 miles through ankle-deep ash to the city of Olongapo, where they boarded an evacuation bus to Manila.
At Subic Bay, officials said it could be two months or more before full electricity and water services were restored to the sprawling naval base. "From all the ash, it looks like a moonscape up here," said Lieut. Comdr. Kevin Mukri, a spokesman at the American-leased naval base.
Rescue workers said the momentous task of cleaning away the volcanic deposits had begun in earnest today in several communities on the main island of Luzon.
"People were just too stunned at first to think about a cleanup," said Frances Magdara, a rescue worker in the city of Angeles, next to Clark. "Now people are accepting what has happened. They can begin to put their lives together."
Philippine officials and Western diplomats said the cost of damage wrought by Mount Pinatubo would total hundreds of millions of dollars. The director of the National Economic and Development Authority, Cayetano Paderanga, said in an interview that the principal damage had been to crops. However, agriculture in the volcano region is only about 4 percent of the nation's total output.
Western diplomats said they believed that the chief economic harm might be a lessening of confidence by potential foreign investors.
"It's one more thing telling an investor to be wary," a diplomat said. "There are so many other problems with the Philippine economy. The volcano is just one more problem among many."
Reuters reported today that the main water supply in Olangapo had run out or was contaminated by ash, and residents were breaking pipes to drain off what little water remained.
