HEADLINE: Learning in the Real World of a Boston School

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOWELL, Mass., June 13

 BODY:
After testimony and deliberation by a jury of his peers, Miguel Rivera stood tugging at his T-shirt, intently awaiting a verdict.
"Your honor, the jury finds the defendant, Miguel Rivera, guilty as charged," the jury foreman told the judge as she pushed aside her ponytail. Miguel glanced at his 12-year-old lawyer, Mark Lynch, with a look of dismay. 
 His offense: Choking another second grader on the playground. His defense: The boy called him a bad name. His sentence: A small fine and two days without recess.
Here at the Clement G. McDonough City Magnet School in Lowell, Mass., the cradle of this country's Industrial Revolution, students are taking part in a small revolution in education.
City Magnet, the nation's first school intended as a microcosm of society, not only has its own court system, but also a representative government and a market economy. Students work as judges, lawyers, editors, bankers and entrepreneurs; they pay rent on their desks and taxes on their salaries. They also buy and sell goods using paper currency called "mogans," named for a former Lowell superintendent, Patrick Mogan.
 
Work Is Made Relevant
 While they teach basic subjects like mathematics, literature and history using traditional texts, teachers also strive to make the work relevant. Adding and subtracting are used to balance bank statements. Instead of book reports, students write book reviews for the school newspaper. While programming computers, students learn lessons in geology.
In a 70-minute activity period at the end of the day, students either do assigned jobs or take part in running businesses or serving in the elected legislature.
"We have regular classes, but they are modeled to mirror outside society," Sue Ellen Hogan, the school's principal, said in a recent interview. "The activity period is to give them hands-on reinforcement."
Students in kindergarten through second grade receive a small salary in mogans for doing their homework and being good school citizens. Beginning in the third grade they are also given jobs and paid bigger salaries.
"Even if kids make it through high school, many of them don't come out with the kind of survival skills they need to make it in the outside world," said Theresa Roach, who teaches government and oversees the court at City Magnet. "This school gives them those skills."
 
Helped Desegregate Schools
 Opened in 1981 in response to a court order to desegregate, City Magnet is based on the ideas of George Richmond, a former Brooklyn public school teacher who first tried the concept and then wrote a book about it, "The Micro-Society School: A Real World in Miniature" (Harper & Row, 1974).
City Magnet has helped desegregate the schools in this working-class city, where 42 percent of the school's 330 students are from minority groups. More than half of the students are poor enough to qualify for free lunches.
Now in its 10th year, the school is also proving a model for educational change and success. Although many parents were initially skeptical, they have seen students' grades and attendance levels rise. There are fewer discipline problems. And, according to school officials, the number of parents waiting to get their children into the program is now the highest of any of the 28 schools in Lowell.
"You're lucky because your school is different," Lee A. Iacocca, chairman and chief executive officer of the Chrysler Corporation, told the eighth-graders at their graduation exercise Thursday night. "It has taught you more than just how to read and write and count. It has taught you about the real world, about the things you have to do in the real world, about how you have to accept responsibility, how you have to work together, and how to discover what you're good at and what you like to do."
Mr. Iacocca invited himself to the commencement after seeing a Public Broadcasting Service television documentary, sponsored by Chrysler, that featured the school.
City Magnet has served as a prototype for an elementary micro-society school in Yonkers, and several other communities are considering the concept.
At the Eugenio Hastos de Maria Micro-Society School, also known as Public School 19, in Yonkers, the program has brought major improvements. In 1987, when the micro-society school was first introduced, only one in four pupils was reading at grade level. Last year, tests showed that half the school's pupils were reading at grade level.
 
Changing School Makeup
 When the program was introduced, more than 90 percent of the pupils were Hispanic or black pupils; this fall, one-third will be white children whose families requested the micro-society magnet school.
"We think this is going to be one of our best elementary schools," said Donald M. Batista, the Yonkers superintendent. "We think micro-society is an extremely effective way to teach our youngsters, especially because we have so many children from other countries. This program helps them learn how to function in a strange society."
The Yonkers program, which is bilingual, also includes regular school visits from local officials and parents, who serve as role models for the students, Dr. Batista said.
Some students say they get tired of the micro-society activities after a few years and that students who are shy do not always fare well. But most teachers and students in Yonkers and in Lowell give the program high marks. It helps the students understand difficult concepts and builds confidence as well, they say.
"When I teach about the Great Depression, I talk to my students about how a depression would happen in their micro-society," Mrs. Roach said. "It's too hard a concept for their little minds to understand otherwise. But when I talk to them about it in micro, all of the little lights go on. They totally see it."
 
'You Learn About Everything'
 Amy Carrington, 13 years old, an 'A' student who left parochial school three years ago to come to City Magnet, agreed. "At my other school, it was really boring because they'd just give you a book," she said. "Here, you learn about everything."
What does she know now that her friends at other schools don't? "They know how to add and multiply and stuff," she said. "But I also know how to handle a bank book and a checkbook. I know how to fill out a tax form. They know how to write essays and reports. I also know how to write newspaper articles, from hard news to editorials.
 
Missing Link in High School
 "My dad works at a high-tech place, and he doesn't know half the stuff I know about newspapers and laws and computers," she added.
But an uncomfortable challenge for Amy may come next year when she enters Lowell High School. The transition from a micro-society school to normal teaching programs can be "very, very difficult," said Dr. Hogan, the City Magnet principal, not because the students cannot do traditional schoolwork but because they miss the attention, independence and responsibility they had in the micro-society school.
George Tsapatsaris, the Lowell schools superintendent, is trying to start a micro-society component at the high school. But Mr. Tsapatsaris must also watch the budget. The micro-society program, because of the requisite teacher preparation and supplies, costs about $50,000 a year more than is allotted by city and state budgets, Mr. Tsapatsaris said.
To date, Federal grants have made up for most of City Magnet's overrun, but the poor local economy has already forced the city to cut the school's supplies budget by 20 percent for next year.
"Even without the extra money, we would try to make this program work," the superintendent said. "The express purpose of this program has been to help all school kids succeed, and we believe the micro-society is doing that."

HEADLINE: SOVIET AID PLANS OUTLINED BY BAKER

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, June 18

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d outlined a series of proposals today under which the United States and its allies could begin to help the Soviet Union out of its economic morass without the infusion of vast amounts of cash.
Although Mr. Baker did not explicitly rule out the large-scale cash aid sought by Moscow, his remarks suggested that the Administration would lobby with its Western allies not to rush into cash aid programs. 
 He included such proposals as support for Soviet associate membership in the International Monetary Fund, a program for encouraging American oil exploration in the Soviet Union and assistance in food distribution there. Mr. Baker's outline was part of a speech on European policy that he gave at the Aspen Institute in Berlin.
The question of how to help the Soviet Union has become acute because President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has been invited to meet with the leaders of the Group of Seven industrial democracies in London next month after their annual meeting is over. The allies are trying to come up with a consensus on dealing with Mr. Gorbachev.
The Secretary urged the peoples of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union to join the "Atlantic Community," which used to be thought of as embracing just the United States, Canada and Western Europe. But to do so, Mr. Baker argued, the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe must first adopt systems of democratic pluralism and market economics.
He said that the United States "has a special role to play in supporting the process of change in the Soviet Union."
"As the Soviets demonstrate the will to help themselves, then we can and should join them, step by step," Mr. Baker said. "I hope President Gorbachev now brings forward a new effort at serious market reform. The door to the Euro-Atlantic community is open. But only the Soviets can decide to step over the threshold."
The notion of step-by-step assistance has become the byword of the Bush Administration when discussing economic aid to Moscow. It is in contrast to the notion of a "grand bargain" in which the West would commit a vast sum of money in return for, and to help cushion, specific Soviet economic and democratic reforms.
Last weekend, Grigory A. Yavlinsky, an independent Soviet economist who has been working with a group of Harvard University economists, presented a "grand bargain" plan to the Bush Administration and Mr. Gorbachev. Mr. Gorbachev was reported to have shown some interest in the plan, but Administration officials have not demonstrated much enthusiasm.
 
Alternative to 'Grand Bargain'
 The Administration, apparently feeling that if it does not like the grand bargain it had better come up with an alternative approach, began hinting a few weeks ago that it was developing a package of step-by-step "supportive measures" for the Soviet reform effort, but did not spell them out.
While saying today that the "complete package is for our President to announce," Mr. Baker nevertheless listed the key elements of what would be Washington's first steps in response to serious steps by the Soviets toward market reforms.
The ideas have all been proposed individually but are now being tied together in a package that is likely to be presented to Mr. Gorbachev.
"As we have pointed out in recent weeks," said Mr. Baker, "elements could include a special association with the I.M.F. and the World Bank to help design and implement serious economic reforms; a public-private project to resolve impediments to private investment in energy development, which can earn hard currency and provide an example of a successful sector operating with property and contract rights; a mutual effort to invigorate the food distribution sector to produce improvements for consumers soon through the establishment of market incentives."
He added that Washington was ready to support the conversion of Soviet defense industries to consumer and other nonmilitary production, would provide technical advice to promote education in market principles and practices and would advance more open trade -- an apparent reference to the impending decision to grant Moscow preferential trade benefits. Mr. Baker also listed in the package the $1.5 billion in additional credits to purchase American grain that President Bush granted the Soviet Union last week.
The rationale underlying virtually all of the Administration's proposals is that the Soviet Union is rich in natural resources and the educational development of its people, and that if it can establish the proper market incentives and inducements to foreign investment it will not need infusions of other governments' cash.
Mr. Baker argued that institutions like NATO, the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe and the European Community had to be used to help the eastern nations make the transition from Communism to democracy, so they would not fall prey to the sort of ethnic and nationalist fragmentation now racking Yugoslavia.
Mr. Baker did not offer much in the way of concrete new proposals. Rather, he attempted to show how many existing programs of NATO, the conference and the community could be used to extend democratic, free-market and federalist principles to the East.
 
Nationalism vs. Interdependence
 A way has to be found, Mr. Baker said, to balance the increasing demands of individuals in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union to express their long-suppressed ethnic and national identities and the demands of an increasingly economically interdependent world, which requires integration with multinational and suprana tional economic institutions.
The 12-nation European Community, said Mr. Baker, has to continue removing economic barriers to Eastern European exports and expand its association agreements with Eastern European nations. As for the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, the Secretary proposed that it establish new agencies to promote market economics and private business among its membership, which includes all of Europe except Albania. He also suggested that the conference might develop a peacekeeping force to help defuse ethnic, national and border disputes when requested.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Arrives in Washington With Conciliatory Words About Gorbachev

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
Fresh from his impressive victory as the first popularly elected president of the Russian republic, Boris N. Yeltsin arrived here today and sounded a conciliatory note about his political rival, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Speaking at a hot and crowded reception at the Soviet Embassy tonight, Mr. Yeltsin said that "the fact that the people of Russia have had an opportunity to elect directly and for the first time ever by popular vote a President is first of all due to the initiative of the pro-democracy movement launched by President Gorbachev in 1985." 
 "Many men and women indeed doubted that our people were ready for that kind of change," he said.
Rejecting any idea that he or his country were supplicants for Western aid, Mr. Yeltsin said the first question he was asked when he arrived in Washington this afternoon, at the start of his four-day visit to Washington and New York, was, "How much money, Mr. President, are you going to beg?"
 
'We Have Not Come Here to Beg'
 "We have not come here to beg, we have not come here hat in hand," he said, speaking Russian that was translated by an interpreter. "We have come here to tell you the truth about the Russia of today."
His comments seemed to be a subtle effort to distinguish himself from Mr. Gorbachev, who has called for Western economic assistance to help the Soviet Union make the transition from Communism to a more Western-style economy.
Mr. Yeltsin, who has attracted a wide following in the Soviet Union, was clearly trying to capture some of the same positive attention here that Mr. Gorbachev has generated on his visits.
No sooner had he arrived at Andrews Air Force Base than he broke away from his security contingent to shake hands with spectators, in the sort of spontaneous pressing-the-flesh that has won Mr. Gorbachev so many admirers in America.
 
Mingling With the Crowd
 At the embassy tonight, Mr. Yeltsin quickly dispensed with formal protocol, abandoning the new Soviet Ambassador, Viktor G. Komplektov, in the receiving line, so he could move into the throngs and mingle more informally. Mr. Komplektov, for his part, had not relinquished his living quarters to Mr. Yeltsin in the gilt-laced downtown embassy, as the Soviet Ambassador has done during visits by Mr. Gorbachev. Mr. Yeltsin is staying at the Madison, a luxurious Washington hotel favored by foreign dignitaries.
Mr. Yeltsin wants to erase the bad memory left by his last visit to the United States in September 1989, when some reporters depicted him as indulging in a long drinking and shopping spree here, accounts that were reprinted in the Communist Party newspaper, Pravda. Pravda apologized to Mr. Yeltsin after encountering a storm of protest from readers and after several witnesses disputed many details in the unattractive profile, which first appeared in an Italian newspaper.
In contrast with his last visit to Washington, Mr. Yeltsin was somber and judicious in the delivery of his remarks, although an occasional flash of his customary puckishness came through.
Although the embassy was stocked with caviar in the heyday of Communism, there was none in sight tonight. The American and Soviet guests had to settle for cucumber and ham hors d'oeuvres and warm vodka.
 
New Envoy to Moscow
 The guests included President Bush's choice to be the new ambassador to Moscow, Robert S. Strauss, and his wife, Helen.
Mr. Strauss was greeted by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Jack Kemp, who laughingly told the ambassador-designate that "Gorby will have a hard time getting a word in edgewise with you in Moscow." Mr. Kemp, who was a quarterback for the Buffalo Bills before becoming a Republican Congressman, also advised Mr. Strauss to import professional football to Moscow.
Mr. Strauss said he has been so busy getting briefings from the State Department that he had postponed his Russian lessons until he gets to the Soviet Union.
 
'Stronger and Stable Interaction'
 Even though his visit is officially billed as private, Mr. Yeltsin had insisted on landing at the military air base used by the President and other Administration officials, as well as important foreign visitors, as a sign that the United States regards him with the proper degree of respect.
When he arrived at Andrews after the 11-hour flight from Moscow, Mr. Yeltsin said that he hoped his visit would "launch a direct dialogue between Russia and the United States in the interests of stronger and stable interaction between the U.S.S.R. and the United States."
He was met by the Senate Republican Leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, and the Senate Majority Leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, who are acting as his hosts while he is in Washington.
Senator Dole told Mr. Yeltsin that his meetings with President Bush and top legislators "demonstrate the new reality of the Soviet Union and the Russian republic, a reality that we are perhaps a bit belatedly coming to accept."
The highest ranking Administration official who came to the airport was Curt Kamman, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State in the Bureau of European Affairs.
The Bush Administration is engaged in a delicate choreography this week. Officials do not want to give Mr. Yeltsin too much attention, because that could annoy and undercut President Gorbachev. Yet they do not want to offend the proud and popular Russian politician, especially now that it seems that he is destined to be a potent force in the future of the Soviet Union.
 
Yeltsin 'Led the Way'
 "We want to convey the idea that we must deal with the central Government of the Soviet Union," said a senior White House official. "But we also want to encourage pluralism and convey that it is important for the Soviet Union to have elections and for Yeltsin to have led the way."
At his briefing today, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, stressed that he does not want Mr. Yeltsin's reception to be seen as a challenge to Mr. Gorbachev's leadership.
"President Bush has met with the presidents of the other republics, as well as the Baltic states, and we certainly are anxious to meet with President Yeltsin as well," Mr. Fitzwater said, adding that "our relationship has been with the central Government of the Soviet Union for the last 40-some years, and that's the way it will remain. So there will be no change in that relationship."
State Department officials said that, when Mr. Bush meets with Mr. Yeltsin on Thursday for an hour, he will want to hear his plans for economic liberalization. "The President will want to know to what extent he's constrained by the central Government and to what extent he thinks he can move forward with these ambitious economic plans he's got," said a State Department official involved with the trip.
Mr. Yelstin said tonight on the ABC News program "Nightline" that he does not like Mr. Gorbachev very much because the Soviet President has shown "inconsistency, half-hearted decisions" and a tendency to change positions under pressure.
Since April, when Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Yeltsin and leaders of eight other republics agreed to reorganize the union, President Gorbachev has been "more stable" and has kept his word, Mr. Yeltsin said through an interpreter.
Mr. Yeltsin was scheduled to appear on the NBC News program "Today" Wednesday morning, before spending a day on Capitol Hill meeting with leading lawmakers.

Among those who greeted him was Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader, who stood to Mr. Yeltsin's right. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Stocks Plunge in Tokyo

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, June 19

 BODY:
Prices fell sharply on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today on higher interest rates and the dollar's continued strength.
The Nikkei average of 225 issues plunged 688.72 points, or 2.79 percent, to close at 23,996.75. On Tuesday, the index fell 257.62 points. 
 Stock traders said there was a pessimistic mood in the market bacause of the dollar's strength and higher interest rates. Higher bond rates tend to indicate traders do not expect a fall in the prime lending rate soon.
Traders said the possibility of lower interest rates was eroded further by Tuesday's Japanese gross national product report, which showed continuing strenth in the economy. The Bank of Japan has been keeping interest rates high to cool the economy and stem inflation.
Brokers said there was selling by investment trusts and some index selling.
A drop in the Dow Jones industrial average, which lost 7.15 points on Tuesday, and heavy sell orders for September futures also helped push down the market.
"Today was a futures-led decline," said Chip Mesics, an equity salesman at Kidder Peabody International.
The dollar was trading at 140.90 yen by late this morning, down 0.16 yen from Tuesday's close. It opened at 141.08 yen.
Currency dealers said the dollar's higher opening followed its overnight advance in New York after remarks by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, that the American economy has hit bottom.

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Roger Cohen

 BODY:

Maggie Joins Norman
Until a few months ago, Marvin Josephson, who owns the International Creative Management agency, had the most exclusive coterie of clients in town. It consisted of just two people: Barbara Walters and Henry Kissinger. But the list has now doubled in size. 
 The first addition was Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, whose proposed book is the object of hotly contested bidding that has reached the $5 million range. The houses still in the game are HarperCollins, Bantam, William Morrow, Alfred A. Knopf and Random House. (Persistent rumors that Disney Publishing is also in the running, with half an eye on developing beaming "Schwarzies" for the theme parks, are unfounded.)
The second newcomer to Mr. Josephson's private client list is Margaret Thatcher. The agent, who founded I.C.M. in 1955, said that he signed an agreement yesterday to represent the former British Prime Minister worldwide and would be offering her memoirs to publishing houses in the next few days.
Asked whether he expected the Iron Lady or the four-star Bear to fetch more money, Mr. Josephson, reached on vacation in Aspen, Colo., said, "I never discuss the money my clients get." Mrs. Thatcher is also expected to command a seven-figure sum.
Several American publishing houses -- including Bantam Doubleday Dell, HarperCollins and Random House Inc. -- now have British arms, and Mr. Josephson said these would be natural places for Mrs. Thatcher to publish her as yet untitled memoirs.
Both Mrs. Thatcher and General Schwarzkopf were pursued by several agents who made pilgrimages to London and Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Mr. Josephson, who is 64 years old, joined the trek to Europe and the Middle East. "I've been surprised by how competitive my juices still are," he said.
 
Disney Plays Hardball
 Although it did not enter the Schwarzkopf race, Disney Publishing, whose adult trade book arm is called Hyperion, has been making a big splash in its first year of activity. It has been bidding aggressively for both fiction and particularly non-fiction books, offering unusual incentives like 17.5 percent, rather than the traditional 15 percent, royalties on some deals.
For example, Robert Miller, the publisher, said it bid $500,000 for two books by Donna Tartt, a first novelist; $500,000 for the memoirs of Peter Arnett, the veteran journalist who was CNN 's man in Baghdad during the Persian Gulf war, $575,000 for "The Force" a nonfiction book by David Dorsey about the driven Xerox sales team in Cleveland.
All of these books went elsewhere in the end: Ms. Tartt's first novel went to Alfred A. Knopf for over $400,000; Mr. Arnett's was bought by Simon & Schuster for more than $600,000, and Mr. Dorsey's book went to Random House for the same price as Disney offered.
Do these failures suggest that the Disney name has an air of frivolity that tends to put serious writers off? Mr. Miller said that it was the Hyperion name that went on books and that he did not feel Disney's image was a problem. On the contrary, he suggested that authors were attracted by the security and stability that comes with being backed by the Walt Disney Company. "That works to our advantage," he said.
Still, he conceded that on "The Force," which was sold to Random House, the fact that Disney was new to adult trade publishing probably was a decisive factor. "When it comes to choosing between us and an editor like Joseph Fox at Random House," he said, "I feel that it will take us time to compete with that kind of prestige. But it is not a problem in many cases."
Among the books Disney has bought in highly competitive auctions is the next work by Dan Raviv and Yossi Melman, whose "Every Spy a Prince," a study of the Israeli secret service, was a best seller. The new book, "Friends in Deed," is a study of relations between the United States and Israel, and will be published in 1993.
Hyperion's fall list, its first, consists of nine books. Among them are "The Art of Mickey Mouse," "The Doors: The Complete Illustrated Lyrics," edited by Danny Sugarman, and a first novel called "The Cooter Farm," by Matthew Jones.
 
Fewer in Frankfurt
 Disney's impact has been that much greater because the largesse of publishing houses has dwindled somewhat this year because of the recession. In a reflection of this, major houses are cutting back on the traditionally very large delegations they dispatch to the Frankfurt Book Fair.
For many years, the Frankfurt fair, usually held in October, has been regarded as essential by any editor who wanted to wangle a trip to Germany. But the fact is that faxes have made international business very easy to conduct without leaving home.
This year, Bantam Doubleday Dell, which is owned by Bertelsmann , , the German publishing giant, is cutting its bandwagon by half, to about 15 people, said its president, Jack Hoeft. HarperCollins is cutting back to 25 people from 30, said Robert L. Biewen, a company vice president. And Alberto Vitale, the chief executive of Random House Inc., said the company was reducing its party by about 25 percent. He declined to say how many people were sent last year.
"Frankfurt had degenerated into a pilgrimage that was obligatory for all publishers," he said. "We should get back to the notion that it is fundamentally a rights fair."
At Frankfurt, in theory, international rights sales are made. But it also amounts to the publishing schmooze par excellence.

HEADLINE: Met Opera Is a Force in Recordings Again

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
After a hiatus of more than three decades, the Metropolitan Opera is not only recording regularly again, but it is also at the center of a battle between two rival record companies, Deutsche Grammophon and Sony Classical, with others waiting in the wings. 
 The reasons for the labels' new activity here are partly economic, with currency fluctuations and changes in union rules helping to make the Met more competitive with foreign orchestras. Spokesmen for the companies say, however, that the main attractions are James Levine and the Met orchestra itself, which under his direction has come to be regarded in recent years as one of the best in the world.
For the last month, the Met's musicians have been camped out at Manhattan Center on West 34th Street, in a ballroom that has been converted into a recording studio. Along with a parade of singers including, at different times, Luciano Pavarotti, Placido Domingo, Jessye Norman, Aprile Millo and Cheryl Studer, they have been recording bits and pieces of music, some only a few minutes long, some lasting half an hour.
Over the next few months, these bits will be stitched together into four operas: Verdi's "Traviata" and Wagner's "Parsifal," for Deutsche Grammophon, and Verdi's "Luisa Miller" and "Il Trovatore," for Sony. The sessions also yielded the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra's first symphonic recording, a collection of Wagner overtures for Deutsche Grammophon.
 
A Record Here and There
 Until 1987, when Deutsche Grammophon began recording the Met's "Ring" cycle, the orchestra's visits to the studio were infrequent. The company made some records in the 1950's, and recorded an isolated "Carmen" in the early 1970's and the soundtrack to Franco Zeffirelli's "Traviata" film in 1983.
Because of the high rates set by the American Federation of Musicians, recording opera in the United States was at the time prohibitively expensive for most record companies. Typically, recordings were made in Europe with combinations that might include, for instance, a London orchestra, an American conductor and an international cast of singers.
 In the mid-1980's, the musicians' union approved a contract that allowed opera orchestras to record at rates about 20 percent lower than standard symphonic rates. Even with the new rates, says Olympia Gineri, Sony's head of production, it can cost as much as $900,000 to record a four-act opera in the United States, about 30 percent more than comparable projects in Europe. But both Sony and Deutsche Grammophon wanted to record with Mr. Levine, and New York was where Mr. Levine wanted to work.
"When you record an opera in London," the conductor said recently, "you have an excellent orchestra, but one that doesn't know the piece. You rehearse the 15 minutes you are going to record, and then you record it. After a while, I thought: This is the reason we have so many anonymous sounding recordings. However good the orchestra is, it's not the same as recording with an orchestra that you play opera with every day. So I decided that I was not going to record that way anymore, and I waited for a time when I could apply what I was doing in the opera house to what I wanted to record."
 
The Met Helps With the Costs
 The Met also offered some financial incentives at first. When Deutsche Grammophon recorded the Met's "Ring" cycle, the opera company contributed about 20 percent of the session costs. It also contributed to the cost of recording Mozart's "Nozze di Figaro" last year. But Joseph Volpe, the Met's general director, said that for the rest of its recordings, the Met has picked up only a few incidental expenses.
Miss Gineri of Sony said in a recent telephone interview that she doubted that her company could afford to record the Met indefinitely without subsidies. This year, in fact, Sony postponed its planned recording of the Met's "Flying Dutchman" because the sessions did not fit into the company's budget.
There is not much sympathy for Sony's budget problems at Deutsche Grammophon, which had an exclusive contract with the Met until Sony came along and persuaded the company to renegotiate its deals.
Sony struck up its relationship with the Met in 1989, and inaugurated it with a recently released "Aida" featuring Mr. Domingo and Miss Millo. For some at Deutsche Grammophon, Sony's signing of the Met was calculated and predatory. Sony's president is Gunther Breest, who until 1988 was head of Deutsche Grammophon. When he joined Sony, Mr. Breest moved the label's headquarters to Hamburg, where Deutsche Grammophon is based, and lured both Vladimir Horowitz and the Herbert von Karajan video archive away from his former label.
Miss Gineri bristles at the assertion that the Met is part of this rivalry. "Who would spend so much money just to hurt another company?" she asked. But Aman Pedersen, head of Deutsche Grammophon's artists and repertory department, said that Deutsche Grammophon had been shocked at first by Sony's move into what had been its territory.
 
'But Things Change'
 "We did feel a rivalry at the start," Mr. Pedersen said. "But things change in the record business. After many years of not recording much opera, CBS -- now Sony -- is doing some serious work again, and we have to accommodate ourselves to that. It also has to do with singers. Some singers are associated with us, and some are associated with Sony. If you look at it that way, it is really not so surprising."
Besides the Deutsche Grammophon and Sony recordings, the Met has recorded Schoenberg's "Erwartung" for Philips , and is discussing recordings with London Records .
But Mr. Levine said: "I'm very anxious that the quantity does not get out of hand. What I would like to see in the future is two or three carefully chosen operas, as well as whatever symphonic repertory we feel we ought to record."
The casts of the recordings are idealized, in the sense that an operagoer is unlikely to run into the same combinations of singers in a single night at the Met. The "Parsifal" recording, for example, features Mr. Domingo and Miss Norman, the Parsifal and Kundry from last season's production. But the recording's Gurnemanz (Kurt Moll) and Amfortas (James Morris) have not yet sung those roles at the Met, though they are scheduled to do so next season. The "Traviata" recording, similarly, features Miss Studer, who has not yet sung Violetta in the house, and Mr. Pavarotti, who has not sung Alfredo at the Met in recent seasons.
 
The Pieces of the Puzzle
 "The casts represent, in various combinations, people who sing a lot at the Met, either in those roles or in others, or singers who are part of the Met ensemble," the conductor said. "You choose singers for a recording, or for television, because you think they will give you the best result in that medium."
At the Met's sessions, as at opera recording sessions everywhere, pieces of an opera are recorded out of sequence, with several takes of each section. Between takes, Mr. Levine tells the performers what changes in detail he wants, and he repeats sections until he either gets what he is looking for, or senses that the performers are losing their freshness. Putting the pieces in order comes later.
"No, I have never found it disorienting to record an opera out of sequence," Mr. Levine said after a "Traviata" session that began with the Act II duet between Violetta and Germont, and ended with the Act I Prelude. "In fact, you can turn to your advantage the fact that you are not recording the work as a straight-through performance.
"Let's say you're recording the third act of 'Walkure.' Wotan has a scene with the Valkyries, and with Brunnhilde and the Valkyries. Then the Valkyries go away, and he has a scene with Brunnhilde, ending with his big Abschied, or farewell. Every Wotan will tell you: unless he is having a magical day, to sing with full vehemence, anger, pressure and intensity during the first half of the act jeopardizes whether the sound will be as glowing and beautiful as it must be at the end.
"So when you record it, you record the first part of the act one day and the end at another session. The result is that he doesn't have to pace himself through one long take, and can give you his best in both. And that's important, because you are not seeing him. On a recording, it must all be there in the sound."

HEADLINE: Food Notes

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:

Where to Find Ware
Many cities have well-stocked stores for well-priced cooking equipment. But where such shops are not conveniently situated, there are new mail-order sources for equipment at a discount. 
 Commercial Culinary , based in Alexandria, Va., is a new venture run by Dave Constantine, who also has another catalogue, Spectacular Sauces. It offers cookware, knives and appliances like food processors, ice-cream makers and espresso makers. Prices run 20 percent to 40 percent below standard list. For example, the heavy duty KSM5 Kitchenaid mixer is $289.95 and the hand mixer $54.95. The Gaggia ice-cream maker is $379.95. Shipping is extra. For more information, call (800) 999-4949.
Also of interest to cooks is European Home Products , a company with a retail shop at 236 East Avenue, Norwalk, Conn., that specializes in replacement parts for appliances made by Cuisinarts, Robot-Coupe and Kitchenaid. The company even has an inventory of blades, bowls and the like for older models, some of which are no longer being made.
Accessories for these appliances are available, as are new appliances, at a discount, many of them at prices comparable to Commercial Culinary's. The company also has replacement carafes for many brands of electric coffee makers. Orders can be placed by calling (800) 225-0760 or, in Connecticut, (203) 866-9683.
 
Ice Cream's Still Cool
It's no surprise that ice cream is the most popular frozen dessert in this country. In a nationwide telephone survey conducted last summer by Dr. Robert O. Herrmann, professor of agricultural economics at Pennsylvania State University in University Park, 53 percent of 1,200 respondents said they had eaten ice cream in the previous four weeks, but 30 percent said that in the preceding year, they ate less ice cream than in the year before that.
Forty-four percent said they had eaten frozen yogurt in the preceding four weeks; 40 percent reported an increase in their consumption of frozen yogurt over the last year, and 38 percent said they had switched from ice cream to frozen yogurt.
The poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. Dr. Herrmann plans a follow-up survey this summer.
 
Real and Hand-Packed
Rich, old-fashioned milk, heavy cream and now, ice cream, are the specialties of Glensfoot Farm in Cherry Valley, N.Y., a farm that dates to the 18th century. A few retail shops in Manhattan carry its products. The cream is not ultrapasteurized, which gives it a fresh rather than slightly cooked taste. It whips up splendidly and can be reduced easily to thicken a sauce.
The hand-packed ice cream is not as dense as some popular premium ice creams and has a smooth creaminess typical of an old-fashioned farmhouse confection. The flavors are clean, without the extra richness found in a custard-based French ice cream.
The ice cream comes in a lush vanilla, bittersweet chocolate, mellow coffee, fragrant strawberry and rich pralines and cream.
The addition of vegetable gums like guar and carageenan, to keep the texture smooth and improve shelf life, differentiate these ice creams from what one might lick off the dasher of a home ice-cream machine.
The heavy cream is $1.75 a half pint and the ice cream is $3.25 a pint at Balducci's, 424 Avenue of the Americas (Ninth Street), $1.89 for the cream and $3.98 for the ice cream at Dean & DeLuca, 560 Broadway (Prince Street), and $1.65 for the cream and $3.49 for the ice cream at Grace's Marketplace, 1237 Third Avenue (71st Street). Jefferson Market, 455 Avenue of the Americas (10th Street) offers the cream for $1.49 a half pint.
 
For Miss Liberty
"Star-Spangled Cooking" (1987), about American regional food, and "A Taste of Liberty" (1985), a survey of ethnic food in America, are two illustrated cookbooks published by Stewart Tabori & Chang . They were produced by Chateau Ste. Michelle, a winery in Washington State, as a project to raise money to support the restoration of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island. The books, which also promote the winery, are now being sold there and are available by mail.
Now, Chateau Ste. Michelle has announced that it is contributing $10 of the price of every book sold to the American Red Cross.
The books are $24.95 each plus $2.50 for shipping, or $44.95 plus $4 for shipping for both. The offer continues through the end of the year.
Orders can be placed by sending checks or credit card information to Chateau Ste. Michelle Winery, Commemorative Cookbooks Center, Department P, 1 Stimson Lane, Woodinville, Wash., 98072.
 
BIG-CITY STRAWBERRIES
IN farm country, strawberry festivals belong to early summer. But there will be a big-city version next Wednesday, complete with shortcake, at the City Bakery, 22 East 17th Street, from 6:30 to 9 P.M.
Fresh strawberries, strawberry desserts and even a strawberry soup made from produce sold at the Union Square Greenmarket nearby will be served with Hudson Valley wines. It's a benefit for Farm Hands City Hands, a nonprofit organization that seeks to preserve farms and foster understanding between urban and rural interests.
Tickets to the strawberry festival are $20 and are on sale at the City Bakery, at the Breezy Hill Orchards stand in the Greenmarket today and Saturday, and at Foodwork, 34 Downing Street (Seventh Avenue South). They will also be sold at the door.
For information, call (212) 255-1780.

HEADLINE: Help Families Choose, Everywhere

 BODY:
Thirty years ago, barely a tenth of the people in developing countries used some kind of birth control. Today more than half do -- in large part because of America's pioneering efforts to help people choose the size of their families. That choice is important not only for individuals but for countries, some of which are so devastated and deforested they cannot feed and house their own.
Seven years ago, at the 1984 World Population Conference in Mexico City, the United States trashed its position as a wise world leader on this issue. It announced it would try to end financial aid to any agency that so much as mentioned abortion. The Agency for International Development, aided and abetted by Congress, then withdrew financing from the United Nations Fund for Population Activities and the International Planned Parenthood Federation. 
 That Congress can put such strictures on its financing is supported by a recent Supreme Court decision. Whether it should, however, is a matter of conscience -- and evidence is mounting that Congressional consciences are troubled.
Last week, for instance, the House Appropriations Committee approved a foreign aid bill that would overturn the ban on American support for United Nations population planning programs. The bill would increase population planning funds by 20 percent (up to $300 million), but earmarks $20 million for the U.N. program. Furthermore, the full House now backs language authorizing the $20 million, and on a roll call vote narrowly supported reversing the Mexico City policy.
A comparable initiative is under way in the Senate, where proposed legislation contains a proposal from Senator Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas to reverse the Mexico City policy. Last week the bill survived an assault by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, by a vote of 13 to 6.
For years, Americans could be genuinely proud of this country's commitment to international family planning. Congress, if it continues down the present path, seems willing to restore the basis for that pride. And so, by overturning the Mexico City policy, could President Bush.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Asserts the Recession May Be at an End, or Nearly So

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the recession might already have ended but that no measurable expansion of the nation's economy had yet begun.
"Clearly we have data which are subject to revision and are likely to be revised one way or the other," Mr. Greenspan told the House Ways and Means Committee. "But it's very difficult to get around the data of the last several weeks, which are strongly suggestive that the bottom is somewhere in the second quarter." 
 The financial markets interpreted Mr. Greenspan's statement as an indication that the Federal Reserve is unlikely to reduce interest rates even though inflation seems well under control, and stock and bond prices fell slightly today.
Mr. Greenspan's remarks were the first in which the nation's principal economic policy maker has said publicly that the recession might be over. A similar consensus has emerged among private economists in the last two weeks.
In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan made these other comments about the economy:
*Banks continue to be reluctant to lend, and credit is still tight.
*The commercial real estate market remains in a slump and is not likely to recover as quickly as the rest of the economy does.
*Foreign trade barriers do not significantly depress American exports, while United States trade barriers cost American consumers tens of billions of dollars a year.
 
Optimism About Inflation
 In response to a question from Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Long Island, Mr. Greenspan said he was "confident that we can come out of this with a recovery without concurrently reigniting inflationary forces, which inevitably, within a reasonably short period, create the next recession."
But he added that "we don't yet see any measurable upward thrust" in the nation's output of goods and services. And in response to further questions, Mr. Greenspan refused to say how long a recovery might last or how strong it might be.
In testimony two weeks ago, however, Mr. Greenspan said the recovery might be stronger than expected.
At a separate hearing by the Senate Finance Committee on the nomination of David W. Mullins Jr. to become vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, Mr. Mullins said the economy had touched bottom in the last month or so, or was about to do so. Edward Kelley, a Federal Reserve governor, told the Senate Banking Committee last week that the economy appeared to have bottomed out.
Congressional pressure for lower rates notwithstanding, Mr. Mullins said, "it's not apparent that there is room" for the central bank to ease monetary policy soon without raising fears of inflation that could drive up rates on longer-term bonds. An increase in interest rates on long-term bonds might defeat the purpose of stimulating the economy by easing monetary policy, Mr. Mullins said.
By pumping more money into the nation's banking system, the Federal Reserve can drive down short-term rates, making it cheaper for stores to hold large inventories and for consumers to take out home equity loans.
But such a move tends to drive up long-term rates, as lenders become concerned that inflation will seriously devalue the money they are to be repaid. Long-term rates tend to affect purchases of homes and other large investments.
Mr. Mullins said any gain to the economy from driving down short-term rates now would probably be offset by the loss from higher long-term rates.
Mr. Greenspan said banks continue to be cautious in their lending practices, as they try to build up capital in case many of their nonperforming loans must be written off entirely. As a result, he said, "We are still in the grips of a credit crunch."
Many of the banking industry's problem loans have financed commercial real estate. Mr. Greenspan said this sector of the economy would "lag quite considerably" in its recovery from the recession.
"It shows very few signs that I can see that it is in the process of stabilizing; there's some, but not a great deal," he said. "But surely there is no evidence at this point which suggests that it is improving or about to."
But an upturn in the number of Americans employed is likely a few months after a rebound in the nation's total output of goods and services, Mr. Greenspan said.
Few questions to Mr. Greenspan from members of the House Ways and Means Committee dealt with the original subject of the hearing, the competitiveness of the United States in international markets.
In his opening remarks, Mr. Greenspan strongly endorsed the Administration's position of eliminating trade barriers and holding down Government intervention in the market. There have been plausible estimates that "the unilateral removal of quantitative restrictions on imports of textiles, apparel and various agricultural products would result in net gains to U.S. consumers amounting to tens of billions of dollars," he said.
"Moreover," he added, "the complete removal of existing foreign restrictions on U.S. exports probably would reduce our trade deficit by only modest amounts."
Mr. Greenspan said the Federal Government should not provide subsidies to specific industries even if they appear especially likely to succeed. If the industries have genuinely good prospects, then the private sector will finance them, he said.
But the chairman of the Federal Reserve has no legal authority over these issues, and many in Congress already have firm views about them.

HEADLINE: Noted Japanese Retailer Plans Ritz Tower Store

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Mitsukoshi, Japan's oldest and one of its more prestigious department stores, plans to open its doors in the spring of 1993 in the Ritz Tower Hotel at 57th Street and Park Avenue, in one of the world's most fashionable retail districts.
To succeed in the heart of New York's highly competitive but financially beleaguered retail market, Mitsukoshi officials said, the store will have to emphasize Japanese retail principles, which are based on the premise that customers should shop in an entertaining and enlightening atmosphere. 
 On the the top floor of the store's four levels, for example, will be a gallery where the company plans to stage poetry readings, art shows and musical and dramatic events.
The 40,000-square-foot store, organized around an atrium, will offer a mix of designer and private-label clothing, unusual gifts and Japanese arts and crafts.
Mitsukoshi said it would tailor its merchandise to appeal to the same customers that shop at Saks Fifth Avenue, Henri Bendel and Galeries Lafayette. Plans call for a basement stocked with fresh and prepared foods ranging from the most ordinary vegetables to delicacies like Japanese Kobe beef.
"The time the customer spends in Mitsukoshi is very important, so we will have a full range of services, products and entertainment to keep her occupied," said Tomio Tambe, president of Mitsukoshi U.S.A. "The idea," he said, "is to enjoy the surroundings and the experience."
Mitsukoshi has stores in London, Paris and Rome, among other cities, and 14 stores in Japan, where its distinctive logo is regarded as a sign of good taste and quality, said John Wheeler, vice president of the Japan Society, a New York group that promotes Japanese culture in America.
The company also has a small shop selling Japanese arts and crafts at Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla.
Company officials conceded that the New York retail climate was difficult, particularly for lavish stores aimed at an affluent clientele. But they said the opportunity to own commercial space in the Ritz Tower, the 1925 landmark building designed by Emery Roth, was too good to pass up. They also said they expected the economy to recover by the time the store opened.
Japanese retailers have had difficulty operating in the American market in the past because they have tried to imitate American stores' products and services instead of distinguishing themselves, said Elizabeth Miller Kummerfeld of Kummerfeld Associates, a management and venture-capital consulting firm in New York.
 
'They Have Deep Pockets'
 "I would say it's going to be tough going for them, but Mitsukoshi is among the most prestigious department stores in Japan," Ms. Kummerfeld said. "They have deep pockets and a long-term perspective on business."
Ms. Kummerfeld, who has advised other Japanese companies entering the American market, said Mitsukoshi would have to invest heavily in advertising to establish its name and bring in merchandise that would distinguish it from competitors.
Although customers will not be required to exchange their shoes for cotton socks, a practice that lasted well into the 20th century in Japanese stores, the company intends to bring many of its other Japanese customs to its Manhattan store. Customers will be greeted at the entrances to the store by bowing sales clerks, and consultants will be on hand to offer opinions and suggestions and guide shoppers to various parts of the store.
The company says it will contain many of its costs by selling items made in factories it owns or supervises. Mitsukoshi supervisers, for example, work in the Chinese factories that make embroidered blouses Mitsukoshi sells in its stores. "There are no middlemen," Mr. Tambe said. "We control the costs and the quality."
 
Came to New York 15 Years Ago
 Mitsukoshi opened an office in New York in 1976 and soon began operating a Japanese restaurant and a boutique that sold clothes made by the Japanese designer Matsuda. Both businesses are in a 10,000-square-foot space that it formerly leased from the Ritz Tower.
Mitsukoshi has now bought that space and an additional 30,000 square feet for $17.25 million. The boutique and restaurant have been closed while the company completes renovations.
In the fiscal year that ended Feb. 28, 1990, the last year for which financial statistics are available, the company had sales of $5.6 billion and a profit margin of less than 1 percent, which is slender by American standards. The stock trades on the Tokyo Exchange.
 
A 318-Year History
 Among the reasons Mr. Tambe gave for his confidence in the store's success was the company's 318-year-old history. Its predecessor was Echigo-ya (pronounced EE-chi-GO-ya), a dry-goods store founded in what is now Tokyo in 1673 by Takatoshi Mitsui.
Profits from Echigo-ya contributed to the the Mitsui family fortune and the vast Mitsui empire in Japan.The retail stores that were descendants of Echigo-ya adopted the name Mitsukoshi Ltd. in 1928.
"We've been in this business since 1673," Mr. Tambe said. "We move very slowly, but we make sure everything is workable."

HEADLINE: Volcano's Ash Dismays Filipinos and Americans

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OLONGAPO, the Philippines, June 19

 BODY:
On both sides of the heavy steel gate that separates this city from Subic Bay Naval Station, the sprawling American naval base, there was a shared sense of hopelessness today.
Five days after Mount Pinatubo covered much of this coastal region with layer upon layer of volcanic ash and sand, which has been turned into a quagmire by the constant rains, the situation had only worsened. 
 There was only intermittent electricity today, little running water and a sense of concern about the future.
There is talk by officials here and in Washington that the cleanup costs from the volcano, 35 miles northwest of Subic, may be so great and the future of the base so precarious that the United States may have to make some hard decisions on whether to keep Subic and the American-run Clark Air Base. The joint lease on the bases runs out in September, and talks had been suspended because the Filipinos had rejected an American offer as too low. Now, many Filipinos wish the lease had been signed.
 
'How Will We Make Money?'
 Here, in Olongapo, a typical city that depends on a military base to survive, many Filipinos strolling past the honky-tonk saloons along Magsaysay Drive this afternoon said the closing of Subic Bay would be an economic calamity.
"Maybe the Americans won't come back because of the volcano," said a 21-year-old e bar hostess, who gave her name only as Miki. "The Americans always talk about how they might have to leave Subic and go home forever."
"But how will we make money if they go?" she said.
Because of the volcano the bar was virtually empty of customers.
 
A Yearlong Cleanup
 "In some ways, life might be good -- better -- without the Americans," she continued. "But how will we survive?"
Frankie Dana, a 27-year-old T-shirt salesman born in Olongapo, was hawking shirts stenciled with the words, "I Survived Mount Pinatubo."
"My only buyers are Americans," he said, frantically trying to cover the shirts with a plastic sheet to protect them from a rainy season downpour. "Americans are all we have."
The cleanup of Subic base, one of the largest American military installations outside the United States and a cornerstone of American security policy in Asia since World War II, will take months, if not a year or more, officials at the base say.
Thick layers of ash emitted by Mount Pinatubo cover virtually every inch of the 100,000-acre installation.
Soaked by rain, the ash, which has the appearance of caked, dirty snow and the consistency of wet charcoal, is jamming electrical generators and has contaminated much of the fresh water supply in Olongapo and at Subic. Scores of buildings at the naval base have collapsed from the ash's weight.
"We got some running water today," said Petty Officer Jerry Moore, a base spokesman. "We were glad to see it, even if it's only for drinking. We still don't smell very good."
Although volcano scientists say the major eruptions of Mount Pinatubo appear to be over, the Defense Department is pressing forward with the evacuation of nearly 20,000 Americans from the Philippines, including the families of all military and civilian workers at Subic and Clark.
 
Families Shipping Out
 Hundreds of the families waited in line this afternoon outside a bowling alley at Subic that was serving as an evacuation center.
"I absolutely understand why the Navy is doing this, but it's still been tears all round for my family," said Petty Officer First Class Patrick Dunn, 34, of Kansas City, Mo., who had come to the evacuation center to see his Filipino wife, Eva, and their three children depart.
"You can't keep families here when there are no showers and no electricity," he said. "I've never seen anything like this. This ash is everywhere and I don't know how you clean it up."
Anne Comer, the wife of a Navy lieutenant assigned to Subic, held tight to 1-year-old Kathryn, the youngest of her five children.
 
Clouds of Volcanic Ash
 "We're supposed to be shipping out tonight and I have to leave my husband behind," said Mrs. Comer, 39, who looked weary from five days of ash storms and earthquakes brought on by the volcano.
"Basically I've had no sleep since this began," she said. "The stress level is very, very high for everyone."
Air traffic has been shut down throughout the central Philippines for several days out of fear that the swirling clouds of volcanic ash might cause jet engines to stall.
The international and domestic airports in Manila, about 65 miles southeast of Subic Bay, have been closed to most flights for five days.
That has required the Defense Department to evacuate the Americans by sea, aboard warships that have been put on a shuttle run this week between Subic and the Philippine city of Cebu, about 300 miles south of the base, where the international airport has not been affected by the ash.
A city that grew up out of the Subic base to service the United States Navy and to entertain generations of American sailors, Olongapo and its 300,000 residents are nothing if not resilient.
Several of the city's best-known places, with names like "The Body Shop" and "Love Disco" were shut down or destroyed by the volcano.
But others have struggled to remain open despite the loss of electrical power and the six-foot-high mounds of volcanic ash and sand clogging the street.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The blanket of volcanic ash that covers the U.S. Subic Bay Naval Station in the Philippines may be too costly to clean up for a base that might close in a few months. A sailor examined cars covered with ash. (Agence France-Presse)
 
Map of Philippines showing location of Olongapo.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes Mostly Lower In Advance of London Talks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended broadly lower yesterday, pushed down by technical factors, economic concerns and fears that world leaders might try to stem the currency's recent rally.
Gold was slightly higher in New York after falling overseas. 
 Dollar sales continued on speculation that this Sunday's meeting in London of the Group of Seven leading industrial nations might result in a concerted effort to keep the value of the dollar down.
In the past, the group has used central bank interventions and interest rates to try to influence the dollar's movement. Some dealers said the Group of Seven officials were unlikely to reach an accord, but investors were not prepared to run that risk.
"We saw a lot of people taking profit on long positions. A few of the longer-term currency funds seemed to be sellers of the dollar," said Bob Morrissey, senior currency trader for the Bank of Boston.
 
Trade Report
 Traders read a mixed message into a Commerce Department report that the United States merchandise trade deficit swelled to $4.78 billion in April, reversing a two-month decline that had put it at the lowest level in eight years.
Some traders said the deficit's widening had hurt the dollar, despite exports totaling $35.56 billion, a 4.5 percent increase from March.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.6325, from $1.6120 late on Tuesday. Sterling also strengthened in New York, rising to $1.6363, from late Tuesday's $1.6103.
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.04 yen to close at 141.10 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 140.03 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 140.05 yen, down from late Tuesday's 141.08.
Other late dollar rates in New York yesterday, compared with late Tuesday, included: 1.7895 German marks, down from 1.8164; 1.5385 Swiss francs, down from 1.5645; 6.0870 French francs, down from 6.1725; 1,334.00 Italian lire, down from 1,351.00, and 1.14325 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14225.
Gold edged up in New York trading, gaining 30 cents an ounce on the Commodity Exchange to close at $368.60. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $368.15 an ounce, up 40 cents from late on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: FEUD UNDERMINING BRITISH TORY UNITY

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, June 19

 BODY:
Since succeeding Margaret Thatcher as Prime Minister in November, John Major has been trying to defuse the two issues that had split Britain's ruling Conservative Party and forced Mrs. Thatcher out of office: a highly unpopular new household tax and Britain's position in the debate on moving the European Community toward political and economic integration.
Mr. Major solved the first issue in April by moving to replace Mrs. Thatcher's tax with a property tax. He thought he was well on the way to resolving the European issue until this week, when the two Conservative Prime Ministers who preceded him, Mrs. Thatcher and Edward Heath, spoke their piece. 
 In speeches in the United States on Monday and Tuesday, Mrs. Thatcher delivered a stinging attack on any attempts to carry European integration beyond the single market that the community envisions by the end of 1992. She argued that a federal Europe would not only deprive Britain of national sovereignty and undermine democracy, but might also bring trade wars, imperil Britain's military alliance with the United States and threaten world peace.
Mrs. Thatcher also said that she regretted Britain's linkup with the exchange-rate mechanism of the European Monetary System, which ties the value of the pound to those of other major European currencies, especially the German mark.
 
Heath Takes Aim at Thatcher
 If those speeches were not enough to make Mr. Major groan, Mr. Heath assailed Mrs. Thatcher's views in television interviews Tuesday night. Mrs. Thatcher ousted Mr. Heath as party leader in 1975, two years after he took Britain into the community as Prime Minister, and Britons are aware that no love is lost between them.
Mr. Heath said Mrs. Thatcher's two speeches were "full of falsehoods -- in ordinary English, lies," and he called her "ignorant" for not realizing that "we have a European culture as well as individual national aspects." Responding to Mrs. Thatcher's description of proponents of a federal Europe as "little Europeans," he said: "The little mind is her own -- minute."
Unlike Mrs. Thatcher, Mr. Major has tried to take a constructive role in talks with other community members on closer economic and political union. He is desperate to forge a compromise on Europe among Conservatives so he can present a united front to British voters. The law requires the Government to call a general election within a year.

HEADLINE: GORBACHEV'S LOT: THE ENEMY WITHIN

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 19

 BODY:
As President Mikhail S. Gorbachev seeks to build new bridges to the West and to the Soviet Union's assertive republics, a rebellion is shaping from a new direction: his Prime Minister.
At the current session of the Soviet Parliament this week, the Prime Minister, Valentin S. Pavlov, surprised legislators by requesting extensive new powers and acknowledging that he had not discussed the matter in advance with Mr. Gorbachev. 
 Mr. Pavlov made the request on Monday after casting aspersions on an unofficial plan devised by a liberal economist, Grigory A. Yavlinsky, and a group of Harvard professors to integrate Soviet economic reforms with Western aid. The Prime Minister dismissed the plan as "a pretty piece of paper."
Mr. Pavlov insisted that the powers he was seeking would not release the Government from the President's and Parliament's supervision, but would "increase its mobility and effectiveness." Specifically, he asked that Parliament give his Government the authority for the rest of this year to enact laws and take temporary action on economic and social issues.
Mr. Gorbachev was not at the session, but his Vice President, Gennadi I. Yanayev, quickly declared that the President did not see any political challenge.
 
Showdown Deferred
 Still, it was evident that a rift had developed between the conservative Prime Minister, a career bureaucrat whom Mr. Gorbachev put in charge of the Government in January, and the Soviet President.
Mr. Gorbachev's allies managed to sidetrack Mr. Pavlov's proposal until Friday, sending it to a committee.
But it prompted some startled comments in the press, including this one in Izvestia: "A situation has taken shape that is simply unprecedented for our country. For the first time in the history of the Soviet Union, the head of the Government not only expressed disagreement with some policies of the head of state, officially, from the parliamentary tribunal, but -- circumventing the head of state, the President -- tried to take some of the President's powers."
Mr. Pavlov and other Communist hard-liners have felt themselves increasingly sidelined since Mr. Gorbachev struck a political truce with Boris N. Yeltsin and leaders of eight other Soviet republics on April 23.
That truce has led to negotiations on a new union treaty with sharply reduced powers for the Kremlin. Mr. Gorbachev has also opened a new dialogue with the West, and has supported the initiative by Mr. Yavlinsky, the primary architect of the 500-day program of radical economic reform that Mr. Gorbachev rejected last fall.
Mr. Pavlov seems especially miffed at having been sidelined in the Gorbachev initiative to the West. In his appearance before Parliament on Monday, he spoke of the initiative in dismissive and scornful terms.
 
A True Disbeliever
 "I can say only one thing: If suddenly, for some reason, the Americans agree to freely help us, I will apologize and confess that I was deeply wrong," he said. "But I do not believe in this, neither as a professional nor as a normal person."
Hard-liners in Parliament adopted Mr. Pavlov's tone, unleashing a round of bitter attacks on Mr. Gorbachev.
Yevgeny Kogan, a leader of the Soyuz group, who has called for Mr. Gorbachev's ouster, declared in an interview that the President's negotiations on a new union treaty and his dealings with the West were "a plot by the country's top bureaucrats against the people's power."
But newspapers and legislators advocating democracy rose up against Mr. Pavlov. Sergei Ryabchenko, a reformist legislator, told the press agency Tass that the requested powers would allow the Prime Minister "to function without the President."
"As a result," he said, "the President would remain in a vacuum while the Cabinet would turn into a new center of political and econmic power."
 
Conjunction of Hard-Liners
 Contributing to the rebellious mood were reportedly alarmist reports on the state of the nation by the hard-line chiefs of the K.G.B., the military and the Interior Ministry. The Parliament session was closed to the press for their appearances, but subsequent comments by lawmakers suggested a dissatisfaction with the new direction of Mr. Gorbachev.
The challenge was not likely to pose an immediate problem for Mr. Gorbachev, who has sidetracked previous attacks from hard-liners with relative ease. But the combined power of his critics was sufficient to give him pause.
Events of recent months, including ill-conceived monetary reforms that Mr. Pavlov introduced and the violent confrontations in Lithuania and Latvia, have demonstrated the capacity of the hard-liners to wreak havoc.
Mr. Gorbachev's position toward them has not yet become clear. After rejecting the 500-day economic plan last fall, he moved toward the political right, prompting Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to resign in December, warning against an incipient dictatorship.
But after the violence in the Baltic republics, a loss of favor in the West and intensifying chaos at home, Mr. Gorbachev struck a truce with democracy advocates and apparently began edging away from the hard-liners. So far, though, he has stopped short of fully restoring his ties to former liberal aides, or of breaking with the hard-liners.

HEADLINE: Gallic Dart Distresses British Men

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 19

 BODY:
The weather in London and Paris has been awful for weeks, but the summer silly season has thankfully arrived on schedule, this time adding a tiff over the relative virility of English and French men to the old perennial of cross-Channel squabbling.
The first shot was fired by Edith Cresson, the first woman to become Prime Minister of France, who was quoted on Sunday as having said that 25 percent of Englishmen -- as well as Americans and Germans -- are homosexual and that, in contrast to Frenchmen, "Anglo-Saxon men are not interested in women." 
 The interview, published in The Observer of London under the headline, "France's femme fatale," was in fact four years old and Mrs. Cresson says she cannot remember giving it. But while Americans and Germans ignored it, England's brave men do not take Gallic taunts lightly -- even when coming from a woman.
A Conservative member of Parliament, Tony Marlow, suggested that the 57-year-old Prime Minister had only herself to blame if "the last time she was in London she did not get enough admiring glances." And he suggested a motion: "This House does not fancy elderly Frenchwomen."
The popular daily The Sun said it was "a bit rich" for English manhood to be questioned by the leader of a country "where men carry handbags and kiss each other on the cheek in public." The Daily Telegraph said it prefered not to ask how Mrs. Cresson had come up with her statistics.
 
newspaper Cartoon
 In The Evening Standard, a cartoon by Jak has an aide to Mrs. Cresson announcing the arrival of the British Ambassador with "a very strong complaint." Wearing an Ascot hat and a flowery dress, His Excellency can be seen waving a newspaper with the headline, "One in Four Brits are Gay."
In France, though, Mrs. Cresson's interview stirred amusement but no criticism. After all, Swinging Edith -- as Le Canard Enchaine nicknamed her -- was only saying what most French have always felt about many Englishmen. "Too many years in all-male boarding schools," one Frenchwoman explained.
The fuss is nonetheless doubly embarrassing for the Prime Minister because it has coincided with a wave of complaints from Japan that she has gone overboard in her criticism of Japan's export policies. With Japanese far-rightists organizing protests outside France's embassy in Tokyo, the latest remark attributed to her is that the Japanese are too busy plotting against the American and European economies to be able to sleep at night.
With the English, at least, she has felt a need to defend herself, noting on Tuesday that it was not "fair play" to publish an old interview and that she loves England, speaks English and enjoys visiting London. But she added: "Englishmen are surely more reserved toward women than Frenchmen but, in the end, each country has its own traditions and culture."
In reality, what grabbed the headlines in her interview in The Observer was her response to the suggestion that in Anglo-Saxon countries men prefer the company of other men. "Yes," she said, "but the majority of these men are homosexual -- perhaps not the majority -- but in the U.S.A. there are already 25 percent of them and in England and Germany it is much the same."
Yet, in a sense, the thrust of her remarks was different -- that Anglo-Saxon men fail to appreciate women because there is something culturally or biologically wrong with them.
 "I remember from strolling about in London that men in the streets don't look at you," she said. "When you do this in Paris, men look at you."
She went on: "Anglo-Saxons are not interested in women as women. For a woman arriving in an Anglo-Saxon country, it is astonishing. She says to herself, 'What is the matter?' It is a problem of education and I consider it something of a weakness. A man who isn't interested in women is in some way a little maimed."
More disturbing to Englishmen is that some Englishwomen agree. "In an English street, you might as well have a paper bag over your head for all the notice any man takes of you," wrote Lesley Garner in The Daily Telegraph, adding that Mrs. Cresson had given a "hurtful, shocking and uncomfortably accurate view" of British men.
In The Daily Mirror, the columnist Marje was gentler with the menfolk, but added: "Keep your heads up, lads, and take a keener and closer look at the passing talent. Somehow we've got to keep on breeding good, strong silent Britons -- and it can't be done without your cooperation."

She is shown arriving yesterday at the National Assembly in Paris. Behind her were members of a visiting Japanese delegation. (Agence France-Presse)
