HEADLINE: Survey by the Fed Sees Modest Recovery Signs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
The economy has begun showing modest signs of recovery, although weaknesses remain in some regions and in some industries, the Federal Reserve said today.
"Economic conditions appear to be improving modestly in much of the nation," it said in a summary of its latest survey of the economy's state. 
 The White House agreed. "We are coming out of the recession," the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said.
And Michael J. Boskin, the White House's chief economic adviser, told Congress that the economy would resume growing during the second half of the year at an annual rate of up to 3 percent.
 
Inflation Seems in Check
 The Fed survey found retail sales up moderately in some of the central bank's 12 districts, with manufacturing gaining strength in some of the regions and home sales continuing to recover.
At the same time, the survey reported that inflation appeared to be in check, with prices "generally steady to up slightly at both the wholesale and retail levels."
But it noted a downside, saying that "stable oil prices and low natural gas prices are keeping oil drilling in check."
The survey, compiled from information supplied by the Fed banks earlier this month, was prepared for top Fed officials to use at their meeting July 2 and 3 to map interest-rate policy. The Fed's district banks get their information by questioning business people in their areas. There has been no noticeable change in interest-rate policy since the central bank lowered two key interest rates on April 30 as a stimulus "in light of continued weakness in economic activity."
 
No Changes Indicated
 The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, and a Fed governor, David W. Mullins Jr., indicated on Tuesday that no change was imminent as policy makers were waiting to see what direction the economy took.
While Mr. Greenspan said the economy appeared to have bottomed out "somewhere in the second quarter," he added, "We see no measurable upward thrust," a view that appeared somewhat at odds with the findings of the Fed's "beige book."
The Fed has been hesitant to nudge interest rates down further out of fear the move could stimulate the economy too much and inflame inflation.
Nevertheless, the White House spokesman, Mr. Fitzwater, appeared to urge the Fed to ease monetary policy more when he expressed concern over the pace of economic growth.
"We are interested in maintaining a good pace of growth as we come out of it so that we can achieve a very strong plateau of growth in the years ahead," he said.
Mr. Boskin told the House Ways and Means Committee that the Administration was continuing to forecast growth in the second half at a yearly rate of 2 percent to 3 percent.
The rebound, he suggested, "will be rather modest" because the recession itself has been shallow.
First-year growth after previous post-World War II recoveries has averaged about 6 percent.
In its survey, the Fed found retail sales varying according to district. Some described gains as slight or moderate, while others reported lackluster activity.
"While there are no reports of substantial improvement, the overall situation is somewhat brighter" than it was during a previous survey in early spring, the report said. "Manufacturing activity seems to be improving over all, but several districts report slower export growth."
 
Increased Construction
 The continuing improvement in home sales is being translated into increased construction activity in some areas, it added.
But it said bank lending remained weak in the eight districts reporting on financial developments, despite a pickup in demand for home mortgage loans. Much of the mortgage activity related to refinancing rather than new purchases.
Demand for business and consumer loans was weak in most regions.
The report also noted that extreme weather conditions in several districts had hampered spring planting and were expected to pare production. Depending on the district, the crops affected included wheat, corn, soybeans, cotton, peanuts, rice and grain sorghum.

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Widened In April

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
The nation's deficit in merchandise trade widened to $4.8 billion in April as both exports and imports posted sizable and somewhat unexpected increases, the Commerce Department reported today.
Although trade figures are relatively poor gauges of overall economic conditions, partly because they are reported later than most other indicators, analysts said today's results were consistent with the increasingly popular view that the economy has begun to pull out of recession. 
 "It augurs well," said Nancy Sidhu, an economist at Security Pacific National Bank. "It gives me a little more confidence" that exports will help drive the recovery and that demand for imports has rebounded following the Persian Gulf war.
 
Reversal in the Trend
 The moderate widening followed two months of sharp narrowing that had reduced the deficit to just over $4 billion, the lowest since mid-1983 and less than half the level a year earlier.
Robert A. Mosbacher, the Commerce Secretary, issued a statement that foreign sales reached a record $35.6 billion in April and that for the first four months of the year had run at a pace 7 percent above comparable 1990 levels.
"Continued improvement in our export performance," he asserted, "will add impetus to the economic recovery in the months ahead." The April advance was $1.6 billion, or 4.5 percent higher than in March.
But some economists, including Harald B. Malmgren, a Washington consultant specializing in trade issues, expressed concern that exports had not been even more robust.
 
Improvement Slows Down
 "The rate of improvement of exports is slowing down," Mr. Malmgren said, contending this important engine of economic recovery as envisioned by the Bush Administration "already looks like it's running out of fuel" because of a slowdown in other countries and a rising dollar.
Imports rose an even sharper $2.2 billion, or 5.9 percent, but at $40.3 billion remained nearly 10 percent below the October 1990 peak. Recession significantly curbed demand for imported tools.
Economists also took encouragement from the broad-based nature of the export gain, which came at a time that the economies of several of the nation's main trade partners are slowing or are already mired in recession.
Exports of capital goods rose $900 million in April; automotive vehicles, parts and engines, $500 million; industrial supplies and materials, $300 million.
"There's stil a demand for U.S. products," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch.
Declines of about $100 million were posted for exports of foods, feeds and beverages and other merchandise, with consumer goods about unchanged.
Among imports, industrial supplies and materials rose $900 million; capital goods and consumer goods each rose $500 million; foods, feeds and beverages rose $300 million, and automotive goods rose $100 million.
The nation's oil bill, meanwhile, climbed moderately to $4 billion, a level equal to 83 percent of the trade deficit. Higher volumes more than offset a 75-cent-a-barrel decline in the cost of crude.
The American trade deficit with Japan narrowed to $3.3 billion from $3.6 billion, the shrinkage equal to reduced imports of Japanese motor vehicles, the Commerce Department report also showed.
 
Wider Deficit With China
 But the deficit grew with China, a country with which the Bush Administration seeks to renew most-favored-nation trade status over the objection of many in Congress. The complaints involve Chinese labor practices as well as political repression.
The amount by which United Status purchases of Chinese goods exceeded American sales to China was $670 million, up from $500 million in March. So far this year the deficit totals $2.9 billion, compared with $2.5 billion in the first four months of 1990.
The American surplus with Western Europe shrank to $2.1 billion from $3.2 billion, and the surplus with the Soviet Union eased to $250 million from $385 million. The deficit with Canada eased about $100 million but the deficit with the newly indistrialized countries of the Far East nearly tripled to $765 million.
 
Advanced Technology Products
 In advanced-technology products, the surplus narrowed $300 million, to $3.4 billion, as exports fell off more than imports.
Before adjustment for weather and other seasonal factors, the overall April deficit was $3.7 billion, compared with $1.9 billion in March. When seasonally adjusted but with dollar values held constant, the April deficit widened to $4.3 billion from $3.3 billion.
By still another gauge, the seasonally adjusted current-dollar deficit when calculated on a three-month moving average improved for the fifth straight time at $4.8 billion, half the November peak.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Headquarters Change For General Dynamics

 BODY:
The General Dynamics Corporation said yesterday that it would shift its headquarters from St. Louis to the Washington area, a move that is likely to cost St. Louis more prestige than dollars.
The company, the nation's second-largest military contractor, said the decision made sense in light of the heightened competition among contractors as the Pentagon cuts costs. While no specific location has been determined, the company said it was considering sites in suburban Virginia and Maryland. 
 "With the end of the cold war and increasing pressure on the Federal budget, the defense industry of the future will be characterized by reduced Government spending and increased competition," said William A. Anders, the chairman. "Consequently, we believe that the company can operate more effectively by having our headquarters and our leadership closer to our principal customers and policy makers."
The change comes amid considerable strife for General Dynamics and for the miltary industry.
Last year, General Dynamics lost $578 million, or $13.86 a share, on revenues of $10.2 billion after taking a $700 million charge on the A-12 Avenger attack plane, which was canceled by the Navy.
The move, to be completed by the fall, will affect a small number of the company's 90,000 employees. About 275 people work in the St. Louis headquarters, with only 115 to be transferred. Thirty people will stay in St. Louis, General Dynamics said, and the rest are being encouraged to remain during the transition.
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the nation's largest military contractor, is also based in St. Louis but is unlikely to follow General Dynamics. McDonnell Douglas has its main manufacturing operations in St. Louis.
Analysts said they were not surprised by General Dynamics' plans. "Their motives are to be nearer Congress and the Pentagon, where most of their business comes from," said George Shapiro, an analyst with Salomon Brothers in New York. "There's really no reason for them to be in St. Louis."
Don Kling, a spokesman for the Missouri Economic Development Department, said that while he would not like to see General Dynamics leave, the economic loss to St. Louis would be negligible.

HEADLINE: Trenton Set to Debate Bills on Citizen Lawmaking

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 19

 BODY:
The New Jersey Senate is set to take up legislation on Thursday that would sharply alter the way the state makes laws by allowing citizens to enact or repeal laws through initiative and referendum, a concept with strong grass-roots support in this legislative election year.
Initiative and referendum, "I & R" in statehouse shorthand, has developed into a major political issue in the wake of anger over Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase last year. Both Democrats and Republicans have introduced bills that would allow the Constitution to be amended to allow citizen legislation. 
 Assemblyman Robert D. Franks, the state Republican chairman and sponsor of one of the bills, said the issue was "the cornerstone of our efforts" in the legislative elections in November, in which all 80 seats in the Assembly and all 40 in the Senate will be on the ballot, which occurs only once every 10 years.
The issue drew important support when the Senate majority leader, Daniel J. Dalton, a powerful Democrat, introduced his own bill.
 
Calling for Action
 "It's time for those who say they support I & R to back up their words with action," he said in discussing the bill to be debated on Thursday. Legislation would have to be passed by late July for the matter to be put on the November ballot.
The Senate President, John A. Lynch, is not a co-sponsor of the bill but he said he could support the idea of initiative and referendum if it could be enacted in a way that would not "be disruptive to the state's government and to its economy."
In the past, the debate has largely split along party lines, with Republicans supporting the citizen lawmaking and Democrats opposed. But Mr. Lynch, regarded as second only to the Governor in legislative power in Trenton, said, "I & R is not a partisan issue and has proponents and opponents on both sides."
Governor Florio is on record as opposing initiative and referendum as "contrary to the principle of representative government," but does not have the authority to veto legislation that amends the Constitution.
 
First Proposed in 1976
 Both inititiative and referendum are forms of popular vote to pass or repeal legislation. Broadly speaking, an initiative proposes a new law and a referendum repeals or upholds an existing one.
Initiative and referendum is not a new issue in the state. The Republican Party has included it in its platform for over a decade, and measures establishing citizen lawmaking have passed one house or the other in the Legislature, but never both, three times since it was first proposed in 1976.
Past efforts have foundered for several reasons:
*Business and industry generally fear that voters would shift taxes from personal-income taxes and property taxes to increased taxes on businesses and corporations. The New Jersey Chamber of Commerce is among those opposed.
*South Jersey legislators fear that the more populous north could dominate legislation, keeping plums like new roads and parks for itself and shifting burdens like prisons and incinerators southward. All the bills before the Legislature include provisions aimed at avoiding such imbalances. They include banning any initiative dealing with the placement of trash incinerators and giving small counties equal weight with large ones in offering initiatives.
*Wary legislators and officials fear that their ability to impose taxes or raise fees could be blocked by citizens with legislative power. Proponents point out that citizens in California and Massachusetts voted just last fall to impose taxes on themselves.
*Even those who support the idea in principle, like Senator Lynch, are wary of "a smorgasbord on the ballot" generated by special interests with the money to pay agencies to gather signatures, which occurs regularly in California, the most active state for citizen lawmaking. New Jersey's proposals would require far more signatures to put an issue on the ballot and would forbid hiring agents to gather signatures. The Dalton bill would require 15 percent of the electorate for an initiative and 10 for a referendum; California requires only 5 percent for either.
 
Citizen Lawwmaking in the West
 Last year, California had 28 propositions on the ballot, only six of which were approved.
The concept of government through initiative and referendum has a long history in the West. Eighteen of the 26 states that allow citizen lawmaking are west of the Mississippi River.
East of the Mississippi, only Arkansas, the District of Columbia, Florida, Illinois, Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan and Ohio empower citizens to inititate statewide legislation, according to the Free Congress Foundation, a Washington public-policy study group that monitors inititative and referendum in the states.
Some states allow direct initiative, others indirect. Direct proposals go directly onto the ballot; indirect proposals must first go to the state legislature for action. If the legislature does not approve the legislation offered in the petition, it then goes on the ballot in the next election.
 
Simple Majority Required
 Once an issue is on the ballot, it is generally accepted or rejected by a simple majority of voters in the case of action that falls short of amending the constitution, like, for example, a measure to ban smoking in government buildings. In some states, constitutional amendment requires a higher percentage of the votes.
The Dalton bill, considered the most likely to go to a vote by the Democratic-controlled legislature, as well as the Republican alternative, provide for indirect methods of passing or repealing legislation.
That means that once a proposal is endorsed by a petition with the required number of signatures it would then go to the Legislature for consideration before being offered to the people in a popular vote. The Dalton bill would require the signatures of 15 percent of registered voters, with approval required in every one of the state's 21 counties to avoid dominance by populous counties.
If the Legislature fails to pass the proposal -- a cut in taxes, for example -- within a certain period, the measure then would go on the next statewide ballot, and if approved by a majority, it would become law.
A major sticking point in the law offered by Senator Dalton is that it gives the Legislature a full year to consider a proposal before it goes on the ballot. The Republican alternative provides only six months.
Phyllis Elston, a lobbyist for Hands Across New Jersey, a statewide tax protest group and a major supporter of initiative and referendum, said that a yearlong wait would be unnacceptable.
"We might prefer no law at all to that," she said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Rise on Short-Term Issues

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Falling stock prices in the United States and Japan helped to push up prices of short-term Treasury securities yesterday, as investors bailed out of equities and sought a haven in highly liquid Treasury issues.
But the drop in equities did not provide much of a lift for bond prices. 
 "People can't buy enough of issues with maturities of five years or less," one government bond trader said. "And a lot of that may be due to what has been going on in the stock market."
A big drop in Tokyo stocks, with the Nikkei index falling by 2.75 percent overnight, provided an early spur for Treasury prices. The decline in the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell just over 1 percent, provided further incentive to move into Treasuries.
 
Federal Reserve Report
 Traders said release of a report from the Federal Reserve Board's regional banks had little impact.
The report, known as the "beige book," showed that economic conditions across the country improved somewhat in the six-week period ended June 10. At the same time, the report said that most commercial banks remained reluctant to make new loans.
People might have expected the beige book "to be a bit more bearish," the trader said. "But the fact that there was mention of continued credit problems helped offset that."
Michael J. Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc., said the report "was more upbeat than I thought it would be." He added: "It is pretty clear the banks were seeing signs of recovery. Retail sales rose, manufacturing activity picked up and housing demand continued to strengthen."
On the negative side, the report said that despite a pickup in demand for home mortgages, bank lending "continues to be weak."
 
Mortgage Financing Demand
 Indeed, most of the increase in demand for mortgage financing stemmed from homeowners seeking to refinance existing mortgages rather than those looking to buy a home. Business and consumer loan demand is weak, the report said.
Corporations may be eschewing bank borrowing, but new debt issuance by highly rated companies remains strong. Yesterday eight investment-grade borrowers offered investors more than $1 billion in new debt securities.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 95 29/32, up 3/32, to yield 8.50 percent, down from 8.51 percent late Tuesday.
"The failure of bonds to benefit from the bad news on the equity front reflects investor skepticism of claims that the upcoming recovery will be mild enough to allow inflation to engage in an extended decline," said John G. Lonski, senior economist at Moody's Investors Service.
Such concerns were not visible in the secondary markets for Treasury notes and bills.
By late in the day, the 7 5/8 percent five-year notes were offered at a price of 98 14/32, up 1/32, to yield 8.17 percent. And the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 3/4, up 1/8 point, to yield 6.88 percent.
The Treasury announced yesterday that on Tuesday it will sell $12.5 billion worth of new two-year securities, to be followed on Wednesday with an auction of $9.25 billion worth of new five-year notes.
Following the announcement the two-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.96 percent. The five-year notes were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 7.94 percent.
The decline in equity prices helped to push down rates on short-term Treasury bills.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.55 percent, down five basis points, or five one-hundreths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.74 percent. One-year bill rates also fell by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.94 percent.
Among the investment-grade companies that priced new issues yesterday was the Dayton Hudson Corporation, which sold $100 million worth of 30-year bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The 9.70 percent bonds, which mature June 15, 2021, were priced at $100, or par, 1.18 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The First Boston Corporation acted as lead manager for an offering of $250 million worth of 10-year securities for Houston Industries, parent company of Houston Power and Light.
The 9 3/8 percent notes were priced at $99.574, to yield 9.44 percent, 1.10 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.
The focus of activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds centered around Columbia Gas System Inc., a leading supplier of natural gas to utilities in the Northeast.
Columbia's surprise announcement yesterday that it was suspending dividend payments and might seek bankruptcy court protection caused traders to push down sharply prices on Columbia's outstanding debt issues.
For example, bids on a 9 percent issue due to mature in 1993 plummeted by more than 12 points, pushing yields on the securities above 16.50 percent. But traders said that few securities actually changed hands.
Commercial paper traders said that the market for the company's short-term obligations vanished after the announcement. Columbia has about $715 million in total short-term debt, of which some $180 million is commercial paper.
"When the news came over, we all looked at each other and said there is no way that stuff is going to trade," one commercial paper trader said.
Away from Columbia, corporate bond traders said that prices of most issues rose by 1/8 point to 1/4 point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged on the day.

HEADLINE: Borrowing for F.D.I.C. Backed by House Panel

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
The House Banking Committee today took the first step down the road to another costly taxpayer bailout. As the first part of broader banking legislation, it completed a measure that will allow the fund that protects depositors in the nation's banks to borrow more heavily from the Treasury.
The loan, of up to $25 billion on top of the $5 billion in taxpayer dollars now available to the fund, is intended to be repaid by the banking industry over the next decade. But neither the lawmakers nor the White House are sure the banks will regain enough strength over the next few years to pay it back. 
 A vote by the committee on the banking legislation is still more than a week away, but no opposition to the borrowing provision was raised today, another sign of the emerging consensus in Congress that a taxpayer loan is the best approach.
 
Fund Eroding Steadily
 The fund protects deposits of up to $100,000 and has been financed by annual bank contributions. It has been steadily deteriorating from the growing number of large and small bank failures. By some accounts, it is already nearing insolvency. While the vast majority of the nation's 12,900 banks remain profitable, a growing number of large institutions are beset by troubled loans.
The extension of the fund's borrowing authority has been attached to a proposal by the Bush Administration that would radically alter the banking landscape. It would permit banks to enter new businesses like securities and insurance, open branches more freely across state lines and be owned by industrial companies.
The lawmakers, feeling pressure from voters who are already being asked to pay for the highly unpopular savings and loan bailout, began today's drafting session in a somber mood, clearly concerned about the prospect of a repeat performance.
 
Impact on Economy
 There was also a strong recognition by the lawmakers that the action by the committee and Congress would have consequences that would be felt by the economy long into the future.
"This is one of the most important days in the history of the banking committee," said Representative Chalmers P. Wylie, Republican of Ohio, the committee's ranking minority member.
Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who heads the committee, said: "What we must do is undertake not only to resuscitate the deposit insurance system, but to set about the task of creating a structure that enables banks to survive and prosper in this new and dangerous world of high technology, integrated world markets and extreme competition. This is not an easy task."
The insurance fund now has the authority to borrow up to $5 billion from the Treasury as well as nine times the fund's net worth for "working capital" that theoretically is to be repaid through the sale of assets of failed banks.
 
Relying on Borrowings
 Officials from the insurance corporation have said they have begun relying upon Treasury borrowings since the $2.5 billion failure of the Bank of New England in January.
The White House had sought an increase in borrowing authority of $70 billion: $25 billion to cover bank losses and $45 billion to be used as working capital.
The legislation before the banking committee does not specify the amount that could be borrowed for working capital, but bases it instead on a formula that it not exceed the total of the fund's cash, 90 percent of the market value of its assets from collapsed banks and the $30 billion credit line for losses.
While there is strong support in the House and the Senate for the borrowing provision, the other elements of the Bush Administration's proposal face considerable obstacles.
 
Package Draws Criticism
 Indeed, the package as a whole has already drawn opposition from Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, which will consider it after the banking committee has completed its work.
The package was also criticized today by Senator Donald W. Riegle, the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee. In a speech on the Senate floor, Mr. Riegle raised objections to expanding the power of banks to enter new businesses.
Mr. Riegle also said that it might already be too late for Congress to avoid a taxpayer bailout of banks.
"Any suggestion that the adoption of the Administration's broad bill will provide an immediate cure for the banking industry or rebuild the bank insurance fund is highly misleading and inaccurate," said Mr. Riegle, referring to the repeated assertions by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady that a bailout could be averted if the Administration's legislation was adopted. "Legislation cannot turn water into wine and no legislation -- not my bill, not the Administration's bill, not anybody's -- can restore value to assets the marketplace has now written down to much lower levels."
 
Other House Moves
 In other action today, the House Banking Committee approved by voice vote a measure sponsored by Representative John W. Cox, Democrat of Illinois, that would give the deposit insurance corporation the authority to borrow money from banks instead of the Treasury. The measure was denounced as "smoke and mirrors" by Mr. Gonzalez because it would be more expensive for the F.D.I.C. to borrow from the industry than from the Government.
By a vote of 28 to 23, the committee also approved a measure sponsored by Representative Richard E. Neal, Democrat of Massachusetts, requiring banks to disclose to regulators the amount of commercial loans made to small businesses, minority businesses and small farms. Mr. Neal said the measure was intended to assist regulators and lawmakers in keeping track of such loans, but opponents of the measure said it was intended to have Congress manage banks by encouraging them to make more such loans.

HEADLINE: Bush to Lift South Africa Sanctions Soon

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
Anticipating a strong challenge in Congress, the Administration intends to certify in the next few weeks that South Africa has met the legal requirements for the lifting of American economic sanctions and then hopes to end the restrictions by mid-July, officials said today.
The officials described President Bush as eager to lift the curbs against Pretoria, which he has often called ineffective, as soon as possible. 
 The 1986 law that imposed the restrictions set five conditions for lifting them and the Bush Administration's position is that South Africa has now met four of the conditions with the repeal Monday of the law that classified South Africans by race. That leaves a final condition, the release of South African political prisoners.
Despite their interest in ending the sanctions, the President and his aides are wrestling with the domestic politics of the move, expecting strong Congressional opposition. They are also grappling with the delicate diplomacy of dealing with the African National Congress, which maintains that there are still many political prisoners.
Administration officials said the United States wants to make its own accounting of prisoners and is determined not to be bound by the congress's accounting. "We have to make our own decision and can't be influenced by what other groups want us to do," a senior official said.
 
Crucial Meeting of South Africans
 But the officials said the Administration has concluded that it cannot move to lift the sanctions against South Africa until after a meeting of the African National Congress scheduled early next month.
By then, officials said, Washington hopes to have accounted for all the jailed South Africans that fall into the American definition of political prisoners. Officials also hope that by then, they will see the results of consultations between the African National Congress and the South African Government on the prisoner issue.
"The key is the A.N.C. meeting," one official said. "We don't want to lift the sanctions with some conditions attached to them, or have the A.N.C. bash us for it after their meeting if their figures on political prisoners don't agree with ours.
"The idea is to talk to everyone about it and get our ducks lined up in advance. By the time the A.N.C. meeting ends, we should have our own work done and be in a position to lift the sanctions if all goes well."
Mr. Bush seemed sure to get an endorsement for ending the restrictions on trade and other commerce when he meets Thursday with Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, the South African leader of the Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom Party, who has been urging the lifting of sanctions.
Chief Buthelezi said today that the sanctions have contributed to poverty and violence among South African blacks. "This is the time to lift them," he said in an interview on "The MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour," adding, "The devastation they have caused is far too much. I don't think it was the aim of the United States to punish our people."
 
Lobbying in Washington
 But the President is already facing opposition from lawmakers, including the Congressional Black Caucus and anti-apartheid lobbying groups, who are arguing that sanctions should be left in place until a new South African constitution is in place giving blacks the right to vote. Should Mr. Bush lift the sanctions as anticipated, Congress would have 30 days under the 1986 law to overturn his decision.
The constitutional right to vote was not one of the five conditions for lifting the sanctions written into the 1986 law. The Bush Administration's position is that with the repeal on Monday of the last major anti-apartheid law, the Population Registration Act, South Africa has met four of those conditions and that all that remains is the freeing of political prisoners.
The dispute over South African political prisoners centers on those who do not fall easily into the American definition of prisoners of conscience, ones who were convicted of crimes against people or property that they say were connected with their political activity. Estimates on the number of such prisoners range from 100 to 600.

HEADLINE: Kohl Says West Has a Duty to Step Up Aid to Former East Bloc

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, June 19

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said today that "all Western countries" had a responsibility to provide greater economic aid to the Soviet Union and the former Communist countries of Eastern Europe to help them make the transition to free markets. But it is unclear whether Bonn is willing to go much beyond the money it has already committed to the Soviet Union and the former East Germany.
Addressing a group of foreign ministers from the United States, Canada and Europe who are taking part for the first time in a post-cold war session of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, Mr. Kohl said of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union: "Additional assistance is needed to bolster the necessary transformation in the reformist countries, and I would emphasize that this assistance must come from all Western countries. It will be help toward self-help. We know that this is a worthwhile investment in peace and stability."
 
Germany's Own Burden
 The Germans are already committed to giving about $31 billion in grants and credits to the Soviet Union, in part because of Moscow's assent to the unification of Germany. But Bonn, faced with mounting costs in eastern Germany, has recently appeared wary of further large-scale aid programs. 
 Mr. Kohl's appeal is part of the diplomatic maneuvering that has begun among the Group of Seven major industrialized democracies in advance of their meeting next month in London with the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
The United States, Canada, Japan, Germany, France, Italy and Britain are trying to reach a consensus on what if anything to offer the Soviet leader, provided that he agrees to move ahead with free-market and democratic reforms.
It was announced today that the Finance Ministers from the seven countries would meet in London on Sunday, in part to coordinate their positions. New York had been considered a possible site of the meeting.
 
U.S. Shows No Enthusiasm
 Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, in a speech to the Aspen Institute in Berlin on Tuesday, outlined some primarily technical aid programs that the Bush Administration is prepared to offer Mr. Gorbachev if he starts down the path toward "serious" economic change. But the United States, unlike Germany, is markedly unenthusiastic about any vast financial aid to the Soviet Union.
The Bush Administration argues that technical assistance to help the Soviet Union tap its own substantial resources through market incentives is preferable to cash aid, which it has no intention of providing right now.
Many Democrats in Congress are arguing that if the reform process in the Soviet Union is to be stable, Moscow will need the same sort of financial safety net that the West provided Poland -- and that this would mean a commitment of cash.
German officials say they have no intention of dictating what contribution the United States or other countries should make to Soviet change. But Chancellor Kohl and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher have privately been urging the Bush Administration to be as generous as possible, provided that Mr. Gorbachev reciprocates with genuine reform.
 
Prospect of Refugees
 The Germans say they are motivated by concern that any economic or political chaos in the Soviet Union could become a pressing problem for them, given the prospect of thousands of refugees spilling westward.
German officials view Mr. Gorbachev as an exceptional figure who was prepared to take the politically risky steps that ultimately paved the way for German unification. Bonn feels it is indebted to him and has an interest in preserving his position in power.
Of the $31 billion that the Germans have already committed to Moscow, roughly $8.5 billion has gone toward removing the Soviet Army from East Germany by providing housing and other aid for Soviet soldiers returning home by the end of 1994. The rest involves loans, grants and credits.
 
Challenge in Eastern Germany
 German officials argue that they have already given as much as they can afford to, since they are also spending billions of dollars on bringing the former East Germany up to Western economic standards. They would like to see other Western allies making similar commitments to Moscow in aid, grants, or technical assistance.
"We in Germany know from our own experience that the transition from a centralized command economy to democracy, rule of law and social market economy is long and difficult," Mr. Kohl said, referring to the unemployment and low productivity in the former East German states.
"The huge challenge we are facing in the new federal states foreshadows the problems that the nations of Central and Eastern Europe, including the Soviet Union, will have to cope with," he said. "Their transition to democracy and a market economy demands courage, patience and a strong predisposition for change -- not the least on the part of the people."
The main effort will have to come from the East European nations and Soviet Union, Mr. Kohl said, "but it is in the interest of all C.S.C.E. members that the reforming countries achieve success and that another gulf does not emerge in Europe -- this time through economic disparity."
 
Invitation to Albania
 At the meeting today of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, the foreign minsters of the United States, Canada and Europe invited Albania to join the organization after its new Government promised to honor the principles of democracy, human rights and market economics.
Albania's Foreign Minister, Muhamet Kapllani, took his seat at the conference table after declaring that his Government accepted the 1974 Helsinki Final Act, which set minimum standards for human rights in Europe. The Albanians were required to include members of the country's political opposition in their official delegation. Mr. Baker is to visit Albania on Friday.
Albania became the 35th European state to join the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which produced the Helsinki accords. The organization is becoming an increasingly important mechanism for bringing together the newly emerging democracies of Eastern Europe with those of Western Europe and North America.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Costs of 'Grand Bargain'
 WASHINGTON, June 19 (Special to The New York Times) -- A Harvard economics professor told a Senate panel today that a proposed $120 billion Western aid package for the Soviet economy would cost the Federal Government as little as $3 billion a year for five years.
After testifying before the Senate Subcommittee on European Affairs, the professor, Jeffrey Sachs, said in an interview that other countries and lending agencies like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank could be counted on to provide the rest of the money for the aid package.
Mr. Sachs is a prominent member of the group of Soviet and American economists who drafted the so-called "grand bargain," a proposal to link vast Western aid to broad reforms of the Soviet economy. He is the first member of the group to offer detailed figures on how the costs of the plan would be covered. He emphasized that he was providing his own estimates and that the group had not reached an agreement on who should pay.
Mr. Sachs said that Japan could be expected to contribute $2 billion to $3 billion a year if 24 Western industrialized countries all agreed to give aid. If only a few large countries took part in a large aid program, Japan might be asked to give $3 billion to $5 billion annually, he said.
Virtually all of the aid outlined in the "grand bargain" would come in addition to economic assistance previously pledged by governments and multilateral agencies.

HEADLINE: Saga of Milken's 'Dream' (Don't Hunt for Warts)

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 19

 BODY:
Michael R. Milken is in jail. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is in bankruptcy. The "junk bond" market is in disarray.
But to a loyal former aide to Mr. Milken, and to companies like Safeway Stores, MCI Communications and dozens of others that were financed by junk bonds issued through Drexel, the benefits of the high-yield, high-risk securities and the financial genius of Mr. Milken live on. 
 That, at least, is the theme of a new book and a series of flashy dioramas on Drexel-backed companies that are scheduled to be unveiled Thursday night in Los Angeles at what could be the largest gathering of former junk-bond clients since Drexel's last "Predator's Ball" in 1989.
 
Propaganda or 'Clarion Call'?
 Developed over the last several years, in large part with Mr. Milken's own money, the project could be viewed either as an audacious piece of pro-Milken propaganda or, as the book's dust jacket puts it, an "evocative and clarion call of affirmation" for the values of entrepreneurship and the American business spirit.
The book, "Portraits of the American Dream," was researched and written largely by freelance writers and public relations executives hired by Mr. Milken to help burnish his image prior to his guilty plea on securities-law violations last year. Its development was overseen by Lorraine C. Spurge, a former executive of Drexel's junk-bond department in Beverly Hills, Calif., who has long been close to Mr. Milken and who dedicated the book to him.
"He had the vision, energy and courage to open a closed system so entrepreneurs -- regardless of race, creed or color -- with ability and a dream to go into business could test themselvesin the marketplace," the book's dedication says of Mr. Milken, who is currently serving a 10-year prison term. "He understood that the most important form of capital is human capital."
The dedication concludes, "In factories, offices, homes and communities across the nation, the strength of his vision endures."
The book's 400 pages and plentiful illustrations profile 146 companies financed through Mr. Milken's junk-bond department during the last decade. The book, which also includes essays by the actor Jimmy Stewart and Peter Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner, extols the role of those companies in creating new jobs and fueling the nation's economic growth.
Somehow, no room was left in the book to mention workers who lost their jobs after Drexel-financed takeovers, the savings institutions and insurance companies damaged by heavy purchases of junk bonds or the default of many Drexel issues.
As the book's dust jacket puts it, " 'Portraits of the American Dream' is no apologia."
 
Excuse for a Reunion
 It is, however, an excuse for the reunion of former Drexel clients. The reception, to benefit Junior Achievement of Southern California, is to have as its co-host Peter A. Magowan, the chairman of Safeway, which went private several years ago with the help of Drexel's junk bonds. A press release said the event would be attended by chief executives and employees of the 146 companies profiled in the book. But it was unclear which companies would actually show up.
The companies profiled in the book include MCI, which is headed by William G. McGowan; Time Warner Inc., headed by Steven J. Ross, and NL Industries, headed by Harold C. Simmons, the corporate raider.
To Ms. Spurge, the book is a long-awaited chance to tell the positive side of what Mr. Milken and Drexel accomplished and to celebrate the drive and hard work behind the growth of American businesses.
"For five years, we didn't talk," Ms. Spurge said, referring to Mr. Milken and his closest associates. "Now it's time for us to talk and to talk about going forward."
But one of the book's writers, Mary G. Gotschall, described the book in more cynical terms.
"One of the things we tried to do in the book was to highlight the instances in which junk bonds had benefited minority- and women-owned companies," Ms. Gotschall wrote in the January issue of Regardies magazine, a Washington business publication. "It was true that you could find a handful of minorities and women who'd prospered thanks to junk bonds, as had many other worthy companies, big and small.
"But the larger story that we carefully omitted from the book -- and that was evident as we sifted through the pages of research on the various companies we were profiling -- was that many of the bonds were going sour," wrote Ms. Gotschall, a former employee of Robinson, Lake, Lerer & Montgomery, a public relations firm that represents Mr. Milken.
Another subject to be avoided, Ms. Gotschall wrote, was "the number of junk bonds that were controlled by a relative handful of corporate titans, and how the bonds had helped them to concentrate their power."
 
Milken Gets a Copy
 Ms. Spurge said she had sent a copy of the book to Mr. Milken at the Federal Correctional Facility in Pleasanton, Calif. "He's satisfied because I'm satisfied," she said of his response.
She said she and Mr. Milken had paid most of the costs of the book, including $1.2 million to print 10,000 copies. Ms. Spurge set up Knowledge Exchange Inc. in Drexel's old offices in Beverly Hills to sell the book to the companies profiled and to anyone else interested.
In this financial transaction, Mr. Milken's former clients will get a better deal than the public: $75 a copy, at least initially, but $100 for anyone without connections to the financier.
Ms. Spurge said 30 percent of the proceeds would go to Junior Achievement, a group that promotes interest in business among teen-agers. The book will not be available in stores.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bank South Chief Quits

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTA, June 19

 BODY:
The chairman and chief executive of the Bank South Corporation resigned today, two months after shareholders complained about the bank's losses.
After the resignation of Robert P. Guyton, Bank South's directors named John C. Wilson as interim chief executive pending selection of a permanent successor. 
 Mr. Wilson is president and chief executive of the Multimart Corporation, an Atlanta-based international marketing company. He is the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta.
Bank South also appointed Lynn H. Johnston acting chairman. Mr. Johnston is also chairman and chief executive of the Life Insurance Company of Georgia.
The bank's executives said Mr. Guyton offered his resignation early today because he was ready to move on, not because of heat the bank has taken over its recent performance.
Last year, Bank South lost $2.4 million, and its fourth-quarter net income totaled $8.4 million, down 43 percent from a year earlier. In April, Bank South reported a net income of $5.6 million for the first quarter, compared with a net of $11.5 million a year ago.
"I believe we have passed through our hard times," Mr. Guyton said in a statement. "The economy appears to be moving out of the recession and that should allow Bank South to make continued progress at a faster pace."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Interim Chief At Fibreboard

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 19

 BODY:
The Fibreboard Corporation said today that it had appointed an interim president and chief executive and an interim chairman to replace Lawrence C. Hart, who resigned from the positions on Tuesday.
The company, based in Concord, Calif., said that James D. Costello, who had been vice president of wood products, would be the interim president and chief executive and that Philip R. Bogue, a member of the board, would be the interim chairman. 
 The company said it was continuing its search for a chief executive.
Mr. Hart had said in April that he would leave the forest- products company, which has been hurt by the recession.
Fibreboard also said that it would close a plant in Roxboro, N.C.. on July 3 unless a buyer was found and that it would record an estimated $19 million pretax charge in the second quarter. The plant employs 230 people and makes lumber products.
The company said it was in discussions with several potental buyers for the plan.

HEADLINE: WNET, Citing Aid Loss, Plans to Cut Staff And Broadcast Hours

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
WNET, the largest public television station serving New York, announced the biggest budget cuts in its history yesterday, caused in part, station executives said, by what it called a devastating reduction in the allocation for the station in the proposed New York State budget.
Among the actions planned to save about $11 million, the station plans to dismiss 69 employees, eliminate 9 positions at the senior vice president level and to go dark for 12 hours each weekend. 
 None of the programs the station produces for national distribution on the Public Broadcasting Service, including "Great Performances" and "Nature," will be affected, station executives said, because they are financed by outside sources. But the executives said some future projects that might have been backed by discretionary funds may not go forward. WNET produces about 30 percent of the national Public Broadcasting Service programs.
 
Hard Times Ahead
 Bruce Christiansen, the president of PBS, said that other public television stations, including those in Boston and Los Angeles, were facing similar financial problems but that the situation in New York "is not an indicator of a national trend for public television."
"We're in a down cycle right now in regards to some of the stations with state funding," he said. "But we've been in these cycles before. They reflect the tightness of the economy in these states."
William F. Baker, the president of WNET, Channel 13, said the cuts at the station were a reflection of the difficult economic circumstances facing both the country and the area. Public and corporate contributions have been flat for two years, he said, while the costs of operating the station have continued to rise.
On top of these problems, the budget presented by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed a 50 percent reduction in the allocation to the station, to just under $5 million for the station's new fiscal year from $9.8 million, a change that begins today.
George Miles, the chief operating office of Channel 13, said that the station had been working for nine months on a budget-reduction plan and that the news of the cut in the state allocation "hit us like a blow to the chest." "Some of the 69 people we are letting go surely would not have been laid off if we hadn't lost the state money," he said.
 
Station 'Not Optimistic'
 Though the cut in the state allocation was not yet official, Mr. Miles said the station was "not optimistic" that any of Channel 13's money would be restored. He cited an effort by the state legislature to restore $2 million in the budget it sent back to the Governor, which Mr. Cuomo cut again in a line-item veto.
"Devastating is the real word for the effect of the state cut," Mr. Baker said. "Governor Cuomo is in the same spot we're in. We understand that. I'm not going to pick on Mr. Cuomo. We need him as a friend."
Mr. Baker said the budget duress had compelled the station's executives to "completely rethink how a nonprofit organization should operate." Among the decisions was that educational programs would receive the highest priority and that local programming would still be produced in some form.
So the station will continue to produce educational programs for use in area high schools and will run many of these in the hours from midnight to 6 A.M., when teachers record them for later use in the classroom. But all the programming Channel 13 has been carrying from midnight to 6 A.M. on Saturday and Sunday nights will be eliminated.
Channel 13 currently broadcasts two half-hour local programs a day, "Thirteen Live," and "Live Wire." Mr. Baker said the station would preserve some local production though it would probably consolidate the two shows into one.
Reorganizing the staff was the only way to save a significant amount of money, Mr. Baker said. Executive salaries, which averaged from $80,000 to $100,000 a year, were the most logical target for the cuts, he said.
In the new structure, four vice presidents, who were formerly senior vice presidents, will take on additional duties, while three other senior vice presidents will be dismissed. The other two senior vice presidents may be offered other positions, Mr. Baker said. None of those dismissed were identified yesterday.
The station will also cut back its program guide from a monthly to a quarterly publication to save on postage.
The budget-cutting decisions were made yesterday morning after a meeting of the station's board of directors. The news was kept from employees for much of the day. Mr. Baker said: "The shock is rolling down the halls. Nobody expected it to be this deep."
Overall, Mr. Baker said the station would have to get by with less supervision. "But we don't want the quality of our programming to slip," he said. "I know we're taking a lot of risks, but what choice did we have? We are not going to allow this station to go into the red."

HEADLINE: If It Gallops or Waltzes, License It!

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
Some 5,000 people jammed into the New York Hilton Tuesday to chase turtles. The task was harder than it sounds.
The species involved was Teenage Mutant Ninja, whose likenesses have helped sell more than $1 billion worth of clothing, toys and movie tickets in the last five years. Their would-be emulators included the owners of cartoon characters, sports teams and thousands of other properties, all hoping to lease their names or logos to the consumer-product manufacturers who were also prowling the Hilton's halls. 
 All of them wanted a part of the nearly $67 billion market for licensed goods.
Some of those attending the 11th annual International Licensing and Merchandising Conference and Exposition, which runs through today, were nearly flattened by a galloping bunch of Bart Simpson balloons. Others stopped to watch the Dancin' Grannies, an elderly aerobics troupe from Arizona that wants to put its mark on food, vitamins and action wear for the senior set, as they pranced to a recording of "Boogie-Woogie Bugle Boy of Company B." At another booth, Kilroy (of "was here" fame) peered from T-shirts and underwear.
In all, 161 exhibitors, a third more than last year, set up 356 booths to hawk their properties-for-hire. Their unabashed hucksterism belied the desultory state of the American economy and underscored many manufacturers' and retailers' belief that planting a character on a carton or clothing can provide a hedge against recession.
"In a recession, you're trying to buy some awareness, and licenses give you awareness for not a lot of added cost," said James R. Black, a vice president at Kenner Products, a Cincinnati-based toy company.
According to surveys of manufacturers and retailers by The Licensing Letter, an industry publication, $66.6 billion worth of licensed goods were sold at retail last year, nearly a fivefold increase over the $13.6 billion sold in 1981. Licensees typically pay licensors -- the owners of properties or their agents -- royalties of 5 to 10 percent of a product line's wholesale cost, said Murray Altchuler, the executive director of the International Licensing Industry Merchandisers' Association.
Some licensors and licensees have done fabulously. Major League Baseball Properties and N.F.L. Properties each sell in excess of $1 billion worth of merchandise annually, Mr. Altchuler said.
But it was the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, socially conscious reptiles that started as a countercultural comic-book creation in 1983 and last year sold $500 million worth of toys alone, that played on the hopes of those at the conference.
"The Turtle wave is about to break, and we're trying to capitalize on it," said Kenneth Freda, the director of licensing and promotion for TTC Animation Licensing, who said his Brooklyn company had invested close to $1 million developing the Toysters, who he described as "eight characters who defend the rights of toys to make kids happy."
 
Green Is the Color
 The Turtles' environmental activism generated the most competition. Green characters -- in color and in concern -- abounded. Among the new creatures being offered for license were the Toxic Crusaders, described as "environmentally informed and hideously deformed," on buttons being passed out by their creators, Troma Inc., the New York producer of "B" movies.
Earth Air Water Wear, a Tennessee company, was promoting the Frogballs, which Kim Osborne, one of their creators, said were "tree frogs in Brazil who were burned out of their homes" by developers and decided to go on "the international volleyball circuit to tell people about the environment."
Ms. Osborne punctuated her story by pulling an enormous live frog from a makeshift pond in her booth. Upon questioning, she conceded that it was not a Brazilian tree frog, but a bullfrog from Sacramento, Calif.
 
Novelty vs. Nostalgia
 Some at the show said the drive for novelty was misplaced, and maintained that the recession was pushing marketers to the tried-and-true names of yesteryear, like Bullwinkle J. Moose and Rocket J. Squirrel.
'We see the hot properties taking a rest and the classics getting stronger," said Don Ratner, the president of Natural Kids Foods, a Westlake, Calif., maker of juice boxes. Parents in their 30's and 40's fondly remember these characters, he explained, and they are being introduced to a new generation of children via cable-television reruns.
Larry Tetenbaum said he had invested more than $500,000 in his leap of faith into yesteryear. His company, Allegiance Advantage Inc. in New York, was hawking "Saints G'Lore," saints of the Roman Catholic Church redesigned in contemporary fashion for use on greeting cards, clothing and other products.
To prove the marketability of these "ordinary people who did extraordinary things," Mr. Tetenbaum pulled out charts projecting the population growth of grandparents and other groups he considers his primary targets.
In the end, though, he said market research was beside the point when it came to saints. "I believe in them," Mr. Tetenbaum proclaimed.

HEADLINE: Cost of AIDS Care in U.S. Is Seen at $5.8 Billion in '91

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FLORENCE, June 19

 BODY:
An estimated $5.8 billion will be spent this year in the United States to treat people infected with the AIDS virus, including those with the disease, a Federal health economist told an international meeting on AIDS here today. The figure is expected to rise to $10.4 billion in 1994.
While costs of treating people with AIDS have been estimated in other analyses, the new study is the first to assess the economic effect of treating both those with AIDS and those who are infected but lack symptoms, the economist, Fred J. Hellinger, said. 
 The estimated annual cost of treating a person with AIDS is $32,000 and the lifetime cost is $85,333, said Dr. Hellinger, who works for the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research in the Department of Health and Human Services. Other studies have put the lifetime costs at $40,000 to $75,000.
 
One Million With AIDS Virus
 The estimated annual cost of treating a person infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS, is $5,150. About one million people in the United States are infected with the virus.
The $5.8 billion figure represents about 0.86 percent of the $671 billion spent on health care in the United States, Dr. Hellinger said.
Previous estimates have understated the costs of medical care because they were limited to AIDS, he said. But, he added, the costs have significantly increased since people with AIDS are living longer because of the introduction of new treatments. Such therapies are being used by 25 percent of the people infected with the AIDS virus but without symptoms.
Dr. Hellinger said that Medicaid, the Federal-state health insurance program for the poor, paid 40 percent of the costs of caring for people with the virus and that private health insurers paid 40 percent. The remaining 20 percent of the cost, representing the uninsured, is often borne by hospitals that care for AIDS patients.
Dr. Hellinger said he could offer no comparative figures for other diseases. The National Cancer Institute estimates that about $35.3 billion was spent on treating all people with cancer last year in the United States. About $20,000 is spent treating a person with lung cancer over a lifetime and about $59,000 is spent treating a person with breast cancer over a lifetime.
The American Heart Association estimates that $101.3 billion was spent on treating all people with cardiovascular diseases in the United States last year. Of that, $44.5 billion was spent treating heart disease patients alone.
In his analysis, Dr. Hellinger drew on data from many studies of the costs of care for HIV in medical centers in several cities from 1984 to 1990. He said his figures could rise, depending on the use of several new costly drugs like erythropoietin for HIV.
In another report, scientists from Boston said findings from their laboratory experiments might explain how HIV begins to infect the body after sexual intercourse and might open new avenues of research toward a vaccine for AIDS. The AIDS virus is known to be transmitted in blood and through sexual intercourse. Although the route of access through blood is easily understood, scientists have been puzzled about how HIV invades the body through the genital or anal areas.
Some experts believe HIV can enter only directly through blood, like from rough sex. Others believe that the virus can enter directly through genital contact similar to the way the microbes that cause gonorrhea and syphilis do. While the mechanism for the gonorrhea and syphilis microbes is not completely known, scientists have found that certain structural components of the bacterium that causes gonorrhea allows it to attach to cells on the mucous membranes of the genital areas.
The Boston scientists found that, in laboratory experiments, a certain type of cell on the surface of mucous membranes that cover the skin in areas like the vagina, anus and urethra is sensitive to infection by very small amounts of HIV. After the cell is infected, it becomes a nonstop factory for HIV, producing large amounts of the virus without being killed. The cell is a form of white blood cell known as a dendritic cell and lives for many years.
The scientists from the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute speculated that for unknown reasons the dendritic cell may serve as a privileged site for replication of HIV, out of range of certain immune defenses and even drugs.

Group May Shun U.S. AIDS Parley
 FLORENCE, June 19 (AP) -- A group of scientists today threatened to withdraw sponsorship of next year's international meeting on AIDS, to be held in Boston, unless the United States lifted its ban on entry by people infected with the AIDS virus. The group, the International AIDS Society, made up of leading researchers on the disease, is a major sponsor of the annual conference.

HEADLINE: Natural Gas Issues Lead Retreat in Stock Market

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The stock market was battered yesterday, largely because of the poor performance of natural gas company issues.
With volume on the New York Stock Exchange a relatively low 159.7 million shares or slightly above Tuesday's 156.3 million, the few big losers weighed down all the popular indexes. In all, 414 Big Board issues advanced and 1,156 declined. 
By far the largest price drop was posted by Columbia Gas System, which announced it was omitting a dividend payment and was considering bankruptcy. Columbia Gas rallied late in the session and closed down 13 3/4, at 20 3/4. It was the most active Big Board issue, on a turnover of 4.4 million shares.
 
Dow Utility Average Falls
 Columbia's woes depressed other natural gas stocks. Consolidated Natural Gas fell 1 3/4, to 39 1/2; Panhandle Eastern, 1 1/8, to 11 1/4; Transco Energy, 1, to 32 3/8. The combined losses caused the Dow Jones utility average, which is usually linked to interest rate trends, to drop by 9.87, to 197.25, its lowest level since October.
The Dow industrial average fell 31.31, to 2,955.50; the Standard & Poor's index of 500 shares lost 3.50, at 375.09; the Big Board's composite index declined 1.85, to 205.78; the Nasdaq composite dropped 6.23, to 485.36; the American Stock Exchange's Market Value Index fell 2.67, to 364.73.
"The market was a bit shaky on overnight weakness in Tokyo stocks and subsequent follow-through selling in London and concern about this Friday's 'triple witching hour' when the news about Columbia Gas hit the screens," said William M. LeFevre, senior vice president for market strategy at Tucker Anthony Inc.
 
An Exaggerated Effect
 "While the relatively light volume in a weak market was a somewhat positive, it caused a handful of issues to have an exaggerated effect on the averages," Mr. LeFevre said. "For example, only three of the 15 stocks in the Dow utility average are natural gas companies, but we can see what clout the three -- Columbia, Consolidated and Panhandle -- had on the Dow utility average."
The triple witching hour occurs on the third Friday each June, September, December and March. That is the expiration date for the current S.& P. 500 futures, options on these futures and options on individual stocks. In the past such expiration days have caused severe price volatility in a few hours.
Yesterday, Standard & Poor's introduced a new index, based on 400 stocks with middle-range capitalization. The index moved between 124.95 and 123.34 and closed at 123.54.
In any event, the program traders who use these futures and options as prime operating tools were not much in evidence yesterday. According to Birinyi Associates, there was only one major buy program and two sell programs during the session. The programs lasted for a total of 39 minutes, and their net effect was to reduce the Dow industrial average by 5.15 points.
 
Semiconductor Stocks Decline
 While natural gas stocks dominated market news, the semiconductor sector continued to be buffeted. International Rectifier, for one, plunged 5 5/8, to 16 1/2, and was the Big Board's third-most-active issue, on a turnover of 2.3 million shares. Another weak issue in this group was Intel, which fell a further point, to 47 1/2, in over-the-counter trading .
Also weighing on the market was an increasing number of brokerage houses that are paring their estimates of corporate earnings for 1991 and next year.
Estimates of lower earnings were blamed for Procter & Gamble's falling 2 3/8, to 81, on a volume of 1.5 million shares, which placed it seventh on the Big Board list of 10 most active issues. The same factor caused Pepsico, the second most active, on 3.5 million shares, to slip 1/2, to 29 7/8.

HEADLINE: Hero in His Own Time, Yeltsin Delights Capital

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
He no longer has to come in the back door of the White House and beg to see the President. Instead of the 10 Senators he met in the fall of 1989, hundreds of members of Congress waited in line today to shake hands with the newly elected President of Russia and shower him with such gifts as a cowboy hat, a leather belt reading "Boris," and a Senator's spy novel in which he is a character.
And when Boris N. Yeltsin dropped by the Lincoln Memorial this afternoon, history teachers conducting class trips to the nation's capital gave their students an impromptu lesson about the latest Soviet star, who was known around Washington today simply by his first name. 
 "They can't pronounce his last name, so they just call him 'Boris,' " explained Linda Hudson, a 44-year-old history teacher shepherding a group of eighth and ninth graders from Dallastown Middle School in York County, Pa. "But that works out fine, because they watch 'Rocky and Bullwinkle' on cable television at home, so it's an easy mental association with Boris Badenov."
A mental association with the small, dark, oily Russian cartoon spy may not exactly be what the tall, silver-haired Russian leader had in mind for his post-victory tour of the United States, but a little name recognition is always welcome.
There was another interesting mental association in Mr. Yeltsin's choice of the Lincoln Memorial. The first popularly elected President of Russia clearly wanted to bask in the glow of American democracy, as he stood amid a throng of photographers at the base of Abraham Lincoln's feet. But it was Mr. Lincoln, after all, who pointed out the dangers of rending the fabric of a nation to resolve disputes among rivals, when he warned at the Republican state convention in 1858 that "a house divided against itself cannot stand."
As leader of the largest of the Soviet Union's restive republics, Mr. Yeltsin is the embodiment of the centrifugal forces that are threatening to rupture his country.
 
Limits of Support
 In a speech tonight at a Kennedy Center banquet in his honor, Mr Yeltsin set forth the limits of his support for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
"While Gorbachev stands for reform, while Gorbachev stands for democratic change, while Gorbachev stands for the independence of the republics, Yeltsin stands for Gorbachev," the newly elected president said through a translator.
Earlier in the day at the Lincoln Memorial, John Stewart, 13, sat on the steps aiming his camera in the air. "Do we get extra credit if we get a picture of Boris?" the youngster asked his teacher, Ms. Hudson.
"No," she replied. "You only get extra credit if you know who he is."
Mr. Yeltsin had a mission as he made his rounds today and prepared to meet with President Bush in the Oval Office on Thursday: He wanted to reverse the bad impression left from his last visit, when some of the Washington and international press accounts, which were found later to be greatly exaggerated, painted him as an inebriated and free-spending buffoon. And he wanted to ply some populist one-upsmanship on his rival, Mr. Gorbachev. "He's going to work the crowd like Gorby," the Soviet Embassy press aide, Ivan Rumyantsev, confided in photographers before the Lincoln Memorial drop-by.
 
At the Lincoln Memorial
 After a morning meeting with lawmakers on Capitol Hill, Mr. Yeltsin swept up the steps of the Lincoln Memorial with only a handful of security agents from his country and from the State Department to run interference with several hundred tourists and photographers.
Although he speaks no English, he impressed the crowd with his warm and energetic presence, using an inventive range of hand motions and facial movements to convey pleasure at the crowd's excited reception.
He raised one hand. He raised two hands. He wiggled five fingers. He gave a thumbs-up. He raised a clenched fist. He put his hand on his heart. He raised his eyebrows dramatically. He held up several small girls, judiciously dividing his hugs between blondes and brunettes.
All the twitching and wiggling and grinning seemed to work.
"The stuff with the children, that was good," said Jean Olko, 50, a media-savvy waitress from Garfield, N.J. "He's extending himself to the people."
Mr. Yeltsin also made a hit on Capitol Hill, where he urged legislators to form closer ties between the United States and the Russian Republic and where he once again sounded a conciliatory note toward Mr. Gorbachev.
On the ABC News program "Nightline" on Tuesday night, Mr. Yeltsin had switched his tone about Mr. Gorbachev from soothing to tart, complaining that the Soviet leader makes "halfhearted decisions" and waffles "first to the right, then to the left."
"To a large extent, I don't like him," Mr. Yeltsin said. "He's inconsistent. He has strength for a period of time, and then under pressure from other forces, he may change his decision. That isn't a good thing."
But in meetings with American legislators today, Mr. Yelstin tried to accent the positive, saying that he and Mr. Gorbachev were trying to work together and that Mr. Gorbachev was committed to reform.
In his speech tonight, Mr. Yeltsin cautioned the United States as it considers how much economic aid it is willing to give mr. Gorbachev. He said: "Do not finance the bureaucracy, either central or Russian. Invest in what people do for themselves."
In his earlier meetings with members of Congress, Mr. Yeltsin said that relaxing trade barriers would be welcome. He suggested that the lawmakers earmark any help for parts of the Soviet Union that are moving toward democracy, such as his republic, since any aid to "an unreformed Communist system," as he put it, would not help democracy advance.
"I think he was no doubt chastened by the experience of his first visit and he was bouyed by his recent overwhelming victory," said Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine. "It has transformed his image so that he doesn't need to go through back doors anymore. Now he's emerging as a very important personality."
Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, presented Mr. Yeltsin with a white cowboy hat and a hand tooled leather belt with "Boris" carved in the back. "The Soviets love all that cowboy stuff," said a Dole aide.
But perhaps the most ingenious gift came from Mr. Cohen, the Maine Senator who is a novelist and the author of a new spy thriller, "One-Eyed Kings," featuring Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Gorbachev as characters.
Mr. Cohen explained the plot briefly to Mr. Yeltsin, explaining that Mr. Gorbachev is overthrown, because of his inconsistency and waffling to the right and left, and that Mr. Yeltsin dies of a K.G.B.-induced heart attack while giving a speech.
When Mr. Yeltsin's interpreter got to the part about his demise, the Russian leader shook his head and waved his hand impatiently.
"Science fiction," he said, in Russian.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Boris N. Yeltsin, center right, the popularly elected President of the Russian republic, greeting American tourists yesterday at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington. "This is a great country," he said. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)
