HEADLINE: Churches Are Caught in Economy's Grip

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
Many of the nation's major Christian denominations have something in common with the Federal Government, the banking industry and the City of New York: trouble balancing their books.
Although churchgoers are putting more money than ever into the collection plates, many church leaders are staring at deficits. The Roman Catholic bishops are cutting spending, the Evangelical Lutheran Church has begun layoffs, and the Episcopal Church has instituted a hiring freeze.
 
Expenses and Inflation Cited
 These and other national church groups are reducing spending on everything from campus ministries and overseas missions to church publications and work with the aged. Expenses and inflation have outstripped the growth in giving, and local congregations are increasingly reluctant to send money to the higher levels of their churches. 
 Each religious group has its special problems, and denominations differ greatly in how they collect money and what proportion is spent through national offices. But leaders from different churches list similar causes for their financial woes.
Like industry, churches have been hurt by skyrocketing premiums for medical care plans and other insurance. Like local and state governments, they have taken on new responsibilities for the poor or homeless. Like the Federal Government, they confront grass-roots distrust of national bureaucracies.
Church leaders said that most denominations had experienced cycles of tight budgets before, but an unusual number are now facing cutbacks at the same time.
Last week, America's 300 Roman Catholic bishops held their regular spring meeting. The meeting was not open, and the delicate topic requiring secrecy was not doctrine but dollars.
Catholic dioceses across the country, many of them burdened by parishes or schools that are no longer self-supporting, have indicated an unwillingness to increase the amount they contribute to the $34 million operating budget of the national bishops' conference. So the bishops planned to cut spending for 1993 by 3 percent from current levels.
 
Rethinking Church's Mission
 For the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, the nation's fourth largest denomination, the moment of truth has already arrived. Hit with deficits at the national level for three years in a row and expecting another one this year, the 5.3-million-member denomination began laying off staff members in May and cutting programs. Church leaders said they would slice $5.2 million from a budget of $84 million through the end of the year.
Last month, the Episcopal News Service reported, "A financial crisis is sending a shudder through all levels of the Episcopal Church and forcing some serious rethinking of the church's mission in today's world." The church recently cut its national budget by 5 percent and has frozen hiring and salaries for 1991. A proposed 1992 budget would cut spending for programs and increase it only for relief efforts overseas.
Also operating under a hiring freeze are the national agencies of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), a denomination with 2.9 million members. The agencies have 20 percent fewer staff members to do the same volume of work they did 10 years ago, and further reductions through attrition are planned.
The denomination has avoided dipping into reserves only by spending less than it had initially budgeted in the last two years. But adhering to current plans would exhaust all the denomination's reserves by 1994 and cripple the church's ability to meet cash flow problems, officials said.
 
Parallels in Jewish Groups
 Even the Southern Baptist Convention, with 14.9 million members and still growing, has seen a decline in the Cooperative Program, which finances most denominational activities. In the early 1980's it was growing at about 8 to 13 percent a year, but in recent years the growth has been less than the rate of inflation.
Parallel trends are apparent in Jewish groups. Fund raising is up, especially for special needs, including the resettlement of Ethiopian and Soviet Jews in Israel. But many synagogues and agencies are facing deficits.
"Synagogues are feeling the pinch even as they try to expand their services," said Rabbi Myron Fenster, president of the New York Board of Rabbis. "Jews are still generous, but selectively generous."
Fred L. Hofheinz, program director for Religion at the Lilly Endowment in Indianapolis, said the financing of American religion has become "a matter of widespread concern" and an important area for research. "We hear one denominational executive after another saying that money is tight and more giving is designated for particular programs rather than general funds," he said. "The patterns are clearly changing."
 
A Majority of Donations
 Church officials are not faulting the generosity of their followers. Only among Catholics is there a question of a decline in giving. In most denominations, contributions have outpaced inflation and managed to offset losses in membership.
About two of every three dollars in charitable donations in the United States were found to go to religious congregations in a 1990 study by the Gallup Organization and Independent Sector, a Washington organization that studies and promotes philanthropy and volunteerism.
An earlier study by the same groups concluded that more than 40 percent of these congregational funds went to support activities beyond religious services and education, primarily general education, health care, international assistance and social welfare.
But if giving has grown, spendin and pressure to retain funds locally have grown even more.
 
Insurance 'Eating Us Alive'
 Health insurance is a major villain. It is "eating us alive," Robert W. Stevens, a church official from Seattle, told the United Methodist Church's Board of Pensions last March.
Mr. Stevens, the chairman of a study group proposing a new churchwide health-care plan, said this week that some of the church's 72 regional conferences faced annual increases of 10 to 40 percent in their insurance premiums while trying to live within no-growth or low-growth budgets. The total cost of premiums for Methodist clergy members and lay employees is estimated at $100 to $125 million a year, and it has been rising at an average of 25 percent a year since 1987.
Unlike many businesses that have faced similar problems with health insurance premiums, churches are reluctant to trim benefits or push costs back on their clergy members and employees through larger deductibles or shared payments. This reluctance stems partly from the major role that clergy members have in church decisions and partly, church officials say, from the sense that clergy members are insufficiently paid.
Another growing burden cited by church officials is the cost of maintaining older churches. Lutheran leaders say that upkeep is now getting costly on a particularly large number of churches built in the two decades after World War II.
Both local congregations and national church agencies have also steadily taken on new responsibilities. Among the new offices, for example, established by the Catholic bishops' conference since 1970 are ones dealing with migration, women in society and the church, Hispanic affairs, science and human values, marriage and family life, black Catholics, farm laborers and evangelization.
In addition, local churches have often taken the lead in providing community services for which government financing have been increasingly difficult to obtain. Congregations have started soup kitchens and shelters for the homeless as well as day care centers, AIDS ministries, drug addiction programs and anti-crime patrols. All this adds to the pressure to keep money locally. The Rev. Joan Campbell, General Secretary of the National Council of Churches, said that a congregation's desire to hold onto money is "not primarily a lack of trust in national offices as much as the satisfaction in seeing the work you're doing."
But many church leaders do not discount distrust as a factor. S. David Stoner, a national officer of the Presbyterian Church, said the churches are influenced by the same attitude that fuels anti-government feeling. "We seem to have an ethos that says I don't trust what I cannot control," he said.
 
More Gifts for Specific Programs
 One result of this distrust is an increase in contributions earmarked for specific programs, a practice that reduces flexibility in national budgets. By designating funds for evangelism programs, for example, conservative congregations have expressed dissatisfaction with national church agencies that advocate liberal causes .
But some Southern Baptist churches have also designated the use of their funds to protest policies by the Southern Baptist Convention's conservative leadership, and moderates in the denomination recently established an alternative fund for steering donations to programs that do not exclude their point of view.
Catholics are one group of churchgoers whose internal differences may be reducing contributions at the parish level as well as nationally. Accurate figures are impossible to obtain, because the 188 Catholic dioceses and archdioceses are financially independent and vary greatly in sharing or making their financial data public.
But in 1987 the Rev. Andrew M. Greeley analyzed polling data about giving. He concluded that while Catholics and Protestants had given the same proportions of their income to their churches in the early 1960's, by the mid-1980's Catholics were contributing only half the amount Protestants were, or 1.1 percent as against 2.2 percent.
Father Greeley, a sociologist of religion who is now a visiting professor at the University of Chicago, matched survey findings on giving and on Catholic opinions. He concluded that half of the decline, which he said had now pushed giving below 1 percent of income, could be attributed to dissatisfaction with church authority, the official condemnation of birth control and church teachings on sex generally.
Comparisons between Catholic and Protestant giving are complicated by many factors, including variations in polling results. Despite those factors limiting Father Greeley's view, "nobody has successfully contested it," said Dean Hoge, a sociologist at Catholic University of America, who is starting a study of religious giving.

HEADLINE: Why India's Unity Matters

 BODY:
Pity India. Not since independence in 1947 has so much conflict beset this huge democracy. A violent election, interrupted by the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi, has left it without a majority party or a visible leader. Hindus, Muslims and Sikhs are mired in quarrels; regions clamor for self-rule, and everyone complains about corruption, the economy and an ossified bureaucracy. The title of V. S. Naipaul's recent book captures the mood -- "India: A Million Mutinies Now."
All this obviously matters to Indians. It should also worry Americans. If chaos triumphs in India, the tremors won't be contained. Indian disunion would be a calamity for human rights. It would fragment markets and accelerate a regional arms race fed by new rivalries. 
 These are reasons enough for New Delhi's politicians to end their quarrels. That won't be easy. Enfeebled by its long dependence on a family dynasty, the Congress Party has no obvious leadership choice. Its dilemma is sharpened by the turbulent rise of a Hindu nationalist party, which placed second in the voting. Unless the Congress Party musters support from other centrists, India's secular tradition is at risk.
Whoever becomes Prime Minister will need to be tutor and taskmaster, surgeon and healer. Growth has slackened, inflation is climbing and just servicing foreign debts consumes 30 percent of export earnings. Opening up an overregulated economy can help. So can a reduction in an ever-rising arms budget. But the paramount task will be to keep India intact. New Delhi has oscillated from appeasement to repression, but to no avail, as communal riots and separatist insurgencies whirl out of control.
History suggests a terrible cost if India dissolves. Tens of millions were uprooted and hundreds of thousands killed when Britain agreed in 1947 to the creation of Pakistan as a separate Muslim state. Partition bolstered the claims of other disgruntled minorities; Pakistan's eastern half seceded in 1971 to become Bangladesh.
If Sikh separatists prevail in Punjab, or if Tamils gain independence, the clamor would spread. Indian states are not ethnically or religiously homogeneous. Disunion means certain upheaval and probable communal massacres.
In times past, awareness of this peril has helped sustain India's secular democracy. Describing India's "million mutinies," Mr. Naipaul also finds a stubborn devotion to democracy among the poor and illiterate. The Indian union, he concludes, has been greater than the sum of its parts: "And -- strange irony -- the mutinies were not to be wished away. They were part of the beginning of a new way for millions, part of India's growth, part of its restoration."
As an anxious world watches, the soundness of his generous vision is now being tested.

HEADLINE: Cameras in Court Benefit the News Media, Not the Public

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Public's Right to Public Justice" (editorial, May 31) overstates the case for audio-visual coverage of court proceedings. You refer to "overwhelming evidence that cameras in courtroom are a boon to justice," and yet there is no such evidence. Like the report by the United Court System, you overlook testimony by experienced trial lawyers about the disruption in the courtroom and dangers to the fair administration of justice presented by cameras. 
 Notably absent in your editorial is concern for the pain and suffering caused to a victim of a crime by having that proceeding televised without his or her consent and the risk that witnesses in a criminal case will either conform their testimony to previously televised testimony or refuse to provide evidence at all.
The courtroom may be orderly, but the trial judge can do little to protect witnesses from pressure outside court that may drive them from the witness stand and make them inaccessible to accused citizens who are otherwise unable to establish their innocence. It is wrong to criticize legislators who address concerns about these problems by insisting on protection for victims and accused citizens, like requiring their consent. I have spoken with many state senators and members of the Assembly about this issue, and not one had the "gripes about the news media" that you postulate.
I doubt that allowing cameras in the courtroom has done anything to educate the public, but I doubt more seriously that the news media have attempted to educate the public. Many media witnesses have candidly acknowledged that public education is not their goal. You do not acknowledge the economic interest the media have in being able to bring cameras into the courtroom.
It is not citizens who wish to be educated or civics teachers who are pressing for this legislation. It is the commercial news organizations, which are not nearly so concerned about victims' rights or citizens' rights as our legislators are. The biggest thing going in support of continuation of audio-visual coverage in the courtroom is the fear of legislators that they will be made to pay a price by the news media if they oppose such coverage.
 
MARK J. MAHONEY
President, New York State Assn. of Criminal Defense Lawyers
Buffalo, June 7, 1991

HEADLINE: Not an Extinct Species: Fast Taxi Meters

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
New York City taxi inspectors recently discovered something under the dashboard of a taxicab that caused them great concern: the driver had spliced his radio microphone into his meter so that whenever he pressed the "talk" button on the microphone, an electrical pulse caused the meter to click off extra miles.
Despite the Taxi and Limousine Commission's efforts in recent years to crack down on such practices, there is increasing evidence that fast meters remain plentiful. 
 The radio microphone hook-up was one of the more sophisticated schemes that taxi officials found in recent months.
"It was an ingenious setup that has caused us to start looking more carefully," said Louis C. Calcagno, who directs the taxi commission's safety and emissions division, which inspects meters. The use of fast meters, some taxi drivers and meter shop owners said, has increased because of a weak regional economy in which there are fewer fares.
"You have some drivers out there who have no scruples and will find any way they can to tamper with these meters to earn a few extra bucks, especially when times are hard," said Robert R. Russnak, president of the New York Independent Taximeter Shop Association. While no one knows for sure how many cabbies are using fast meters, taxi officials have several indications that the number is substantial.
One indicator is meter testing at the commission's vehicle inspection center in Woodside, Queens, prompted by passenger complaints.
 
Dramatic Rise in Cheating
 From July 1, 1990, to May 31, 1991, the meters on 341 cabs were tested, the commission's statistics show, and 42 percent were found to be running fast. In the previous year, 366 cabs were tested, and 10 percent were fast.
The increase is so great that commission officials feared the statistics might be wrong.
 Typically, the commission says, fast meters overcharge passengers about 25 cents a mile. Thus a five-mile ride without waiting time, a trip that should cost $8.75, would cost $10 with a fast meter.
The rule of thumb for passengers is that a properly set meter should click off 25 cents every four short blocks.
The taxi meter is connected to the vehicle's transmission and determines how far the vehicle has traveled. The most common way to make the meter run faster is to "zap" it, or connect it to something that transmits an electrical pulse, like the directional signal. But some drivers alter the pinion gear attached to the transmission or manipulate tire pressure or size.
Taxi commission officials said that in recent weeks they had uncovered a significant number of fast meters in spot checks of cabs on city streets.
In one such test on a major thoroughfare in Manhattan on Tuesday, inspectors pulled over Koffi Tsogbe, a 41-year-old cabby from the Bronx, and instructed him to drive down a one-mile test run. The stretch should cost exactly $2.75, because the taxi meter is reset to count only the distance traveled and not waiting time. The commission allows drivers 75 feet of leeway.
 
18 of 43 Fail the Test
 About 250 feet before the end of the one-mile stretch, Mr. Tsobge's meter registered $3. Andres La Salle, an inspector, gave him a summons that requires the meter to be recalibrated before the taxi can go back into service.
Mr. Tsogbe, who has driven a cab for 14 years, complained bitterly that the cab and its meter had been leased.
"This is very unfair," he said. "It's not my fault."
Of 43 taxis so tested in the last week, officials said, 18 failed the meter test.
When a rider complains to the commission that a driver has overcharged by using a fast meter, the agency instructs the driver to go to its center in Queens to have the meter tested. But not all fast meters have been tampered with. Many run fast, commission officials said, because drivers fail to have them recalibrated after repairs or mechanical changes to the vehicle. A new transmission or new tires, for example, may cause the sensitive electronic meters to overcharge.
Technicians at Midtown Taximeter Sales and Service in Manhattan said that of the 100 taxi meters they put through a one-mile test each year, about 20 failed because drivers had tampered with them. "In the past you didn't have as many drivers deliberately cheating people, but it seems to be getting worse," said a technician who spoke on the condition that he remain anonymous.
Taxi commission regulations require drivers to have their meters calibrated and sealed by a licensed taxi meter shop at least once a year. The meter shop performs two tests.
In one, called a bench test, the meter is removed from the taxi and connected to a device that transmits electrical pulses to determine if the meter is registering correctly.
The second test is conducted with the meter inside the taxi. The cabby drives down a one-mile stretch, and the tester observes if the meter is charging the correct amount.
Drivers who fail to have their meters recalibrated after mechanical changes to the cab or who have been found tampering with meters are subject to fines of $25 to $300 and possible suspension or revocation of their hack licenses and medallions.
Fidel F. DelValle, whom Mayor David N. Dinkins has nominated as chairman of the taxi commission, said passengers who believed they had been overcharged because of a fast meter should ask the driver for a receipt and then file a complaint with the commission.
Although some cabbies complain that random meter testing is unfair, Salvatore Saporta, who has been driving a taxi for 22 years, isn't one.
"I like this very much," he said after passing a meter test on Tuesday. "People always complain that we try to rip them off. This test will insure that we are all accurate."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 22, 1991, Saturday

Chart: 'Being Taken'
 
A properly set taxi meter should click off 25 cents every four short blocks or one avenue block. This is after the drop fee of $1.50 and does not include the extra 25 for every 75 seconds of waiting time and the 50 charge for night fares.
 
Passengers who believe they have been overcharged because the meter was fast should ask the driver for the receipt. The receipt shows the taxi medallion number, the charge and, in some cases, the miles traveled.
 
Complaints should be called in to the Taxi and Limousine Commission at 212-221-TAXI (221-8294). The commission requires drivers who have a complaint filed against them to bring their taxi meters to the Woodside inspection center for testing. (pg. B6)

HEADLINE: The Last Domino

BYLINE: By Sali Berisha; Sali Berisha is chairman of the Democratic Party of
Albania.

DATELINE: TIRANA, Albania

 BODY:
Tomorrow, Secretary of State James Baker will make the first visit by an American Secretary of State to Albania. His arrival will mark one more step in my country's march toward freedom. To continue that march, to consolidate democracy and join the economic community, we need help from the West.
 For Albanians, the U.S. has always been synonymous with freedom and democracy. President Woodrow Wilson kept our neighbors from partitioning our country after World War I. Mr. Baker's visit makes us hopeful. 
Forty-seven years of Communist rule have made us the poorest country in Europe. We are desperate for humanitarian aid -- food and medicine -- as well as technological and economic assistance. Albania needs American business to invest in developing highways, textile industries and oil exploration.
 Albania overthrew the most perverse and militant communist regime in Eastern Europe. In December, students took to the streets and forced the Albanian Communist Party to relinquish its 47-year monopoly on power by holding multi-party elections. Intellectuals and professionals immediately formed the Democratic Party and other opposition groups.
 Though foreigners, rarely allowed in Albania under Communist rule, weren't able to observe this historic event, they were present in March to view the elections.
 The Democratic Party emerged as the main alternative to the Communists. We one-third of the seats in the People's Assembly. Most of our support came from the cities where residents, after four months of activism, were no longer afraid of the Government.
 The Communists won two-thirds of the vote, mostly from the countryside. Foreign observers misinterpreted the results. The rural vote was based largely on fears that are no longer realistic: the Democrats' victory showed the peasants that it was possible to act against the Communists and survive.
 This proved true two months later when 350,000 workers went on strike, demanding higher wages and greater freedom. The support the workers received from the villagers, including food, enabled them to hold out and force the Communists to relinquish power and form a new coalition.
 On June 12, a transition Government with representatives from all political parties was installed. It is expected to preside until new elections are held next year. In recognition of these steps, Albania was admitted to the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe at the foreign ministers' meeting in Berlin this week.
 For students, intellectuals, working people and peasants, socialism is dead in our country as elsewhere, and we are disposing of its remains. Building a democracy won't be easy. Aside from our grave economic problems, we are concerned about the abuse of the human rights of the Albanians in Kosovo, Yugoslavia. A great threat to peace in the Balkans is posed by Slobodan Milosevic, the president of the Yugoslav republic of Serbia.
 Still, with the advice and friendship of the United States, I am certain that Albania will soon make its own contributions to the world.

HEADLINE: Bat Yam Journal;
In Promised Land, Jobs Don't Match the Dream

BYLINE: By SABRA CHARTRAND, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAT YAM, Israel

 BODY:
All over the wide boulevards of this seaside suburb of Tel Aviv, middle-aged Jews apathetically push trash-can carts, brooms and dust pans. Slowly, these street cleaners collect leaves, cigarette butts and other litter.
The work pays about $350 a month. Many doing the work now are recent immigrants from the Soviet Union who held more prestigious jobs there. They say they were scientists, doctors, engineers and the like and are taking jobs like street cleaning in desperation because of the shortage of jobs matching their skills. 
 First-generation immigrants in many countries, including the United States, are often forced to lower their job status and standard of living. But in Israel's case, the problem is particularly acute because there has been an unexpected surge of immigrants at a time when the Government is doing little to invigorate the country's stagnant economy.
Now, news of the scale of underemployment reaching Jews still in the Soviet Union has apparently prompted thousands to delay their move to Israel. Last December, more than 35,000 Soviet Jews immigrated here. But in May, just 16,048 Soviet Jews arrived, hardly more than came in April. Even so, these numbers are astronomical compared with several years ago when fewer than 1,000 Jews left the Soviet Union in a year.
 
'So Tired I Can't Study'
 "I didn't anticipate this," said Maya Stirota, a 53-year-old metallurgist who left Odessa in January. Leaning on her broom on a busy downtown street, she fought unsuccessfully to hold back tears. "I expected we'd have a chance to learn the language, so I could work at an interesting job. But with this cleaning I'm so tired I can't study."
"I was the head of my department," she added, wiping her eyes. Traces of her former life were evident in the blue eyeshadow, pink lipstick and gold and opal earrings she wore to sweep trash. "I had a challenging job, and I never thought I would wind up like this."
Employment for new Soviet Jewish immigrants was until recently considered a secondary crisis. The big problem was housing. But now officials of the Israeli Government, the Jewish Agency, which coordinates immigration, and Soviet Jewish immigrant groups say the housing problem is slowly dissipating. This is in part because new apartments are being built more quickly and because of the vast decrease in Soviet Jewish immigration.
"Employment is the unmitigated disaster," said Deborah Lipson, an official with the Soviet Jewish Zionist Forum, a group headed by Natan Sharansky, the former Soviet dissident. "This is the overriding, overwhelming, sole problem now."
Some Soviet Jews, particularly those who arrived early in the immigration wave, have found jobs in their professions. But now, even those who have finished Hebrew-language studies, passed Government licensing exams or taken retraining courses have increasing difficulty finding jobs. There are simply too many engineers, doctors and scientists to find work in Israel's stagnant economy.
The employment crunch could reactivate the housing crisis, since many immigrants cannot afford their apartments. High rents have already forced some Soviet Jews onto the streets.
Twenty-six families have been living in tents in the northern town of Carmiel for several weeks. After their first year in Israel, they ran out of the 12-month living subsidy the Government gives Soviet immigrants. Because they are either jobless or doing menial work, they could not afford to pay the increasingly steep rents demanded on the open housing market.
"More and more people are finishing their absorption stipend and not finding work," Ms. Lipson said. "They have to live off small unemployment benefits or are getting menial jobs."
"Anybody who doesn't have a Soviet cleaning woman is paying too much," she added wryly.
 
Many Jobs, Little Pay
 One such cleaner is Natalie Shpilko, a 40-year-old mathematics professor from Kiev. She rattled off her jobs as she waited in line for lunch at a subsidized cafeteria opened recently for impoverished immigrants in Ramat Gan, a Tel Aviv suburb.
"I clean apartments, I tutor a child, I do some work for a telephone survey company, and sometimes I baby-sit," Mrs. Shpilko said. "Altogether I earn between 1,000 and 1,500 shekels in a good month," she said. That equals $417 to $625. "But I know a lot of people who can't find work," she added. "I'm lucky."
Everyone agrees that Soviet Jewish immigrants will accept menial jobs as a temporary means to an end. But more and more the immigrants and their grass-roots organizations say such work may be all Soviet Jews have to look forward to.
"There is an atmosphere of concern that the future here is no better than the future in the Soviet Union was," Ms. Lipson said. "So some people are leaving, some are not coming, and those already here are disillusioned and depressed."
She blamed the Israeli Government for not "taking economic action, initiating job projects, creating incentives for widespread foreign investment." But she also emphasized that "the task is overwhelming and the burden is unbelievable.
"The United States, for example, largely limits immigrants to the best, the healthiest, to those who can work," she said. "Israel takes everyone."
It is likely the United States would also struggle if faced with millions of new immigrants in the space of a few years, but that does not stop some Soviet Jews here from wishing they had gone to America instead. Talking of her efforts to go to the United States from Odessa, Mrs. Stirota was so overwhelmed by tears that she could not speak for a few minutes.
"Three months after we came here, we heard we had been approved for visas to the U.S.," she said finally. "Now we have no money. The only thing a Russian woman can do here is sweep streets and clean apartments."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Yen Gains Against Dollar; Gold Closes Slightly Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar retreated sharply against the Japanese yen and ended mixed against other currencies yesterday amid confusion over this weekend's meeting of leading industrial nations. Gold was slightly lower after rising overseas.
In New York, the dollar closed at 138.22 yen, down from 140.05 yen late on Wednesday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar fell to 139.20 yen, from 141.10 yen at Wednesday's close. In London, the dollar fell to 138.60 yen. 
 Dealers have been selling dollars recently on speculation that Sunday's meeting in London of the Groupof Seven leading industrial nations will result in efforts to stem the dollar's powerful rally this year.
That speculation was counteracted, however, early in the New York session when the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, indicated that the meeting was unlikely to set a coordinated currency policy.
Helmut Schlesinger, who will succeed Karl Otto Pohl as the head of the Bundesbank, also said he saw no reason to raise German interest rates.
"This left the market in a somewhat confused state. No clear direction has emerged," said David Jaques, a corporate dealer with Barclays Bank in New York.
Market participants said the dollar's sharp fall against the yen in New York was a carry-over from the overnight drop in overseas trading.
With traders focusing on the Group of Seven meeting, the market seemed to ignore negative economic news that might ordinarily have pushed down the dollar, dealers said. The Labor Department reported the number of Americans filing new unemployment claims surged in early June, raising fresh doubts about whether the recession is ending.
The dollar strengthened slightly against the British pound. In London, sterling fell to $1.6310, from $1.6325 late on Wednesday. In New York, the pound bought $1.6355, slightly less than late Wednesday's $1.6363.
Other late dollar rates in New York yesterday, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.7915 German marks, up from 1.7895; 1.5355 Swiss francs, down from 1.5385; 6.0925 French francs, up from 6.0870; 1,334.00 Italian lire, unchanged, and 1.1415 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14325.
Gold slipped on the Commodity Exchange in New York, falling 60 cents an ounce from late Wednesday's $368. The Republic National Bank later quoted a price of $368, which was off 15 cents from the bank's late Wednesday bid.
In London, gold edged up to a late bid of $367.75 an ounce, from a $367.25 bid late on Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $368, up from $366.90 late on Wednesday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose 67 cents to close at $368.29.

HEADLINE: Selling Planes That Won the War

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 20

 BODY:
President Bush and President Francois Mitterrand of France have recently called for limiting arms exports, but their message has clearly not sunk in at the Paris Air Show, the world's largest showplace for fighter-bombers, attack helicopters and air-to-air missiles.
Since the 10-day show opened on June 13, dozens of combat aircraft have been parked on the tarmac at Le Bourget Airport, including an oversized Soviet MIG-31, a British Tornado GR, a French Mirage 2000 and a stubby Yugoslav G-4 Super Galeb bomber. But the aircraft drawing the most attention among the 400,000 expected visitors is Lockheed's F-117A Stealth fighter, whose pinpoint bombing wreaked so much damage on Iraq during the Persian Gulf war. 
 Though hurt by the industry's downturn, this year's show has become a celebration of the victory of the anti-Iraq coalition. It is certainly not a sober setting for arms merchants to reflect on problems stemming from weapons sales to renegade third-world leaders like President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. The United States Department of Defense, eager to crow about its air superiority in the gulf war and bolster exports for the nation's troubled arms makers, has assembled the largest armada of American aircraft seen at the show in years.
There are Grumman EA-6B Prowlers for electronic warfare, McDonnell-Douglas F-15E fighter-bombers, Boeing Chinook helicopters and General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcons. A battery of Patriot missiles stands in front of the American pavilion, and husky soldiers give out literature about the "combat-proven air-defense system of the free world."
Standing alongside the 15 or so American aircraft are other American troops, many wearing sand-colored desert camouflage outfits during the frequent drizzle this week. "It's great being here," said Lieut. Bill Siegler, 26 years old, a navigator for a Navy F-14. "People who don't speak English come up and say to me, 'Good job, Desert Storm.' "
Lingering excitement about the victory in the gulf has saved the show and its 1,000 or more participants from absolute gloom. The show's two areas, commercial and military, have both fallen on hard times. The recession and the airlines' loss of traffic during the gulf crisis caused a sharp drop in orders for commercial aircraft. On the military side, the end of the cold war and cuts in military spending are making life difficult.
Serge Dassault, chairman of the show and also of Dassault Aviation, has acknowledged that his company, France's largest producer of warplanes, expects revenues to slide to about $2.5 billion this year, from $2.8 billion last year.
While President Mitterrand opened the show, Dassault's new fighter-bomber, the Rafale, serenaded him with dives, rolls, loops and climbs that the American contingent saw as the most impressive of any aircraft at the show.
 
Americans Mostly Grounded
 The airfield, six miles north of Paris, was where Charles Lindbergh landed after his pioneering trans-Atlantic flight in 1927.
Many visitors are disappointed that for all the American combat aircraft on the tarmac, hardly any participate in the daring daily flight displays. The Pentagon paid to fly the aircraft to Le Bourget, but industry executives say they have been asked to pay for any demonstrations. The companies balked because of the costs of fuel and insurance against crashes onto bystanders. Two years ago, a Soviet MIG-29 crashed at the show.
The Department of Defense has said there is no need to participate in the flight demonstrations because the aircraft had shown their capabilities in the gulf war. A popular joke here is, "The most interesting airplane flying in the show is the Stealth, but no one can see it."
Lockheed held a news conference about the Stealth's capabilities, even though Lockheed officials say their only authorized buyer right now is the Pentagon. "I'm here to highlight the capabilities of the Lockheed Corporation," said Jack Gordon, a Lockheed executive who worked on the Stealth. "Our advanced tactical fighter may be available for export one day."
 
Congressmen Stay Home
 Americans are practicing austerity in other ways. Before huge budget deficits and the flap over the use of military and corporate aircraft by John Sununu, the White House chief of staff, up to 100 Congressmen came to the Paris show, where pate and Bordeaux wines abound. Just two Congressmen attended this year, an American official said.
Many American companies, hit by the recession, have also reduced their presence, believing that few additional sales turn up to justify the high cost of participating, often more than $2 million. "I don't know if we sell any more aircraft here, but it's part of the marketing equation so you do it," one American executive said.
Some of Europe's largest aircraft makers have no such ambivalence. At its airport chalet, Dassault, the show's host, has greeted more than 50 defense ministers and armed forces commanders from around the world.
Dassault executives doubt that American and French proposals on arms proliferation will harm the industry, since these restrictions would primarily limit nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, not conventional warplanes.
The French contend that the American makers, despite President Bush's proposals, are seeking to cash in on their gulf war successes by pushing exports more than ever. "The Americans are applying sales pressure everywhere, including in markets we long considered our own," said Charles Edelstenne, a senior vice president of Dassault.
Deutsche Aerospace, a subsidiary of Daimler-Benz A.G., also looms large here. It has rented a gleaming white chalet the size of a Boeing 747, with a dozen bulletproof Mercedes automobiles parked in front like a pack of metallic bulldogs. Now that Daimler-Benz has bought much of Germany's aircraft industry, the Germans palpably want to show that they are again a power in aerospace.
Deutsche Aerospace is the main force behind a German-French-Italian consortium to build an 80-to-130 seat aircraft; the Germans would also be the main shareholder. The aircraft could compete with a proposed 130-seat Airbus jetliner, and Airbus executives fear that Deutsche Aerospace, which is also a large Airbus shareholder, will block the Airbus project in favor of the other consortium's.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lockheed's F-117A Stealth fighter is one of about 15 American aircraft on display at the Paris Air Show. During the show, the aircraft has been guarded by United States troops wearing desert camouflage uniforms. (Susan May Tell for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sanitation Workers Begin Slowdown

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
Sanitation Department employees, angry over layoff notices sent to nearly 450 of their colleagues, began a work slowdown yesterday, delaying garbage collection across the city.
It was not clear how long the slowdown would continue. Sanitation Department officials said they might be forced to assign workers on overtime to complete the work of disposal. 
 With talks with municipal unions on averting thousands of layoffs stalled, the job action is the latest problem to confront the Dinkins administration in its budget crisis. Up to 20,000 city workers may be laid off in the next year, but sanitation workers are the only uniformed, unionized employees who face layoffs, a situation they view as a slap in the face.
The slowdown was "well-organized and citywide," said Anne Canty, a department spokeswoman. Some garbage was left on the street, she said; she gave no estimate of how much. The biggest impact of the slowdown, she said, is that the department is being forced to redeploy workers to get its disposal job completed.
 
Union Order Denied
 Ms. Canty said the department was trying to determine if those engaged in the slowdown were violating work rules and subject to discipline. A spokesman for the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, Jim Grossman, said that the union had not authorized a job action but that the workers were so angry about the forthcoming layoffs that wildcat actions were possible.
About 200 shop stewards gathered Wednesday night in a "raucous" meeting at union headquarters near the South Street Seaport in Manhattan, he said, observing, "The guys were very, very upset."
Sanitation workers staged a three-day wildcat strike in July 1975 after nearly 3,000 union members were laid off in the city's last financial crisis.
Last April Mayor David N. Dinkins proposed laying off more than 20,000 city workers, including 447 sanitation workers, as part of deep cuts in city services to close a $3.5 billion gap in his $29 billion budget.
At the same time the Dinkins administration began negotiations with the state, the City Council and municipal unions in an effort to avert the worst of the cuts. But the negotiations have made little progress, and city workers have become increasingly disillusioned, especially after the administration began distributing layoff notices at the end of last week.
The Council, vowing to approve no more than $300 million of the $776 million in property taxes that the Mayor wants, is drafting $500 million more in cuts to make up the difference. That would be on top of the $1.5 billion in cuts that Mr. Dinkins has proposed.
On Wednesday night negotiators for the city met for six hours with representatives of the two unions representing nonuniformed employees -- the Teamsters and District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees -- to find savings to avert some layoffs. Afterward both sides said they remained far from any agreement.
Sanitation union officials say one major obstacle is their need for assurances that any sacrifices they agree to will be shared by all city workers, including firefighters and police officers, who have been exempted from layoffs.
Besides the uniformed sanitation layoffs, the department also expects to furlough 250 civilian employees.
 
A Backup of Garbage
 There are now about 6,800 members of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association. The union has been working without a contract since its three-year agreement ended last June 30.
Unless the City Council restores funds to the department's budget, fewer workers will be needed because the city's recycling program will be suspended and street cleaning drastically reduced.
By noon yesterday it had become evident a slowdown was under way, Ms. Canty said.
Under normal conditions, after workers finish their collection routes, they have time remaining in their shifts to dump the garbage at a marine transfer station. From there, the garbage is taken by barge to the Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island.
In the slowdown, Ms. Canty said, some trucks returned to their garages filled with garbage at the end of the 6 A.M.-to-2 P.M. shift. Workers in the next shift had to be re-assigned from regular chores, like garbage collection or street cleaning, to take filled trucks to the transfer stations to be emptied.
The last significant job slowdowns among sanitation workers occurred between 1981 and 1983, when the city and the union were negotiating a reduction in the number of workers on collection trucks from three to two. Both management and union officials agree that the change has saved the city millions of dollars.
 
A Feeling of Betrayal
 Having agreed to those productivity measures, the union members are incensed that they alone among the uniformed services are being asked to absorb layoffs, Mr. Grossman said.
"There's a sense among our sanitationmen that the city has betrayed them," he said.
In current talks with the union, the Sanitation Department has been trying to obtain new productivity savings. The department asserts that in many neighborhoods where residents are recycling newspapers, bottles and cans, the garbage collection crews are picking up as much as 20 percent less tonnage.
Department officials want to extend the collection routes so the crews pick up the amount they had been doing before recycling began. This could save tens of millions of dollars by reducing the number of trucks needed for collection, the department says.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
I.B.M. Sees A Gloomy 2d Quarter

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
I.B.M. told Wall Street analysts yesterday that its earnings for the second quarter were likely to fall below expectations and hinted that new cost-cutting moves could soon lead to further special charges.
The International Business Machines Corporation, based in Armonk, N.Y., also broadened its explanation of why it is ailing as it struggles to return to earlier levels of profitability and dominance of the industry. 
 In April, when it reported gloomy first-quarter results, I.B.M. officials insisted that the company was sound even as it went through changes but that it was being plagued by a dismal economy.
 
Conference Call With Analysts
 But in a 90-minute conference call with financial analysts yesterday morning, the analysts said, I.B.M. cited additional factors dragging earnings down: pricing pressures from competitors and uncertainties surrounding the introductions of new products.
The stock fell, but far less than the $12.75 tumble it took on March 19, when the company warned analysts of its earlier difficulties. I.B.M. shares lost $1.75 yesterday, to $99.25. With 4.1 million shares traded, it had the second-highest number of shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange.
The company said that while analysts' earnings projections for the quarter had ranged from 50 cents to a $1.10 a share, the actual numbers would be far lower. And while the company said it did not expect a loss, it could not rule one out.
 
Cuts in Earnings Estimates
 A number of analysts cut their earnings expectations for the year, and several said that 1991 earnings of $5 and $7.50 a share were more reasonable than estimates above $10 that many analysts had several months ago.
"In the past they said the problems were all the economy, but I never bought that," said Stephen Cohen, a financial analyst at the Soundview Financial Group.
Company officials said yesterday that they now saw some hints of a turnaround in the economy and expected recovery in the third quarter and modest qrowth in the fourth. But they also said great economic uncertainties remained.
During the call the company said that of its various markets, Asia was likely to be weakest during the quarter, followed by the United States. Europe remained the strongest region, but it had also weakened.
Despite the gloomy forecasts, a number of analysts saw some favorable signs for the future. Mr. Cohen said he was pleased with I.B.M.'s cost-cutting progress. He said the company had indicated that it planned to increase its dividend.
Other analysts said there were a number of signs that indicated I.B.M. was growing more nimble and aggressive in the market place.
"They are moving very quickly in a number of areas," said Daniel Mandresh of Merrill Lynch. "Their talks with Apple and the Wang relationship happened with lightning speed."
This will be the second consecutive quarter that I.B.M. has disappointed Wall Street analysts. For the first quarter, the company's operating earnings plunged 48.7 percent, from $1.04 billion to $532 million, and revenues fell by 4.5 percent, from $14.2 billion to $13.7 billion.
For the last quarter, the company had reported double-digit revenue declines in a number of its product lines, including both mainframe and personal computers.
 
Effect of Product Introductions
 During the conference call I.B.M. said it was feeling the effects of new product introductions in all of its major hardware categories. In areas like its mainframe computer line, short pauses in purchasing can have a devastating impact on revenues in a particular quarter.
The company has recently introduced new models in the mid-range of its PS/2 personal computer family and its AS/400 minicomputer line and is currently preparing to introduce high-end mainframe computers later this year.
"Customers tend to pause and defer purchasing decisions while these transitions are occurring," said Robert Wilson, an I.B.M. spokesman.
In addition, I.B.M. said that more employees than expected were departing under a special incentive plan to encourage workers to leave the company.
Originally, I.B.M. had said that it hoped 10,000 employees would take advantage of the most recent plan, but yesterday it said it expected several thousand workers to take advantage of the program and depart by the middle of the year. Analysts said they expected an additional 2,000 to 4,000 employees to take advantage of the incentive plan, which is named the Voluntary Transition Plan.
Employees have until the end of July to tell the company whether they wish to leave under the plan.
In addition to those who are choosing to leave voluntarily, I.B.M. has reduced its employment this year by another 4,000 by spinning off its Kentucky-based typewriter and keyboard division as Lexmark International Inc.

HEADLINE: Probation and Therapy Help Some Drug Users

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., June 20

 BODY:
Combining the therapeutic principles of addiction programs and the incentive contracts popular in the juvenile court, a judge here is using the engine of the criminal justice system to prod adult offenders into drug treatment.
The experiment, conducted by Judge Jeffrey T. Tauber of Oakland Municipal Court, has attracted the attention of criminal justice and drug abuse experts, who say it is the first serious effort to get adults charged with drug possession out of the courts and prisons and into rehabilitation. 
 Since the early 1970's, when courts became clogged with marijuana cases, many states have "diverted" certain drug possession cases by allowing defendants to choose a period of supervised probation rather than entering a plea and standing trial. A defendant in a diversion program can avoid a criminal record if there are no subsequent arrests.
 
Critics on the Programs
 Criminal justice experts say that standard diversion programs are usually worthless. They are haphazardly supervised and rarely include adequate drug treatment, and a high percentage of participants disappear or are rearrested.
By contrast, the early results of Judge Tauber's experiment, which began in January, are good.
"Diversion in most places means neglect," said Peter W. Greenwood, a senior researcher in criminal justice at the Rand Corporation, the research concern. "Here they're actually doing something with the cases."
The program in Oakland is built on the four pillars that experts say are the foundation of behavioral change: the speedy processing of cases, contracts with clear rewards and punishments, group therapy sessions and frequent contact with an authority -- in this instance, Judge Tauber -- who dispenses praise and blame like a stern, but attentive father.
"It is very unusual for the stodgy justice system to respond in a psychologically sound way," said Douglas Anglin, the director of the Drug Abuse Research Group at the University of California at Los Angeles.
For participants, the point of Judge Tauber's diversion regime is not merely staying out of trouble. These defendants are expected to participate in a variety of drug education and counseling groups, which simulate the sort of out-patient treatment commonly used for alcoholism and addiction to crack. They also take urine tests at regular intervals to verify that they have been abstinent.
 
Initial Resistance
 The program depends in large measure on the Alameda County Probation Department. At first, several probation officers said, they resented trading familiar tasks like writing reports for new ones like running group counseling sessions and having their discretion eroded. But they quickly found their new roles more satisfying than the old ones and the results inspiring.
"Before I didn't feel I was getting anything out of it or helping anybody either," said a probation officer, Patricia Blades Oneto. "I really like it now. Judge Tauber has made us real partners with the court for the first time."
Judge Tauber has gathered data tracking the first 100 diversion defendants this year and comparing them with the first 100 last year. California law permits diversion for people with no felony convictions in the previous five years and no prior drug convictions. Judge Tauber estimated that one in five drug cases in Oakland, or about 1,200 a year, fall into this category.
The comparison showed that arrests on new offenses have dropped 48 percent, to 36 from 69. If that recidivism rate remains constant, 1,100 arrests a year would be avoided.
Each arrest costs at least $300, according to the Oakland Police Department. The elimination of those arrests, not counting subsequent court and prison costs, would save $330,000, which is about how much the judge's program costs.
Early data also show a sharp reduction in missed court appearances. Among the first 100 defendants, attendance at a diversion hearing, the session in which a participant is assigned to the program, has been perfect, while one-third of the defendants last year did not show up. The dropout rate between arraignment and the granting of diversion -- the time period when defendants are most likely to disappear -- has fallen by 77 percent, largely because the wait has been cut, to the day after arraignment from the previous one of four months. Later in the program, the dropout rate has fallen 40 percent.
 
Rewards for Performance
 It is impossible to predict how the defendants will fare as their supervision continues, or when they are no longer being monitored. The incentive contracts reward good performance in a variety of ways, including a reduction in the term of supervision, which presumably motivates defendants to behave in order to get out sooner.
Judge Tauber, who began his legal career as an environmental lawyer, developed an interest in drug cases after switching to criminal practice. After joining the bench, he requested an assignment that nobody else wanted: handling the drug cases.
"This is the most central problem facing our cities and our judicial system today," he said.
In the courts and corridors here, a sad cast of men and women slump in their chairs, nodding and sniffling from the effects of drugs. Many clutch Bibles or carry squirming children. They are arrested and re-arrested, appearing again and again before the same judges and probation officers.
To try to stop this revolving door, Judge Tauber consulted drug abuse experts, who taught him the tenets of their trade, first among them that a crisis in a drug abuser's life, like an arrest, presents the best opportunity for successful intervention.
In the old system, defendants' assignment to the diversion program would wait while investigators from the probation department wrote long and largely pointless reports. That paperwork has been eliminated.
 
Terms of Contracts
 On entering the program, the defendants sign a contract under which points are assigned to the completion of certain tasks, like attending drug education classes. For those who earn enough points, there is a substantial reduction in the two-year term of supervision and the $220 fee that the state has always required of people in the diversion program.
The orientation, and most other contacts with probation officers, are conducted in groups, a break from common practice. This makes possible frequent supervision with fewer officers, which is economical. Judge Tauber said his motive was to make the program more therapeutic, mimicking successful anti-addiction programs like Alcoholics Anonymous and Smokenders.
Probation officers were trained to run the groups by addiction experts, who say this is one way to reach more people at a time when outpatient and residential facilities are often full.
The contracts take into account the likelihood of relapse among drug abusers and provide for a second chance. Those who do not earn enough points are permitted to repeat each stage of the program once. Those who are thrown out because they fail to earn enough points are allowed one reinstatement. A positive finding on a urine test means fewer points but not automatic dismissal.
 
Some Are Excluded
 This week, during a review of cases, Judge Tauber was by turns strict and lenient. Several defendants who did not show up in court were tossed out of the program and bench warrants were issued for their arrests.
One man, who recently learned he had AIDS, had earned only 2 of 14 points in the initial phase of the program. Judge Tauber put him into custody for failure to follow the regime, then released him several hours later, reinstating him and offering encouragement.
The judge reduced the term and fee for a man who had not attended community counseling, one of the requirements, but who otherwise performed well. The man explained he was uncomfortable talking to a group of strangers. Judge Tauber instructed the man's probation officer, Frank Tapia, to find a counseling situation where that would not be necessary.
The judge's direct contact with defendants is the main predictor for success, many criminal justice and addiction experts said.
"The genius of the operation is the level of judicial involvement," Mr. Zimring said. The law professor added that if such programs were widely used in California, they could reduce the state prison population by 5,000 to 10,000 inmates. The population quadrupled in the last decade, to 101,000.
Dr. Alex Stalcup, a former probation officer and a physician who is advising Judge Tauber, said that personalizing the judicial system would make all the difference.
"This intervention is human," he said. "They have to encounter Jeff, respond to him, say something, do something. This is a very new definition of diversion and word is getting out on the street."

HEADLINE: U.S.-Backed Shift in Policy Is Rejected at World Bank

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
The executive board of the World Bank today rejected an agreement made by the bank's management to provide greater private-sector support in developing countries in exchange for United States backing of an increase in the capital of the bank's private-sector lending arm.
Bank and Administration officials said only a handful of the bank's 22 board members endorsed the pact between the United States Treasury and Barber B. Conable Jr., the bank's president, who is a former Republican Congressman. No consensus was reached, and no vote was taken at the tense and somber meeting, the officials said. 
 The board's action was a defeat, both for the Bush Administration, which is pushing multilateral institutions to be less committed to the public sector in the developing world, and for the bank, which is running low on money to lend to third world businesses.
At the meeting, directors representing a wide range of countries -- from poor to rich and spanning the political spectrum -- criticized the bank's willingness to change its policies under United States pressure, an official said.
A World Bank official who insisted on anonymity said that the aggressive American insistence on new policies toward the private sector in the third world had antagonized the executive board.
An Administration official agreed that the policy changes were the sticking point. "There were a lot of fears, a lot of concerns," he said.
One common theme was that the bank might be forsaking its goal of alleviating poverty in the developing world to help third world businessmen, said an Administration official. No meeting was scheduled to break the impasse.
"I think everybody's going to sleep on it," the official said.
The World Bank issued no comment on the board meeting, and canceled a news conference by Mr. Conable that was scheduled for Friday morning.
The bank is seeking a $1.3 billion increase in the capital of the International Finance Corporation, which lends to businesses in the developing world. The corporation has already been slowing its growth of new lending, from more than 20 percent a year in the late 1980's to 4 percent in the fiscal year ending on June 30.
The United States has contributed a quarter of the international corporation's capital and 17 percent of the World Bank's capital, and has a proportionate vote on the 22-member boards of each body, which are separate but identical. Yesterday's session was technically a simultaneous meeting of both boards.

HEADLINE: New Claims By Jobless Rise Sharply

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new unemployment claims surged in early June, the Government reported today.
The jobless claims number, which rose 47,000 for the first week of June to cancel out a decrease of nearly that amount the week before, added to conflicting evidence of late about the health of the nation's economy, analysts said. 
 "It's not good news," said Jack Albertine, who heads an economic forecasting firm in Washington. "It may indicate that the economy has not bottomed, or that a recovery had begun and then got short-circuited."
 
'Confusion Reigns'
 Other recent economic data have shown rebounds in factory orders, retail sales and hiring practices. Two weeks ago, the Government said the unemployment rate rose to 6.9 percent, while a separate survey showed businesses adding on more workers.
"It's another sign that confusion reigns relative to the start of this recovery," Mr. Albertine said.
Comparing this recession with past recessions, Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company, said: "It was much easier with earlier episodes, when we came barreling out, firing on all pistons with explosive jobs growth. That's not happening this time."
Many analysts expect this recovery to be weak and anemic, with various sectors of the economy slow to turn around.
 
Report for Week Ending June 8
 The Labor Department said that for the week ended June 8, there were 448,000 Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits, an increase of 47,000 from the previous week.
In May, jobless claims had fallen for four straight weeks, something that had not happened since 1982, when the United States economy was pulling out of the last recession.
Another sign of weakness seen in today's report was that the number of people actually receiving unemployment benefits during the week ending June 1 rose as well, increasing by 136,000, to 3.6 million.
That figure pushed the percentage of the labor force receiving unemployment aid to 3.4 percent, up from 3.3 percent, meaning that about half of the nation's jobless are receiving benefits.

HEADLINE: California Inches Toward Closing Big Budget Gap

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 20

 BODY:
 With the state wracked by recession and grappling with the largest budget deficit ever faced by a state, the California Assembly passed a $55-billion spending plan today, only 11 days before the new fiscal year begins.
The budget action came after one of the most extraordinary sessions in the Legislature's history. Liberal Democrats pleaded with conservative Republicans to back their own party's Governor, Pete Wilson, and accept his package of cuts in welfare grants and the largest tax increase in state history. 
 The state Senate passed the budget package on Saturday, but until today Mr. Wilson, a moderate, had been unable to persuade enough members of his own party in the Assembly to go along with the compromise he had worked out with Democrats.
 
The Gap: $14.3 Billion
 But the budget battle is by no means over. The Assembly has yet to pass most of the $7 billion in tax increases and cuts in welfare-grant formulas needed to balance the budget as required by law. The unfinished legislation leaves the state facing a $14.3 billion gap between spending and expected revenue.
Still, today's action was considered a major breakthrough in a process that could well influence the future of Governor Wilson, who has been widely mentioned in Washington as a possible Presidential contender.
The Governor had spent most of the week twisting the arms of Republicans in the Assembly, who have fiercely resisted any new taxes without steep cuts in spending and sweeping "structural" changes in state government to prevent spending from consistenly outpacing revenue.
Finally today, nine Republicans broke ranks with their conservative leadership and joined 45 Democrats to provide 54 votes, the bare minimum for the two-thirds margin required to pass budget measures in the 80-member Assembly. There were 23 votes against the package.
The vote came after an impassioned plea for Mr. Wilson's budget from one of his sharpest critics, Speaker Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco, a liberal Democrat. Mr. Brown said there was much in the budget he disliked, but he warned that the state faced a collapse of essential services if the compromise was not passed.
"This is a Pete Wilson budget," he said. "But I am happy to see a demonstration of clear responsibility in this chamber. It is a product of the Democratic process."
In a dig at conservative Republicans from Orange County who opposed the budget compromise, the Texas-born Mr. Brown, a black man who was the son of a railroad porter, said it was essential to the needs of Orange County residents, "who would not want me in their district after sundown."
 
Conservatives' Pleas
 Conservative Republicans issued equally impassioned pleas against the budget.
Assemblyman Patrick Nolan of Glendale, near Los Angeles, said that the state had suffered through 20 years of the "failed policies of socialism" and that he refused to vote for billions in tax increases that would be "pulled out of the productive sector to just maintain the status quo that we all know has failed our people."
But other Republicans, like Tricia R. Hunter of Bonita, near San Diego, said she would vote for the budget on Mr. Wilson's promise to veto it if the Democrats did not agree to various reforms.
Under the compromise reached with the Democrats, the Wilson plan would do the following:
*Increase the state sales tax by 1.25 cents on the dollar and broaden the tax to include newspapers, candy and snacks, bottled water and ship and aircraft fuel. This would raise the sales tax to 8.25 percent in many major cities, costing the average Californian $130 more a year and raising about $4 billion a year.
*Cut grants to Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the major component of the welfare system, by 4.4 percent, a reduction of $31 from the current $694 monthly allotment to a mother with two children. It would also eliminate the automatic cost-of-living increases to such grants, at a saving of $440 million to $455 million.
*Increase taxes from 4 cents to 20 cents a gallon on beer, from 1 cent to 20 cents a gallon on wine and place higher rates on various types of liquor, raising $200 million.
*Freeze salaries of 218,000 state workers.
A spokesman for Mr. Wilson, William Livingstone, said that many in the Assembly had voted "courageously" and that while the process was not over, there was "clearly some momentum."

HEADLINE: Bush Meets and Commends Yeltsin But Cites Support for Gorbachev

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
President Bush gave Boris N. Yeltsin a brief pat on the back today for pushing "democratic values and free market principles," but emphasized his own support for the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
"We have been heartened and encouraged by President Yeltsin's commitment to democratic values and free market principles, and we look forward to working with him," Mr. Bush said in a Rose Garden appearance with the newly elected President of Russia before their meeting in the Oval Office. "But at the same time -- I want to be very clear about this -- the United States will continue to maintain the closest possible official relationship with the Soviet Government of President Gorbachev." 
 Mr. Yeltsin had urged Congress on Wednesday to direct help for the Soviet Union to individuals who are moving toward democracy, rather than to "an unreformed Communist system," as he put it.
And today at a National Press Club luncheon, Mr. Yeltsin indicated that the United States would be wise not to wager all its diplomatic chips on Mr. Gorbachev, since, he said, Mr. Gorbachev alone cannot save the Soviet Union. "There is no one, there is no way for one man to preserve the Soviet Union," he said.
But Mr. Bush politely rejected these ideas today, saying his Administration would continue to deal with the central Government of Mr. Gorbachev.
The White House had been fretting over how to strike the proper balance of encouraging Mr. Yeltsin's rush toward democracy without undermining or offending Mr. Gorbachev.
Unlike the last time he was here, in the fall of 1989, this time Mr. Yelsin did not have to come in the back door and bargain for a few minutes of Mr. Bush's time during a meeting with one of his aides. Mr. Yeltsin's resounding victory in the Russian elections has made him impossible for the Administration to keep at arm's length.
Mr. Bush met with Mr. Yeltsin for an hour and 40 minutes in the Oval Office and posed for the cameras in the Rose Garden. But the President, who is a strong believer in supporting the global club of leaders, spent most of his time in their joint appearance praising Mr. Gorbachev.
"He knows," Mr. Bush said of Mr. Yeltsin, "that I have great respect for President Gorbachev, as I do for him, and we have an excellent relationship. And our ability to work together has produced, I think, enormous benefits for both of our countries and it's served the cause of world peace and stability in the world.
"So let's not forget that it was President Gorbachev's courageous policies of glasnost and perestroika that were the pivotal factors enabling us to end the cold war and make Europe whole and free."
Administration officials said this week that they hoped that Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Gorbachev would work together, so any support of Mr. Yeltsin's more dramatic reforms would not be perceived as a threat to Mr. Gorbachev.
But Mr. Yeltsin seemed to want to have it both ways this week on his four-day visit to Washington and New York. He wanted to say, as he did today at the National Press Club, that he has "a balanced working relationship" with Mr. Gorbachev. "It has not been an even relationship," he conceded. "But there has been no rivalry, and certainly no personal hostility. It was, and sometimes still is, a matter of diverging positions."
But the Russian leader is also a skillful politician, and he wanted to cast himself as a man possessed of a bolder, surer vision about how to save the Soviet Union than Mr. Gorbachev has.
 
A Promise to Gorbachev
 When a reporter at the press club asked him whether he would not be urging moderation, too, if he were "in Gorbachev's shoes," Mr. Yeltsin responded: "I shall never step into Gorbachev's shoes. I have promised him that."
He continued, more seriously: "I shall never be an advocate of slow, half-hearted change because this is a mortal danger to our country. If we go along that path, the system will take a revenge on us. It will never let us achieve democracy."
Mr. Yeltsin has been saying this week that he would like all Soviet foreign aid, including money for Cuba, to end, and that he would like large cuts in military spending.
Asked about that today, as he stood beside the smiling Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Bush said that the Soviets must decide on their own internal policies, but that "they know that we've had our differences on Cuba,and it wouldn't hurt my feelings a bit if they cut off all foreign aid to Cuba."
Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said he thought that Mr. Yeltsin was a different man from the one who met with him in 1989 and lectured the President on the problems of his country.
He said the meeting today had been friendly and "a good opportunity for the two to get really acquainted."
He said the two Presidents had talked largely about Mr. Yeltsin's agenda for democratic change and economic reform and how the United States might assist it.
The possible American initiatives Mr. Scowcroft cited -- training Russians in Western business practices, advising on such problems as food storage and transportation -- were bland in comparison with the much larger aid packages being discussed with Mr. Gorbachev.
Mr. Yeltsin also met with Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and a group of American business executives to sell the Soviet Union as a good investment, as he will do on Friday when he meets with business leaders in New York. He arrived in New York this evening.
In Washington, Mr. Yeltsin also went to the Pentagon to talk to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Mr. Yeltsin told Mr. Cheney that he favored the Kremlin's keeping control of the armed forces but wanted the Russian republic to get control of the defense industries, the Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, said.
Mr. Cheney "didn't express any reaction" to Mr. Yeltsin's argument, Mr. Williams said.
Mr. Bush had breakfast with former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and told reporters he was "picking her brains" about his meeting with Mr. Yeltsin.
"Democracy has come to the Soviet Union," Mrs. Thatcher said, as she left the White House. "It now has to be backed up by full economic reform, with everyone pulling together."
