HEADLINE: BERLIN TO REGAIN FULL CAPITAL ROLE

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, June 20

 BODY:
The German Parliament voted by a narrow margin today to move the seat of federal Government 350 miles eastward, from Bonn to Berlin, the country's historic capital.
The vote, taken after nearly 12 hours of vigorous and often bitter debate, was 337 for Berlin and 320 for Bonn, a small city on the Rhine that became West Germany's temporary capital in 1949 pending eventual reunification with East Germany. Over the years, Bonn increasingly took on the look of a permanent capital as its bureaucracy grew and hopes for unification faded. 
 But after the sudden collapse of East Germany's hard-line Communist Government in 1989 and the unification of Germany last October, the question of whether to move the seat of power became a major issue, even though the treaty joining the two Germanys had officially restored Berlin's status as the capital.
Given the huge expenses involved in shifting the seat of Government, the resolution approved today gives German leaders 12 years to make Berlin a fully functioning center of power. Care was also taken not to unduly upset those who campaigned to keep the Government in Bonn.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who favored Berlin, said he was satisfied with the result. But he was clearly anxious not to antagonize Bonn's supporters.
"This is not a ground for celebration," he said on television. "Celebration would mean there were losers and winners and that would be the wrong feeling at this moment."
"This was the correct decision," he added. "For me, this decision is of great importance for the future of Germany."
 
Signal to Easterners
 The vote in the federal assembly was viewed as a signal of support for people living in the former East Germany, many of whom had campaigned on behalf of Berlin. The transfer of Germany's seat of power to the eastern city is expected to bring heavy investment to the region, which is suffering from unemployment and other effects of entering a free-market economy. The decision also symbolizes Germany's ties to the countries of Eastern Europe.
The timetable for the move to Berlin will be mapped out in a series of new laws. Finance Minister Theo Waigel, who voted in favor of keeping the central Government in Bonn, said that parts of the federal power structure would remain here.
"Not everything that is in Bonn must go to Berlin," he said. "I can tell you that in my budget projections through 1995, I don't have any money allotted for this."
Mr. Kohl and Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg said after the vote that they did not know how quickly they would move to Berlin.
Foreign embassies will also have to be transferred. The United States and many other nations have held onto buildings that were accredited to the the former East German Government when it had its capital in East Berlin.
The United States is expected to build a new embassy on land near the Brandenburg Gate that was the site of the pre-World War II embassy. The old building was destroyed during the war.
 
No Winner, Mayor Says
 Tonight, Mayor Eberhard Diepgen of Berlin interrupted a television interviewer who introduced him as "the day's big winner."
"I don't feel like a winner, and the city of Berlin did not score a victory," Mr. Diepgen said. "What happened was that the Parliament made an important political decision."
Mr. Diepgen, Chancellor Kohl and several other officials said that some lawmakers appeared to have changed their minds on the issue as late as today.
Before the decision, both sides rejected efforts to reach a compromise.
"The Bonn people are going to ask themselves if they might not have been better off going for a compromise," said Heiner Geissler, a lawmaker who had proposed a two-city capital. Several legislators said that Bonn would need special aid to cope with the economic shock.
"We can't just leave ruins here," said Rita Sussmuth, the president of Parliament.
The vote, which was conducted openly, cut across ideological and geographic lines. Leaders of the major parties and lawmakers from eastern and western Germany spoke on both sides of the issue.
Twelve of the 16 German state governments urged that Parliament choose Berlin. Among them were all five of the states that made up the former East Germany.
Chancellor Kohl attended part of the debate, and spoke briefly. He reiterated his support for Berlin, but said he hoped the debate would not become a source of future discord.
"However the vote comes out, I hope we all understand that it should not affect our duty to help the country grow together," he said.
The treaty under which Germany was united last October designated Berlin as the capital, but did not specify where the Prime Minister and other ministers would work.
"Since we have said that Berlin is the capital, it stands to reason that the Parliament and the Government should be there," said Klaus Reichenbach, one of the first lawmakers to speak in favor of Berlin. Civil but often passionate, it was the most vigorous debate to date in the new Parliament.
 
A Study in Contrasts
 The two cities represent the poles of German society. Bonn is a traditional sleepy Rhine city, eclipsed to a large extent by nearby Cologne and Frankfurt. Berlin is a sophisticated metropolis that was for generations one of Europe's most attractive cities, rivaling London and Paris as a center of creativity.
Once the seat of the Prussian kings, Berlin became the capital of the German empire when Otto von Bismarck unified the country in 1871.
Lawmakers who favored Berlin pointed to the commitment made by West Germany's founders in 1949 to return the capital there.
"The credibility of this Parliament is at stake," said Gabriele Iwersen of the Free Democratic Party said. "It was always understood that when Germany became free and united, Berlin would be the capital."
Lawmakers who favored Bonn argued that it was already a smoothly functioning capital; that to move it would cost an enormous amount of money, and that Berlin's history made it a dangerous choice.
"With the name of Bonn, we associate the longest period of peace enjoyed by any German state," said Labor Minister Norbert Blum.
"Bonn will lose a great deal if it loses the Bundestag," or federal assembly, "and the Government," he said. "Berlin, on the other hand, would win only problems: housing, rent, traffic and environmental problems."
Among those who spoke for Berlin were several former leaders of the non-Communist Government that briefly ruled East Germany in 1989.
"To me, the fact that we are even discussing this question here today is a scandal," the former East German Foreign Minister, Marcus Meckel, said. "We are only asking you to do what you said for so many years you wanted to do."
"A vote for Bonn would be seen as a betrayal by many people in the east who worked and fought for unity," Mr. Meckel said.

HEADLINE: Dinkins to Crack Down on Guns in Public Housing

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins announced yesterday that the city would mount a major campaign to evict public housing tenants who own guns illegally. In a dramatic reflection of his theme, his speech in a Brooklyn housing project was interrupted by the noise of nearby gunfire.
The plan, modeled on programs under which hundreds of drug dealers have been evicted, would be the most sweeping effort of its kind in the nation, although a similar effort has been mounted in Chicago. But civil liberties advocates in New York immediately challenged the constitutionality of evicting people merely for possessing guns illegally. 
 No one was injured when a string of shots rang out across the Cypress Hills Houses project in the East New York section, but some in the crowd of 150 listening to Mr. Dinkins ducked and others started to run.
After a moment of shouts and confusion, the Mayor calmed the jittery crowd, telling them to let the police handle the situation. He then finished his 25-minute speech and stayed to shake hands with residents of the drug-embattled project.
"The irony of it," the Mayor said later. "Here I am talking about gun control and I'm hearing gunshots."
Hearing shots and ducking for cover, people in the audience said later, is a familiar activity in the Cypress Hills Houses, where a 4-year-old was hit in the leg by a stray bullet early Monday.
"To the Mayor, the gunshots probably came as a surprise," said Timothy Luis, who is 40 years old. "To those of us who live here and raise our children out here, the shots were nothing out of the ordinary."
In the last six months, 72 people have been killed and 470 have been wounded by gunfire in public housing projects in New York City, housing officials said.
The program the Mayor announced includes a number of initiatives to rid the projects of people who own guns illegally. The plan would start eviction procedures against tenants who have been arrested on weapons charges, would speed criminal prosecution of the cases and would offer cash bounties to people who tip off the police about residents who keep weapons.
It also calls for the deployment of 63 officers on overtime wages to patrol nine of the most dangerous projects every day between midnight and 4 A.M.
 
'Why Should I Harbor Criminals?'
 "People are living in terror and many are living captive to the inner rooms of their apartments," said Laura D. Blackburne, the chairwoman of the Housing Authority. "It infuriates me because it is not necessary. I have 200,000 good families on my waiting list who want to get into public housing, so why should I harbor criminals?"
Ms. Blackburne and the plan's proponents say they are certain of their legal right to evict people for possessing illegal guns, but civil libertarians say such a blanket rule may run afoul of constitutional guarantees to due process under the 14th Amendment.
"We have serious problems with it because it's another attempt at a shortcut," Norman Siegel, director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said. "What they would have to show in our opinion would be activity that interferes with other tenants and their rights."
Ms. Blackburne and Federal housing officials disagree, saying the state housing authority law and Federal regulations give the authority the right to evict "undesirable" tenants.
"We believe that we have as much right to require occupancy standards as any other landlords," Ms. Blackburne said. "The possession of illegal firearms is a crime and we have no responsibility to house criminals. If we can evict people for keeping unauthorized dogs in their apartments, then we can evict people who keep guns in their apartment."
Ms. Blackburne said the authority would also require all tenants to sign an amendment to their leases specifying that illegal gun possession and drug-related activity are causes for eviction. In addition, the authority will set up a hot line number -- (212) GUNSEND -- for residents to provide information about illegal gun possession to the police on an anonymous basis.
The authority has been successful in ousting residents accused of drug dealing. In addition to using the normal eviction procedure, which can take up to three years, housing officials said, the authority, along with District Attorneys and Federal prosecutors, has also used a state statute, the Bawdy House Law, that allows the evictions of tenants who use their apartments for "illegal or immoral activities," and Federal forfeiture laws to cancel the leases of drug-dealing tenants.
In 1990, the authority evicted 492 families and individuals for drug dealing. None of the evictions have been successfully challenged, officials said.
In Chicago, lawyers for the city's Housing Authority said they had not met any serious legal challenges to evictions for gun possession, although the National Rifle Association has threatened to take the issue before a judge.
There was no evidence that the shots that interrupted Mr. Dinkins's speech were intended for the Mayor, said Vincent Pizzo, the Chief of Detectives for the housing police. He said the shooting was caused by an argument between two groups of young men in front of a Cypress Hills building at 700 Euclid Avenue, which is about a block and a half from where the Mayor was speaking.
A 22-year-old man who lived in that building was arrested last night and charged with firing the shots. The suspect, Ivan McLoughlin, who is unemployed, was charged with reckless endangerment and criminal possession of a weapon.
Mr. Pizzo said the two groups were apparently arguing over drugs or turf. He said the gun had not been recovered.
The Mayor had received an anonymous death threat earlier in the day, but the police discounted it and said there was no connection to the shots.

HEADLINE: Plan to Raise Foreign Cash For Airlines

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, June 20

 BODY:
The Bush Administration will seek legislation to allow foreigners to own up to 49 percent of the voting stock of United States airlines, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today. The proposal is intended to attract foreign capital to shore up the troubled American industry.
In January, Mr. Skinner decided to allow foreign carriers to buy up to 49 percent of the equity of American airlines, but a 25 percent limit remained on voting rights. He said today that the change had proved insufficient to attract as much foreign capital as the airlines need. 
 In a speech to the American Chamber of Congress chapter in Britain today, and at a news conference afterward, he also called for the European Community to begin talks with Washington about an agreement that would replace bilateral aviation treaties between the United States and the 12 individual community members. Mr. Skinner said the Administration, which is negotiating with Canada about opening up domestic markets to each other's airlines, wants an agreement that would deregulate and create much more competition and service in the trans-Atlantic market.
Discussing the need for capital, he pointed out that the downturn in airline traffic caused by the Persian Gulf war and the recession had left several carriers in a precarious financial position. Eastern, Continental, Pan American and Midway have filed for bankruptcy protection from their creditors, and Trans World Airlines is also weak.
He also said that United States airlines needed foreign investment to pay for the large number of new aircraft they had ordered. "U.S. passenger carriers have firm orders for over $47 billion in new aircraft between 1991 and 1995," he said. "Yet a major U.S. financial institution estimates that an additional $11 billion will be required to cover those costs beyond lease financing and returns from operating cash flow."
Mr. Skinner said he had chosen the 49 percent figure because he doubted Congress would agree to allow foreigners to control an American carrier. One issue is national security: During the Persian Gulf crisis, for instance, the Government called on American carriers for help in transporting troops and equipment.
 
Welcomed by Foreign Airlines
 British Airways and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines today welcomed the Administration's decision to seek the change in the law, but said they would be more excited once Congress passed such a law.
Mr. Skinner said he hoped to obtain the change in the foreign-ownership law this year. But he said he was firmly opposed to re-regulation. The Bush Administration is concerned that some in Congress, like Representative James Oberstar, a Minnesota Democrat who is chairman of the House aviation subcommittee, want some re-regulation and might make this the price for allowing an increase in foreign voting rights.
Several European carriers have already bought minority stakes in United States carriers. KLM owns 10.5 percent of the voting rights and 20 percent of the equity of Northwest Airlines. Scandinavian Airlines System owns 18.4 percent of the voting rights and 16.8 percent of the equity of Continental, and an S.A.S. spokesman said the company did not plan to increase that stake. And Swissair and Singapore Airlines each has a stake of about 5 percent in Delta Air Lines, which has a similar stake in them.
British Airways has been eager to buy a controlling interest in a United States carrier that might feed it international passengers. Airline industry analysts speculate that British Airways may be interested in USAir, which has lagged in expanding into the North Atlantic market. A deal that would have given British Airways a sizable stake in United Airlines fell through in 1989.
Mr. Skinner noted that a big obstacle to starting talks on an "open skies" agreement with the European Community was that the community is in the midst of a deregulation process aimed at turning the 12-nation market into a single market with much more competition.
British Airways, Western Europe's largest carrier, has been lobbying for Britain and the community not to negotiate new deals with the United States until European deregulation is completed. Then, it argues, the community would be in a stronger bargaining position.

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
Britain And Europe

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: OXFORD, England

 BODY:
Imagine Rip Van Winkle awakening after decades and finding the politicians of his country arguing exactly the same issue as when he went to sleep. That is what he would find in Britain today: the same old arguments, long since threadbare, about Britain's place in a uniting Europe.
Here are the same old fears of wily Continentals and Brussels bureaucrats, the same obsession with "sovereignty." And the same delusion that Britain can go it alone. 
 To find those attitudes still is to confront a painful truth about Britain. The political culture of this country has atrophied. The vision and daring that once put the mark of Britain on the world has shrunk. Mentally, it is a small island.
Forty years ago, when the European Community was formed, Britain stayed out. It was a disastrous decision; the British economy fell further and further behind the Community's. In time Britain sought to enter, and eventually got in. But it has been a grudging member, repeatedly resisting efforts toward greater economic and political unification.
This week the E.C. foreign ministers discussed a draft of a revised Community treaty. The preamble spoke of "a process leading gradually to a Union with a federal goal." This anodyne sentence set the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, off like a rocket. Britain could never accept the word "federal," he protested.
Much of the popular British press also reacted with expostulations. Even The Times charged Jacques Delors, the president of the European Commission, with twisting "the federalist screw."
As a matter of dictionary meaning the reaction was preposterous. The word "federal" signifies a political system in which much power is retained by constituent states, as in the United States. But the reaction was a question not of logic but of emotion -- instinctively anti-European emotion.
Then in waded Margaret Thatcher. In a speech in New York, the former Prime Minister condemned the Community's plans to move toward a common monetary policy and a single currency. Britain's Parliament had managed its economic affairs for 700 years, she said, "and most of us think" that that system "should be kept for the next 700."
The speech showed Mrs. Thatcher's true beliefs, concealed to a degree in office. She detests the whole idea of the Community, seeing it as an infringement on British sovereignty. What she wants instead is an Atlantic free trade area including the United States -- and inevitably dominated by it -- with no common economic or political institutions.
Mrs. Thatcher's views have little or nothing to do with reality. For example, she objects to the idea of a single European central bank, arguing that it would end Britain's right to make its own monetary policy. But in fact today the German Bundesbank makes the decisions that matter, and Britain has less input into its workings than it would with a European bank.
The blindness of Mrs. Thatcher, and her detachment from reality, were bad enough. Even worse was the reaction of her successor as Prime Minister, John Major. He fudged and fumbled, as if he were afraid to say anything very definite.
In the last 40 years Britain has had just one Prime Minister who really understood that the country's destiny lay in a uniting Europe. That was Edward Heath, who negotiated Britain's entry into the Community. He denounced Mrs. Thatcher's speech this week, angrily and rightly, but he did not get much support from other politicians.
What is so sad about all this is that the British people and their leaders are missing the chance to take part in a great enterprise. The shaping of a new Europe, slow as it has been and must be, is in truth a political drama of a high order.
Think what America would be like if our Constitutional Convention 200 years ago had been dominated by little minds like most of today's British leaders. The delegates would have been intent on protecting their little state sovereignties, and there would be no United States.
The European Community does not have to end up as a United States of Europe. But it must develop a constitutional faith of its own, a federalism of ancient cultures. Britain of all member states should be playing a full part in the shaping of that future. Alas, there is no sign that it will.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Learning With Yeltsin

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The last time Boris Yeltsin was in Washington he had advice for the United States about how to deal with the Soviet Union. It is lucky we did not listen to him -- lucky for us, for the Soviet people and particularly lucky for Boris Yeltsin.
Mr. Yeltsin then was the leader of the opposition to Mikhail Gorbachev within the Communist Party. In the U.S., he criticized Mr. Gorbachev and said that within a year the Soviet Union might fall into the abyss. 
 So, he said, hurry up and give the Soviet Union loans, credits, technology, build a million apartments for us -- take the heat off and maybe we won't fall in. He sketched out his own goals if he ever had the chance to change the Soviet economy: 10 to 15 percent privately owned, 85 to 90 percent state-owned or collective.
At that time, way back in September 1989, the United States declined the urgent advice of Mr. Yeltsin and of the collection of Soviet and American experts who also were telling Washington to jump in with large-scale aid to save Mr. Gorbachev, or positively rue the day.
Listening to Mr. Yeltsin now, I keep wondering what would have happened if the U.S. had accepted his advice to prop up the then-existing Soviet structure. Certainly the present chance for total change would have disappeared for years. And it is reasonable to suppose that a freshly strengthened Communist machine would have forbidden such nonsense as the free election that has just made Mr. Yeltsin president of the Russian republic.
Now he is giving different and more sensible advice. He is finished with Communism and with Socialism -- none of this about just 10 to 15 percent private. He tells Washington not to give aid either to the Kremlin or Russian bureaucracies. The right way, he says, is through private investment in private enterprise.
The lesson is that Mr. Yeltsin was wrong in 1989 when he urged the U.S. to intervene in Soviet history by massive aid that would have kept the remnant Soviet system alive longer. He has gone a long way since then.
But whole faculties full of American and Soviet economic experts are still telling us it is Gorbachev or disaster, so quick with the billions.
No, the time for help is when we can be sure that aid does not go to saving a system the Soviet people despise -- or into the mattresses of Communist apparatchiks suddenly converted to capitalism.
The Soviet people deserve more than economic change. Free markets yes, but that may take years. The U.S. and all other Western countries are still working on it themselves.
Soviet political freedom -- the right to vote, think, write, believe -- can come quickly and is important beyond Soviet boundaries. Democracies do not go to war with each other.
For Soviet citizens who fought the Communist system while Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin were part of it, the litmus test is the K.G.B. Neither have fully committed themselves; the K.G.B. is still too powerful.
After five years in power, Mr. Gorbachev liberated most political prisoners. But the chief of the K.G.B. is very close to him -- ever closer.
In Washington, Mr. Yeltsin says the K.G.B. is a monster. He says he intends to reduce its size, and on Russian soil will be its boss. He says he hopes that one day its job will be limited to fighting crime and protecting human rights.
The millions of Russians who have been sent to K.G.B. political prisons by K.G.B. judges may be sourly amused by the idea of the K.G.B. turning into the Russian branch of the International League for Human Rights. They want no new boss for the K.G.B. and no K.G.B. -- just an accounting of its crimes.
 But Mr. Yeltsin has something essential that Mr. Gorbachev dares not reach out for -- the support of the Russian people, in open election, for himself and the democratic road.
Mr. Yeltsin quit the Communist party on July 12, 1990. It makes me a little queasy for the U.S. to embrace a longtime Communist leader with the enthusiasm that we should save for Communism's victims. But he was elected freely and fairly and he represents hopes for more of the same in the Soviet Union.
So he deserves a clap on the back, and that fine Stetson cowboy hat that Senator Bob Dole gave him. When Mr. Yeltsin visits again and tells us that he has wiped out the K.G.B., we will give him the horse.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Generally Higher and Gold Moderately Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mostly higher in quiet trading yesterday as the foreign exchange markets awaited the outcome of a weekend meeting of Group of Seven monetary officials. Gold prices fell moderately. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold fell $2.10 an ounce, closing at $365.90. The Republic National Bank later quoted gold at $365.50, off $2.50.
The dollar has soared about 20 percent in recent months on optimism about an economic turnaround in the United States. The improving economy raises the prospects of higher interest rates, which support the dollar by increasing foreign demand for United States investments. 
 Analysts said traders were unwilling to make commitments before Sunday's meeting in London. Finance ministers from the seven nations -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada -- were gathering to discuss the dollar's recent rise and what to do about it.
 
Skepticism Over Group's Stand

Earl I. Johnson, a vice president with Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said the market was skeptical about the group's ability to agree on a strong stand on the dollar.
"The market will take it as a free license to buy dollars" on Monday if nothing concrete emerges from the meeting, Mr. Johnson said.
Overseas dealers said they expected a communique from the group that would be sufficiently ambiguous to leave the market guessing and remove any incentive to buy the dollar heavily.
The British pound slumped against the dollar, falling to $1.6260 in New York, from $1.6355 late Thursday. In earlier London trading, the pound was unchanged, at $1.6310.
The dollar rose to 138.90 Japanese yen in New York, from 138.22. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar fell 0.05 yen, to a closing 139.05 yen, and in London it was quoted at a lower rate of 138.85 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.8015 German marks, up from 1.7915; 1.54785 Swiss francs, up from 1.5355; 6.1225 French francs, up from 6.0925; 1,341.25 Italian lire, up from 1,334.00, and 1.14325 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1415.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's, included: 1.7990 German marks, up from 1.7953; 1.5460 Swiss francs, up from 1.5375; 6.1115 French francs, up from 6.1055; 2.0265 Dutch guilders, up from 2.0220; 1,338.25 Italian lire, down from 1,338.50, and 1.1428 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1413.
In London, gold fell to a late bid price of $366.80 an ounce, from $367.75 late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $366.50, from $368.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 20 cents an ounce to close at $368.09.
Silver slipped 7.1 cents an ounce on the Commodity Exchange to close at $4.374. In London, silver rose to a late bid price of $4.45 from Thursday's $4.43.

HEADLINE: What Next? The Macaroni Knows

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Spotting the recession's end is not that hard. Just forget the index of leading economic indicators. Ignore consumer confidence. And don't even give a passing thought to the stock market. Ponder, instead, macaroni and cheese. Kraft General Foods does.
Like ancient Roman priests peering at bird entrails, executives at the nation's largest food company contemplate the vagaries of creamy carbohydrates for clues to the economy. 
 When the country feels flush, Kraft executives say, people buy fancy foods, like caviar or arugula. But when the going gets tough, the tough get macaroni and cheese -- cozy, filling, and, above all, the right price at an average of 54 cents for a 7 1/4-ounce package.
 
Not Scientific but . . .
 If oddball indicators like macaroni and cheese often lack the scientific validity of true indicators, like the Commerce Department's index of leading economic indicators, they somehow seem to make more sense.
When motor-oil sales slump, for example, the makers of motor oil conclude that recession-spooked drivers are skimping on their cars. When sales of cats pick up, pet retailers say people want an animal that does not eat as much as a dog. And apparel makers think that when sales of cheap sweatshirts heat up, it means, well, nobody really knows what that one means.
At Kraft General Foods, executives swear by the macaroni and cheese index. The economy turned down last July, and sure enough, sales of macaroni and cheese turned up. That month, Americans bought the equivalent of more than 53 million boxes of macaroni and cheese of all brands, compared with 50 million in July a year earlier.
Macaroni and cheese is "a classic recession food," said Michael A. Miles, the former chairman of Kraft General Foods who will soon become chairman of the Philip Morris Companies, which owns Kraft.
And at the moment, the macaroni and cheese index is showing some hopeful signs. This year, Kraft expects Americans to buy nearly 748 million boxes of macaroni and cheese, or about 3 boxes each, up 2.9 percent from 1990. That modest gain would be considered a good economic sign, because it would be a reversion to the growth rate of the 1980's, after the 3.4 percent spurt in 1990 at the start of the recession.
Coincidence? Well, yes, maybe. The reason hordes of economists do not feed, so to speak, data on macaroni and cheese into their computers is simple. Sales of the food may signify nothing, no matter how closely they track the gross national product. And even in tough times, people still like their little indulgences, like a fine silk blouse or a dish of rich super-premium ice cream.
In the $5 trillion American economy, there are many events that only seem to be related to other events. Gumming up the economic forecasting game are what James H. Stock, an economics professor at the University of California at Berkeley, calls "spurious co-movements" -- trends that only seem important.
"Technically speaking," Mr. Stock said, "you want something that is not only plausible but is also a stable statistic relating to economic activity over many recessions."
Mr. Stock is a researcher at the National Bureau of Economic Research who is trying to refine the Government's index of leading indicators. His staff has combed hundreds of statistics, looking for good indicators to add to the index. In addition to problems with spotty or otherwise inadequate data, they are bedeviled by real-world changes that invalidate the prospective indicators.
"Let's take drafting paper for architects," Mr. Stock said. "The higher the sales, the more blueprints for buildings, the more buildings get built, the better the economy, right? But sales dropped, not because of economic activity but because architects now use computer-aided design. So the stability of the relationship breaks down over time."
Then there is the motor-oil index, which is sluggish. Valvoline Inc., a leading maker of motor oil, estimates that the sales of motor oil will rise only 1 percent this year, to 593 million gallons, about the same rate as that of 1990 and half the usual rate of increase. "In a recession, people re-examine their motor-oil-changing behavior," said Larry K. Solomon, Valvoline's manager of market analysis.
 
 Pets as an Indicator

Maybe people are staying home and feeding their new cat. The cat index is up. Retail sales of cats in pet stores shot up 66 percent last year, to $25.6 million, according to Pet Supplies Marketing magazine. Sales may be rising because cats are generally cheaper to buy ($20 for a kitten, $100 for a puppy) and cost less to feed (a few ounces of food a day for a cat compared with a pound or more for a dog). On the other hand, sales rose steadily throughout the 1980's, when the economy was expanding.
And on the third hand, the popularity of cats may have nothing to do with the economy. "The cat is a loner, and can pretty much fend for himself for the day," said Hugh E. Bishop, editor of Pet Supplies Marketing. "You've got to socialize with a dog, sometimes a lot."

HEADLINE: Japan's Socialist Party Leader Quits

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 21

 BODY:
The leader of the Socialist opposition, the best-known woman in Japanese politics, said today that she would resign to take responsibility for the party's recent electoral defeats.
The resignation of the politician, Takako Doi, after five years as the leader of the Japan Socialist Party marks the end of a failed revolution in postwar Japanese politics. 
 Her party's tremendous success in the summer of 1989, in the aftermath of an unpopular new sales tax and a huge corruption scandal that engulfed the governing Liberal Democratic Party, led many to predict that Miss Doi could become the first woman to be Japan's prime minister.
But the party quickly floundered amid factional bickering. Most of the disputes centered on whether the party should abandon its more radical platforms -- particularly its insistence that Japan cancel its 30-year-old security treaty with the United States and dismantle its military -- in favor of positions that would attract more mainstream voters.
 
'Time for New Faces'
 Miss Doi, who is 62 years old, referred to that debate in a brief news conference today, saying she wanted to "pave the way for the reform of the party."
"It's time for new faces," she said, looking drawn but somewhat relieved.
While her successor has not yet been officially named, the nearly certain choice is Makoto Tanabe, a senior deputy chairman of the party and the leader of its most conservative faction.
Among party members, Mr. Tanabe has often been charged with working too closely with some leaders of the Liberal Democrats. But his selection would probably quiet speculation that the Socialists will split into two parties.
Mr. Tanabe also lacks Miss Doi's greatest asset: her instant recognizability in a political world that is almost entirely dominated by elderly men.
 
A Forceful Style
 In campaign stops around the country, Miss Doi was known for her forceful, no-nonsense speaking style. It was a style particularly suited for politics here in the summer of 1989, after the Recruit stock and influence-peddling scandal had led to arrests and resignations. Miss Doi capitalized on the anger at the governing party and on the unpopularity of the 3 percent consumption tax.
In that election, the Liberal Democrats lost control of the upper house of Parliament for the first time in 35 years. The Socialists, hoping to build on Miss Doi's popularity among women, started what became known as the "Madonna strategy," fielding large numbers of women for local and national posts.
But after initial success, the strategy quickly faltered. Powerful business groups counterattacked, asserting that the Socialists lacked any vision for the nation and held fast to a platform that threatened economic prosperity. As the Recruit scandal faded, that argument drew many disaffected Liberal Democrats back into the fold.
In elections for the more powerful lower house of Parliament in February, the governing party did much better than expected, losing only 20 of the 293 seats it held before the Recruit scandal. While the Socialists did better than at any other time in recent memory -- winning 26 percent of the seats, up from 16 percent -- most of those gains came at the expense of smaller opposition parties.
Then in local elections in April, the Socialists failed to make any gains at all, even though the Liberal Democrats were badly divided.
 
Party Mishandling Charged
 "A great deal of Doi-bashing has gone on," said Masao Kunihiro, a close adviser to Miss Doi. "But the Socialist Party also handled some things in a miserable, lucrative way. The party thought that it won in 1989 by virtue of its own merits. The real reason was that the L.D.P. committed so many blunders."
Miss Doi herself never seemed in control of the party. A former professor of constitutional law, she is not a member of any of the party's major factions, and was chosen by party elders who badly needed a fresh face to regenerate the party, which has not headed a government since 1948.
The party also struggled with how to tone down its Marxist-Leninist dogma. The left and right wings of the party have spent the last year arguing vociferously over whether to abandon fundamental positions.
In the end, compromises were reached that resolved some issues and sowed even further confusion on others. For instance, drafts of the party's new platform recognize Japan's right to defend itself, but insist that the Self-Defense Forces, as the military here is called, are unconstitutional in their present form. It still condemns the security treaty with the United States, but in more muted terms. It drops some of its objections to building new nuclear power plants, where previously it had opposed all such development.

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Link With Lotus Is Expected

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
I.B.M. and the Lotus Development Corporation plan to announce an alliance based on Lotus software designed to permit groups of office workers to share electronic information and to work on common projects using personal computers.
Analysts and several industry executives said that under an agreement scheduled to be announced at an I.B.M. news conference Monday in New York, the International Business Machines Corporation would agree to use an innovative Lotus program called Notes in its OfficeVision desktop software. 
 The analysts said the Lotus-I.B.M. deal was a good indication of how new software and computer technologies were rapidly changing business alliances and reshaping the computer business.
 
 New Style of Computing

Notes represents a new style of computing, referred to variously as network or interpersonal computing, that is the fastest-growing sector of the computer industry. With Notes, computer users can confer on their individual computers, adding comments and reading those of other participants. Corporations are beginning to link thousands of desktop machines, and as a result they are searching for software that harnesses the power of these networks.
I.B.M. confirmed that the company planned a significant software announcement on Monday, but it refused to divulge details.
The agreement is expected to provide a vital lift for both companies. I.B.M.'s OfficeVision, software that performs a variety of basic office applications, has so far had only a lackluster reception from corporate and business users. Lotus, on the other hand, has been searching for an effective way to market its Notes program, which analysts said required more support from systems departments than other personal-computer programs.
 
 'Marriage Made in Heaven'

"This is a marriage made in heaven," said Stuart Woodring, an industry analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. He added that by using the Lotus software, I.B.M. would also receive a much-needed lift in the effort to market its OS/2 operating system.
The OS/2 program, which is intended to replace MS-DOS so that personal computers can use more memory and therefore run more powerful programs than DOS allowed, was originally introduced jointly by the Microsoft Corporation and I.B.M. in 1987. Few users made the shift, however, largely because of the high cost needed to adopt the program and the lack of advanced applications to run with it.
The new Lotus-I.B.M. strategic relationship is also a further indication of the growing separation between I.B.M. and Microsoft. The two had jointly dominated the direction of the personal computer industry until they separated their software development strategies last year. Microsoft is now at work on its own version of OS/2, called OS/2 3.0, which will run with the its program Windows. Windows controls a personal computer with the aid of a mouse pointing device.
 
 I.B.M. Effort to Get Partners

Since publicly breaking with Microsoft last September, I.B.M. has been seeking out a variety of business partners to help it develop an advanced-software strategy.
Most recently I.B.M. was reported to have entered into discussions with Apple Computer Inc., possibly to help develop an advanced operating system to run on future personal computers.
By contrast, Microsoft officials in Redmond, Wash., have recently begun to express dismay that many companies in the industry appear to be ganging up on it. In a memo written to his senior executives last month and recently reported by a number of newspapers, Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates, wrote: "Our nightmare -- I.B.M. 'attacking' us in systems software; Novell 'defeating' us in networking and more agile, lower-cost structure, and customer-oriented-applications competitors getting their Windows act together -- is not a scenario, but a reality."
 
 Importance of Lotus Alliance
 Analysts said the Lotus alliance was an important one for I.B.M. because it would give the Armonk, N.Y., computer maker access to software designed for the fast-growing network computing market, which is rapidly providing an alternative to traditional mainframe and minicomputer-based office systems.
"It puts I.B.M. a little ahead of the curve," said Stewart Alsop, publisher of the personal computer industry newsletter PC Letter. He added that it was another indication that I.B.M. was beginning to respond decisively to industry trends like downsizing and network computing.
"It's another reflection of the fear and loathing at I.B.M.," he said. "They're so scared now that they are starting to do the right thing."

HEADLINE: Seidman Asks for Hiring of a 'Strong' Bailout Chief

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, proposed today that a "strong" chief executive be hired to oversee the nation's savings and loan bailout and repeated his view that an additional $80 billion would be needed to keep the bailout going.
As part of a proposed restructuring of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency in charge of the bailout, Mr. Seidman presented two alternatives that would reduce the role of the F.D.I.C. in the trust agency's operations and would structure it more like a corporation. 
 Speaking before the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Seidman also denied that he was ousting David C. Cooke, the trust agency's current executive director. "No one has removed or agreed to remove Mr. Cooke in his current position," Mr. Seidman said.
The New York Times reported today that according to Administration officials, Mr. Seidman had decided to replace Mr. Cooke as a way to mollify Congress and win support for further trust agency funds. The agency is facing rising criticism over internal disarray and the rising cost of the bailout.
Mr. Seidman told The Times on Thursday that he had proposed a new position to manage the bailout and doubted that Mr. Cooke would want the job. Mr. Seidman added that Mr. Cooke, a 24-year career F.D.I.C. official, was "committed" to stay in his job only until Mr. Seidman's departure, which is expected in October.
But today Mr. Seidman sought to play down his earlier statements. In response to a question from the committee's chairman, Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, as to whether Mr. Cooke was being offered as a "human sacrifice," Mr. Seidman said, "I am not offering up any bodies for sacrifice."
And he praised Mr. Cooke, who was his choice to head the new agency, which was created by Congress in 1989 and has, so far, inherited some $318 billion in assets from failed savings and loan institutions.
"David Cooke has done an outstanding job under very, very trying circumstances," Mr. Seidman said. "He has put a new agency of the Government in operation."
And, he said, Mr. Cooke should not be blamed for any shortcomings of the agency. "If anyone is to blame, it's me," he added. "David is working under my direction."
Mr. Seidman said he would not be in a position to select a new chief executive should his proposal be enacted. And he acknowledged, in questioning after the hearing, that Treasury officials had "indicated they have some concerns about the management" of the trust agency.
For his part, Mr. Cooke, who sat behind Mr. Seidman at today's hearing, expressed "shock" at reports of his departure. At the same time, however, he made a distinction between the chief executive position being proposed by Mr. Siedman and his role at the trust agency, which he said was far more akin to being a chief operating officer who oversees the day-to-day operations of a large organization. "I'm not looking for the C.E.O.'s job," Mr. Cooke said. "My plans don't go beyond my job."
 
 'Will Continue to Serve'
 The trust agency said today that Mr. Cooke "will continue to serve" in his present position.
Under Mr. Seidman's proposal, the trust agency would be restructured to eliminate the role of the F.D.I.C. as manager of the agency. He offered two options -- one that provided for more independence by the trust agency and another, drafted apparently to meet objections from the Treasury Department, that would retain the trust agency oversight board, which would have been eliminated in Mr. Seidman's initial proposal.
"From the beginning, it was thought that the F.D.I.C. involvement should be temporary," Mr. Seidman said. "We've reached the point when the R.T.C. can operate without having the F.D.I.C. as general manager." F.D.I.C. involvement was deemed necessary at the beginning because of the insurance corporation's long history in closing failed financial institutions and selling their assets -- the same task faced by the trust agency.
 
'Normal Authority' Asked
 Mr. Seidman told the lawmakers that he felt the chief executive of this restructured organization should have the "normal authority and power and clear lines of authority" that is found in corporations. He added that the structure of the trust agency, which suffers from overlapping boards and confusing lines of authority "is not used anywhere else."
He said a "national search" should be undertaken to find the new chief executive, and that candidates should be sought from the private sector as well as within the trust agency and other Government agencies.
The pressure for making changes at the top levels of the trust agency has taken on increased urgency since it will soon be coming before Congress to ask for additional funds to continue the savings industry bailout.
Senator Riegle linked the agency's proposed management changes and its need for additional funds. "Unless there is an improvement in the general ability of the operation to function efficiently within an efficient structure, the support is not going to be there for the next funding leg," he said.
Mr. Seidman repeated an earlier estimate that $80 billion more would be needed to finance the bailout. The Administration is expected to ask Congress next week for at least $50 billion more for the bailout.
At the same time, Mr. Seidman repeated a higher set of estimates for the bailout's total costs, reflecting inflation and a decline in real estate values -- which comes to about $135 billion to $150 billion, depending on the number of savings and loan institutions that fail.
But that number does not reflect the total cost of the savings and loan crisis, which could reach $235 billion to $240 billion. That higher amount was arrived at, Mr. Seidman said, by including $66 billion to finance deals completed by regulators in 1988, before the trust agency was created, and $12 billion to $15 billion to refinance the savings and loan industry insurance fund.

HEADLINE: Budget Deficit a Factor as Bond Prices Fall

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday, while most shorter maturities posted modest declines. Dealers attributed the weaker bond prices more to the absence of buyers than any significant selling pressure.
What kept many buyers away, they said, was the record Federal budget deficit of $53.35 billion for May, the relatively large amount of short and intermediate Treasury debt scheduled for sale next week, and the usual caution that precedes a meeting of the Group of Seven nations. 
 While the budget deficit was only slightly higher than the previous record of $53.32 billion of March 1990, it followed a surplus of $30.13 billion reported for last April. The meeting of the seven major industrialized nations tomorrow is expected to ask for measures to reduce the value of the dollar. If so, it would make Treasury debt and other dollar-denominated investments less attractive.
"Also depressing the Treasury market is the relatively large amount of short- and intermediate-term notes on dealer shelves, which reduces the amount of cash available to take up the two- and five-year notes to be auctioned next week," said Andrew J. Schnydrig, Treasury securities trader at the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer of Zurich.
On Tuesday, $12.5 billion of two-year notes will be sold, followed on Wednesday by $9.25 billion of five-year notes. The notes traded on a when-issued basis to yield 6.96 percent and 7.94 percent, respectively.
In addition to the note auctions and a total of $20 billion in the regular Monday sales of three- and six-month bills, the Treasury will offer $12.5 billion of one-year bills on Thursday.
Mr. Schnydrig said that in view of the large inventories of unsold two- and five-year notes from last month's auctions, "the tendency of some market participants is to sell the short end and buy the longer maturities." He added, "But unless the Federal Reserve moves to ease interest rates soon, the reverse course may be the most practical."
In late trading, the Treasury's bellwether long bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing in May 2021, were offered at 95 28/32, down 15/32 on the day, which caused the yield to climb to 8.50 percent, from 8.46 the day before and 8.45 a week ago. The long notes, the 8's of May 2001, lost 8/32, at 97 31/32, for a yield of 8.30 percent.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
 WIDER 8-MONTH GAP
 WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Government posted a record $53.35 billion deficit in May, wiping out a surplus in April and surpassing the previous monthly high set 14 months ago, the Treasury said today.
The May imbalance increased the gap for the first eight months of the 1991 fiscal year to $175 billion, up from $151.49 billion in the corresponding period last year.

HEADLINE: GORBACHEV TO MIX PLANS ON ECONOMY OF LEFT AND RIGHT

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 21

 BODY:
Confronted with competing economic plans from left and right, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that he was preparing to combine them to present to the leaders of seven major industrial nations next month.
His decision not to support in its entirety the radical plan worked out by a liberal economist, Grigory A. Yavlinsky, in collaboration with Harvard economists and instead to seek to merge it with a somewhat more conservative "anti-crisis" reform favored by Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov, underscored Mr. Gorbachev's continuing efforts to keep a centrist policy, in the face of competing pulls and tugs. 
 Mr. Yavlinsky said at a news conference later that his program and that of Mr. Pavlov were not compatible. This is a view shared by President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic, who is now campaigning for reform on a trip to the United States, and by most Western economists as well.
 
Stormy Session of Parliament
 Mr. Gorbachev commented on the programs during a stormy session of the Soviet Parliament at which he fired an unusually fiery broadside at his hard-line critics and stopped the deputies from granting sweeping new powers requested by Mr. Pavlov.
Even though all the evidence during the week was of a fight between Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Pavlov, Mr. Gorbachev insisted that this was not so.
"There is no conflict between the President and the Prime Minister in principle, nor in human or organizational terms," Mr. Gorbachev said. He attributed the widespread reports to the contrary to "hysteria" fanned by his far-right foes.
 
Middle Ground Is Elusive
 Though the day's conflict was with the conservatives, who have not concealed their dissatisfaction over the President's truce with republican leaders and his initiatives to the West, Mr. Gorbachev suggested that he was still struggling to find that increasingly elusive middle ground between impatient reformers on the left and resentful conservatives on the right.
Mr. Gorbachev said his program would include elements of the Yavlinsky and Pavlov plans, plus suggestions from the International Monetary Fund and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
"It will be the program of the President with which I will go to London," Mr. Gorbachev said, referring to the July meeting with the leaders of seven industrialized powers. "There are no contradictions between the 'anti-crisis program' and the blueprints brought by Yavlinsky. Those who want to pass off the first as misconception and the second as brilliant foresight mislead society and provoke misunderstandings and clashes."
He denied that he was repeating the mistake he made last fall when he tried to combine the "500-Day" program of radical economic reforms -- to which Mr. Yavlinsky was a major contributor -- and the Government's considerably less dramatic reforms.
"A premature baby was born then in the form of the 'Main Guidelines,' " he acknowledged. But he insisted that there was no parallel, saying: "We had to cover this stage. Society was ill-prepared, no answers were available, we had to find the common mainstream of movement. We are now reaching a stage when direct action will be taken."
The latest challenge to Mr. Gorbachev took shape Monday, when Mr. Pavlov unexpectedly asked Parliament to give him additional powers independent of the President's. Under the arrangement in force since last fall, the Prime Minister and Cabinet answer directly to the President, who has broad powers to govern by decree.
 
Hard-Liners Watch Grimly
 Mr. Pavlov's request was caught up by the far-right "Soyuz" block and found support among the hard-line security leaders, Vladimir A. Kryuchkov of the K.G.B., Interior Minister Boris K. Pugo and Defense Minister Dimitri T. Yazov. All three sat together in a corner of the Supreme Soviet chamber today grimly watching the proceedings.
At the session, Mr. Gorbachev came out swinging. He turned on leaders of the Soyuz faction, accusing them of constantly seeking confrontation "for their narrow-minded purposes." He accused the co-chairmen of the bloc, Col. Viktor Alksnis and Yuri Blokhin, of "demagogic" efforts to trip him and his policies at every turn.
"You can take my statement as evidence that democracy is still in force, and nobody will usurp that democracy to achieve their own ends," Mr. Gorbachev declared to loud applause from liberal ranks in the Supreme Soviet. Those comments echoed to some extent the resignation speech last year by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who warned of the threat of a dictatorship from the right facing Mr. Gorbachev.
In the voting, Mr. Pavlov's request for additional powers was easily defeated in a procedural vote, and Parliament voted instead to request the President to study the proposal, insuring that it would die.
 
Pavlov Denies Conflict
 Mr. Pavlov, who sat through the debate grimly buried in paperwork, rose briefly to deny any conflict with the President and to declare his full agreement with the positions set out by Mr. Gorbachev.
Only one day earlier, however, he had repeated in a radio interview that he believed too many powers were concentrated in the President, saying, "I'm sorry, but one person can't substitute for the entire Government."
Mr. Gorbachev also emotionally defended his request for Western aid and his negotiations with leaders of nine republics on a new Union Treaty, both of which have been anathema to the right-wing.
"We need cooperation with the republics," Mr. Gorbachev said. "Those who say we should ignore the republics and other social-political forces have not understood what has happened recently."
He was especially forceful in defending his foreign policies, which lately have been focused on attracting new foreign assistance. "As long as I'm in office, I'll follow this foreign policy," he said. "We need it abroad, and we need it at home."
 
Defending the Center
 The right-wing challenge to Mr. Gorbachev was played out against the well-publicized American visit by Mr. Yeltsin, confirmed as the leader of liberal forces in his strong victory in the Russian federation's presidential elections last week.
The contrast underscored the task Mr. Gorbachev faces in defending his crumbling center against the increasingly antagonistic forces of left and right. After introducing "perestroika" in alliance with liberal reformers, Mr. Gorbachev shifted to the right last fall after losing faith in the radical reforms proposed by his liberal advisers, including Mr. Yavlinsky.
But after reaching a political stalemate and watching the economy deteriorate to dangerous levels, Mr. Gorbachev struck a truce with Mr. Yeltsin and eight other republican leaders in April. Since then, he has led intensive negotiations for a new union treaty in which the Kremlin would cede substantial authority to the republics, and has shown renewed interest in Mr. Yavlinsky's ideas.

HEADLINE: Scientists Encouraged By Two AIDS Vaccines

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FLORENCE, June 21

 BODY:
Scientists today reported surprisingly encouraging results from tests in the United States of a combination of two experimental AIDS vaccines in a small number of uninfected human volunteers.
The combination yielded the best immune responses recorded in vaccine experiments to date, the seventh international AIDS meeting was told, increasing hopes that a vaccine might be developed by the turn of the century. 
 As the meeting ended, the urgent need for a vaccine and improved treatment for AIDS was underscored by the head of the World Health Organization, Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima, who told the nearly 10,000 participants that AIDS had become "a public health threat of unprecedented magnitude."
 
Worldwide Epidemic
 The size of the worldwide epidemic and the impending social and economic consequences, particularly in Africa, "are truly awesome," Dr. Nakajima said. International and local partnerships "are vital if we are to prevail over a pandemic that threatens the stability, the socioeconomic development, and the very survival of whole communities and countries," he said.
The World Health Organization in Geneva, a co-sponsor of the AIDS meeting here, has estimated that 10 million adults and children have been infected and that the number will reach 40 million by the year 2000.
The vaccine findings were reported by Dr. Barney S. Graham of Vanderbilt University in Nashville, who said that the two AIDS vaccines were given months apart.
Ten healthy volunteers at low risk for AIDS and who had never been vaccinated against smallpox received the vaccines in the study carried out at Vanderbilt and four other medical schools in programs sponsored by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.
 
Genetically Engineered Vaccine
 The first vaccine was made by genetic engineering techniques. The gene for a protein on the outer coat of the AIDS virus known as gp160 was put into live vaccinia virus, which was once used to vaccinate against smallpox. The vaccine was made by Bristol Myers-Squibb and used vaccinia virus.
Most recipients developed only weak immune responses, although they usually lasted for more than a year, Dr. Graham said. The immune responses were a measure of the antibodies developed reacting to the vaccine.
Dr. Graham credited experiments carried out by researchers at the University of Washington in Seattle for his team's decision to use a second vaccine as a booster dose.
The booster is a subunit vaccine of purified gp160 made by MicroGeneSys Inc. The volunteers were given the booster from 11 to 27 months after the first vaccine.
After receiving the vaccine with the booster dose, the volunteers showed strong enough immune responses to gp160 to be in the range that would be expected for an effective vaccine, Dr. Graham said.
Further research is needed before larger trials are undertaken.
The international AIDS meetings customarily close with a welcoming speech from the chairman of the next meeting. But the next chairman, Dr. Max Essex of Harvard, said he was "not hopeful" the meeting would be held in Boston as planned.
"There will be no conference in Boston unless all American travel and immigration restrictions against HIV-infected people are lifted by August 3," Dr. Essex said. The human immunodefiency virus, or HIV, causes AIDS.
The International AIDS Society, which chooses the sites for the meetings, the World Health Organization and the National Commission on AIDS have said they would support the Boston meeting if travel restrictions alone were lifted.
But the Gay Men's Health Crisis and Act-Up, an advocacy group for people with AIDS, have said their members would disrupt and shut down any conference that takes place if the immigration restrictions were not lifted as well, Dr. Essex said.
Dr. Giovanni Battista Rossi, the chairman of the meeting here, said the organizers were sending Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, a summary of the latest findings that "confirm the unanimously held opinion regarding the negligible nature of" the risk of transmitting the AIDS virus from infected travelers.
Dr. Paul Volberding, the president of the International AIDS Society, which is based in Germany, said the society would withdraw its endorsement of the meeting if the ban was not lifted by Aug. 3. The Bush Administration has said it would decide by then whether to lift the ban. He said the society would not endorse any other site as a substitute, but gave no explanation.

HEADLINE: VICTORIOUS REBEL SEES ERITREA VOTE

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ASMARA, Ethiopia, June 20

 BODY:
With a modest show of war weaponry and a parade of guerrillas at an outdoor stadium, the leader of Eritrea addressed the people today for the first time since his rebel group defeated the last Ethiopian Army outpost in the region four weeks ago.
Dressed in civilian clothes instead of the khaki garb of his fighters, Isaias Afewerki, the 46-year-old secretary general of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, told the crowd that he would seek to legalize last month's military victory through a United Nations-sponsored referendum on independence from Ethiopia. He said the referendum, a basic goal of the Eritrean Front's separatist campaign, would take place within two years. 
 The vote, which is expected to favor independence by a wide margin, was expected earlier. But Mr. Isaias, flanked by Sudanese officials and a sole member of the new administration in Addis Ababa, said time was needed for the transition to independence. He also said it was necessary to promote stability in Ethioipa. The separation of Eritrea is strongly resisted in some influential sectors of Ethiopian society and could threaten the interim Government struggling to establish control in Addis Ababa.
Mr. Isaias has often said a stable Ethiopia is vital to the success of an independent Eritrean state. With its 600 miles of Red Sea coastline, an independent Eritrea would make Ethiopia a landlocked country.
In the last two years, Mr. Isaias has successfully courted American officials, and last month the United States endorsed Eritrean self-determination for the first time. The Eritreans claim that Eritrea, an Italian colony from the 1880's until World War II, was wrongly given to Emperor Haile Selassie in 1952. At first the region was part of a federated Ethiopia, but when Ethiopia annexed the region outright in 1962, the rebellion started. After 1977, it developed into a full-scale guerrilla war with the Soviet-backed Marxist Government of Mengistu Haile Mariam.
 
To Attend Ethiopia Conference
 To foster good relations with Addis Ababa, Mr. Isaias said he would attend a conference in Ethiopia on July 1 to form a provisional government there. The convening of the conference was part of the agreement with American officials in London last month, when the United States gave its blessing to the new administration of the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front, a group based in neighboring Tigre province. The Tigreans entered a loose alliance with the Eritrean Front in the battle against the Mengistu Government.
The United States said economic aid for Ethiopia was contingent on including all Ethiopian ethnic groups in a provisional government and asked Mr. Isaias to attend the conference.
The Eritrean Front is not expected to join the provisional Government in Addis Ababa, but Mr. Isaias said in an interview this week that he also had no intention of announcing a formal provisional government in Eritrea until after the referendum.
"The E.P.L.F. is the government of the day," he said. "We are saying take it or leave it."
Mr. Isaias said that he was keeping his title of secretary general and that departments of the Eritrean Front would be reorganized a bit and function as national institutions, but would not be named ministries.
Asmara and the rest of Eritrea remain cut off with no working public international telephone or telex lines.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Nomura Securities admitted that it had discriminated against the majority of its customers by improperly compensating some of its biggest clients for stock market losses. A Nomura executive also confirmed reports that the company, which wields enormous political influence, had provided more than $150 million in financing to one of Japan's most powerful and best-known crime families. The money was apparently used for a stock-manipulation scheme that Nomura helped execute. [Page 1.] 
 I.B.M. and Lotus Development plan to announce an alliance based on Lotus software designed to permit groups of office workers to share electronic information and to work on common projects using personal computers. [33.]
F.T.C. attorneys have been inquiring about Intel's business practices, industry executives said. It does not appear the F.T.C. has begun a formal investigation but rather that the agency is making some preliminary inquiries because it has received complaints of anti-competitive practices by the chip maker. [33.]
The F.C.C. gave permission to a start-up company to launch a satellite that will provide service to countries throughout Africa and the Middle East. It would be the first venture to broadcast radio programming directly to listeners by satellite. [33.]
Looking for an alternatve to the car? The Festival of Solar, Electric and Human-Powered Vehicles has begun a six-day trip to New York from Washington, featuring experimental bicycles and cargo tricycles, high-tech electric go-carts and a solar-powered plastic car. The vehicles will roll into New York on Tuesday. [33.]
A venture between G.E. and Snecma of France received an order for up to $1 billion in jet engines for the Soviet Union, the latest in a series of East-West aerospace deals. [35.]
 
 The Economy
The chairman of the F.D.I.C. presented two alternatives that would reduce the agency's role in the Resolution Trust Corporation, and would structure the trust agency more like a corporation. L. William Seidman also denied that he was ousting David C. Cooke, the agency's current executive director. [33.]
Spotting the recession's end is not hard. Just forget the index of leading economic indicators. Ignore consumer confidence. Ponder, instead, macaroni and cheese. Kraft General Foods does. [33.]
Credit bureaus have inaccurate data and do not keep a lid on their files, according to members of Congress, consumer advocates and individuals. [48.]
 
 International
The British Government will buy a battle tank built by Vickers, rejecting competing bids from the U.S., France and Germany. [35.]
 
 Markets

HEADLINE: I-80 Journal;
Where Interstate Means A War Along the Border

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAVENPORT, Iowa, June 18

 BODY:
To George Malito, Interstate 80 is not just a highway; it is an asphalt-covered conveyor belt bringing customers to the service station he operates here.
So when he heard about an attempt by Illinois to renumber part of the highway and thereby reroute some of the interstate's traffic through the Land of Lincoln, Mr. Malito was irate. 
 He wrote his Congressman and called every nearby hotel and restaurant he could think of to warn them about the threat coming from the other side of the Mississippi.
"What Illinois wants to do is to steal business from Iowa," he said the other day. "They just want to get some of our money."
For more than a year, Interstate 80 has been the source of a tug-of-war between Iowa and Illinois, a battle that even reached the United States Senate last week as members wrestled with provisions of the $123 billion Federal transportation bill.
At issue is a nondescript line of the east-west highway that cuts across the middle of Iowa, rolls past mile after mile of farmland and fast food signs as it approaches what is known as the Quad Cities, Davenport and Bettendorf in Iowa and Rock Island and Moline in Illinois. It then dips into Illinois and continues almost all the way to Chicago.
Interstate 280 is a short length of highway that quickly ducks below Rock Island and Moline before connecting again with I-80, which carries the bulk of the area's traffic.
Citing safety issues, Illinois proposes that I-280 be changed to I-80. A 30-mile stretch of I-80 in Iowa from about Davenport, east to the Mississippi River, would become I-74.
The effect would indeed be to rer oute more traffic through Illinois and, Mr. Malito and the Davenport Chamber of Commerce fear, away from Iowa businesses.
But Illinois officials say highway safety and the chance to save taxpayers $35 million in highway reconstruction -- not economic gain -- are the main reasons for the proposal.
The current problem, they say, is the winding and confusing convergence of interstates 80, 280 and 74 about 10 miles inside the Illinois border. The interchange has been the site of dozens of accidents and must be reconstructed at a cost of $35 million if the interstates are not renumbered and the traffic rerouted to avoid several sharp turnoffs, Illinois officials say.
Ken Schloemer, the chairman of the Illinois Quad Cities Chamber of Commerce coordinating committee, said, "We don't want to spend that tax money, when all we have to do is change the signs and save millions and millions of dollars."
But Ruth Shuck, the manager of a Davenport hotel, said she did not come all the way here from Memphis, Tenn., just to get thrown out of work. "For the life of me," she said, "I don't know why Illinois wants to meddle in Iowa's affairs."
But Mr. Schloemer contended: "We're not meddling in Iowa's affairs. The interchange is in Illinois and it's dangerous."
A spokesman for the Illinois Department of Transportation, Richard Adorjan, said some work on the interchange would have to be done no matter what happens to the road signs. But if the interstate is renumbered, he said, only about $2.5 million will have to be spent on improvements.
Iowans are not buying it. And right now, Iowa holds all the cards.
Under Federal rules, highway numbers affecting more than one state can only be changed when all affected states agree. So far, Iowa has said: "No. No. No."
Undaunted, Illinois tried an end run last week when one of its Senators, Alan J. Dixon, called for a measure that would have empowered the Secretary of Transportation to form a panel to decide the issue. The Senate also said no.
But Illinois may still have a plan or two just around the next bend.
"We're not discussing our plans," said Mr. Schloemer. "We're proceeding with other alternatives. You might say, Illinois has a history of not giving up easily. A great example of that is the Chicago Bulls."
The other day as the sun was setting over Davenport, weary travelers from West Virgina and Nebraska and other states filled the lobby of the Davenport Motel 6. The desk clerk, Kenny Sederstrom, said area businesses would not be the only ones to suffer if the highway is renumbered.
"I think," he said, "that changing the numbers would create one hell of a lot of problems for Rand McNally.'
