HEADLINE: Health Jobs Defy Recession in New York

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
New York's health-care industry is one of the few areas of growth in the city's faltering economy, providing thousands of new jobs, especially for immigrants and members of minorities.
But the growth has provided little stimulus to the economy over all, and the health-care jobs often offer workers only a tenuous economic foothold. 
 Pausing the other day as her colleagues marched to protest the lack of a new labor contract, Alta Gracia, a home health-care worker from Brooklyn, measured her progress in the decade since she arrived from the Dominican Republic.
 
Rapid Growth in Jobs
 She likes her job, most recently caring for an elderly woman who has diabetes and is confined to a wheelchair. She does not like the pay, about $11,000 a year. But any day now, Ms. Gracia, a single parent, will learn whether she has passed a state exam and can take the next step, into nursing and toward the middle class.
With an increase of 10,000 jobs in 1990 alone, New York City now has more than a quarter of a million private health-care jobs, a 33 percent rise from 1980. One of every 12 private jobs in the city is in health care, which has become New York's second-largest private industry after business services.
The proliferation of jobs at New York hospitals and clinics and the rapid growth of home care have partially offset the huge job losses the city has suffered in other areas in the last few years. The growth, coinciding with a surge in immigration to the city, has also recast traditional patterns of ethnic succession. There are home health-care workers from the Caribbean and South and Central America, and nurses from the Philippines and Ireland. Respiratory, X-ray and other technicians have arrived from India, Bangladesh and the Soviet Union.
Labor shortages still exist in many technical fields, and despite a basic union contract under which the most experienced nurses can earn $60,000 or more a year, they are still in demand.
But some economists and public-health experts regard the surge in health-care jobs warily.
Private hospitals are under increasing cost pressures and have already trimmed a few thousand jobs from their payrolls, and this week the city's Health and Hospital Corporation sent out 2,700 layoff notices covering virtually every type of position except nurses.
And far from strengthening New York City's position in research or advanced medicine -- and drawing new money to the city -- much of the health-care boom is seen by experts as the city's attempt to cope with drug abuse, AIDS, a rising birth rate and an aging population. These costly efforts are increasing the strain on city and state budgets and absorbing health-insurance premiums of residents and businesses.
"This employment is really a double-edged sword," said Kenneth E. Thorpe, associate professor at the University of North Carolina School of Public Health. "It's true it's a growth area, but if it wasn't a growth area, all that money wouldn't have to be spent, or could be spent on something else."
Although overshadowed by Wall Street and business and professional services, the city's health-care industry accounted for 60,000 new jobs in the 1980's, one in four created during that prosperous decade, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. The number of workers at the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, who are counted separately as public employees, reached 45,000, a gain of about a 25 percent, during the same time.
The number of private home-care workers -- narrowly defined by the labor statistics bureau as people who provide limited medical care under a doctor's supervision -- soared in the 1980's, to about 17,000 from 2,400. However, the hospital workers' union puts the total of home-care workers far higher, at about 70,000.
Jobs at drug, alcohol and other rehabilitation and outpatient clinics rose to 10,000 from 8,500. Jobs at homes for the aged and the handicapped and other residential-care centers rose to 18,000 from 10,000. Jobs in drug manufacturing, counted separately by Federal officials, increased to 8,800 from 8,300 in New York City between 1979 and 1987, a trend even more pronounced in New Jersey, where many large drug makers are located.
In recent years, said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, "health care has played a predominate role in whatever growth there has been in New York City's service industry."
But a report in October by the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York found that in 1988 and 1989, the increase in the number of physicians, laboratory technicians and other highly skilled professionals -- which was 6 percent nationally and 4 percent in New York State -- was just 1.7 percent in New York City.
"It appears that employment has been growing very rapidly in health care, but the most rapid growth is in the lower end," said Rae D. Rosen, the organization's vice president and senior economist.
"If that's where your growth is coming from, you won't get the multiplier effect," she added, referring to the progression in which salaries are spent and transformed into other salaries that are spent again, increasing their impact throughout the economy.
Because lower-paying jobs in health care and social services, which are largely health related, are increasing while new jobs in more lucrative fields such as law, accounting and engineering are growing scarcer, the result is a downward shift in New York's service economy. In the last three years, there have been 50,000 new service jobs created in the city, 80 percent of which were in health care, education or social services.
And despite the job growth, the city has been slipping in the share of grants and research money it attracts. Twenty years ago, the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York has reported, New York City captured 10 percent of the research funds from the National Institutes of Health, nearly a third more than second-place Boston. By 1987, Boston had moved ahead of New York.
Nonetheless, Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union -- which has grown to 100,000 members, from 65,000 in 1973 -- noted that hospitals are among the largest employers in some boroughs and are a source of stability in some of the city's poorest neighborhoods.
The union negotiated a contract for registered nurses in 1989 that has increased pay and improved recruiting, easing workloads and schedules.
Carol Johnson, a registered nurse in the medical-surgical department at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan, said she was considering leaving nursing a few years ago. Now, she said, "working conditions have tremendously improved."
A union-management training program has helped thousands of health-care workers, including dieticians, maintenance and clerical workers and nurses' aides, move into jobs as nurses, therapists and pharmacists, advancing their careers and helping to fill shortages in the industry.
But salaries for home-care workers are typically $9,000 to $11,000, and the workers have been without a contract for almost a year. Even with a better contract, advancement will be difficult for these workers, many of whom speak limited English and have little training. Should Ms. Gracia, who was a practical nurse in the Dominican Republic, make the transition in New York, she would be an exception, union officials say.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Gives His Regards To Wall Street (Soberly)

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

 BODY:
On his last day in America, Boris N. Yeltsin addressed the issue of hooliganism head-on.
Although he indulged a bit too much in Jack Daniel's and jackanapery on his last visit to the United States in 1989, leaving an impression of rowdiness, the new President of the Russian republic defended both his maturity and morality before an audience of students and guests at New York University yesterday. 
 "At the National Press Club in Washington, they mentioned that I sometimes spoke about myself as a mischievous person, something of a hooligan," he said in Russian, acknowledging that his remarks might be "quite unexpected or surprising."
"They should have gone a bit further and pointed out that, of course, when one is young, when you're a student, that's normal," he said. "You would not expect much more of that in me now."
Mr. Yeltsin, who clearly seemed sensitive about the issue of his image in America, also recounted a reporter's question about his morality. "They also asked me about my moral perspective," he said, "and what I said to that is that I've been married for 35 years and I've spent these 35 years with my wife and no one else."
Mr. Yeltsin had said at the Press Club event in Washington on Thursday that although he did not "have a real faith in God" and "although a lot of people have poured a great deal of slime on me, I still think of myself as a morally pure person."
Yesterday, he followed that up with praise of the Gospels, saying they were the "foundation of human morality."
Mr. Yeltsin is an impulsive and sentient politician, and at home that is part of his great appeal to the voters who gave him a resounding victory last week as the first popularly elected President of Russia.
 
Correcting Past Impressions
 But, on his four-day trip to Washington and New York, he wanted to convey a brisk, sober and businesslike demeanor, as a way of correcting any exaggerated impressions of his freewheeling style.
With symbols and substance, he wanted to show the skeptics -- including Mr. Bush and his advisers, who considered Mr. Yeltsin's behavior on his last trip petulant and dogmatic -- that he had grown into his role as a major force in Soviet politics.
Mr. Bush and his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, came away more impressed with Mr. Yeltsin this time around.
Although Mr. Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle elaborately praised President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a way of making it clear that his is the primary relationship on which they will focus, the President did put in a good word for Mr. Yeltsin when he talked to Mr. Gorbachev on the phone yesterday.
When Mr. Gorbachev called, Mr. Bush urged him to work with Mr. Yeltsin on political and economic reforms. In a 40-minute conversation, Mr. Bush also underscored the need to conclude a treaty reducing long-range nuclear weapons to pave the way for a United States-Soviet summit meeting this summer.
With the New York University students, Mr. Yeltsin struck an avuncular tone, telling them that "the college years are the most wonderful time in our lives, the feeling that your entire life is still ahead of you."
"Most important is the feeling of creativity, the freedom from prejudice or mental stereotypes, and the quest for the new," he said.
Outside the university's Vanderbilt Hall, where Mr. Yeltsin spoke, a group of demonstrators held signs that read, "Yeltsin: Wall Street Tool" and "Bush, Wall Street and Yeltsin Aim: Destroy Socialism, Bring In Capitalism, Poverty and Racism."
Mr. Yeltsin, who appeared buoyant about the reception he has gotten in America, was not deterred in his celebration of capitalism. He went on to spend the afternoon in New York meeting with Federal Reserve Bank leaders and business executives, trying to build confidence in investment possibilities in the Soviet Union.
At the university, he spoke of a vision in which most of the Northern Hemisphere would be led by similar political and economic principles.
"For the first time in our meeting with President Bush," he said of his hour-and-40-minute Oval Office talk with Mr. Bush on Thursday, "we have reached an understanding that, from now on, the United States will maintain direct contacts not only with the single Government of the Soviet Union" but also with the republics.
Administration officials said Mr. Yeltsin seemed to be overdramatizing the "understanding." They said the Administration has been reaching out to the individual Soviet republics for the last six months.
Also, Administration officials said the United States Embassy in Moscow has been expanding its contacts with the individual republics to follow the development in economic and political reform.
Before going to lunch at The New York Times, and then on to Wall Street, Mr. Yeltsin made a brief stop in the garment district to show that he had not lost interest in the fate of the working class.
He stopped at 530 Seventh Avenue and toured the offices of "Party Formals," the makers of the evening gowns that were worn by contestants in the 1991 Miss America contest.
Wearing an International Ladies Garment Workers Union hat, Mr. Yeltsin flipped through the pink satin strapless dresses, the jeweled jackets and the plaid sequined gowns.
Trying out a sewing machine while visiting with a dozen women who make patterns for $8 an hour, Mr. Yeltsin eyed a $500 sequined jacket and asked, "Is this for actors?"
No, he was told, it was not a costume, but a jacket that a typical woman might wear on an evening out.
Afterward, Mr. Yeltsin went to Wall Street for two meetings and dinner with officials of the Federal Reserve Board of New York and various corporate officials. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, flew in from Washington to attend the meetings and dinner.
The sessions drew such prominent financiers as Robert E. Rubin, co-chairman of the Goldman Sachs investment house. The visit was viewed primarily as a chance to discuss a number of issues that might affect American investment in the Soviet Union.
"Mr. Yeltsin is focusing more on direct investment than aid and that's why he seems interested in meeting American executives," said Robert D. Hormats, a vice president of Goldman Sachs.

HEADLINE: Thomas I. Emerson, 83, Scholar Who Molded Civil Liberties Law

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
Thomas I. Emerson, a legal theorist who was a major architect of civil liberties laws, died on Wednesday at the Yale Health Services Center in New Haven. He was 83 years old and lived North Haven, Conn.
He died of complications from a stroke, said Martha Matzke, a spokeswoman for Yale. 
 Professor Emerson, who taught at the Yale Law School for three decades, was a scholar whose career involved him in many of the great societal and political issues of the century.
As a young lawyer in 1931, fresh out of Yale, he served on the defense team that successfully appealed the convictions of the "Scottsboro boys," nine black Alabama teen-agers sentenced to death after they were convicted of raping two white women. The case came to be regarded as the beginning of the civil rights era.
 
Foreshadowed Roe v. Wade
 In 1965, Professor Emerson successfully argued Griswold v. Connecticut before the United States Supreme Court, which overturned a state law banning the sale of contraceptives. The ruling established a right to privacy and foreshadowed the Roe v. Wade decision legalizing abortion.
Professor Emerson was born in Passaic, N.J., and was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Yale before going on to its law school and becoming editor in chief of The Yale Law Journal.
He went to Washington with President Roosevelt's New Deal in 1933 and worked in the National Recovery Administration, on the National Labor Relations Board, on the Social Security Board and in the Attorney General's office.
In World War II he was deputy administrator for enforcement of the Office of Price Administration, general counsel for the Office of Economic Stabilization and general counsel of the Office of War Mobilization and Reconversion.
 
Honored for Civil Liberties Work
 He was named a professor of law at Yale in 1946 and in 1955 became the Lines Professor of Law. He retired in 1976. He was the author of several books, notably "The System of Freedom of Expression," published in 1970. It was regarded as a major treatise on free speech.
Professor Emerson was president of the National Lawyers Guild in 1950 and 1951 and was the first recipient of the American Civil Liberties Union Medal of Liberty for his lifetime service in defense of civil liberties.
He is survived by his wife, the former Ruth Calvin; a daughter, Joan, of San Francisco; two sons, Robert, of Los Angeles, and Dr. Luther Emerson 3d of Brattleboro, Vt., and three brothers, Luther Jr., of Demarest, N.J., James, of Lyons, Colo., and Paul, of Somerville, N.J.

HEADLINE: BAKER URGES END TO YUGOSLAV RIFT

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 21

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d made a highly unusual attempt today to persuade the feuding leaders of Yugoslavia's six republics not to let their country break up into separate states, but said his appeal got nowhere and that Yugoslavia could be headed for "disintegration."
Mr. Baker was visiting Yugoslavia for the first time, and was not expected to make much headway in defusing a welter of old nationalist feuds. Nonetheless, he sounded something of an international alarm.
 
Fear of Broad Consequences
 After individual meetings with the leaders of the six republics, Mr. Baker said he had heard nothing to reduce his fears that this nation could break up in violence, fomenting the kind of instability in the Balkan region that helped touch off World War I. 
 "We came to Yugoslavia because of our concern about the crisis and about the dangers of a disintegration of this country," Mr. Baker said. "Instability and breakup of Yugoslavia, we think, could have some very tragic consequences, not only here but more broadly in Europe. We are obviously not alone in having these concerns."
Mr. Baker continued: "The concerns that we came to Yugoslavia with have not been allayed by the meetings we had today. We think that the situation is very serious. We worry frankly about history repeating itself. Frankly, we don't want to see that and I don't think anyone in the international community wants to see that."
He told the Presidents of the republics of Slovenia and Croatia, who are planning to announce some form of independence in the next few days, that the United States and its European allies would not recognize them if they were to unilaterally break away from Yugoslavia and that they should not expect any economic assistance.
 
Withholding U.S. Recognition
 Mr. Baker told the President of Serbia, Yugoslavia's biggest and most populous republic and the one least willing to countenance any breakup of the 72-year-old country, that he should consider granting limited autonomy to republics within a looser federation in an effort to satisfy the different Yugoslav ethnic groups.
Speaking of the pending announcement of Slovenia's independence, which could come as early as next week, Mr. Baker said, "It would not be the policy of the United States to recognize that declaration because we want to see this problem solved through negotiations and through dialogue."
He said that while the United States wanted to see Yugoslavia's territorial integrity preserved, it would welcome any federal restructuring accepted by the republics.
American diplomats here said that since all the republics contain large minorities of people who identify culturally and linguistically with other republics, some form of federal arrangement would be preferable to separation.
"Everyone is interested in finding a way through dialogue to craft a new basis for unity of Yugoslavia and to find a way to see the devolution of additional authority and responsibility and sovereignty to the republics of Yugoslavia," Mr. Baker said.
President Ante Markovic, who is trying to hold his country together, met with Mr. Baker immediately after the Secretary arrived. After their meeting, Mr. Markovic made a speech to Parliament, warning that the federal army would "take measures" to prevent unilateral action by any republic to change the borders of Yugoslavia.
 
Republics Ignore Appeals
 The Secretary spent the afternoon holding separate 30-minute sessions with the Presidents of the six republics. But they ignored Mr. Baker's appeals, just as they have those from the Soviet Union and the European Community.
When the President of Slovenia, Milan Kucan, seated next to Mr. Baker, was asked what he wanted to hear from the Secretary of State, he answered, "That all the nations of Yugoslavia may live as they wish."
How would Slovenia like to live? he was asked.
"The same way as other European nations," he answered. "As an independent nation which, out of its own will, has ties with other nations."
On the other end of the issue, the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, told Mr. Baker that his republic was not interested in seeing the federal Government of Yugoslavia cede any serious powers to the republics.
 
'Limit to Our Flexibility'
 "Our policy is to preserve the integrity of our country in order to realize democratic changes within the country, but not to liquidate the country as a state," Mr. Milosevic said. "Flexibility has some limits."
The Federal Government must have "some minimal function without which Yugoslavia cannot be a country," he said. "It means defense, foreign affairs, human-rights protection, national rights protection and one market with one central bank."
The independent Yugoslav daily newspaper Borba said on Thursday that Mr. Baker "is arriving too late." Logical argument simply will not work at this stage, when ethnic and nationalist passions suppressed by 45 years of Communist rule are exploding to the surface, the paper said.
The republics are split three ways on the question of devolution. Slovenia and Croatia, the two most Westernized republics with the highest per-capita wealth, want to move ahead quickly with independence, but say they are prepared to take part in some loose federation with the other Yugoslav republics. Slovenia has already set up its own border posts and is planning to issue its own currency.
The largest republic, Serbia, which has traditionally dominated Yugoslav politics, and Montenegro, the smallest, want to preserve the status quo. Bosnia and Macedonia, republics created by the Communists after World War II, are pushing a compromise plan under which republics would be given partial sovereignty but the central Government would retain federal functions.
Mr. Baker flies on Saturday to Albania, which is emerging from decades of isolation and Communist dictatorship. A new coalition Government took over in Tirana this month.

HEADLINE: The Yeltsin Touch

 BODY:
On his visit to America this week, Boris Yeltsin has shown himself to be, in the very best sense of the word, a pol -- something to hearten Americans watching soberly as the Soviet people cross the great political and economic divide.
The Russian republic's president-elect talked easily with professional politicians, journalists and others, warmly complimenting the American system. He demonstrated wit, tenacity and a comfortable willingness to defer to his advisers on detail. He showed that he knows how to deal deftly with symbols, when he donned a cowboy hat and posed for photographers. 
 And, with one sentence, he demonstrated how to stand by President Mikhail Gorbachev even while reaffirming his own authority in the Russian republic: "While Gorbachev stands for reform, while Gorbachev stands for democratic change, while Gorbachev stands for the independence of the republics, Yeltsin stands for Gorbachev."
To Americans who worry that the new Soviet politics is all posturing and sloganeering without much democratic give-and-take between leaders and constituents, Mr. Yeltsin's performance is a revelation. The Soviet Union is going to need a lot more such political dexterity to emerge transformed from its current travail.
The challenges that the Soviet people confront would test the most skillful and dedicated of politicians. Lincoln had to bind up the wounds of secession. F.D.R. had to lead Americans out of the deprivation and despair of the Great Depression. Churchill and de Gaulle had to preside over the dissolution of empire. Today's Soviet leaders confront all these problems and more: They have to cope with the collapse of an entire political and economic system.
For generations, politics in the Soviet Union meant Byzantine maneuvering and public manipulation. The popular cynicism and distrust left behind makes leadership now even harder. Competitive elections are essential to allay the distrust, and renew the political elite. Otherwise an entrenched old guard will block economic and political reform.
That danger was apparent this week when Mr. Gorbachev, responding to the Communist Party's rout in Russia's election, showed signs of accelerating the move to markets. A sizable group of old-guard deputies in the Supreme Soviet tried to stymie him by enhancing the authority of Government ministries at his expense, but Mr. Gorbachev fended off a vote on the power grab with a scathing counterattack.
Soviet government won't work without the masterful inside politics practiced by Mikhail Gorbachev. But for the Government to build trust with the Soviet people requires a popular political touch like that demonstrated by Boris Yeltsin. The Soviet Union will need both sources of strength to survive the strain of difficult decisions still to come.

HEADLINE: How Banks Can Help Children

BYLINE: By Jill M. Considine and Linda Tarr-Whelan; Jill M. Considine, managing director of American Express Bank, was State Superintendent of Banks. Linda Tarr-Whelan is president of the Center for Policy Alternatives.

 BODY:
Bringing up children is a responsibility shared by parents and the community. Still, while 90,000 children under 3 years of age need day care in New York City, only 6,100 licensed slots are available. And local and state government certainly cannot afford to foot all the capital costs of building and starting new child-care centers.
But no one should give up hope. One solution is to find financing partners. Banks are more than a resource. They have expertise in investing in child care and they also have incentive. In New York, local banks are required by Federal and state Community Reinvestment Acts to meet the credit needs of all segments of their communities. Nationally, the Federal law has encouraged banks to commit more than $7.5 billion in loans to poor communities. 
 Last fall, with help from the Center for Policy Alternatives, the New York Banking Department and Department of Economic Development invited bankers to explore ways to invest in child care. Banks were asked to identify the risks, including cash flow restrictions and profitability, and then to cooperate with government and community groups to reduce those risks. As they have done so successfully for low- and moderate-income housing, banks can form lending consortiums and work with intermediaries to lessen risks on individual loans and spread the costs associated with nontraditional lending.
In New York, the Wyoming County Bank has already invested in a day-care center in Attica. Based on that success, the bank and the state Urban Development Corporation have each committed $132,000 in Batavia to build and equip a center that will serve some 44 children.
In New York City, two nonprofit groups, the Local Initiatives Support Corporation and Child Care Inc., are working on day-care projects that will rely heavily on bank financing.
New York State, a leader in child-care and economic development programs, provides management assistance, loan guarantees, direct loans and equity grants. Even so, its efforts can't keep up with the demand for child care. The programs can have a much greater impact if private money is also invested.
To encourage additional financing, the New York Banking Department notified its state-chartered institutions that it will consider child-care lending in its assessment of bank performance under the Community Reinvestment Act. Banks are given ratings from "substantial noncompliance" to "outstanding," based on efforts to meet the credit needs of their communities. We hope this clear sign promotes investment in child care and other emerging social needs, and we urge Federal regulators and other states to follow New York's example.
Financing child-care services offers banks the chance to serve their communities with safe and profitable loans. It also offers less affluent entrepreneurs in cities and rural areas the funds to start small businesses, which provide jobs. But the chief beneficiaries would be working parents and single mothers who badly need safe, affordable places to leave their children.

HEADLINE: A Small Town in the Grand Style

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES; WILLIAM GRIMES is an editor of The New York Times Magazine.

 BODY:
LIKE all great ideas, the Midwest is deceptively simple -- plain, plausible and, ultimately, elusive. Geographically, it's hard to pin down, a vast, amorphous territory somewhere west of the Alleghenies, east of the Rockies, south of Canada and north of the South. As a metaphor, it's ambiguous. Tradition assigns the Midwest a glorious role: the Heartland, Middle America (repository for all the core values), the Nation's Breadbasket. But for those who see it as nothing more than the endless expanse that makes LAX to JFK a six-hour proposition, it's America with the points of difference shaved smooth, sort of like Johnny Carson's Nebraska non-accent.
We need an Institute of Midwestern Studies to sort these matters out. In the meantime, the rule of thumb is this: drive inland, and after a while the scenery flattens out, the people get friendlier and funnier, and Paul Harvey dominates the radio. Behold the Midwest, where the doughnut and pie reign supreme. 
 It is a land of small towns. Other regions have them, but the Midwest perfected the form, laid down the rules for the kind of place that Americans shed tears over every Christmas when "It's a Wonderful Life" comes on. Needless to say, the 20th century has brought blight. Pull off the Interstate, and the road into Centerville, U.S.A., administers a pistol-whipping to the senses. Out the side window, a nightmare unfolds: Jiffy Lube, Mr. Tire, Tae Kwan Do Academy, Great Wall of China Cantonese/American Restaurant, Noble Roman Pizza, Jay-Bee's Video/Tanning Salon. By comparison, the aging Dairy Queen at the edge of town acquires a certain dignity.
On the other side of the Welcome to Centerville sign ("A City on the Move"), things take a sharp turn for the better. Improbably large houses appear, plopped down on expansive lawns. Home to the local gentry, surely. Serious-looking trees arch over neat residential streets -- streets lined with more of those whopping houses and park-size lawns. A flash of insight: ordinary people live in those houses.
Everywhere, there's a lot of room. And everything looks solid. The courthouse, the post office, the library. The streets are laid out on a grid. Their names tend to be State, Walnut, Lincoln and Monroe. Main Street is a no-nonsense affair, a stern rebuke to the suspect values of the commercial strip leading into town. It has a hardware store, a drugstore, a department store, a gift shop and a couple of cafes, strong on the basics. The local manner is affable but not fulsome; the sense of humor is rooted in a keen sense of the absurd, as though settling this far from an ocean amounts to a huge, richly enjoyable joke. Welcome to Centerville. Sinclair Lewis hated it. Today, it's looking pretty good.
Consider Marshall, Mich., population 6,900 -- "Town of Hospitality." Not all that many people do. In the south-central part of the state, about midway between Detroit and Chicago, it plays its strongest card on billboards along I-94: "Home of Schuler's Restaurant." This is a modest pitch, for the traveler who pulls off the highway gets a bonus: a gem of a town that one architectural historian has called "a textbook of 19th-century and early 20th-century American small-town architecture." This month, the Department of the Interior will designate a large chunk of Marshall, including about 800 structures, a National Historic Landmark District.
On its best blocks, Marshall makes the Midwest seem like the sweetest place on earth. The wide streets are lined with heroic tulip, maple and pine trees, home to svelte-looking black squirrels. Plush stretches of green turf release a pleasant lawny fragrance, and seem to soak up sound like soft acoustic tiles, turning the mean snarl of the lawn mower into a somnolent drone. Overhead, suspiciously on cue, birds twitter, warble and chirp.
Marshall is defined by its houses. Set well back from the sidewalk, with plenty of elbow room on either side, they evoke a freer, ampler way of life, when families were large, when front porches could accommodate multitudes and interiors offered the mysteries of nooks and crannies. Architecturally, Marshall cast its net wide. Its houses have towers, gables, gothic windows, front, side and rear porches, widow's walks, campaniles, dentellation, bargeboards, tracery, lacy woodwork trim, porticoes, columns, additions, subtractions and God knows what else.
The writer John Bellairs found that his hometown worked perfectly as a setting for his teen mysteries. "Even the ordinary white-frame houses had things that made them seem different -- a stained-glass window or a bouquet of iron flowers on top of a cupola," the narrator marveled in "The House With a Clock in Its Walls." "And so many of the houses seemed to be hiding secrets."
The white-frame houses are dwindling in number. Marshall's homeowners have returned to the rich, extroverted palette of the 19th century, correcting the historical mistake of a century ago, when America decided to imitate New England and paint its houses chalk white. Marshall houses are cream-colored with chocolate trim, canary yellow with black shutters. They're blue-gray and royal blue, teal and white, pink and red. Pleasing in itself, color causes the architectural details to pop out in sharp relief. According to John J. Collins, former head of the Marshall Historical Society, a visiting town official from Biloxi, Miss., recently requested a copy of Marshall's color ordinance. "I told her, we don't have one," he said. "All we have is good taste and peer pressure."
Peer pressure opens a handful of houses for public view every September, when Marshall holds its annual historic house tour, a festival of snooping that draws some 10,000 visitors. The tour began innocently enough in the 1950's, when women members of a local church began throwing open their kitchens, newly stocked with postwar wonder appliances, for inspection and socializing. Before long, the kitchen tour had evolved into a wildly popular house tour, which the Marshall Historical Society took over in 1967.
More than half of Marshall's buildings date from the 19th century, most of them from 1850 to 1870. The architectural styles neatly coincide with the town's three economic eras. A sprinkling of Greek Revival buildings, grandiose classical blockbusters with columned porticoes, reflect the heady days when Marshall expected to be named the capital of Michigan. A fickle legislature decreed otherwise. In 1847 Marshall, the fifth-largest town in the state, lost out to Lansing, which had only eight registered voters at the time. The area of town known as Capitol Hill serves as a reminder of dashed hopes, most visibly the "Governor's Mansion" at 612 South Marshall Avenue, a noble effort that faces the intended site for the state house, now a fairground.
A SECOND era of splendor began with the arrival of the Michigan Central Railroad in 1844. A 30-year building boom ensued, leaving the town with a legacy of Italianate and Gothic Revival homes. One of the most impressive is 603 North Kalamazoo Avenue. Built in 1869, it is a stately red-brick Italianate pile surrounded by towering Norwegian spruces and miniature gardens. Its most famous resident was the writer William Wallace Cook, who, under various pseudonyms, and with the aid of a story-generating system he called Plotto, cranked out dime novels featuring Buffalo Bill, Deadeye Dick, Frank Merriwether and Nick Carter.
A worthy rival to the Cook house is the J. Cronin Jr. house at 407 North Madison Street, the inspiration for John Bellairs's house with a clock in its walls. An upbeat version of the Addams Family residence, it's an idiosyncratic white-brick Italian villa, built in 1873, with a 60-foot mansard roof tower and an observatory.
Plump and prosperous, Marshall suffered a blow when the Michigan Central decided to move its yards to nearby Jackson in 1874. With its largest employer gone, Marsall showed old-fashioned enterprise and developed into a center for the manufacture of patent medicines, a lucrative industry that died after the passage of the Pure Food and Drug Act in 1906. The era lives on in Stuart's Dyspepsia Tablets (now made near Chicago), and a handful of houses in the grab-bag Queen Anne style -- Victorian confections with tall, narrow windows, steeply pitched roofs, and a generous assortment of peaks and turrets and towers.
The most famous building in Marshall reflects no style known to man. It is the Honolulu House, at 107 North Kalamazoo Avenue, a tropical fantasy painted in ivory, red and three shades of green -- the architectural equivalent of a four-rum cocktail served in a coconut. Now a museum, the house was built in 1860 for Abner Pratt, a former United States consul to the Sandwich Islands. To re-create a bit of the South Pacific right in Marshall, Mr. Pratt ordered up a grand two-story wood-faced structure with an enormous raised veranda and a pagoda-topped central tower. Inside, an ornate free-standing staircase of imported teak, ebony and mahogany rises to the central tower, and murals depicting tropical plants and animals decorate some of the walls and ceilings. The Honolulu House makes a purely American statement. Unself-conscious and exuberant, it's the product of money and whim.
The Honolulu House, and much of the rest of historic Marshall, owes its survival to a benevolent bully named Harold C. Brooks, the town's richest, and therefore leading, citizen. The family fortune, based on rupture appliances ("Brooks Supports the World -- And Will Never Let It Down"), left Mr. Brooks time and money enough to rearrange the town to his liking.
BEGINNING in the early 1920's, he would buy up fine old houses languishing on the market and simply hold them until a buyer came along. He maintained the trees in the town's parks. When Mr. Brooks got wind of outsiders offering to buy old walnut trees, he would approach their owners and offer the same money to keep the trees in place. He didn't care for the post office, so he paid to have it torn down and rebuilt his way. In 1930, he endowed the town's traffic circle with a marble Grecian fountain, a reproduction of the Temple of Love at Versailles -- minus the nude Aphrodite. Mr. Brooks knew where to draw the line.
The statueless fountain has a commanding view of Marshall's main street, Michigan Avenue, a broad thoroughfare with two hardware stores, the grand Brooks post office, several dentists' offices, Darling and Daughter variety store, several antiques and gift shops, a Rexall drug store, the Brooks rupture-appliance business (now a mail-order operation) and the American Museum of Magic. The museum is a private operation run by Bob Lund, a lifelong collector of magic memorabilia, who maintains a library of about 12,000 volumes. The museum is a mandatory visit for the magicians who in August converge on Colon, about a 40-minute drive to the southwest, hometown of the renowned Harry Blackstone and headquarters of Abbott's Magic Company, the country's main producer of commercial magic supplies.
Marshall's main street also offers three cafes that make convenient stops -- Ken's, the Dugout and the Coffee Pot, where my wife and I achieved a lunch bill of $4.06 for a superior meatloaf sandwich, a cheeseburger, competition-worthy French fries and two iced teas.
The serious eating inevitably takes place at the famous Schuler's, a family-run enterprise for four generations. The menu sticks to basic American fare with an inspired digression here and there, and one oddball offering: New Zealand orange roughy, a fish that's probably less surprised to find itself broiled on a plate than it is to be in Marshall, Mich. In truth, despite the Lake Superior whitefish, meat is king at Schuler's: roast rib eye of pork with ginger root glaze and onion marmalade; Indiana duckling with a merlot cherry glaze, and the splurge entree, roast prime rib of beef, slowly roasted on rock salt. Seconds of prime rib are on the house. The wine list, in addition to a reasonable spread of California and French wines, offers six Michigan wines (mostly white, surprisingly good), from vineyards that begin about 75 miles to the west.
Here in the nation's midriff, a calorically ambitious meal still counts for something. The region was built on wheat and meat, cattle and corn, so it's a kind of treason to ask for ascoop of cottage cheese on lettuce. Besides, the frank and friendly invitation to stop in Marshall and dine at Schuler's reflects an earthy sense of priorities. Eat first, look at the houses later.
Marshall looks in the mirror and likes what it sees. It is an amiably self-promoting kind of place, keen on historical markers (44 in all) and lists of firsts, bests and biggests. The ever-vigilant historical society prints not only a 103-house "Walking Tour of Historic Marshall" pamphlet (free at the Chamber of Commerce or the National House Inn), but also a detailed guide to the town cemetery and a self-propelled tour of notable trees.
This small-town pride is a genteel descendant of the boosterism that Sinclair Lewis savaged in "Main Street" and "Babbitt." The brash marketing reflected the profound insecurity of citizens who had left the civilized East and, in a desperate roll of the dice, gambled on greatness. In virtually every case, they settled for something better. When Marshall lost the race for state capital, it began life in earnest. The dream faded, but the town flourished. And there are hundreds more like it all over the Midwest.
 
DROPPING BY MARSHALL
 
Getting There
From Chicago or Detroit, take Interstate 94 to exit 110. If approaching from the north or south on Interstate 69, take exit 36, east to Marshall.
 
Sights
The Honolulu House Museum, 107 North Kalamazoo Avenue, (616) 781-8544, is open daily noon to 5 P.M. from mid-May to Oct. 31. Admission is $2.
The Marshall Historic Home Tour will take place Sept. 7 and 8. Tickets are $8 on orders received by Aug. 31, $10 thereafter. There is no charge for children under 12. Tickets are good both days and cover admission to the seven public and seven private buildings on the tour, related events and attractions, and shuttle-bus. Guides at entry points to the town will point motorists to parking areas and bus stops. Tickets may be purchased in advance by sending a check or money order payable to the Marshall Historical Society, Post Office Box 68, Marshall, Mich. 49068. Tickets can also be purchased at the Interstate approaches to Marshall or, on tour days, at the private homes on the tour. For more information call the Marshall Chamber of Commerce: (800) 877-5163.
To see the American Museum of Magic, 107 East Michigan Avenue, call Bob Lund at (616) 781-7674 at least a day in advance. The Abbott Magic Get-Together, about 40 minutes away in Colon, Mich., ("Magic Capital of the World") takes place Aug. 7 to 10. Full $75 registration covers all evening magic shows and lectures. A one-day registration costs $22.50. For information, call Abbott's Magic Company, (616) 432-3235.
 
Where to Eat
Schuler's Restaurant, 15 South Eagle Street; (616) 781-3961. Appetizers include barbecued meatballs ("a Schuler tradition") at $3.65 and seafood chowder served in a loaf of whole-grain bread, $5.35. Among entrees, all served with salad, potato and vegetables, are broiled New Zealand orange roughy at $14.95, charcoal-grilled chicken breast for $12.95 and prime rib of beef (second helpings at no extra charge) at $17.25.
Ice-cream pies plus a fruit pie of the day dominate the dessert menu.
 
Where to Stay
 There are several standard-issue motels in the area. But two inns deserve special mention.
National House Inn, 102 South Parkview Street, Marshall, Mich. 49068; (616) 781-7374. Built in 1835, this is said to be the oldest operating inn in Michigan. It is a solid, red-brick building whose reception area has rough-hewn plank floors and a large fireplace. There are 16 rooms, decorated in period style, 14 with full bath, 2 with half bath and shared shower. Rates with two in a room are $64 to $109, including Continental breakfast. All rooms are $56.95 on Sunday.
McCarthy's Bear Creek Inn, 15230 C Drive North, Marshall, Mich. 49068; (616) 781-8383. Two miles west of Marshall, just off Michigan Avenue west of Interstate 69, the inn has a main building and a converted barn behind it overlooking a creek. There are 14 rooms, all with full bath, at $63 to $93 in the inn, and $76 to $85 in the Creek House. All rooms are $54 on Sunday. -- W. G.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3; Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Summer Hotel Deals: Good Buys Abound

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
THE recession's toll on the travel industry is producing something that you might not believe possible: a brand-name New York hotel room in the range of $100 before taxes. Across the country, too, big-city hotels are posting offers -- $49, $69, $89 -- in line with motel prices.
Low occupancy rates for the year to the end of April -- 57.5 percent against the industry's general break-even point of 65 percent -- mean "it's going to be a long summer" for the industry, in the words of Mark Lomano, of Smith Travel Research of Gallatin, Tenn. But the empty rooms mean travelers can get a really good buy if they focus on the trends. If your vacation plans are still amendable, consider these facts. 
 First, with some phone checking, you can probably stay in a good hotel, complete with health club, restaurants and all sorts of extras, in a popular tourist city with attractions at your doorstep, for something near the price you might pay for a motel outside the city.
Mr. Lomano said that the highest-priced hotels were not doing so badly, but that hotels in the next rank, Hyatt, Marriott, Sheraton and the like, were badly hurt by the sharp decline in leisure travel. These, no surprise, are the chains advertising big discounts.
Second, resorts are hurting. If you want to try a resort you once thought out of reach, call about weekday reservations, when business is normally slower.
Conversely, for a hotel with big convention business, you should ask about weekend rates, when conventioneers have seized briefcases and fled, probably to a resort. Be sure to ask the hotel what constitutes a weekend: Friday and Saturday nights, yes, and sometimes Thursday or Sunday or both.
Third, Mr. Lomano does not believe that even the big discounts advertised now will bring business back to desired levels, so there are probably deeper cuts coming. This means that if you make a reservation, keep an eye on what the competition is doing and call back to ask for a bigger room or a lower rate.
 
The Major Chains
 Here are some hotel offers in the category where good deals are likely to be found. Each of the chains says that a member hotel joining in a program must set aside 10 percent of its rooms for sale at these special prices. This means you are more likely to get the advertised rate the earlier you make a reservation. Certain dates may be exempted.
About 90 Hyatts of the 110 in the United States and Canada are offering rates of $69, $89 and $109 for a room, depending on the city, for each night of a stay that includes a Friday or a Saturday night, or just for a Friday or Saturday night. The special rates, in effect until Sept. 2, apply to the hotels in the chain and two of its resorts, the Scottsdale Hyatt Regency, where the rate is $109, and the Grand Champions in Indian Wells, Calif., where the rate is $89. At both Hyatts in Denver, for another example, the rate is $69 and at the Grand Hyatt in New York City, $109. None of these rates include taxes, which should be asked about in all cases. In New York, they are high: 8.25 percent sales tax, 6 percent city occupancy tax, 5 percent state occupancy tax if the room costs $100 a night or more and a $2 city tax for rooms over $40, bringing a $109 room to $130, still an amazing buy in New York.
The Hyatts are also throwing in a $25 certificate for each room for food and beverage bought during the stay. The Sunday checkout time has been extended to 8 P.M. The Hyatt number is (800) 233-1234.
The Sheraton chain has two programs at 200 hotels, one for weekdays that requires reserving 14 days ahead but no payment, and the other for weekends, meaning arrival Thursday, Friday or Saturday, which requires no reservation. Either way, the price is reduced as much as 60 percent. For the Sheraton Washington, the rate is $79 rather than $231 a room a night; for the Sheraton Boston, $108 rather than $250 a night. At the Sheraton Centre in New York, the regular rate is $225 a night but the special rate is $109.
The weekday program runs to Sept. 3; weekend rates to Dec. 29. Sheraton's number is (800) 325-3535.
Radisson calls its program Shades of Summer. It offers discounts of 25 to 50 percent. A reservation is required, but there is no deadline and no advance payment. The available days vary by hotel, so you have to check. At the Radisson Empire in New York, rooms are available for $98 Sunday to Thursday that would normally cost $150 to $250.
In Minneapolis, the Radisson Plaza is offering rooms for Friday or Saturday night at $85 that would usually cost $114 to $169. At the Radisson Suite Hotel Rancho Bernardo in San Diego, rooms are $68 to $78 that would normally be $95 to $105. The Radisson number is (800) 333-3333.
Marriott began its advance purchase-discount plan last week. If you book and pay 21 days ahead at 190 of its 200 hotels, you can get 40 to 60 percent off the regular rates for rooms that can be used by one to five people. On a weekday at the Washington Marriott, it would be $89 a night for a room, in contrast with the regular July weekday rate of $200 for a double; on the weekend, the advance-purchase price would be $65 for the room; at the Cambridge, Mass., Marriott, a weekday room would be $95 instead of $190 for a double; the special weekend rate is $79. At the Marriott on Lexington Avenue in New York, a weekday night would be $99 instead of $230 for a double; the weekend night special is $79. Payments 14 days ahead bring lesser discounts. These programs continue until Sept. 2. Reservations are not changeable or refundable.
In addition Marriott has a $99 Discover Manhattan discount for its Lexington Avenue and Financial Center hotels. It does not involve advance payment. This is offered for Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights until Sept. 8.
Marriott's number is (800) 228-9290.
 
Is the Rate Available?
 The day after Marriott's Discover Manhattan $99 plan was advertised June 9 in this newspaper and others, a Detroit man called to reserve a room for Sunday, June 23, and was told that rooms at that price for that night were sold out. Instead he was offered a room for $199, and he complained to the Travel section of The Times .
A call to Marriott reservations not identifying this column was placed on June 11, with the same result. However, a $99 room was available for Sunday, June 30, and a reservation was confirmed. Marriott said that the 10 percent set-aside meant that 117 rooms in all were available each night in Manhattan, but the spokesman, Gordon D. Lambourne, said that advertisements had appeared earlier than June 9. For some weekends, the set-aside was 20 percent, he said.
The New York City Consumer Affairs Department complaint section reported receiving no complaints about the June 9 Marriott ad. The city policy on specials of this sort is that the merchant must earmark for sale at the advertised price a supply large enough to meet "reasonably anticipated public demand." Susan Kassapian, the department's chief of litigation, explained that expectations of demand would usually be based on responses to earlier advertisements of the sort. "When we get an avalanche of complaints," Ms. Kassapian said, "we investigate to find out how many were set aside in advance of the ad. The tipoff is if they all call the day after the ad runs." The commission is at 42 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10004, and the complaint office number is (212) 487-4444.
Independent hotels in Manhattan say they set aside much higher percentages of rooms for advertised specials, because of the Consumer Affairs Department's activism. Last fall, hoteliers at a dozen moderate-priced hotels said the range was 30 percent to 98 percent of rooms. One offering this summer, at the Roger Smith Winthrop, Lexington Avenue and 47th Street, is $99 a night for two weekend nights, with breakfast in bed for two included. As long as the hotel is not fully booked, anyone who calls and asks for this Fun Quick Getaway rate will receive it, a hotel spokeswoman said.
Mr. Lomano's view that the bottom line is not the bottom line was borne out this month by a New Jerseyan who wanted to reserve at the Vista Hotel in Lower Manhattan. Told that the rates were $215 to $240, he said he guessed not. "What were you thinking of?" the reservationist asked. They agreed on $160, and the traveler said he would call back. He got another reservationist then, but the agreed-upon price was accepted. With taxes, it came to $192.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 22; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2546 words

HEADLINE: Kayak Odyssey in Alaska

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD; ROBERT REINHOLD is chief of the Los Angeles bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
WE had been in our kayaks not more than 20 minutes, paddling out into Icy Strait at the beginning of a five-day sea-kayaking tour in Alaska, when there was a loud whoosh nearby and a tall spray of water shot into the cool air. We turned and suddenly a huge, dark glistening form rose from the water nearby, showed a large fin and dived again. It was a humpback whale, which played cat and mouse with our six tiny kayaks for the next half hour as a bald eagle circled overhead and sea otters and seals popped their heads up from the water to peer at us quizzically.
The encounters were an exhilarating start to a kayaking tour of the waters and forested islands near Glacier Bay in southeast Alaska, an adventure that offered a close-up glimpse of some of Alaska's great natural wonders, a world of whales, seals, grizzly bears, mink, bogs, meadows and wildflowers all set in a vastness and near pristine desolation that persists despite the advancing depredations of the timber, oil and mining industries. 
 It should be stated that this is not for the frail or those who demand modern comforts when they travel. While the basic technique of kayaking is easy enough to learn for any moderately fit person, it requires stamina and lugging of boats and supplies. It also means camping in small tents on remote beaches, accepting an element of risk and, almost inevitably in southeast Alaska, being cold and wet much of the time. We had eight inches of rain in five days, which was not unusual in the rain forest that is southeast Alaska.
But for those willing to endure such discomforts the reward is a rich experience and an education about the fauna, flora and geology of the last American frontier. I was on the Marine Mammal Discovery tour of Alaska Discovery, a 19-year-old outfit based in Juneau , the state capital, which runs a variety of kayaking, river rafting, hiking and other wilderness adventures in Alaska and the Soviet Far East.
Joining such a group tour with strangers is always problematical. The entire trip could be spoiled by one or two complainers or, conversely, by an environmental zealot who lectures you about where not to spit your toothpaste water. Even worse, an inexperienced or unqualified guide could turn the adventure into misery or even danger.
No such problems arose, though. The group was led by two thoroughly professional Alaska guides, Judy Brakel and Art Bloom, both unflappable and assured. Judy had been leading such tours for a dozen years and was something of an expert in the edibles of the rain forest and intertidal zone, disappearing at times and returning with plastic bags full of such delectables as beach spinach and wild asparagus. Art, a Brooklyn-born former biology researcher for the United States Forest Service in Alaska, was enormously informative about grizzly bears, fish and other wildlife. Actually, we had two and a half guides, for Art brought along his good-natured teen-age son, Scott, who was the ultimate Boy Scout, quietly wandering off with his fishing pole after we camped and returning with a dozen or so fish for dinner.
The guides typified the kinds of lives led by those who have migrated to Alaska for its wild splendor, piecing together unconventional livelihoods. Judy guides kayak tours by summer, processes unemployment claims for the State of Alaska by winter. Art spends his summers in Alaska and goes south for the winter, to Chile, where he has a business guiding fishing and rafting trips.
The group itself was an odd but affable mix that seemed to work well. There was a newly married couple from Minneapolis of stern Norwegian stock who thought sleeping in a leaky tent was a splendid way to spend their honeymoon, two single women, both graduate students from the University of Michigan, and four single men: two of them environmental lawyers, one a maritime engineer from Florida and myself, trying not to be obvious as I took notes on a soggy pad. All were experienced in back-country camping. The Alaska Discovery brochure had warned participants that they should have spent sufficient time tent camping and hiking and should be in good physical condition and excellent general health.
For all the wildness, this was by no means the strictest of wilderness regimens. An advantage of travel by kayak rather than foot is that the boats have plenty of room for fresh food, a large propane stove, fishing gear and numerous other small comforts that loom large after a strenuous day of paddling against wind and rain. The meals, prepared mainly by Judy, were delicious and generous. And the object was to view marine mammals and other wildlife in a leisurely way, not break any kayak speed-racing records. We spent four to five hours a day kayaking and covered three to four miles for a total of perhaps 20 miles, but each day was a different outing, not part of continuous route.
The trip started in Gustavus, a 30-minute flight across the Inside Passage from Juneau. Gustavus (pop. 218) is a rather spare place, unincorporated without paved roads, government, police, doctors or building codes, spread over a flat glacial plain homesteaded earlier in this century. Today the village, with a handful of small inns and bed-and-breakfast establishments, is the entry point for Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve.
After a briefing from our guides, we pulled on our rain suits and boots. We loaded the six two-people kayaks and all our gear onto two fishing boats at the Gustavus pier for the three-hour ride across the mouth of Glacier Bay and then across Icy Strait to a small sheltered cove on Chichagof Island. It speaks volumes about Alaska to say that this vast island, an area of thick forests and mountains that is larger than Delaware, has only three permanent settlements with a total population of about 1,000. In five days, we saw no other humans except for fishing boats far out in the strait.
A high ceiling of gray clouds over the craggy snow-clad Fairweather Range gave a forbidding hue to the vast expanse of icy water and islands that opened before us as the boat churned across the strait. We planned to paddle along the north coast of Chichagof Island, ending at Point Adolphus, a favorite haunt of the thousands of humpback whales that migrate north to Alaska for the spring and summer.
It was sobering to know that the forces of nature are so powerful and rapid in Alaska that this journey would have been impossible 200 years ago. The British explorer George Vancouver ventured through Icy Strait in 1794 and found an intimidating wall of ice 4,000 feet thick across the entry to what is now Glacier Bay. Since then, for reasons not well understood, the ice has retreated with astonishing speed 65 miles north into Glacier Bay, bringing vast ecological changes to the region.
We unloaded at Gull Cove, on an inlet homesteaded half a century ago but now quite desolate. In the calm waters, Judy and Art instructed us in how to get into the kayak, attach the splash skirt meant to keep water out of the holes in which the paddlers sit, legs straddling bags of gear, and to paddle. The worst fear in such frigid waters is turning over, but the fiberglass craft seemed fairly stable.
THE first day was purposely a short one. We paddled for about three hours, covering maybe two miles, with a detour to chase our first humpback, and put in at a long crescent-shaped beach of blackish sand to set up the first night's camp. Behind us was an almost impenetrable forest of Sitka spruce and western hemlock, a climax forest, as foresters call it, meaning that it has never been logged, and the older trees -- some as old as 350 years -- have begun to die.
Camping anywhere in Alaska presents one particularly tough problem -- bears. Chichagof is inhabited by grizzly bears, or brown bears as they are more commonly called in Alaska, and an effort must be made to avoid too close an encounter and to prevent them from raiding the food supply. Brown bears, which can weigh as much as 1,100 pounds, are determined scavengers and are said to be particularly menacing once they learn that campers carry food. So we carefully placed our cooking area far from the tenting area, thoroughly washed all plates and pots before retiring and hung the food bags in trees at night.
A nice thing about Alaska in the spring is that the days seem to last forever. It did not get dark until nearly 11 P.M. and first light appeared by 3 A.M. As we set up for dinner, Art and his son Scott disappeared for a long time. They returned with two large Dolly Vardens, a type of char similar to trout. Judy, meanwhile, wandered down the beach and came back with wild celery and yellow violets and something she called beach lettuce. The first supper was nothing short of sumptuous: spaghetti with meat sauce and salad of cauliflower, carrots, mushrooms and the wild greens, plus the two fish, cooked on a grate over an open fire, all washed down with a California Riesling. The night ended with a hilarious group effort at trying to lift the food bags into trees with ropes.
The second day started with breakfast of French toast and coffee, supplemented by limpets, small shellfish, and seaweed, which Judy found when the tide was out and later fried. With that, we lugged the kayaks back into the water and set out for a long day of paddling through beds of kelp and some fairly rough seas. For company we had sea otters, seals, sea lions, dolphins, Canada geese, brent -- almost every variety of bird and mammal that haunts this coast.
At midday we got a spectacular surprise. With the tide high, we wandered up a creek that opened into a large grassy meadow behind the trees. Art was the first to spot them and hushed everybody. We beached the kayaks and grabbed our binoculars. There, at the edge of the meadow, two enormous brown bears were feeding peaceably on the vegetation. Silently, we marched forward to get a closer look, Judy bringing up the rear with a rifle slung over her shoulder. The weapon was for protection, not hunting. We kept a distance of at least 100 yards, watching the bears for half an hour. It troubled me a little that should our curiosity have enraged these animals, it might have been necessary to kill them. It is legal in Alaska to shoot a bear if threatened, but we retreated without incident.
Soon after, the rains that dogged us for the rest of the trip began. Rain in southeast Alaska is usually not heavy -- more relentless drizzle than downpour -- and we soon became accustomed to it. The guides were certainly prepared; when we arrived on the second night at a broad delta called Mud Bay, the kitchen was placed under a large tarp held up by four kayak paddles. Tired, wet and cold, we devoured a dinner of couscous, vegetable soup with seaweed, wild asparagus, salad and chocolate mousse and watched the tide douse the fire we had set on the beach.
Before we left Mud Bay the next morning, Art led a walking tour through the brackish delta, meadows and moss-covered forest bottom behind the beach, explaining that these fragile ecologies on the margin of the island provide habitats for deer and other mammals to survive the long, harsh winter. The snow is generally not as deep here as inland because of the warming effects of the sea. In spring, the meadow was abloom with lupine, marsh marigolds, skunk cabbage and other Arctic flowers. Two black-tailed deer grazed at the edge, then fled as we approached.
We spent the next couple of days paddling along the coast toward our final destination, Point Adolphus. We spent the last night on a beach near the point where, after a dinner of spinach fettucine with pesto sauce and more Dolly Varden, we watched the sky clear enough to give us a fine sunset over the Fairweather Range.
THE last day was in a way the best. I awoke at 5 A.M. in my tent to a loud whooshing sound, pulled on my boots and walked to the beach. The water was glass calm, and just offshore a parade of perhaps six humpbacks lumbered by. They dove one by one, their enormous flukes flying into the air and then gracefully slipping into the water. After breakfast we hiked along a deer trail for a mile or so and came upon yet another glorious sight high in a spruce tree: a bald eagle's nest with two chicks. The vigilant mother flapped her four-foot wings as she hopped from limb to limb, not at all happy about our presence, her fierce yellow eyes darting about under the white feathers of her head. Soon after, we broke camp to head for our pickup by the fishing boat and on the way fell in with a pod of nearly a dozen humpbacks. There followed a mad scramble as we paddled wildly to get nearer. They came so close we could almost touch them, and they rewarded us with a spectacular display of flukes.
Just then, far out in the strait, a cruise ship headed for Glacier Bay appeared on the horizon. As it neared, we focused with binoculars on the decks of the ship, the Star Princess, and pitied those who had spent thousands of dollars to see all this from a remote distance. They looked back at us through binoculars, and perhaps they pitied us. We had paid $1,000 each to spend five cold days in kayaks and tents.
 
GETTING CLOSE TO WHALES
 
When to Go
Southeast Alaska sea-kayaking season is from about May 20 to Sept. 5.
Experienced kayakers can rent boats for an unguided tour. Rentals are available from companies like Glacier Bay Sea Kayaks in Gustavus. Daily rates are $40 for up to three days, $35 for four to six days and $30 for seven days or longer. Drop off by charter boat deep in Glacier Bay is $88 a person one way, $166 round trip. Details from Post Office Box 26, Gustavus, Alaska 99826; (907) 697-2257.
 
Accompanied Trips
Alaska Discovery offers regular departures to destinations like Icy Strait, Glacier Bay and Icy Bay. The five-day, four-night marine mammal excursion costs $950 a person, which includes everything but air fare from Juneau to Gustavus and sleeping bag, rain gear and rubber boots, available at $50 extra if needed. A seven-day tour through Glacier Bay National Park is $1,300. Details from 369 South Franklin Avenue, Juneau, Alaska 99801; (907) 586-1911.
Another operator is Spirit Walker Expeditions in Gustavus, which offers guided whale-watching trips ranging from two days and two nights at $450 a person to seven days and six nights at $1,000. Details from Post Office Box 240B, Gustavus, Alaska 99826; (907) 697-2266. R. R.
 
FOR FACTS, WAIT
If you are planning a trip to Alaska and want a tourist brochure, you will have to wait till fall to get one. Last fall the state printed 700,000 brochures for 1991. By April they were gone, except for a cache in Canada, which was virtually depleted this month. When the Persian Gulf war began, demand for domestic travel cleaned out the supply of brochures. "And at this time last year," Nancy Smith of the Division of Tourism said early in June, "we still had 13,000 copies on hand."
People writing now get a "we regret to inform you" note on a picture postcard and a promise to receive 1992 brochures when they arrive this fall. Requests, preferably on a postcard, should be sent to: Alaska Division of Tourism, Box E, Juneau, Alaska 99811.
