HEADLINE: Chicago Gets Hot as a Site for Film Making

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
For years Chicago was a pleasant afterthought in Hollywood, the source of gangster movies or period pieces or the Chicago-specific productions that did not lend themselves to New York or Los Angeles. Now Chicago is becoming the first choice for a generation of film makers who are escaping the expense and congestion and cliches of the coasts or are seeking unvarnished realism.
The result has been an explosion of film activity here in the last few years. Major producers and directors like John Hughes and Ron Howard are turning to Chicago to create all-American stories of ordinary people, people who may not eat tofu and use cellular telephones but who bring in big numbers at the box office. 
 Two of what are expected to be the summer's biggest releases were shot entirely in Chicago and are suffused with Windy City sights and sensibilities. One is Mr. Howard's "Backdraft," the current hit starring Kurt Russell and Robert De Niro. This adventure-mystery, which is about firefighters and an investigation into the death of one, features fire trucks racing through the city and a funeral procession down Michigan Avenue. The other major new release is Mr. Hughes's "Only the Lonely," a romantic comedy starring John Candy and Ally Sheedy that is intended to be to this city what Woody Allen's "Manhattan" was to New York.
This summer, yet another crop of films set and shot in Chicago are to open. Disney Studios is coming out with "V. I. Warshawski," starring Kathleen Turner as the Polish-Italian private detective of the title; Columbia Pictures is offering "Gladiators," starring Brian Dennehy in a story about underground boxing; and Warner Brothers will release Mr. Hughes's "Curly Sue," starring Jim Belushi as a homeless man who lands in Chicago with his adopted 9-year-old girl. Later this year, Mr. Hughes will begin production in Chicago's northern suburbs on 20th Century Fox's "Home Alone II," the sequel to last summer's big hit, which was also shot here.
All of this is helping a city better known for its bare-knuckles politics and cutting-edge architecture make a name for itself in the world of dollies and grips. Chicago was perhaps the prime beneficiary of the seven-month film-craft union strike in New York that ended in late May. Several indigenously New York productions -- from the film adaptation of the Broadway play "Prelude to a Kiss" to the pilot of a detective series set in New York and fittingly called "Empire City" -- are being shot in the Windy City instead of the city that spawned them.
Yet the infatuation with Chicago began before film making virtually shut down in New York. In the quest for a new realism and an authentic Middle America of corn dogs and mini-vans, many producers have chosen Chicago over rival sirens like San Francisco and Boston and even Toronto, despite its favorable exchange rate.
What producers and directors find appealing, they say, is Chicago's mix of down-home ethnic and city sophisticate, its post-modern and turn-of-the-century architecture, and an Everywhere, U.S.A., quality that lets film makers convert it easily into other cities. Particularly attractive is its unjaded, what-can-we-do-for-you approach, which makes the implausible in New York -- like shutting down a major artery for a couple of days -- a breeze in Chicago. "The city sort of hands you the keys to the city," said Steve Roth, the producer of "Gladiators."
In a competitive, bottom-line industry, many say they work better in Chicago because its film industry is innately less neurotic than that of New York or Los Angeles. "There is still an underlying normalcy in Chicago even though it's a big city," said the actress Elizabeth Perkins, who got her start on the Chicago stage and appeared with Demi Moore in the very Chicago movie "About Last Night . . ." (1986). "Chicagoans," she said, "are still like people you'd see in a mall in Rockford."
The relatively recent discovery of Chicago by producers and directors also means it hasn't gotten hackneyed, that it looks vaguely unfamiliar to film makers and their audiences. "It still feels special to do a film in Chicago," said the director Chris Columbus. "It hasn't been overused like New York and L.A. It's like a little jewel for some of us."
 Mr. Columbus and Mr. Hughes have entered a kind of symbiosis with Chicago. Mr. Hughes has shot 11 films here in the last eight years, two of them directed by Mr. Columbus ("Only the Lonely and "Home Alone"). And both men have developed such an affection for the city that they have bought property and moved here.
 Lately they have been operating out of an abandoned high school converted into a makeshift studio, where interiors are shot in the gymnasium and dailies are screened in the auditorium. Over the years, Mr. Hughes's films have used everything from O'Hare Airport to the annual German-American Parade, leading many people to call Chicago "John Hughes's back- lot." It is a mutually beneficial relationship that is likely to continue now that Mr. Hughes has signed a seven-picture deal with 20th Century Fox. The first movie will be the "Home Alone" sequel, to be directed by Mr. Columbus. It will be shot a few miles from where Mr. Hughes lives.
Mr. Hughes, who grew up in Chicago's affluent North Shore suburbs, tried living in Los Angeles once. It lasted only a couple of years. "Los Angeles is a very special place," he told The Hollywood Reporter last winter. "It's richer, more diverse, nicer weather. It's a newer place, a place of dreams." But, he added, "Chicago is a place of realities."
That realism is what Mr. Columbus says makes their movies accessible and lucrative. The two men surround themselves with people who drive carpools to Little League practice rather than the hip men with ponytails and Armani suits tooling around Westwood. "As you're driving to work, it's nice to know that you're going to make a movie while other people are going to a law firm or to fix somebody's plumbing," Mr. Columbus said. "You're around real people."
 Other film makers are learning what Mr. Columbus and Mr. Hughes have known for some time. And so for reasons of art and economics, the story of the most famous New York Yankee ever to pick up a bat will be recreated not in the Bronx, where Babe Ruth made his name, but in Chicago, where Cubs fans still haven't gotten over losing the 1932 World Series to him and the Yankees.
For the Babe Ruth story, currently in production, Wrigley Field was the logical choice: it was in the best shape and had none of the neon billboards that would give away the decade. Wrigley will play three roles in the movie -- Yankee Stadium, the Polo Grounds and itself. A ballpark in Danville, Ill., will serve as Fenway Park in Boston and an old field in Baltimore. And a chic North Side street is being converted into turn-of-the-century and Depression-era New York, Boston and Baltimore, with period awnings and cobblestones and hay over the asphalt.
"Chicago is probably the only city in the country where, with the exception of a few days in Danville, we can film the whole picture," said William Finnegan, an executive producer of "The Babe," which stars John Goodman and Kelly McGillis and is to be released next year.
Union problems figured more prominently in the decision to move the film version of "Prelude to a Kiss," which ended its Broadway run last month, from New York to somewhere else. New York was central to the urban fairy tale of a young bride named Rita whose soul gets trapped in the body of a dying widower who gives her a fateful kiss on her wedding day. But those involved with the film say that Chicago had what was necessary for the story.
"All that was important was that it be a big city with grit," said the playwright Craig Lucas, who adapted his play to a new medium and setting. "Chicago's not quaint like Boston and San Francisco. Those towns are so romantic, it was too easy. I didn't want charming. I wanted the feeling of a very on-the-edge world. Chicago has a much bigger edge to it."
"Only the Lonely," a comedy about an Irish cop torn between his overbearing mother and the mortuary cosmetician he falls in love with, was supposed to be shot in New York, too. But between the film maker's love for Chicago and the argument that the story of an Irish cop made more sense here than in New York, the movie ended up on the shores of Lake Michigan. Thus filmgoers get the grand tour watching Mr. Candy and Ms. Sheedy picnicking on the infield grass of old Comiskey Park and watching the sun rise over Lake Michigan.
One measure of the city's growing maturity is the way film makers cast their films here now. For years, directors would fill all but the most peripheral parts in Los Angeles or New York and fly the cast in mainly for exteriors. But the growing reputation of Chicago theater, whose alumni include David Mamet and John Malkovich, has created a pool of talent that directors are starting to use. "The Babe," for example, is hiring dozens of Chicago actors and thousands of extras in period knickers and bowler hats.
Its polyglot population makes Chicago a kind of film makers' supermarket. If a script calls for it, casting directors do not have to settle for somebody who can act Polish; they can just go to the Northwest Side and find a real Pole. That is what happened when the Warner Brothers movie "Men Don't Leave" (1990) was in town and needed a couple of hundred Polish polka dancers, the stouter the better, to dance with Jessica Lange. Poles from the local polka parlors turned out in droves.
And when Lorimar Pictures' "Next of Kin" (1989) needed Italian women to mourn at a funeral, dozens of them in their 80's and 90's showed up from a nursing home around the corner, dressed in black and wailing as if they had lost their firstborn.
 There was a time when Chicago was not so amenable to film makers. The late Mayor Richard J. Daley was especially protective of Chicago's image and practically forbade film making during his 22 years in office. After his death in 1976, officials aggressively sought the attention of Hollywood with former Governor James Thompson traveling to Los Angeles to lobby the city's case. The town's breakthrough movie was the oddball 1980 hit "The Blues Brothers," starring John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd.
Now, however, the officials' salesmanship is really paying off. "We've been on top of the roller coaster for a year and haven't come down yet," said Barbara Roche, a Chicago-based casting director. Which leads some to worry that Chicago, like New York and Los Angeles and New Orleans before it, could become a cliche, that maybe people will get tired of the ubiquitous, you're-in-Chicago El train. Especially as long as film makers look through the same lens as, say, Jeff Kanew, who directed "V. I. Warshawski" with this premise: "Any location we picked, we tried to get it near an El train."
Chicago fans in Hollywood doubt that could happen. They say it is too versatile a location to become passe just yet. "I've got 20 years' worth of films left to do in Chicago," Mr. Columbus said. "I'll never get tired of it."
 
 
 
ON THE SCENE
 Seven feature films are either in production in Chicago or about to begin by early summer. They are:
* "Prelude to a Kiss," directed by Norman Rene and starring Alec Baldwin and Meg Ryan.
* "The Babe," directed by Arthur Hiller and starring John Goodman and Kelly McGillis.
* "Folks," directed by Ted Kotcheff and starring Tom Selleck.
* "Mad Dog and Glory," directed by John McNaughton and starring Robert De Niro.
* "Straight Talk," directed by Barnet Kilman and starring Dolly Parton.
* "League of Their Own," directed by Penny Marshall and starring Debra Winger.
* "Mo' Money," directed by Peter MacDonald and starring Damon Wayans

 
 
OF 'BLUES' AND GREEN
 Major film making in Chicago is considered to have begun in 1978. That's when chase scenes for "The Blues Brothers," starring John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd, sent cars careering down lower Wacker Drive and crashing through glass windows at Daley Plaza, proving that Chicago could handle the oversized, stunt-filled productions usually reserved for the coasts.
Eight film and television projects were shot in Chicago that year. By 1980, the number had reached 19. And after a lull in 1987 and 1988, attributed to the screenwriters' strike, 28 companies chose to work in Chicago in 1989, spending $33 million in the process.
Last year, slightly fewer projects -- 24 -- were filmed in Chicago. But the productions, including "Flatliners," "Home Alone," "Uncle Buck" and "The Music Box," were large scale. They frequently stayed for extended periods, used a greater number of Chicago locations and employed more local residents. The contribution to the city's economy was a record $65 million. -- Pamela Kripke

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
On the Block, Glossy Survivors From the 18th Century

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
Rare when they were made, American 18th-century furnishings with lacquerlike japanned finishes continue to be uncommon commodities on the antiques market. In recent months, however, two pieces have become available for sale in New York, focusing attention on the fewer than 50 surviving period chests, clocks and chairs with this Oriental-style decoration, which imitates the hard, shimmering finish of Japanese lacquering.
Last October, a William and Mary highboy was exhibited by Israel Sack, a Manhattan dealer, at the International Antique Dealers Show in New York. Its price tag of $2.75 million was one of the highest for any object at the fair. Although not sold at the show, the flat-topped cabinet with trumpet legs, all lavishly embellished with exotic birds, flowers and pagodas in Oriental landscapes, was bought in March for $1.5 million by the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts in Richmond. 
 "This important piece will serve as an anchor for the museum's American collection," said David Park Curry, deputy director for collections and curator of American art. "It pulls its weight as an artwork, not as an artifact." He cited its rarity, saying the 64-inch-tall chest, made in Boston, is one of fewer than 10 extant from the William and Mary period.
The second japanned object to become available is a signed Queen Anne clock from Massachusetts, made in 1740, that is almost eight feet tall; it is to be auctioned on Thursday at Sotheby's in New York. Unknown to scholars until it was sent to the auction house in February by an unidentified seller, the clock is gilded and decorated with Oriental figures, birds and foliage on a tortoise-shell ground, a painted finish popularized by Boston and New York artisans during the period. Although the surface is lusterless and certain sections are worn, most of the japanning is intact, according to William Stahl, who heads Sotheby's sales of American decorative arts.
"The clock has been lived with for more than 200 years and was not abused," he said. "There are some areas where there is minor damage to the raised decoration. All things considered, the fact that this has survived with 90 percent-plus of its gilt, gesso and background intact is extraordinary."
The seller told Sotheby's that the clock had been owned by only one family and had never been on the market. The owner gave the auction house an undated, unsigned, handwritten note, which Sotheby's has published in its catalogue; it details what the auction house says is the clock's early pedigree. According to this document, the clock was inherited "from Thomas Clap manse." Sotheby's states that the Thomas Clap in question is the man who was president of Yale College from 1740 to 1764 and a member of the Clap family, which had settled in Scituate, Mass., in 1633. Sotheby's presale estimate for the clock is $200,000 to $300,000.
According to Harold Sack, president of Israel Sack, a concern founded in 1905, the scarcity of japanned American furniture is nothing new. "We've handled no more than three or four pieces in all our years in business," Mr. Sack said. "No one knows how many were made and how many were stripped of their finishes when they became discolored, were partly destroyed or were judged to be less fashionable."
When asked why he had lowered the price of the highboy when he sold it to the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, Mr. Sack said it was because of the recession. "It's possible that in a couple of years someone would have come along and paid the price," he said. "But we had too much invested in the piece and decided we should not wait."
The costliest piece of American japanned furniture sold at auction was the only known example of a kneehole chest, a 1730 Queen Anne design made in Boston that brought $264,000 at Christie's in New York in 1988. The buyer, Eddy G. Nicholson, a New Hampshire industrialist, recalled recently that Christie's faxed him when he was on safari in Kenya to tell him how rare the bureau was.
"It is difficult to call from Kenya -- but I reached New York and said, 'Just buy it for me,' " Mr. Nicholson said. "It took almost two years to be restored, and it turned out that 90 percent of the decoration was still there."
The largest collection of American japanned furniture is at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, whose William and Mary and Queen Anne highboys, lowboys, mirrors, a shaving stand and clock are on permanent display. The surfaces are covered with the full repertory of Oriental motifs, plus, on a William and Mary highboy, offbeat additions like kites, bats and a well-fed camel.
"Painted surfaces on furniture and in architecture were extraordinarily widespread and popular in the 18th century," said Morrison Heckscher, the Metropolitan's curator of American decorative arts. "The japanned painted decoration was a Western imitation of Japanese lacquer, which was so much admired but unavailable. Most of these japanned surfaces were stripped down during the early 20th century when there was a preference for natural wood."

HEADLINE: BROADWAY;
Indifference To Culture

 BODY:
To the Editor:
What Frank Rich expresses when he deplores the exclusion of work by excellent producers like Joseph Papp, Lynne Meadow and Andre Bishop for Tony competition is that all theater is really one theater, each part nourishing and depending upon the others, no matter how experimental or escapist. But by giving an appreciative picture of the accomplishments of Papp, Meadow, Bishop, etc., Mr. Rich overlooks the dark side of the situation: that the theaters run by those producers are as endangered as those on Broadway, not to mention the many others that are even more venturesome and vulnerable and serve as the laboratories and seedbeds of the art. 
 A rotten economy and shrinking arts dollar are the immediate causes of the dire circumstance, but even more disturbing for the long term is a prevalent social and political sensibility indifferent to the arts in general and hostile to the ones that can somehow "talk back." Not just a superannuated Broadway but an entire theater culture is in jeopardy.
The truth is that the substantive theater for adult minds that Mr. Rich and everyone who loves the power of human expression wish for is, and long has been, impossible within the commercial structure of Broadway. Audiences who pay those prices just aren't in the mood for risky experiment or challenging exchange. In "Phantom of the Opera," the chandelier falls every night -- a type of certainty that Mr. Rich's justly esteemed young playwright Jon Robin Baitz, or a truly well served Shakespeare, for that matter, will never provide.
The theaters in the West 40's that now stand dark could be lighted up with both contemporary and classic work, but that would take subsidy far beyond what is now even imagined as adequate. And the public subsidy I refer to requires public will. In a society that refuses to educate its young, protect its elderly and satisfactorily serve the rest, just when might we expect that to appear?
 
JAMES LEVERETT
New York
 
The writer is dramaturge at the Berkeley Repertory Theater in Berkeley, Calif.

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory;
Summer Offers In Caribbean

 BODY:
Every summer Caribbean tour operators and hoteliers join forces in offering discounted travel packages to lure tourists during the off-season. This year's off-season lull comes on the heels of a particularly slow winter, when the combination of war in the Persian Gulf and the economic crisis in the United States discouraged many would-be vacationers. As a result, some promotional packages offered this summer have been sweetened more than usual.
Trans World Airlines' tour group, T.W.A. Getaway, has lowered prices of its packages by about 30 percent compared with last summer. Among the packages is a three-night, four-day stay at the Sands Hotel and Casino in San Juan, Puerto Rico, for $439, which includes breakfast and dinner each day and round-trip air fare from New York. More information: (800) 438-2929. 
 Several resorts on the island of St. Lucia have discounted their rates. Among them is Le Sport, an all-inclusive resort and spa, which will refund $349 to guests paying summer rates of from $185 to $240 a day a person and staying seven or more nights. The rates include all meals and drinks, spa treatments, sports facilities, taxes and gratuities. The offer is good until Dec. 15.
Air Aruba is offering a package that provides air fare, lodging and food at selected resorts for children between the ages of 2 and 11 when an adult buys a full-price ticket. The plan is available on Aruba, Bonaire and Curacao. More information: Air Aruba, (800) 827-8221.
Club Med at Punta Cana in the Dominican Republic will allow children aged 2 to 6 to stay free, excluding air fare, as part of a family, until Aug. 26.

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory;
Route Reopens In California

 BODY:
Visitors exploring the California coast north of San Francisco can once again enjoy easy access to the Marin County seaside with the reopening June 15 of a stretch of State Route 1 between Muir Beach and Stinson Beach. The road had been closed since January 1990 when a 600-foot section began sinking toward the ocean after the Loma Prieta earthquake in October 1989. Over 500,000 cubic yards of earth have since been moved to recarve the roadway deeper into the hillside.
While Stinson Beach remained accessible by a twisting two-lane road known as the Panoramic Highway, the reopening of State Route 1 provides a welcome straight and rapid route to the tiny beach town that has suffered tremendous economic loss during the closure. Beyond Stinson, visitors can continue north to Point Reyes National Seashore.

HEADLINE: First-Time Home Buyers Now Leading The Market

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
AT the end of 1988, when Robert and Christine Scuderi decided to marry, they talked, as newly engaged couples often do, about buying a home some day. Back then, the prospects for homeownership for the 21-year-olds seemed like a distant dream.
But the right combination of timing and hard work -- they both took on second jobs, he cutting grass and trimming hedges, she waiting tables -- put the Scuderis in a two-bedroom condominium in Carmel, N.Y., in February. 
 "After we decided to get married," said Mr. Scuderi, assistant controller for the National Realty Company in Purchase, N.Y., "we could see prices starting to come down. We decided that buying a home was more than just a pie-in-the-sky idea. So we started saving in a serious way. Chris and I were each able to save at least $200 a week."
The Scuderis are not alone. After years of sitting on the sidelines because of soaring housing costs and high interest rates, first-time buyers throughout the metropolitan New York region are returning to the housing market in large numbers and now dominate it. They are benefiting from a decline in home prices, favorable interest rates and flexible home-loan policies in both the private sector and state mortgage agencies.
Among the recent first-home buyers are Garfield and Donna Hall, who set up a household in a new condominium in Ridgewood, Queens. They took advantage of a low-interest, low-down-payment State of New York Mortgage Agency loan.
Gina and Christopher Russell held on to an inheritance earmarked as down-payment money, waiting for prices of their ideal home -- a loft in Manhattan -- to come down to their price range.
Robert A. Marino is one of the stouthearted first-time buyers who have ventured into the fray of real estate auctions. He was among the successful bidders at a May 19 auction for one of 54 apartments in Columbus Common, on West 90th Street and Columbus Avenue in Manhattan. Mr. Marino's bid of $300,000 captured a three-bedroom apartment with skylights and a balcony. The asking price in the prospectus was $469,000.
First-time buyers like these were the dominant force in the market in the Northeast last year, according to Century 21, the national residential brokerage company. The company's records show that this category of buyer represented 52 percent of all 1990 sales in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Rhode Island, Maryland and Massachusetts.
"The current market has been a cyclical break for buyers who had the door shut on them in the 1980's," said John A. Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors. "Affordability has increased for first-time buyers because of a moderation in prices and interest rates. But down payments are still an obstacle for many."
ESTELLE KLEIN, a sales associate with Coldwell Banker in northern New Jersey, said that in many places it is the first-time buyer who is keeping the market afloat. One reason is that first-time buyers are not encumbered with homes they have to sell. Many families who already own homes and want to move up to something larger or more luxurious find themselves trapped because they cannot get prices they find acceptable.
Despite the large number of first-time buyers, the Census Bureau reported earlier this month that home buying was still an impossible dream for most American families. The bureau found that 57 percent of all families did not earn enough to buy houses in their regions. The report further noted that home ownership was particularly difficult for black families and young couples.
Nevertheless, many banks and independent mortgage companies say that loans to first-time buyers have become a larger percentage of all mortgages written in the last year or so.
A major reason is that the average rate for a 30-year fixed instrument has hovered around the 9.75 mark, a drop from the 10 percent average rate of a year ago.
The State of New York Mortgage Agency, known as Sonny Mae, which caters to first-time buyers, reported that between January 1990 and March 1991 the dollar amount of loans made through the agency increased from just over $24 million to $41.7 million.
Paine Webber Mortgage Company, the residential lending division of the financial services company, has seen about a 50-50 split in the loans it is making to first-time buyers and those trading up or buying a second home.
Carmen A. Culpeper, president and chief financial officer of Sonny Mae, said the decline in prices was starting to provide much-needed relief to moderate-income buyers.
"In New York City an income of $50,000 or $60,000 was not high enough to buy for many years," she said. "But these days the drop in interest rates and lower prices, coupled with the push by lenders like us and Fannie Mae [the Federal National Mortgage Association], have made the difference to a lot of people.
"I don't know how long prices will continue to drop. We are trying to make the most of it by offering loans that will bring as many people into the market as possible."
She said Sonny Mae's most popular loan is a 30 year, fixed-rate mortgage, currently at 8.4 percent interest and 95 percent financing. In March the agency introduced a new fixed-rate mortgage with down payments as low as 2 percent. The mortgage, backed by tax-exempt bonds, has limits on both household incomes and the home-purchase price.
The Halls, who last month moved into a new town-house development, Cypress Gardens, in Ridgewood, Queens, are among those who bought with the help of a Sonny Mae loan. "The loan put our plan to be in our own place a bit ahead of schedule," said Mr. Hall, who is the manager of a home-supply store. "The 8.5 percent rate that Sonny Mae was able to arrange meant that we were in our new place as soon as it was finished."
The Halls, who used wedding-gift money for the down payment, paid about $128,000 for their two-bedroom town house. They were also able to save about $2,000 while living with Mrs. Hall's family.
Creative loan programs by mortgage lenders have not been limited to agencies like Sonny Mae and Fannie Mae. Paine Webber Mortgage is among the lenders designing new products with the first-time home buyer in mind.
One loan being offered by the company is a 30-year, fixed-rate instrument that has an introductory rate below 8 percent. This mortgage, which carries 3 points, currently has a rate that starts at 7.78 percent in the first year, rises to 8.78 in the second year and reaches a permanent rate of 9.25 in the third year.
"This provides a two-year cushion," said Christopher Puorro, a senior loan officer with Paine Webber Mortgage in Cranford, N.J. "The lower payments can be a help to some first-time buyers because it gives them some breathing room in the early years of the loan. In some cases the points can be wrapped into the loan amount."
CHRISTINE CULLEN, a first-time buyer who works for Nabisco Brands as a manager of a fleet of company automobiles in Parsippany, N.J., hopes to use the mortgage to buy in Hopatcong, N.J., where she recently bid on a two-bedroom house.
"With this loan," said Ms. Cullen, who said her price range is between $110,000 and $115,000, "I would like to try to buy the most I can afford right now while prices are low and interest rates are good."
Not only has the marketplace been more welcoming to first-time buyers, but the fresh opportunities also seem to have encouraged families to help. Gift money figures prominently in the financial equations of many first-time buyers, particularly newlyweds.
In addition to holding two jobs each, the Scuderis also had help from her parents. They cashed in A.T.&T. stock they had bought when Christine was an infant. That put $27,000 into the couple's wedding and house purchase fund.
The moonlighting and living at home before they married enabled both Scuderis to put away at least $200 a week. By last fall they had more than $50,000 in savings and gift money. That covered their wedding as well as the $27,000 down payment on the condominium and $3,000 in closing costs.
In another stroke of luck, the builder of the complex, the Fairways in Carmel, took 22 percent off the prices of the last 20 units in an effort to close out the development. The Scuderis paid $124,000 for a 1,500-square-foot unit with two bedrooms, a den, an eat-in kitchen and two and a half baths.
"We worked hard," said Mrs. Scuderi, who is employed as a secretary until she can find a job that will put her marketing degree to work. "But everything came together for us. If the market and interest rates had not been on our side, Bob and I would have had to choose between the kind of wedding we wanted and buying a home."
For many first-time buyers the drop in prices has provided not only a toehold in the market but also a chance for a better buy.
Gina and Christopher Russell, who closed in May on a loft in the West Village, believe that if they had tried to buy their first home two or three years ago their budget would have taken them no further than a cookie-cutter apartment in a high-rise.
"We have had a lot of friends buy lofts over the years," said Mrs. Russell, a graphic designer. "As artists, a loft was the ideal home for us. But we had a pretty good idea what most of our friends were paying for their lofts and it was basically out of the question for us."
The couple, who have lived in an apartment in Brooklyn for the last few years, started looking at lofts after Mrs. Russell inherited money. "My inheritance made it possible for us to start considering buying a home," she said. "But the main factor in our getting the loft was the market. If prices had not fallen we might have been able to buy an apartment, but we would not have been able to get what we really wanted."
The Russells paid $330,000 for a 1,350-square-foot loft on Hudson Street with private roof space. Units the same size have sold for more than $400,000.
Donald C. Hannah, president and chief executive of U.S. Auctions, a marketing consulting company in Stamford, Conn., said the promise of bargain-basement prices had made auctions particularly appealing to people who had never been able to afford their own apartments.
"MANY of the auctions being held in the metropolitan area now are offering products that fall into the economic realm of the first-time buyer," said Mr. Hannah, whose company organized the auction of the units at Columbus Common last month.
But Mr. Marino, who bought at that auction, which drew 1,200 bidders, described the event as stomach-churning.
"I have a professional familiarity with the market," said the 38-year-old Manhattan-based real estate tax consultant, "and I was really nervous."
He said his strategy was to sit as far back in the room as possible to see all bidding hands and to wait until bidding got close to his price range before joining in because "I was determined to stick to my ceiling of $300,000."
"But it happened so fast," he said. "In about five minutes I went from being a renter of a studio to owning a three-bedroom apartment. There was a lot of luck involved."

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Staff Reduction
Question: I am a rent-stabilized tenant in a 131-unit co-op. The co-op owners account for 40 percent of the occupants and rent-regulated tenants the rest. Until recently, the maintenance staff included a superintendent, two porters and a handyman. In the last few weeks, however, the sponsor has defaulted on maintenance payments. To reduce costs he dismissed the handyman with the blessing of the co-op board.
They seem to be reducing services to safeguard their financial investment. Do they have the right to do this? . . . Franklin Schornstein, Jackson Heights, Queens 
 Answer: It depends on whether the dismissal constitutes a reduction in services to tenants. It would be up to the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal to determine this.
The sponsor and board had the right to make the change without consulting the other shareholders or tenants, but not at the tenants' expense. Co-op and condominium laws say remaining tenants in converted buildings have a right to the same services and conditions as before the conversion.
The board may plan to have the handyman's jobs done by another employee or part-time worker. But if you and other tenants find this unsatisfactory, you can file a reduction in services complaint with the state housing agency. You should be prepared to describe exactly how the loss of the handyman affects the quality of tenants' lives. If the agency agrees with your complaint, it can order a reduction in rents of all units owned by the sponsor.
The appropriate forms are available at the Queens office of the D.H.C.R., 92-31 Union Hall Street, Jamaica.
 
Air-Conditioner Noise
Question: Recently the building across the street was renovated from warehouse to office space. A large ventilation system was installed on the roof. It runs all day and sometimes at night, making a loud noise that can be heard in my apartment even with the windows shut. Are there legal limits to these types of noise levels? . . . Andrew J. Miller, Manhattan
Answer: Yes. The city has standards limiting the level of persistent noises. Martha Holstein, a deputy commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, which enforces the laws, says you should call the agency to make an appointment for an inspector to measure the noise from your apartment.
This can be done after business hours if that is when the noise is most bothersome. If the noise is above the legal limit, the owner will be required to correct the situation.
"Sometimes it is as simple as turning off equipment during nonbusiness hours," said Ms. Holstein.
Businesses that ignore requests for modification risk violations.
 
Paperwork Fee
Question: I recently decided to have the old, single-paned windows in my co-op apartment changed. I found a contractor, got a bid and asked the managment agency what else I would need to get approval. It is asking for the usual things (proof of contractor's insurance, etc.) plus a $150 processing fee. I think the fee is outrageous. Can I refuse to pay it and still put in my windows? . . . Kevin Ramsey, Manhattan
Answer: Probably not. The co-op board has the right to set procedures and require permission for this sort of work. Proceeding without permission would risk more serious problems with your co-op, including a possible suit. If other shareholders agree with you, together you might be able to get the board to drop or lower the fee.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: St. Ann's Church;
An 1869 Work With a Shaky Future

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
NEXT Sunday is the cutoff date for the New York City Council to establish new procedures for nonprofit owners of landmark buildings to appeal for relief because of financial hardship. Preservationists are nervously considering which buildings might be the first to bring a request for demolition under liberalized rules.
One that always gets a second look is the 1869 St. Ann's Church, owned by Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn Heights. This elaborate Victorian gothic sanctuary has been vacant since 1967 and requires at least $6 million in repairs. Dr. Frank Bookhout, the school's business manager, calls it a "bomb that's ticking away." 
 The parish was organized in 1787 and in the mid-1860's plans were prepared by the firm of Renwick & Sands for a new church building. James Renwick's St. Patrick's Cathedral was then largely complete in Manhattan; that and his 1843 Grace Church at 10th Street and Broadway in Manhattan had put him and his Gothic Revival designs at the forefront of church architecture in the city.
But for St. Ann's the architects chose the "Second Pointed style," in the words of Harper's Weekly in 1869. The new St. Ann's that rose on the northeast corner of Clinton and Livingston Streets was a rich polychrome mix of cocoa-colored Belleville brownstone, stripes of white Cleveland stone and contrasting roof slate.
The interior, designed to seat 2,000, is a vast, high space with intricate timber trusswork, a broad three-sided gallery and dozens of richly colored stained-glass windows. There are elaborately carved Gothic style pews, polychrome tile floors and broad sweeps of stenciled and mosaic decoration, especially around the chancel. The Harper's Weekly article attributes the original decoration to "Cohn," apparently Louis H. Cohn, an active decorative painter in the period.
Large, undisguised cast-iron columns support the gallery and roof and run down each side of the nave. There is also cast-iron wainscotting along the side aisle walls. Andrew Dolkart, a specialist in the history of church design in Brooklyn, said that St. Ann's is among the earliest American churches to use cast iron in such a way.
Harper's Weekly called the church "a masterpiece of art"; it was one of the many that made Brooklyn "the city of churches." Indeed, St. Ann's was built within three blocks of two other churches, Grace Church at Hicks Street and Grace Court and the Church of the Holy Trinity at Montague and Clinton Streets.
According to an article in The World, the congregation went into debt to build its new church. By 1878 the debt amounted to $135,000. On May 28 of that year the Union Dime Bank began foreclosure proceedings. But the next morning, Robert F. Cutting, a Wall Street banker, contributed $60,000, enough to keep control of the structure. The World article said that Cutting gave the money as a memorial to his wife, the eldest daughter of the rector at St. Ann's, Dr. Noah H. Schenck.
There was little change in the building through 1964, when the Rev. Melville Harcourt, the rector, complained that the parish was shrinking because "when a couple is blessed by an addition to the family . . . it is generally more economical to move elsewhere."
In 1967, the congregation sold the church to its neighbor, Packer Collegiate Institute, and merged with Holy Trinity as St. Ann and the Holy Trinity. Packer renovated the undercroft for its use but apparently did not have a clear idea for the 7,800-square-foot sanctuary, which has not been used on a regular basis since the congregation left.
NOW the interior is a mix of pigeon droppings, minor leaks, age-darkened paint and soft rays of light filtering through the stained glass. Little has been changed. The velvet pew cushions remain untouched and there is such an emptiness that the settling of dust can almost be heard.
Dorothy Hutcheson, assistant head of Packer, said the school has given up trying to sell, share or rent the church. The Brooklyn Heights Synagogue was interested for a time, she said, but was put off by the high cost of repairs. Packer retained a respected preservation firm, Mesick, Cohen & Waite, to study the building. Its estimate, just to repair the existing structure, comes to about $6 million.
Now, Ms. Hutcheson says, "we have basically prostrated ourselves at the feet of the New York Landmarks Conservancy," a private preservation group helping St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in its own $16 million rehabilitation campaign. Packer has not ruled out applying for a hardship permit, Ms. Hutcheson said, but "we need to feel we've done everything we could to save the building."

GRAPHIC: Photo: St. Ann's Church, erected in 1869 in Brooklyn Heights, in 1896. (Brooklyn Historical Society)

HEADLINE: Eighth-Grade Parties: Tuxedos, Gowns and an Uneasy Air

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

DATELINE: RUTHERFORD

 BODY:
"THIS is hysterical," said Joan Froelich, 19 years old, as she watched the young people in strapless gowns and tuxedos posing unself-consciously before a phalanx of video cameras. "No way are these kids eighth graders," she said.
But they were.
Ms. Froelich, a sophomore at Scranton University in Pennsylvania, had returned to her old elementary school to watch a time-honored rite of passage: the eighth-grade Pierrepont School graduation party. But this was not the same event Ms. Froelich remembered from six years ago. 
 "I wore a party dress," she said. "Only one girl was really dressed up, and she was the richest girl in the class."
Ms. Froelich's reaction underscores a trend in elementary and middle schools statewide -- a trend parents call expensive, psychologists call excessive and teen-agers call exciting.
"I think they're growing up too fast," Ms. Froelich said.
 
At Graduation, a Transformation
 The Pierrepont School in Rutherford is a typical elementary school in Bergen County. Students arrive with books in hand and cross the street only at the command of crossing guards. At the end of the day they head home in small clusters: boys with boys and girls with girls.
Then, on the eve of graduation, they are transformed.
"It took me almost five hours to get ready," said Karri Bille, 14 years old, who arrived at the party in a strapless aquamarine gown matching the color of her eyeshadow. The dress, she said, cost $120, adding, "I'll probably never wear it again."
Nearby, Erica Lima, 14, stood with her date, Mark Ramdas, also 14. Mark, his hair short, stiff and very shiny, was wearing a tuxedo carefully tailored to his compact frame. In a flash of boyish impulsiveness, he momentarily abandoned his date and went chasing after a colleague who was also wearing a tuxedo.
Erica, in a red satin gown with high puffed sleeves, took advantage of the moment to confide to a friend, "My feet are killing me."
Each year, parents of Pierrepont eighth graders reward their sons and daughters with an end-of-the-year dinner-dance. The parents decorate the school gym, prepare the meal and then, in a role they are no doubt accustomed to, serve as waiters and waitresses for the youngsters.
But the dinner-dance, which began as a simple graduation party, has evolved into an elaborate affair. Last year, before the recession hit suburbia, some students arrived in limousines.
"We really don't encourage the children to dress up," said Ellen Keane, co-chairwoman of this year's event. "We try not to make this a grammar school prom."
But for the students, that is what the dinner-dance is.
"We just don't go down to the Shore after it," said Glenn Lynch, 14, who wore a cream-colored tuxedo for the affair.
 
'It's Getting Out of Hand'
 The Pierrepont School is not alone. Many elementary schools and middle schools across the state have their own versions of eighth-grade graduation parties. Some are in school gyms or local halls; others are fancy catered affairs in expensive restaurants or luxury hotels.
The Mount Hebron Middle School in Upper Montclair has its annual eighth-grade dinner-dance at the Atrium West Caterers in West Orange. Students, or more precisely their parents, pay $35 each to attend.
"I think it's getting out of hand," said Diana Quinones of Upper Montclair, whose daughter, Amy, is graduating from Mount Hebron. "I think the kids these days are rushing things. They're trying to make this more than it should be."
Mrs. Quinones said her daughter asked if she could rent a limousine to take her and some friends to the affair.
"I told her I would be her limousine for the night," Mrs. Quinones said. "I'm not going to pay for a limousine for an eighth grader."
School officials at Mount Hebron say that while they do not prohibit formal dress and rented transportation, they do encourage students to dress in a way that is appropriate for an eighth-grade activity.
But Mrs. Quinones said the school should set definite rules. "These are 13- and 14-year-olds," she said. "They're not adults."
Officials of the Toms River Regional Schools in Dover Township have also notified parents of the district's desire to keep this year's affair simple. The message, however, has often been accompanied by protestations from the children.
 
'Everybody's Dressing Up'
 "Everybody's dressing up," Danielle Onorato, 14, a student at Toms River Intermediate East, said while conferring with two friends about potential dates. "It's like a competition. Everybody tries to dress better than everybody else."
And while Danielle's mother, Debbie Onorato, says she believes that the affair has become "a bit much," she is in a quandary: How can she force her daughter to wear a simple party dress when all her friends will be wearing formal gowns?
"Every year the principal writes home and says there is no need to go out and get ultra-fancy dresses, and every year the kids continue to dress up," Mrs. Onorato said.
Mike Wherry, assistant superintendent of the Toms River schools, said it was up to the parents to set the limits on what their children could wear.
"We've tried to tell the parents to have the kids dress nice and neat and to discourage all this other stuff that goes on," he said.
Mr. Wherry said that this year, as a result of that message, he expected students to dress a bit less elaborately. "It's really nothing more than the eighth-grade social," he said, adding that almost 1,000 students are expected to attend.
But if Danielle and her friends are right, most of the students are buying gowns or renting tuxedos, and some, perhaps many, are renting limousines.
While school officials say parents should draw the line and parents say officials should, psychologists say the children are getting mixed signals.
"You're giving the kids a double message," said Dr. Lois Goorwitz, a psychologist in Upper Montclair. "If you really want to discourage this, you lay down ground rules: No one wears strapless gowns. No one wears tuxedos. And no one arrives in limousines. Period."
Dr. Goorwitz said that encouraging or allowing 13- and 14-year-old children to act and look like adults was a mistake.
 
'Are We Pushing Them?'
 "To give kids that age the message that they should be engaging in what is basically a precocious sexual relating is just not wise," Dr. Goorwitz said.
While teen-agers are now being warned of the dangers of casual sexual behavior, she said, younger children are being encouraged to act more and more like adults.
At the same time, Dr. Goorwitz said, "the ante keeps going up in terms of what behaviors are socially acceptable."
Some parents, while acknowledging that their children's lives are more adult-like than their own were, see no harm in allowing youngsters to enjoy themselves.
"Are we pushing them?" asked Dr. Eugene Graziano, a Rutherford physician who was a waiter at his daughter's Pierrepont School dinner-dance. "Maybe we are. But this is something that we didn't have as kids. Maybe it's guilt on our part. We didn't have it so we want them to have it."
 
No Reason to Deprive Them
 Dr. Graziano said that as long as parents could afford to provide such experiences for their children, and followed up by being good, caring parents, there was no reason to deprive the children of such social activities.
 
Life as a Black-Tie Affair
 But some parents do not like the idea that their sons and daughters are being rushed into adulthood and perhaps being given a distorted sense of values.
"The children here in Woodcliff Lake think that life is a black-tie affair," said Leslie Ryan, a teacher of the visually impaired whose daughter, Katie, will be graduating from the Woodcliff School next year. The school, which holds its annual dinner-dance at the Woodcliff Lake Hilton, discourages the wearing of formal attire.
Mrs. Ryan said that for Katie, who is 12, next year's dance will probably be anticlimactic. Her daughter, she said, has already been to nearly 25 black-tie affairs, mostly bar mitzvahs and bat mitzvahs for her friends.
 Mrs. Ryan, like Mrs. Onorato and many other parents, is caught between her daughter's predictable response to peer pressure and her own sense of what is appropriate for her child.
"So we're going to teach her a lesson," Mrs. Ryan said. "Next month we're taking her camping. She's already in a cold sweat."

HEADLINE: Ossining Architects Join Team to Return Soviet City to Glory

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: OSSINING

 BODY:
AN ambitious project to create a new tourist center in Odessa, the Soviet port on the Black Sea, has found a base in this Hudson River town. How Gershon Palevski, an Ossining architect, found himself immersed in the dreams of Soviet planners is a story of imagination, vision and a kind of naivete.
For the last year, Mr. Palevski, a native of Vilnius, Lithuania, and his partner in the architectural firm of Studio RAI here, Lucio Di Leo, have been working on a master plan to rehabilitate Odessa. The plan was conceived by a Soviet artist and designer, Eugeniy Olenin, whom Mr. Palevski met on a trip to the Soviet Union last year. 
 The Ossining architects are the only Americans on the design team, which includes French and Soviet architects, chosen to help restore the deteriorating city, which was once known for its artistic vitality and eclectic charm. The team is backed by the Odessa City Council.
 
Money Lacking for Project
 Mr. Palevski explained that in Odessa, age and neglect are undermining the limestone buildings that survived two world wars and decades of Communism. Unlike streets in Moscow, for example, where the Soviets demolished historic structures, "the fabric of the 200-year-old city has been left intact," he said.
The architect described the seaport as "neoclassical, on a nice scale," and noted its reputation as a former "center of Russian culture with a cosmopolitan, multinational tradition."
Mr. Olenin, the project's director, said a tourist industry based on free enterprise could flourish in a revitalized Odessa, where miles of ocean beaches and restored hotels, museums and parks could attract visitors.
For the moment, though, efforts to attract foreign investors in the project are hampered by a lack of money. Thus, when the Russian-Jewish Cultural Center in Chicago invited Mr. Olenin to attend the center's second yearly festival of Russian art last month, he seized upon the chance to publicize his plan.
The project director also arranged to send a huge painting, representing the rise and fall of Odessa, to the United States. The work -- 24 feet wide, 10 feet high and 5 feet deep, and painted in three panels placed one in front of the other -- was meant to be the backdrop for a display in Chicago of the architectural models for the project, many of which remain in the Soviet Union.
But the 17 boxes holding the sections of the painting and its construction materials were marooned at Kennedy International Airport in New York City after arriving from the Soviet Union, Mr. Palevski said. No provision had been made either to send the large work from New York City to Chicago or to have it released from the airline's cargo building.
 
The Logjam Is Broken
 Mr. Palevski, as a member of the design team, was called to help get the painting through customs. After two days of discussions with increasingly higher placed officials, he said, he succeeded in breaking through what had become a logjam. The architect said he was not prepared, however, to pay for shipping the work to Chicago. He had it trucked to Ossining, where he assembled one part of the painting -- the middle section -- in the sheltered driveway of friends, Galina and Dimitri Kanevsky.
There it stood, a surreal sight among the trees, while Mr. Palevski tried to figure out what to do next. Painted in oils on boards by Aleksandr Roitburd, an Odessa artist, the work shows angels rising and falling amid landmarks of the city. Mr. Olenin and Mr. Roitburd, who own the painting, said the work would be too expensive to return to the Soviet Union, Mr. Palevski said.
The owners and the architect said they thought publicizing the painting's plight might attract someone who could arrange for a gallery showing or use the painting to help raise funds for the project. Meanwhile, Mr. Palevski said, he would hang as much of the work as will fit on his office wall, where people can go to see it.
In a subplot to this story, as told by Mr. Palevski, a group of people, as well as the painting, was stranded at Kennedy. Mr. Olenin, Mr. Roitburd, a Russian musician and several Russian painters en route to the Chicago festival with other artwork arrived at Kennedy without airline tickets for the trip's next leg, and with little money.
With the help of Mr. Palevski and Russian immigrants in Brooklyn, a bus was found with drivers willing to take the people and their smaller, more manageable paintings to Chicago. When the bus broke down on the ride home, more help was rounded up to get the visitors back to New York.
 
'Dedicated' People, if Naive

"They are naive people," Mr. Palevski said of the Russians. "They have little understanding that everything here costs a lot of money."
But he added that they were also "honest, dedicated" people, who "don't look for personal gain." He noted that he had not told the Olenin entourage of his own sacrifice: two weeks spent rescuing the painting and helping their group while his own work piled up.
Neither Mr. Palevski nor his partner has received fees for their designs for the Odessa project.
Mr. Palevski looked out his office window at the hills of Ossining, a town he said he picked to live and work in because it reminded him of Vilnius, "as much as an American city can resemble a European city."
He believes in the Odessa project, he said, because "it is the perfect region to restore" because it could again be a center of culture and tourism. And the city, in the southern Ukraine 750 miles from Moscow has "less bureaucratic problems" than areas closer to Moscow, making it more amenable to free enterprise, he said. But while Odessa would be "very easy to restore" architecturally, Mr. Palevski said, the project's success would depend on social and economic reforms in the Soviet Union. The planners want to create "a living, blooming city, not a museum," he said.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

WOMEN AND FITNESS
 Westchester County's Women's Health and Fitness Weekend, to be held at the County Center in White Plains from Friday through next Sunday, is expected to draw 5,000 women and their families to a battery of events designed to shape them up and ship them out in improved condition.
 A Citibank Women's Health Conference on Friday from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. offers free testing for blood pressure, cholesterol, skin and breast cancer and glaucoma; and workshops on a variety of subjects including single parenting, Elderlaw, menopause, arthritis and osteoporosis, and nutrition. The only charge is a $70 fee for mammograms, available to women older than 35. 
 During Saturday's Women's Health and Fitness Expo, from 9 A.M to 5 P.M., visitors may try rollerblading on one of the 100 pairs of two- wheeled skates available to be lent. Among 75 other exhibits, workshops, demonstrations, health tests and activities for children are a 17-foot-high simulated boulder for a bit of rock-climbing; aerobic and exercise dance sessions, low-impact bench-stepping, face-painting and karate.
 The big event is the Danskin Triathlon beginning at 8 A.M. Sunday with a half-mile swim in Lake Isle in Eastchester, followed by a 12.4-mile bicycle race on the Bronx River Parkway in White Plains and ending with a 3.1 mile footrace along the Bronx River Parkway to Kensico Dam Plaza in Valhalla, where prizes will be awarded. Triathlon training clinics will be held Saturday at 10 A.M., noon, 2 and 4 P.M.
 Last year's winner, Renee Goldhirsch, will compete again, as will Ethel Autorino, winner in last year's women's 60 to 64 age group of the Hawaiian World Ironman Triathlon, and the 1990 International Women's Triathlon Champion, Karen Smyers, who competed last September at Disney World in Florida. Each leg of the Danskin Triathlon is half the distance of the international competitions. For more information, call 285-2650.
 
UKRAINIAN FOLKWAYS
 Children from the Ukrainian American Youth Association of Yonkers will perform folk dances and songs of their ancestral country at 7:30 P.M. Tuesday in the New Rochelle Library.
 As students at the School of Ukrainian Studies of St. Michael's Ukrainian Catholic Church in Yonkers, they learn to sing and dance the way their forefathers and mothers did and learn to read and write in Ukrainian. From 5 through 16 years old, they also study the history, culture and literature of that republic, which is said to be the richest in the Soviet Union and has the cities of Kiev, Odessa and Lvov.
 The program will be narrated by Maria Kozicky under the direction of Dr. Orest Kozicky. It is free.
 
WEEKEND COLLEGE
 Working men and women who can't find time to pursue an undergraduate degree during the week now have an alternative. Marymount College offers the Weekend College, in session from Friday evening through Sunday. It features majors in business, economics, education, English, history, information systems and psychology.
 It takes about four-and-one-half years to acquire the credits necessary to obtain a degree, not much longer than daytime college. The cost is $215 a credit and classes begin in September on a year-round trimester basis.
 An open house in which the proram will be fully explained is to be held Saturday from 10 A.M. to noon on the Tarrytown campus. Personal interviews with admissions counselors are available Saturday by appointment from 9 to 10 A.M. and from 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. Call 631-3200, extension 295.
 
GALACTIC EVENTS
 Nine hundred and 37 years ago next month, in July 1054, a star in the constellation of Taurus the Bull exploded after running out of nuclear fuel, causing a supernova so bright that it was seen in broad daylight.
 This, and many other spectacular galactic events, may be seen in the new planetarium show opening at the Hudson River Museum titled "Galaxies," based on the book of the same name by Timothy Ferris, who narrates the program. Published by Sierra Club Books in San Francisco in 1980, "Galaxies" was also printed in paperback in 1982 by Stewart, Tabor & Chang in Manhattan.
 The show begins with Galileo's concept in 1609 identifying the hazy band of light that we call the Milky Way as a conglomerate of individual stars. It goes on to explore galaxies beyond the Milky way, some 100 billion of them, each containing billions of stars, observable through the planetarium's Zeiss Star Projector.
A supercluster of galaxies near the constellation of Virgo has as its core Virgo A, the giant ellipse of a thousand billion stars containing what some astronomers believe is a black hole in which hundreds of millions of dead stars are entombed.
 "Galaxies" can be seen through Nov. 24 on Saturdays and Sundays at 1 and 4 P.M. Admission is $4 for adults and $2 for children and the elderly. It will also be shown through September on Thursdays at 7 P.M. when admission will be free. The museum is at 511 Warburton Avenue in Yonkers. Call 963-4550 for more information.
 
LOOKING AT INSECTS
 Carol Maslansky, a former entomologist for the state, was involved in a yearlong surveillance program designed to combat an insurgence of Rocky Mountain spotted fever and equine encephalitis in the 1970's. She is now a consulting toxicologist, and she will conduct a four-session entomology course sponsored by the County Parks Department.
 From 2 to 4 P.M. today, July 28, Aug. 25 and Sept. 22 at the Marshlands Conservancy in Rye, Ms. Maslansky will lead field trips into the conservancy grounds and discuss the life styles and uses of the broad range of insects that live there.
 "I try to orient toward the majority of participants who come on a given day," she said. "If there are many children it will be a simpler program. Adults with a higher level of understanding will prompt a more complicated session." The course is free and there is no obligation to attend every session, but "people tend to come back at least once or twice," Ms. Maslansky said.
 She usually starts out with the basics -- such as, what is an insect and what makes it different from ticks or spiders, which are not insects. "There are a lot of misconceptions," she said. "Solitary nesting bees who do the majority of the pollination are not dangerous. Most insects are really quite mellow unless they're disturbed. They prefer to leave people alone."
 Insect behavior, in which a small group may observe the daily life of the dragonfly or damselfly in its native habitat, is the kind of program she devises on a more complex level.
 She recommends that particpants wear long pants, socks, long sleeves, comfortable shoes and carry an insect repellent. No pre-registration is required. The conservancy is on Route 1 just south of the Rye Golf Club. Call 835-4466 for more information.

HEADLINE: ART;
Capturing the Range of Nature in an Exhibition on Wave Hill

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

DATELINE: THE BRONX

 BODY:
A "NEW POVERTY" in the museum scene has been replaced by resourcefulness. There has always been fund raising, of course, but now the need is for income to replace lost Federal and local funds. As a result, development officers are blooming like desert flowers (which may explain the surge in duplicate and irrelevant mailings) but there are other, firmer implications of privatization, like art auctions and museum exhibitions sponsored by galleries.
Even so, it is a bit of a shock to hear that Wave Hill, the Riverdale mansion where Teddy Roosevelt summered, Mark Twain lived and Toscanini stayed, is now considering weddings as a source of income. Not that the economic strain is visible: this estate overlooking the Hudson never looked better and the exhibition on view in the Glyndor House and Wave Hill itself might have been designed for those who love it but are not up to walking its 28 acres. Titled "Wave Hill Pictured," it brings some of these acres indoors by way of photographs in black and white and color. 
 Since 1965, when the estate, a gift to New York City, was incorporated, gardeners have been at work restoring the grounds and converting them for public use. This observer, for one, looks forward as much to the hickories and red (actually, port-colored) beeches as to the exhibitions and, strange to say, the present show and its book represent the first celebration of "plein-air" Wave Hill.
This began two years ago when Jean Feinberg, then Wave Hill's curator and director of exhibitions, chose the photographers, Lois Conner, Jan Groover, Stephen Scheer and Philip Trager. She gave them their heads with the scenery, keeping her own for a grave essay on the history and nuances of landscape photography. This takes into account a wide range of exponents from Timothy Sullivan to Stieglitz, from Eugene Atget, the chronicler of Paris, to Frederick Evans, the English specialist in churches; and from Ansel Adams to Minor White, Eliot Porter, Paul Caponigro and Lee Friedlander.
The Wave Hill group is not as varied as these photographers, perhaps because all focus on the same subject. Ms. Feinberg said they are so different that academics might see the "subjective and interpretative nature" of their pictures as detracting from their "informational value."
Despite her beginnings as a fashion photographer, Lois Conner, Ms. Feinberg says, is the only one of the group to have worked outdoors "almost exclusively." For Wave Hill, Ms. Conner mostly uses that gift to landscape, the banquet camera yielding a 7-by-17-inch image. The resulting panoramas have their disadvantages, because the eye is not always comfortable traversing wide tracts of wooded scenery. But for the shot of an American yellowwood, the format is ideal. Truncated, the tree stands slightly off-center with its four large lower limbs spread out and casting shadows on a lawn that seems powdered with snow. Behind, is a pergola, a balustrade and, under a thunderous sky, the dark mass of the Palisades. The lighting is strange; it could as easily come from tall Klieg lamps as the overhead sun.
A photographer who also paints, Jan Groover is noted for her carefully orchestrated and often mysterious still lifes. Yet at Wave Hill, she headed for the wild garden that adjoins the greenhouse and the aquatic garden. Working with two cameras, an 8 by 10 inch and a 2 1/2 by 4 1/2 inch, she surveyed the thickets where grow Snow in Summer, Warminster Broom, the occasional cutleaf staghorn Sumac and many other species.
Ms. Groover was there in all seasons but did her best work in the seasonless greenhouse filled with succulents, prickly, smooth and webby-looking. There is one picture that covers all kinds and their colors -- icy green, pink, orange and golden brown -- make them look good enough to eat, spines notwithstanding. The hothouse atmosphere suits this photographer.
With the color prints of Stephen Scheer it is necessary to have a cool head and a liking for what used to be called trick photography. Of all the exhibitors, Mr. Scheer is the least experienced with nature and the least willing to let it get the upper hand -- hence, perhaps, his partiality for double exposures. He also uses two cameras -- a 2 1/4 by a 2 1/4 inch and a 4 inch by 5 inch -- and sometimes a Polaroid for, as it were, preliminary sketches. Those who would know more about his technique should consult the catalogue.
As for the double exposures, it takes a few seconds to realize what Mr. Scheer is doing and to be sure he is doing it in every print, because some look like images of reflections in glass. This is not Surrealism a la Jerry Uelsmann nor is it abstraction for its own sake. It is not really anything but a virtuoso demonstration of what can be done with a camera.
Last but not least is Philip Trager, a lawyer in Bridgeport who began attracting attention with photographs of architecture in the late 1970's. He has produced three books, one of Connecticut photographs, another about Wesleyan University and the third on the villas of Palladio. While this is probably his most prestigious album, the reviewer remains loyal to the harder-won Connecticut images.
Mr. Trager's great gift is for treating buildings as if they were sculpture; he seems to be thinking about the invisible rear of a structure even as he photographs the visible front. And to Wave Hill he brings his same gift and a view camera to bear on the landscape, the sky and some of the incidental architecture. He pays attention to both the classical pergola with its stumpy columns, and the greenhouse with its Tudor outline and a classical stone portico.
It is in the scenes like that of two trees facing each other across a lawn that sweeps like a driveway around a creeper-covered wall that Mr. Trager does his finest work. The V of cumulus clouds hanging over the greenhouse at sunset is another stirring shot. On second thought, he is not a photographer treating nature like architecture but a photographer who portrays both with an intensity more often applied to human subjects.
The show that gives viewers fresh eyes with which to enjoy the nature outside. It remains through Oct. 27.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Berkeley;
636 Professors Accept Early-Retirement Offer

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif.

 BODY:
Under an early-retire ment plan offered to meet a budget crisis, the University of California system will lose 636 faculty members.
Thirty-two percent of the eligible faculty members and 59 percent of eligible staff members have accepted the retirement package offered, said a system spokesman, Paul West. 
 But some of the faculty retirees will return as part-time employees either to teach or conduct research, said Carole Swartz, assistant vice president of the system's benefits program.
The University of California campuses at Berkeley and Los Angeles will shoulder the most severe losses. Nine percent of Berkeley's faculty, or 150 people, have agreed to retire, compared with 7 percent, or 159, at U.C.L.A.
Several prominent professors, however, are planning to return part-time at Berkeley, including Gerard Debreu, a professor of economics and mathematics who won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1983, and Loftie Zadeh, noted for his work in artificial intelligence.
Two percent of Berkeley's staff members, or 320, have accepted the retirement plan, compared with 3 percent, or 532, at U.C.L.A. They will also be eligible for part-time employment, university officials say.
 
Infusion of Younger People
 The loss of faculty members is double-edged, administrators say. "Younger people will be coming in with new ideas, and that's good," said Earl Cheit, chairman of Berkeley's Walter Haas School of Business, "but the biggest problem is that you lose people who have institutional memory and experience that can't be replaced rapidly."
Eight of the 13 professors retiring from the business school will return to teach because they are "crucial to the curriculum," Professor Cheit said.
Vitelmo Bertero, who has been teaching civil engineering at Berkeley for 33 years and was director of an investigation of the 1989 San Francisco Bay area earthquake, will return to continue research in earthquake engineering. But 37 of 231 faculty members in Berkeley's College of Engineering will not.
"The faculty retiring all at once will probably affect the quality of education for a few years," Professor Bertero said, "but the young people have learned all that they can from us, and once the new group gets established, they may be better than the ones around today."
"I just hope the professors don't have to teach more courses," he said, "because then the research will be hurt, and you can't have a graduate school without research."
 
Minority Hiring Pushed
 Recalled professors will be paid as part-time employees, but with no benefits. After five years, they can be rehired as career employees. The number of professors returning part-time is not yet known.
Upon retirement, faculty and staff members who have accepted the "Five Plus" plan will receive five years of service credit plus a one-time sum equivalent to three months of salary.
Those urging the university system to hire more members of minority groups and women hope that the retirements will lead to more diversity among the predominantly white male faculty.
But Margarita Melville, associate dean of the graduate division at Berkeley, noted that in some departments hit hardest by the retirements, like engineering and mathematics, there were still comparatively few women and minority candidates from whom to choose. And some specialized subjects within departments might not draw a diversity of applicants, she noted.
"The chancellor's office can only recommend hiring a more diverse faculty," she said.
The retirement program, approved by the Board of Regents last fall, is intended to ease fiscal pressures on the university system, which since 1983 has had a budget gap of about $60 million a year. Recently Gov. Pete Wilson cut $295 million from the system's proposed budget for 1991-1992.
Ray Colvig, director of public information at Berkeley, said: "Money saved from those professors receiving high salaries can be used for purposes of part-time or temporary professors. Even though quite a lot of faculty will be coming back, the university will still save a lot of money."
Salaries for full professors range from $59,600 to $106,000 a year; most make about $80,000.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Wisconsin;
Korean Company Uses Campus As Film Backdrop

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis.

 BODY:
A feature film that will give audiences in Korea a look at what American campus life is like is using more than 100 University of Wisconsin students as extras.
The Patmos Production Company of Seoul shot campus scenes Thursday and Friday for "My Beloved Agnus," a film that follows a Korean lawyer's investigation into the murder of a Korean graduate student studying in the United States. 
 The director, Young Jin Yoo, said the Madison campus was chosen as the backdrop for the film because of its beauty and because the university has more than 400 students registered in the Korean Student Association. Between 20 and 30 Korean students took part in the filming.
"As students of the university, we are concerned about the image of the school shown to people in Korea," said Sunah Kim, an extra in the film and a sophomore from Seoul majoring in marketing. "We want them to see where we live and study."
 
Presenting a Positive Image
 Korean students participating in the film said they wanted relatives and friends back home to see a positive image of the university, said Young Kim, president of the Korean Student Association and a senior majoring in economics.
He said that with an increasing number of Korean students traveling to the United States, Koreans in general were becoming more aware of Western culture. He said he hoped the film would add to that awareness.
More and more Korean companies are going abroad to shoot their films, said Kyung Sick Shin, the producer. And there is a growing market in Korea for movies about colleges and universities in other countries, he said.
"People want to see what students do over here, what it is like for them," Mr. Shin said.
Theater and drama students at the university will be learning from the film as well, said Peyton Smith, the assistant director of university relations, who went on location with the filmmakers. He noted, for example, that students had a chance to learn first-hand about filmmaking and about Korea's film industry.
Scenes shot around campus will include the State Historical Society of Wisconsin, various university classrooms and the Union Terrace. The rest of the film will be shot in Chicago.
The filmmakers said the movie would be released in Korea and later translated to be shown in the United States. No release date has been set.
