HEADLINE: There's No Stopping Europe's Airbus Now

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Five years ago, when Airbus Industrie was still an unproven underdog, many airlines hesitated to order its aircraft because they were uncertain that Airbus would be around in a few years' time.
But Airbus is still alive and kicking. The European aircraft consortium has captured 30 percent of the world market and is gunning for close to 40 percent. It has shoved McDonnell Douglas aside to take the industry's No. 2 spot, and its rapid ascent even has some Boeing officials worrying about their company's survival. 
 With about half the world's aircraft market, the Boeing Company is not easily cowed. But Boeing officials say they are competing not just against a company -- but against the deep pockets of the French, German, British and Spanish governments, which the Americans say have improperly pumped $26 billion into Airbus to propel Europe into the aviation big leagues.
While Washington has taken little action against Airbus to date, the conviction that huge subsidies have enabled Airbus to mount a serious challenge in one of the few areas where the United States retains industrial superiority is fueling talk of a trade war. Airbus's success is all the more galling for American officials because aerospace is one of the major areas of surplus in the nation's trade balance.
For Boeing, the stakes are higher than ever in its jousting with the 21-year-old European consortium. Now that Airbus has a family of five aircraft, its order book has exploded, causing Boeing's share of last year's orders to plunge to less than 50 percent for the first time in decades. What is more, at this year's Paris Air Show, which ends today, Airbus's president, Jean Pierson, announced that the consortium would begin studying the development of a 600-to-700 seat aircraft, the largest passenger plane in history. This super jumbo jet would provide the first head-to-head competition for Boeing's 747, which has long been Boeing's cash cow.
Fearing that the 747's days as the unrivaled king of the skies may soon be over, Boeing, along with the Bush Administration, has turned up the rhetoric about Airbus's subsidies. Boeing executives say Airbus could undertake such a multibillion dollar project only with the support of big subsidies from the European governments.
"If they continue these subsidies, then there may be no one left in the business except Airbus in 15 years," said Lawrence Clarkson, Boeing's senior vice president for international affairs. "It doesn't take a lot to imagine a scenario where Boeing could not afford to bring out new aircraft. And if your product line becomes obsolete, you're out of the business."
 
Airbus's Bigger Bite
 Some industry officials say Boeing is crying wolf. But there is no denying that Airbus has bitten into the profit margins of Boeing and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, making it harder for them to develop new aircraft. Airbus has chopped Douglas's market share over the last decade to 15 percent from 30 percent, and many analysts say Douglas's survival in commercial aviation may be in danger.
Industry officials also say that if the Europeans reject American demands to curb Airbus subsidies in trade talks being held in Geneva, Washington might slap higher duties on Airbus aircraft, Mercedes-Benz cars or other European products. Mercedes cars could be a target because Deutsche Aerospace, a subsidiary of Daimler-Benz A.G., is one of Airbus's shareholders. The others are British Aerospace P.L.C., Aerospatiale, a state-owned French company, and CASA, a state-owned Spanish aerospace company. The group formed because each thought itself too small to challenge Boeing.
Airbus officials say the Americans are angry because Airbus had the effrontery to break up the cozy hold that Boeing and McDonnell Douglas had on the world's aircraft market. In the Europeans' view, government aid was essential if they were to break into the business and develop modern aircraft. Airbus's advocates also accuse the Americans of hypocrisy, asserting that Boeing's and Douglas's commercial aircraft operations have received billions of dollars in indirect aid through Pentagon contracts.
 
The European Response
 "The Americans take the position that the Europeans are the black sheep and the Americans the white sheep, when the truth is that all the sheep are gray," said Airbus's Mr. Pierson, a big, bluff man who is alternately charming and combative.
"Whoever starts a war is going to find himself in a war," he added in an interview during the Paris Air Show. "If the Americans take some action, I can assure you the Europeans will respond."
To resolve the dispute through negotiation, the Americans and Europeans will somehow have to bridge a huge philosophical chasm. Washington's hands-off approach to commercial aviation clashes fundamentally with the hands-on approach Europe is taking in building a world-class aircraft industry.
Amid Europe's efforts to bolster high-tech industries, including computers and semiconductors, Airbus is one of the few successes. "Airbus is the jewel of European industry," said Paul Quiles, France's Transportation Minister.
Airbus expects to produce 200 aircraft a year beginning in 1993, compared with just 28 in 1986. Its order backlog of 990 aircraft, valued at $68 billion, is larger than the 722 aircraft it has delivered since its inception. If Boeing's 747 is excluded, because Airbus has no comparable aircraft, then Airbus won more orders than Boeing last year. What is more, despite the decline in orders because of the Persian Gulf crisis and the airline industry's financial crunch, Airbus forecasts it will sell more than one-third of the $680 billion worth of aircraft expected to be purchased over the next 18 years.
"The consortium is doing spectacularly well and is clearly exceeding by some distance its intitial objective of 30 percent of the market," said Wolfgang Demisch of UBS Securities in New York.
Airbus reported its first-ever operating surplus last year, which Mr. Pierson said means that it can rely less on government aid to develop aircraft. Last Thursday, Airbus for the first time entered the commercial bond market, borrowing $110 million to help fund the $480 million development of a 180-seat aircraft, the A321 -- a stretched version of its fast-selling 150-seat A320.
 
Far-Flung Operations
 Airbus reported revenues of $4.7 billion last year, and industry officials estimate that its surplus was between $100 million and $150 million. Mr. Pierson forecasts profits again this year on revenues of $7.4 billion, with sales climbing to about $15 billion in 1995, when its A330 and A340 long-range jets are in production.
At first glance, Airbus's truncated structure would seem destined to fail. The fuselage for each of its jets is made by Deutsche Aerospace in Germany, the wings by British Aerospace, and the tailfins in Spain by CASA. Then, big-bellied airplanes called Super Guppies fly the parts to Toulouse, France, where Airbus is based and where Aerospatiale assembles the parts.
Airbus started slowly, with two wide-body, medium-range aircraft, the A300 and A310. But Airbus's orders mushroomed as airlines became convinced that it was here to stay and as its planes demonstrated their reliability. It further caught fire three years ago with the introduction of its 150-seat A320, which competes against Boeing's 737. Its A330 and A340 long-range jets, for which deliveries are to begin next year, have garnered 250 firm orders.
"Now that they have a full family of aircraft and are making money, why should they still need subsidies?" asked Boeing's Mr. Clarkson.
For years, the overwhelming obstacle Airbus faced was breaking into the American market, which represents nearly half of worldwide aircraft sales. But Airbus gained a foothold by making aggressively priced offers to struggling carriers like Braniff and Eastern, whose bankruptcies have been a blow to Airbus. Today, it counts more solid carriers among its customers including American Airlines, Northwest Airlines and Trans World Airlines. And Airbus officials voice confidence that they will soon clinch a $6 billion deal from Federal Express involving 25 firm orders and up to 50 options.
Airbus's big break was Northwest's order for more than a hundred aircraft in 1987, of which 17 A320's have been delivered. "We were attracted to Airbus because it offers a new generation of technology," said Lawrence Kahn, Northwest's director of fleet planning. "The cabin is more spacious and comfortable and its cost of operation is lower. And the aircraft's computers have a self-diagnostic capabilities, which makes maintenance easier."
 
Complaints on Pricing
 Boeing and Douglas often complain that Airbus aggressively underpriced them, knowing that subsidies would help offset any losses. They criticize in particular the Northwest order, in which Airbus provided below-market-rate financing not just for the aircraft, but to help Northwest rejigger its balance sheet.
Alan Boyd, chairman of Airbus's North American operations, said his tactics are no more aggressive than his rivals'. "When you hear people talk about aggressive pricing, you're hearing people talking about our early days when Airbus was trying to penetrate the American market," he said. "Those days are over. There are no giveaways at Airbus."
Now Airbus is squaring off with Boeing and McDonnell Douglas in a high-stakes contest at Delta and United, which are expected to order dozens of long-range jets over the next few years to replace their aging DC-10's and Lockheed L-1011's. Airbus's A330 and A340 are pitted against Boeing's new 777 and Douglas's MD-11. Airbus has yet to sell any planes to Delta or United.
 
Boeing's Big Worry
 But for Boeing, the biggest worry is Airbus's hope to build a super jumbo that would trump the 747. Airbus plans to decide by 1995 whether to build a super jumbo, which could be ready for the market early in the next century, when a maximum number of 747's are expected to be retired.
Mr. Pierson said it would take up to $4 billion to develop the super jumbo. Airbus officials say they could finance this out of their fast-growing cash flow, but do not rule out obtaining refundable aid from European governments. Analysts say the price tag could soar to $10 billion.
Boeing is studying three options for building a successor to the 747: a stretched version of the 747, a double-decker 747 and a wholly new aircraft. But financing the project could be a problem because Boeing is already weighed down with the roughly $4 billion cost of developing its 777.
"If Airbus builds a super jumbo, it will be a serious problem for Boeing" said Morten Beyer, chairman of Avmark, an aviation consultant in Alexandria, Va.
Analysts say Boeing aims to push Europe to slash subsidies to prevent that problem. But achieving that goal will not be easy. Washington wants Europe to limit subsidies to 25 percent of development costs, while the Europeans insist on a 45 percent ceiling, down from Airbus's original level of 100 percent. American officials say European governments have provided $13 billion in development aid to Airbus since its founding, or $26 billion including interest.
Airbus officials say this aid is more loan than subsidy, because for each airplane it sells, Airbus repays the governments a predetermined sum. Washington complains that the repayments should be carried out under commercial conditions: over 15 years and at market interest rates. American officials also say Airbus's financial statements are confidential so competitors have no definite idea how much Airbus is earning, losing or being subsidized.
"I don't think there is anything transparent in Airbus," said S. Linn Williams, Deputy United States Trade Representative.
Mr. Pierson lambastes Washington's estimate of $26 billion in subsidies and cites a European study that asserts that America's commercial aircraft industry has received $23 billion in indirect subsidies. Airbus argues, for example, that Pentagon money that helped develop the C-5A military cargo plane indirectly helped Boeing design parts for the 747 -- an assertion Boeing denies. Mr. Pierson also says that the Americans are hypocritical, asserting that the Japanese government is helping finance development of the 777.
"They seem to be taking us for imbeciles," Mr. Pierson said
Airbus and European officials are demanding strict rules limiting the Pentagon's indirect subsidies. But Mr. Pierson seems convinced that the governments will ultimately agree to allow some subsidies in such a high-prestige industy. "All the sheep are gray," he said. "Our negotiations have to determine whether they'll be light gray or dark gray."
 
 
 
AIRBUS'S AFFABLE IRONMAN
 Jean Pierson, Airbus's burly president, breaks into a smile as he discusses how the consortium earned its first-ever profit last year. The 50-year-old Frenchman was an engineering whiz early in his career, and, at the age of 36, became head of the factory in Toulouse, France, of Aerospatiale, the state-owned aerospace company that is one of four Airbus shareholders. When Mr. Pierson took Airbus's helm in 1985, he proved himself adept at marketing.
Now he is trying to show he can handle finance, too. He says Airbus's profits were largely a result of his following the advice of a commission of experts to increase financial controls and to pressure the consortium's suppliers, which also happen to be its shareholders, to hold down costs.
The Tunisian-born Mr. Pierson hints that Airbus's shareholders should make the consortium's finances public because, he says, their secretive policies may be doing harm in Washington, which complains that Airbus is addicted to subsidies.
In the face of such criticism, he is proud that Airbus last week went for the first time to the international bond market to help finance a new aircraft. "The United States cannot deny that there is a declining curve of our subsidies," he said.
Mr. Pierson's big worry now is the financial crisis in the airline industry, caused by the Persian Gulf crisis and fiercer competition in the United States and Europe. "The problem in the years to come," he said, "is where will airplane financing come from?"

 
 
FIGHTING FOURSOME
 When it comes to fighting the Americans, Airbus's four partners present a united front, but on other matters they are often far less united.
Last year, Deutsche Aerospace, the German shareholder, was frustrated that all of Airbus's final assembly was done in France, so it demanded that some of the work be moved to Germany. Aerospatiale, the French shareholder, jealously guarded its role and opposed the request as inefficient, but finally agreed to allow final assembly of the 180-seat A321 in Hamburg.
Now Deutsche Aerospace is causing another spat within the group. It has persuaded Aerospatiale and Alenia, the Italian aerospace group, to study development of an 80- to 130-seat aircraft.
The Germans, eager to make their mark in large aircraft, would lead this consortium, which would be separate from Airbus. The problem is, Airbus is considering its own 130-seat aircraft, the A319, to complement its 150-seat A320 and 180-seat A321.
Airbus officials say the A319 could help Airbus compete against Boeing's 737 series. Airbus officials say it would cost $400 million to develop its A319 aircraft, but some $4 billion and huge subsidies for the German-led group to develop a 130-seat airplane from the ground up.
"I don't see why the Deutsche Aerospace group feels the need to reinvent the wheel," said an Airbus official.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Business Diary/June 16-21

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Disloyal American Buyers Are Detroit's Latest Challenge 

Detroit continues to lose market share to the Japanese. But it is no longer a matter of poor quality. Nor of cost. The reason, according to a study released last week by the Brookings Institution in Washington, is that the Big Three have lost the loyalty of their customers. The authors, Fred Mannering and Clifford Winston, studied 488 households and their vehicle purchases over several decades. The authors argue that Americans are now more loyal to Japanese brands than to American ones. "Loyalty means repeat purchases, all other things like price and quality being equal," said Mr. Winston. A decade of poor products and poor service is to blame. Losing loyalty has been costly. "General Motors lost the most loyalty; Chrysler was next and Ford lost the least," Mr. Winston said. If the patterns persist, the General Motors Corporation's market share will fall from about 36 percent today, to 31 percent by 1995. Regaining loyalty will be difficult, the authors say. Not everyone agrees. "Early in the 1980's, Ford had a dismal product image," said Scott Merlis, an auto analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York. "No front-wheel drive. Its Pintos exploded. Then they unleashed a series of home runs and turned their market share and brand loyalty around." But the Ford Motor Company's revival took money and time, which are both in short supply.
 
Old Blue Gets Hit Again . . .
 
Poor old I.B.M. First it posted a 48.7 percent drop in earnings in the first quarter. And its stock fell sharply. Then there were two messages to managers from John F. Akers, the company's chairman, that got wide circulation. A little more hustle, they said. The market frowned again. Finally, the International Business Machines Corporation told analysts to prepare themselves -- earnings in the second quarter would not meet projections of 50 cents to $1.10 a share. The stock bumped to a bargain $99.25, down $1.75. But not everyone thinks I.B.M. is in such horrendous shape. "There are problems endemic to the industry right now," said Daniel Mandresh, who follows I.B.M. for Merrill Lynch. "It is still a $66 billion company and all that stands in the way of Japan's domination of our market," he said. I.B.M. finished the week at $99.60.
 
. . . And So Does Microsoft
 
Once friends, the Microsoft Corporation and I.B.M. are are increasingly rivals. William H. Gates, chairman of Microsoft, the largest publisher of software for the personal computer market, has written a memo of his own to his top managers, which was leaked to The San Jose Mercury News. In it, Mr. Gates worried about I.B.M. attacking Microsoft in systems software and about Novell Inc., another big software publisher, beating it in networking applications. Mr. Gates also groused about a lawsuit filed against Microsoft by Apple Computer Inc. and about a Federal Trade Commission investigation into the company's business practices. "Nightmares," he said. The stock market agreed. Microsoft's shares promptly fell $8.50, to $103.37, and finished the week at $102.25.
 
Subaru Switches Agencies
 
For 17 years, Subaru of America was loyal to its New York advertising agency, Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver. No more. It is switching its $70 million account to Wieden & Kennedy, a small shop in Portland, Ore., with about $250 million in billings. Wieden has the Nike Account -- which is hefty -- but not much else. Levine had taken Subaru from obscurity to prominence and then back toward obscurity. Subaru sold 150,000 cars in the mid-1980's, but only 108,000 last year. And Levine recently lost another big client, Frito-Lay. Some are wondering if Levine has a future.
 
Northrop Gets the BAT
 
It may have lost out on the most lucrative military contract in history -- up to $95 billion to build as many as 650 F-22 jet fighters -- but last week the Northrop Corporation won a consolation prize: A $2.2 billion contract from the Pentagon to build a super-smart thing called the BAT (brilliant anti-tank) weapon. It is a missile that is launched inside another missile. The development phase of the program is expected to last another 42 months..
 
Here Comes the Humvee
 
Americans love rugged all-terrain vehicles. Consider the success of the Jeep. Now they will get another. The LTV Corporation said last week it will begin selling the Humvee -- the high-mobility multipurpose wheeled vehile -- to the public. The Humvee, which is wide and low and possibly the homeliest champion of the Persian Gulf War, will cost between $40,500 and $44,000.
 
Visa, an assocation of banks and savings institution, got a Federal Appeals Court in Denver to stop Sears Roebuck & Company from issuing Visa cards. Sears already offers Discover cards.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
A Reward for South Africa?
 
Last week the South African Parliament scrapped its policy of classifying people by race. Four of Congress's five conditions for lifting sanctions against South Africa have now been met. And many believe the final condition -- release of all political prisoners -- will be met within a month. Will the Bush Administration lift sanctions? Most are betting it will, and soon. But there is strong opposition from the Congressional Black Caucus and anti-apartheid lobbyists. Don't lift sanctions until South Africa adopts a new constitution, they say. One that -- at a minimum -- gives black South Africans a vote. So far that change is elusive. South Africa's President, F. W. de Klerk, said he's willing to negotiate on a constitution. But he did not say when.
 
Trying to Win Back MGM-Pathe
 
Last week, Giancarlo Parretti, who owns 98 percent of the stock of the MGM-Pathe Communications Company, tried to fire Alan Ladd Jr. and Jay Kanter, the producers who run the company. But the courts said Mr. Parretti could not do so. Mr. Parretti, the Italian financier, bought the MGM studio last year for $1.3 billion. Then he merged it with Pathe Communications. It wasn't an easy deal to make. There were allegations about his character and about how he rose so quickly to power -- he started as a hotel clerk in Sicily. Though he did round up the cash to buy the studio -- mostly from Credit Lyonnais, the big French bank -- he did not have enough money to run it. So Credit Lyonnais advanced some more, but with a major catch: Mr. Parretti would have to give up his vote and his seat on the board. He agreed but is contesting the loss of control. On July 2, a Delaware court will hold a hearing. Mr. Parretti is not likely to get his company back.
 
Foreign Help for Airlines
 
How do you get capital to the nation's ailing airlines? Let foreigners buy in, says Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner. Now foreign carriers can buy 49 percent of an American carrier but only 25 percent of its voting stock. Not good enough to get the capital flowing. So Mr. Skinner is proposing to let them buy 49 percent of the voting stock. With commitments to buy $47 billion worth of aircraft by 1995, the industry needs money. But will Congress agree to Mr. Skinner's idea, especially when airlines are regarded as a strategic asset? As long as Americans still have 51 percent of the voting rights, Mr. Skinner believes Congress will go along.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
What After the Recession?
 
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, sounded chipper last week. He told the House Ways and Means Committee that the recession may have already ended. The data "are strongly suggestive that the bottom is somewhere in the second quarter," Mr. Greenspan said. And he told them that the recovery might not reignite inflation. That remains to be seen. "Recovery without recession requires subdued growth," said Alan Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Company. And while it is true that the "forecasts are for anemic growth of about 2 percent, we recognize this is out of line with history," Mr. Sinai said. Growth after a recession typically averages 6.5 percent. "In this economy that would be inflationary," Mr. Sinai said.
 
Bad News on the Trade Front
 
There's another little snag in the recovery. The merchandise trade deficit widened to $4.8 billion in April, according to the Commerce Department. That is a 17.4 percent jump. Most economists think that the increase in imports reflects the effects of a recovering economy. Demand is picking up, they say, and foreign companies are satisfying that demand. But exports were also strong -- just not strong enough. They increased about 4.5 percent for April to a record $35.6 billion.
 
Housing's Scant Gain
 
The housing industry continues to recover, but it is doing so without much oomph. New homes and apartment construction moved up a scant one-tenth of 1 percent in May, according to the Commerce Department. It was the first time since July 1989 that new construction registered gains two months in a row, but April's gain was a strong 8.2 percent."The housing sector leads the economy out of recession," said Thomas M. Holloway, senior economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association in Washington. "But for sustained growth, the economy needs to grow."
 
Bumps in the S.&L. Bailout
 
So far, the bailout of the savings and loan industry has cost taxpayers about $80 billion. The nation's top banking regulator, L. William Seidman, said last week that he needs about $80 billion more, which the Administration is expected to request. But neither Congress nor the Administration is happy with the way the bailout is going. "We were asking for corrections and improvements the last time the Administration sought funding," said Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who heads the House Banking Committee. "The reality is they've got to have structural and substantive changes if they want to make the case for more money."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 510 words

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
An Unsettling Look Inherent In Recovery

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar

 BODY:
People love to talk about the Dow as if they were talking about a person. "The market is feeling nervous," they say. "The market wants to go higher." These days the market is acting more like a lottery winner worried that the telegram is a practical joke.
 Nobody can be absolutely sure that the recovery that seems to be underway is the real thing. "There's a possibility of a false start in the economy," said Laszlo Birinyi, a financial consultant. Indeed, the gross national product has popped up in the middle of half of all postwar recessions, only to slump anew. 
 That's what happened in the last recession, which was the worst since the Great Depression. In the spring of 1982, gains in consumer spending and homebuilding raised hopes that the recession was ending. Indeed, G.N.P. did post a tiny gain in that quarter, but it was half a year before the economy began growing. Ditto for the 1969-70 recessionette, the one that the current downturn was supposed to resemble.
It isn't hard to see why everyone's reluctant to pop the champagne corks. Last month's rally in cyclical stocks has petered out. Downbeat economic reports -- like those last week of a jump in unemployment claims and a levelling out in homebuilding -- keep trickling in. They helped send the Dow down to 2965.56, a decline of 34.89 on the week. Then, too, there are some scary-looking indicators lurking out there.
Mortgage rates have climbed along with long-term bond yields and are now more than a half a point higher than in February. Higher rates could clobber the nascent housing recovery. Rising unemployment could turn consumers skittish again. Recession abroad could keep European and Japanese buyers from snapping up United States exports.
But the threats look less fearsome up close. For starters, those mid-recession upticks in G.N.P. during past recessions mostly reflected unwanted inventory buildups. Today, business is still cutting stockpiles while sales are actually improving.
Even if unemployment passes 7 percent, the rise will have been less in this recession than in most others, and as long as the layoffs taper off, consumers should keep their cool. "Consumer spending probably rose at a 3 percent rate this spring," said economist Bruce Steinberg at Merrill Lynch.
Building permits shot up in May. Mortgage rates are likely to stay south of 10 percent, predicts David Wyss at DRI/McGraw Hill. "That's not enough to strangle the housing recovery," he said. "Besides, if people think mortgage rates are rising, they usually rush out to buy."
Exports aren't apt to collapse either. Growth in Germany and Japan, which has been stronger than predicted, may well slow. But other big United States trading partners like Canada are recovering and Mexico and Southeast Asia are booming. Despite its recent rise, the dollar is no stronger than it was last summer.
Uncertainty and mixed signals are bound to persist for a while. But that may not be all bad. Remember, that unsettled state is itself one of recovery's most reliable signs.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
The Money Man at Baltia

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
About a year ago, Harold J. Pareti, the president of Airline Economics Inc., a Washington-based consulting firm, was asked to help arrange financing for a group that wanted to start an airline.
Mr. Pareti, who had helped to get People Express and Presidential Airways off the ground, quickly raised a small amount while the owners of the nascent Baltia Air Lines mobilized for hearings at the Department of Transportation. 
 Earlier this month, the group, headed by Igor Dmitrowsky, a Latvian immigrant, hit the jackpot: Baltia won the right to fly from New York to Riga, Latvia, to become only the fourth American carrier with routes between the United States and the Soviet Union.
Now, Mr. Pareti seems on the verge of landing enough money to buy Baltia its first planes. In recent days, he has been working with the Waterford Group, a Texas-based investment concern that has told Baltia it may soon put together a $150 million package of loans. An announcement is expected this week.
Mr. Pareti left People Express in January 1985 as it was being taken over by Texas Air and helped start Presidential Air that year. Because of a major buildup by United and Continental airlines at Presidential's hub, Dulles International Airport outside Washington, the carrier was forced to liquidate.
Mr. Pareti, 43, has been named vice chairman and acting vice president of finance for Baltia. But he does not plan to stay with the carrier for long; instead, he said, he would remain at Airline Economics, where he is a principal investor. Baltia has given the firm 4.8 percent of its stock in return for his help.
